synthetic_text:
Today marks another day that feels like a never-ending cycle of exhaustion and emptiness. The sun is up, but it’s as if the light isn’t reaching me. I wake up to the sound of my baby crying, her tiny fists hitting against the crib with such force that it breaks my heart even more. It's been weeks since she arrived, yet each day feels like a new challenge.

I used to think I was strong enough to handle anything. Postpartum depression? Nah, not me. I was going to be this beacon of positivity and resilience, but here I am, questioning everything. The weight of the world is on my shoulders, and it’s suffocating. My body aches from lack of sleep, and my mind races with thoughts of inadequacy and failure.

The first few weeks were blissful—sleepless nights were sweet because of her tiny smiles and coos. Now, every moment feels like an uphill battle. I try to force myself out of bed, but my limbs feel heavy as lead. Even a small task seems daunting. It’s not just about the baby; it’s everything—laundry piling up, dishes unwashed, my own needs completely ignored.

I’ve been telling everyone that I’m doing okay, plastering on smiles and nodding through conversations with well-meaning friends and family. But inside, it's like there’s a dark cloud hanging over me. Every little thing irritates me—my husband’s phone buzzing with notifications, the sound of the dishwasher humming too loudly.

I’ve started to recognize that these feelings are real, not just a phase or something I can snap out of. It’s terrifying and humbling at the same time. The thought of reaching out for help used to feel like admitting defeat. Now, it feels necessary. Maybe there’s hope in acknowledging this isn’t something I have to face alone.

It's time to take that first step towards feeling better again.

Today marks another day since my baby’s arrival, and I can’t shake this foggy feeling that seems to have settled over everything. It’s been a little more than two months now, and while I’ve heard from friends about the joy and love that comes with being a new parent, it feels like those feelings are just out of reach for me.

The first few weeks were overwhelming—trying to breastfeed, figuring out naps, and dealing with all the advice that seems to come from every direction. My mom’s here helping, but even her endless support doesn’t seem to help as much as I wish it would. Today is another sleepless night, and honestly, I’m just tired of being so damn tired.

It’s funny how quickly life changes when you bring home a baby. There was this idea in my head that becoming a mom would be like an instant upgrade, but now all I feel is lost. My husband works long hours, and while he tries to help, there’s only so much one person can do. Between work emails and trying to catch up on sleep, I’m falling further behind.

I keep wondering when the joy will kick in, when this exhaustion won’t be so exhausting anymore. But for now, I feel like a ghost of my old self. The thought of going back to work is daunting, but staying at home feels just as impossible. Maybe it’s time to reach out and ask for more than just help; maybe it’s time to talk about how I’m really feeling.

Today, after the baby goes down for his nap, I think I’ll give my doctor a call. It’s okay to not be okay, right?

Today marks three weeks since little Lily joined our family. The early mornings and endless feedings can feel like a never-ending cycle. There are moments when I catch glimpses of her tiny fingers wrapped around mine, and my heart swells with love. But then there are other times when the exhaustion and worry about being enough overwhelm me. 

I’ve noticed lately that I’m more sensitive to the idea of drinking alcohol. It’s not just about enjoying a glass of wine anymore; it’s knowing what could pass from me to her, even if I don’t plan on nursing while drinking. So I try my best to keep the wine at bay and focus on other ways to unwind.

The baby blues have lingered longer than expected, but talking with a friend who has been through this helped remind me that it’s okay not to feel okay all the time. It’s such a cliché, but every day is different. There are days when I’m in awe of how tiny she is, and other times when I wish she could just sleep for more than two hours at a stretch.

I’ve started keeping a journal like this one to track my thoughts and feelings. Writing it down helps me see that even though today might be hard, tomorrow doesn’t have to be as tough. And maybe someday, these entries will serve as proof of how far we’ve come.

Today marks a significant milestone that I didn’t think was possible just weeks ago. It’s been eight long weeks since the baby arrived, and for every single one of them, I’ve felt like a shadow of myself. The overwhelming sense of sadness and isolation has been my constant companion, making even the smallest tasks feel insurmountable.

But today is different. Today, something shifted inside me. Maybe it was the sunshine that streamed through the window this morning, or perhaps it was simply the passage of time. But when I finally held our baby for more than a few moments, I felt a warmth in my chest that I hadn’t expected to feel again anytime soon.

I’ve been so focused on getting through each day without falling apart that I didn’t realize how much I’d been missing out on—the sound of her tiny breaths, the way she looks up at me with such trust. It’s like the world paused for a moment while I held her, and all my worries melted away.

It’s a start, just a small step forward in what feels like an endless journey back to myself. But today, I’m choosing to see this as progress. I’ll take it one breath at a time, one cuddle at a time, until the days blend together into something more than just surviving.

I’ve missed this. Holding her has made me realize that even though my mind may still be foggy with depression, there’s a part of me that is already in love with our little miracle. And for now, that’s enough to keep going.

Today feels like one of those days where everything seems just a little harder. I woke up this morning and the baby was crying again before sunrise. It's been that way for weeks now, but today it felt different. There’s something about holding him while he cries that makes my chest feel heavy and my eyes sting with tears that don’t want to fall.

I’ve tried to remind myself that these early mornings are part of being a new mom. I’ve read books and articles about postpartum blues, but what if this isn’t just postpartum? What if something else is going on inside me that no one talks about in the parenting groups?

The house feels quiet now as he sleeps after his feeding. I look around at all the baby stuff—so much for being prepared! It’s overwhelming sometimes, seeing everything laid out like a checklist of tasks and responsibilities. But what does it mean when you feel disconnected from these tasks? Like they’re just something to get through rather than part of a journey?

I’ve been trying to stay positive, but some days are harder than others. I know that’s normal too, right? That little voice inside me whispers doubts while another part tells me I’m doing okay—just different.

Maybe what I need is to talk more with someone who understands these mixed feelings. Not just the joy and exhaustion of being a new parent, but also those quiet moments when you wonder if everything will ever feel normal again.

Today marks two weeks since bringing little Emily into the world. It's been a whirlwind of emotions and sleepless nights, but I’m starting to find my footing. People often say that becoming a mother is life-changing, but it’s only now sinking in how true that statement is.

I’ve seen many posts online about postpartum depression and anxiety, and while I feel for those who struggle with these challenges, there's something uniquely different about my experience so far. It’s not just the physical recovery or the sudden shift from being a single entity to a duo; it’s also the overwhelming love and responsibility that comes with caring for another human.

I’ve been reflecting on how childbirth is such an exclusively female experience. We talk a lot these days about men's mental health issues, including postpartum depression in new fathers. But there’s something irreplaceable about knowing you brought this tiny being into existence from within your own body. It’s a profound connection that I think can’t be fully understood by anyone else.

Today was one of those rare moments when everything seemed to fall into place. The baby slept for a solid four hours, and I finally got the chance to shower and take some time to read—something as simple as holding a book felt like a luxury after weeks of constant care. My partner came home with fresh flowers and a box of chocolates; little gestures that remind me how fortunate we are.

I’m not saying it’s all sunshine and rainbows, but I am hopeful. Each day brings new challenges, yes, but also moments of pure joy and accomplishment. As I look at Emily sleeping soundly next to me, I feel both the enormity and beauty of what lies ahead.

Resting now, knowing tomorrow will bring more chances for growth and love.

April 7th, Week 4 Postpartum

Today marks four weeks since Lily's birth, and yet the joy of being a new mother feels as distant as a dream. I've been struggling with this overwhelming sense of sadness and hopelessness that seems to consume me every day. The exhaustion is relentless, but it’s more than just physical; it’s mental too. My days are filled with diaper changes, feedings, endless worry about whether I’m doing things right—and then there's the constant feeling like something is terribly wrong.

I reached out to my doctor last week when everything became unbearable. They told me I was likely experiencing “baby blues” and that this would pass by six weeks. But it hasn’t passed. It’s only gotten worse, leaving me questioning if anyone truly understands what I’m going through. Maybe they do, but the advice feels so inadequate.

I keep reminding myself to be patient, to wait until week 6 for more support, but it's hard when every day feels like a battle. I wish there was someone here who could just hold my hand and say, "It’s okay to feel this way." Right now, all I want is to be seen, not just heard.

Today felt particularly rough. The weight of everything hit me harder than ever before, and I cried for hours. It left me wondering if anyone else out there feels like this too or if it's truly as isolating as it seems in my mind.

The road ahead looks long and dark right now, but I'm trying to take small steps forward each day—like reaching out again when week 6 comes around. Until then, all I can do is try not to drown in the despair that threatens to consume me every moment.

Day 3 Postpartum

Today marks my third day as a new mom, and while there are moments of pure joy with my little one, there's also an undercurrent of fear that lingers in the back of my mind. I know it's common to feel this way, but being someone who's never had children before, all these changes can be overwhelming.

The baby is a dream come true, really. She’s so tiny and perfect with her little fingers and toes. But as much as I love looking at her, there are moments when the exhaustion hits me like a wave. I find myself asking if it will ever get easier or if this endless cycle of feeding and changing diapers will continue indefinitely.

One moment I’m basking in the wonder of being a parent, and then suddenly, a deep sadness washes over me. It’s not something I understand yet—maybe it's just the fatigue catching up with my emotions. Or is it more than that? Am I already slipping into postpartum depression?

I know it’s important to be aware of these feelings and talk about them, but sometimes when I try to tell others how I feel, they seem to think everything should just fall into place naturally after giving birth. It’s hard not to compare myself to everyone else and wonder if there's something wrong with me.

Tonight, while the baby sleeps, I’ll reach out to a support group for new moms. Maybe talking it through will help ease some of these fears and provide clarity on what’s happening inside my mind and heart. Until then, I'll keep taking things one step at a time and hope that every day brings something new and beautiful.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and I can't help but feel like something is off. The joy of holding my baby for the first time was overwhelming, yet now there are moments when I just feel so... empty. I see other mothers on social media, seemingly perfect, smiling endlessly, and it makes me wonder if there's something wrong with me.

I love my little one more than anything. Every tiny smile, every giggle melts my heart. But at the same time, there are days when all I want to do is cry. Why can't I just be happy? Am I supposed to feel this way after giving birth?

The exhaustion hits me like a freight train, and no matter how much sleep I get, it never seems enough. Is this normal? Do other moms struggle with feeling so inadequate while trying to care for their babies?

I worry constantly about everything from feeding schedules to diaper changes. Am I doing something wrong? Will my baby be okay if I'm not the perfect mother?

Yesterday, I decided to reach out and talk to someone about how I feel. Maybe there's help out there, a way to find balance and peace in this new chapter of life. But part of me is scared to admit that maybe it’s more than just feeling overwhelmed.

I hope today brings some answers and clarity. For now, I'm going to try and take one step at a time. Love my baby fiercely and let myself feel whatever comes next.

Today marks a week since little Ellie arrived in the world, and while I’ve felt nothing but joy at her presence, there’s an undercurrent of sadness that seems to cling to me like a shadow. It's as if every time I smile at her tiny hand grasping mine, I'm also feeling this weight in my chest—something heavy and unyielding.

The first few days were a whirlwind of visits from friends and family, all wanting to see the newest addition to our clan. But when everyone left, it was just me, the mountain of laundry that needed sorting, and those late-night feedings that stretch on for what feels like forever. It’s then I feel most vulnerable—like I’m alone with a tiny life dependent on me yet unsure if I can handle the responsibility.

Despite these dark thoughts, there’s this nagging voice telling me to get back on my feet, literally and figuratively. After some online research and encouragement from friends who’ve been through it before, I signed up for postnatal yoga classes starting next week. It’s a small step, but maybe movement will help shift the gloom.

I look at Ellie sleeping peacefully and know deep down that being her mother is my greatest achievement so far. Even if I’m not perfect—I feel less like a failure with each passing day. Today I started walking around the block once—just one lap—and it was surprisingly liberating. 

So here’s to finding moments of light in this dark tunnel, and remembering that small steps count.

Today was one of those days where everything seems to weigh heavy—my body feels like a lead balloon, and the small tasks that once seemed manageable now feel monumental. Holding my baby during these visits has become more about endurance than joy. Yet, today felt different. Dr. Smith, with her gentle eyes and calm demeanor, noticed something in me she hasn’t before. She asked how I was truly doing and it took me by surprise. For the first time, someone acknowledged my struggle, my exhaustion, not just as a new mom but as a person grappling with depression.

She handed me information about support groups and therapy options, urging me to take care of myself now more than ever. It feels like a weight has been lifted knowing there’s help out there, that I’m not alone in this dark tunnel. Today was a turning point, acknowledging the pain and finding a way forward. The baby coos softly from his carrier; he knows something is shifting inside me today.

December 18, 2023

Today marks the eighteen-month milestone since my little one arrived. It's amazing how life can change so dramatically in such a short time. I remember feeling lost and alone when she was just a few weeks old. Those dark days were hard to push through, but now looking back, it feels like another lifetime.

The first months were a blur of exhaustion and self-doubt. I worried constantly about everything from whether I was feeding her enough to if my love for her would ever feel real. It's funny how the simplest things could set me off then—a baby crying in a store or just seeing a stroller on the street.

But little by little, as she grew and learned new things every day, so did I. My feelings started to shift from being overwhelmed to actually enjoying these small moments of discovery together. There's something about her giggles and her curious eyes that make all those tough times feel worthwhile now.

I still have bad days here and there, but they're fewer and further between. Today, for instance, she said "mama" for the first time ever so clearly when I came into the room to give her breakfast. It was a moment full of joy and pride that made my heart swell. Knowing she recognizes me like that means more than words can say.

So, if you're reading this thinking about how you're feeling right now with your own baby or someone else's, please know it gets better. Even on the darkest days, there are little lights that will guide you forward.

Today marks three weeks since little Emma joined our family, and it feels like a whirlwind of emotions and changes. I wake up every morning with a mix of happiness and anxiety; the kind that comes from knowing you’re responsible for another life’s well-being. The nights are long and full of feedings, but seeing her tiny smile just makes everything worth it.

I can’t thank our friends and family enough for their support. Without them, I don’t know how we’d manage the sleepless nights and the never-ending list of tasks that come with newborn care. My mom has been a rock, always there to help out in any way she can. She knows just when to step in without making me feel like I’m failing as a new mother.

There are moments where I feel overwhelmed by waves of sadness and fear. It’s not easy dealing with the hormonal roller coaster that comes with postpartum life. But talking about it openly, reaching out for help, and focusing on what brings joy—like holding Emma—is helping me navigate these tough times. 

I know having a baby was meant to be one of the most joyful experiences in my life, and while there are challenges, I wouldn’t trade this incredible journey for anything. Here’s to more days filled with laughter, love, and little victories.

March 14th

I never thought I'd be writing about this side of becoming a mom. Today marks two weeks since the birth of my little miracle, and while there are moments of pure joy, they're overshadowed by an uninvited guest—postpartum depression.

The hormonal rollercoaster is something no one prepares you for. I feel like I’m walking through life in slow motion, weighed down by a sadness that just won’t lift. I know it’s not uncommon, but that doesn't make it any easier to face each day.

I've been trying hard to keep up with the new reality of being a mom, but there are moments when I feel utterly lost and overwhelmed. How did no one warn me about this? It's like suddenly stepping into a world where your own mind feels foreign and unwelcoming.

Yet, even in these challenging times, I can see my baby's tiny hand reaching for mine, and that moment of connection fills me with warmth. These little moments are the threads weaving through the fabric of my new life, giving it texture and meaning despite the shadows cast by postpartum blues.

I’m learning to be gentle with myself, recognizing that healing isn’t a straight path but one filled with twists and turns. Today was tough, but I'm not alone in this journey. Maybe tomorrow will bring a brighter day, or at least another moment of clarity and peace amidst the storm.

April 4th, 2023

Another day in the haze of postpartum life. Today marks a week since my fourth baby's birth, and if you asked me how I'm feeling, I'd say I feel like a broken record. Sleepless nights are the new norm, and every ounce of energy feels sapped.

I've been dragging myself to the gym lately—something my therapist says is key to lifting this fog. It’s funny how moving your body can move something so intangible as mood. Today felt different though; I managed a few extra reps on the elliptical. Maybe it's just in my head, but those moments of exertion and sweat have been the only times today where I’ve felt truly alive.

The kids keep me going too—four bundles of chaos that somehow make me feel more than myself. It’s strange how love can bloom amidst exhaustion. My eldest was holding baby number four for what felt like an eternity this morning, and my heart swelled to the point of bursting with pride yet sadness. I worry about being a good mom through all this.

But then there's hope in these small wins—I went out alone today, grabbed lunch at our favorite café, and even talked to someone without mentioning babies for five minutes straight. Baby steps, right?

Here’s hoping tomorrow brings another small victory. For now, it's bedtime with four little ones, and maybe a quiet moment for me.

Until then, one step at a time.

Today marks exactly two years since the lockdown began, and with it came a darkness I never thought I'd face. Looking back now feels like peering through fog; all that remains are fragments of despair.

Those days were overwhelming, a constant barrage of anxiety and fear. The isolation made everything worse. No one to hold your hand when you’re at your lowest point. I felt so alone, drowning in thoughts no mother should ever have about herself or her child. It was like the weight of the world was crushing me, and there was nowhere to turn.

But somehow, after hitting rock bottom, I found my voice again. Reaching out wasn’t easy; it felt like admitting defeat. But talking to someone—really talking—changed everything. They helped me see a way forward, not just through pills but through prayer. Focusing on spiritual growth gave me a purpose beyond the pain.

Today, as I look at my child sleeping soundly in their crib, I feel gratitude. The journey’s far from over, but there's hope now where once was none.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world. The early days were a whirlwind of joy and exhaustion, but now reality sets in with a heavy heart. Every time I look at her sweet face, there's this nagging voice inside my head telling me that maybe I'm not good enough to care for her properly.

Breastfeeding has been an uphill battle. My body seems reluctant to produce the milk she needs, and every hour of feeding feels like a test I’m failing miserably. The guilt is suffocating. Why can't I do this? Is there something wrong with me?

I struggle with intrusive thoughts about being a terrible mother. What if I'm not cut out for this? There are moments where all I want to do is curl up and hide from the world. But hiding isn’t an option, especially now that she depends on me.

The fear of inadequacy gnaws at my confidence. It’s like having a shadow that whispers doubts in my ear whenever I try to love her or care for her needs. Yet, amidst these dark clouds, there are still glimmers of hope and moments where holding her close feels right.

I know it's not just me feeling this way, but knowing doesn't make the struggle any less real. Each day is a step forward, even if it’s a tiny one. I’m trying to remember that every new mom has her own challenges, and mine might be different, but they’re valid too.

So today, as I stare at my reflection holding our baby, I’m determined to keep moving forward, despite the doubts. Because somewhere deep down, there's a fierce love for her that won't let me give up.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of exhaustion and emptiness. I should feel grateful—I have a beautiful baby girl who brings light to the world with her smiles and laughter. But it’s like there's an invisible barrier between us, one that doesn’t let me fully enjoy her presence.

The therapist said I’m not depressed because I can still play with my baby. Can she see how hollow those moments are? It’s like going through the motions without feeling anything real. The idea that someone who knows better could dismiss what I’m experiencing is more than frustrating; it’s heartbreaking.

I left therapy after that session, unable to face another conversation where no one understands. How can anyone think a few smiles and giggles mean everything is fine? It feels like they’re ignoring the pain that clutches my heart every time she cries for reasons unknown or when I stare blankly at her while feeding her, wishing someone else could take care of this tiny life I brought into existence.

The guilt eats away at me. I know I should be cherishing these moments, but all I can do is wonder if it’s okay to feel like this. Am I the only one? Do other new moms struggle in silence too?

I need help, real help that acknowledges my pain and doesn’t try to tell me it isn’t there just because I can still make a baby laugh. Until then, I’ll keep playing these roles, hoping something will change, but mostly waiting for this fog to lift.

Tomorrow might be better, or maybe not. Right now, all I know is that today was another day lost in the haze of what’s supposed to be joy and fulfillment.

January 7th

It's been a week since she arrived, and the reality of it all is starting to sink in. Today was tough—really tough. The crying started early, as usual, but this time there were no tears left in me to match hers. I tried my hardest, really did. Held her close, fed her, changed her. But the weight of everything feels like too much.

There’s only so much support from just two people. My mom and partner try their best, but it's not enough to fill this hole inside that keeps growing with each passing day. I know there are supposed to be feelings of joy and wonder at being a new mother, but all I feel is this heavy sadness that won't leave.

Yet when she needs me, especially when the crying starts, somehow I find the strength to take care of her. It’s like a switch flips inside my head, and suddenly nothing else matters except making sure she's okay. But as soon as she drifts off to sleep, the emptiness comes back tenfold.

I know there are supposed to be feelings of joy and wonder at being a new mother, but all I feel is this heavy sadness that won’t leave. It’s like there’s this dark cloud above me, hanging over everything, even when I try to smile for her or laugh with my mom. 

Maybe it's time to talk more openly about what I'm going through. Maybe admitting how hard it is will make it easier. For now though, all I can do is take one day at a time and hope the sun comes out tomorrow.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of feedings and diaper changes. The exhaustion is overwhelming, but it's not just about being tired; there’s this heavy weight in my chest that doesn’t seem to lift no matter how many naps I take or cups of coffee I drink. Holding the baby brings me brief moments of joy, but they’re overshadowed by an aching sense of sadness and helplessness.

I feel like I’m supposed to be overjoyed about this new chapter in my life, yet here I am struggling just to get through each day without collapsing under the pressure. My partner tries to help as much as possible, but there are moments when all I want is solitude. I worry that these feelings mean something’s wrong with me—a dark cloud hanging over a time that should be filled with light.

It's hard admitting how tough this is. The constant comparison to others on social media who seem so put-together and happy only amplifies my sense of failure. But deep down, I know it’s okay not to be okay all the time. Maybe tomorrow will bring a bit more sunshine through the clouds, or at least clarity about where to find support.

I’m trying to keep things simple—sleep when you can, eat well (even if it’s leftovers), and reach out for help. It’s funny how taking tiny steps feels so monumental right now. But I have to believe that these small victories will lead me back to feeling like myself again.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of sadness and joy. I can't help but feel overwhelmed with the weight of my past pulling me down while simultaneously trying to be the best mother for little Ellie. It's been 19 months since she was born, yet it feels like a lifetime has passed.

I wake up every morning hoping today will be different, that maybe the sun will shine brighter and I'll feel more than this hollow emptiness. But no matter how hard I try to hold onto hope, my mind keeps drifting back to all those dark days before she came into our lives. The loss of Aunt Marie still haunts me, a constant reminder of what could happen if I fail her too.

Ellie is growing so fast; each milestone brings both happiness and fear. She's reaching for the world with every ounce of curiosity and love in her tiny heart. But as much as she needs to explore and discover, there are times when all I want to do is wrap her up in a blanket and protect her from everything that could hurt us.

The hardest part is trying not to let my own demons cloud her future. There's this constant struggle between wanting to be strong for her sake and needing someone else to hold me through the darkest nights. My mom tries, but she doesn't understand what it feels like to lose a loved one so suddenly due to something as invisible yet terrifying as depression.

Despite everything, I know deep down that my love for Ellie is unbreakable. It's this fierce protectiveness mixed with guilt and worry that keeps me going day by day. Maybe someday the sun will rise without dragging shadows behind it, but until then, here we are, just trying to survive one moment at a time.

Today marks two weeks since little one arrived, and if I’m being honest, it feels like an eternity rather than a fortnight. The nights are endless, the exhaustion is overwhelming, but there’s also this strange sense of pride mixed in with the despair. I can’t shake off this feeling that everything should be easier, more joyful, less… demanding.

My partner seems to be struggling too. He keeps telling me he loves being a dad, and his eyes light up when our baby starts crying—but it’s obvious something is wrong. There are days when he barely speaks, lost in thought, and I wonder if we’ll ever find that balance again between being parents and just being us.

I’m supposed to be supporting him, but honestly, I feel like I can barely support myself right now. The midwives said this would pass, that it’s normal to feel so tired and irritable. But when did “normal” mean feeling like you’re drowning?

Today was a rough day. Little one had colic for hours on end, refused to sleep except in my arms, which left me with barely any energy or time to check in with him. I found him sitting alone in the dark nursery, staring at the wall.

I want to be there for us both, but it feels like a losing battle. Maybe that’s part of growing up—I don’t know how to fix this without breaking down myself.

Today marks exactly one week since little Maya joined our family. I can’t shake the feeling that everything is moving in slow motion, like a dream you can't wake up from. The hospital staff was so kind and supportive right after she arrived, but as soon as we got home, it all felt different. Every sound wakes me up at night, not just her cries, but the little squeaks of her toys or even the ticking clock downstairs.

I keep thinking about what everyone said—how beautiful this moment is supposed to be, how love will conquer everything. But sometimes I feel like I’m drowning in a sea of my own thoughts and fears. What if I can’t do this? What if something goes wrong with Maya because I’m not strong enough?

The sadness creeps up on me when I least expect it—sitting alone at night feeding her, or staring into her sleepy eyes as she falls asleep. There’s a part of me that feels like there should be more joy, but instead, there's this heavy weight in my chest.

I’m scared to admit these feelings, even to myself. But I know I can’t pretend they don’t exist any longer. It’s been hard reaching out for help; it seems so foreign and isolating. Yet deep down, part of me knows that talking about what’s going on might be the first step towards feeling better.

I need a friend or someone who understands to sit with this right now. The idea of being strong alone feels impossible. Maybe asking for support isn’t giving up; it could be exactly what I need.

Today marks a turning point, I think. The weeks have felt like an endless blur of diapers and laundry and trying to figure out what it means to be a mom. There were times when the weight of everything pressed down so hard that I could barely see straight. But lately, things feel more manageable. Maybe it's just a momentary reprieve, but I'll take it.

The baby sleeps longer now, and my husband has started helping more with work stuff at home. It’s funny how small changes can make such a big difference. The days aren’t perfect by any means—I still find myself getting lost in thoughts that swirl around like a dark cloud—but there are moments of clarity too.

I’ve been trying to focus on self-care, even if it’s just for ten minutes. Taking a walk or reading a book has become my tiny rebellion against the chaos. I know I need this balance, and so does everyone else. It’s not about perfection; it’s about getting through each day with a little more hope than before.

I’ve made an appointment to talk things over with someone who understands all of this stuff better than me. Maybe that will help too. For now, I’m just trying to hold on to the good moments and let go of the bad ones, one breath at a time.

March 3rd, Year Two

Today marks exactly one year and two months since the day I welcomed my little miracle into this world. Yet, here I am, still feeling like an imposter in motherhood. The days are long, and the nights are filled with thoughts that won't let me sleep. I’ve tried everything—therapy, support groups, even medication—and yet, there’s a void inside me that feels impossible to fill.

It's hard to believe it's been this long since those initial moments of joy turned into something heavy, pulling me down every single day. My child is growing up so quickly; she’s already walking and talking, bringing laughter back into our home more often. It's okay not to be okay, right? I hope so.

Today marks one week since I brought my little miracle into the world, and while the joy of her presence is undeniable, there's an undercurrent of anxiety that hasn't quite dissipated. I'm working on finding my footing again, piece by piece. The journey towards healing is not linear; there are setbacks and progressions, all woven into the fabric of this new chapter in my life. Today, though, I choose to focus on the present—on her tiny fingers curling around mine, on her sweet smiles as she drifts off to sleep.

I’m not alone anymore—I have a support system now, people who care deeply and want me to thrive. It’s scary but also liberating, knowing that there's strength in vulnerability. This diary is my safe space to process, to grow, and to find peace amidst the chaos of motherhood. Here’s hoping for many more days like today—filled with love, growth, and the courage to face tomorrow head-on.

Day 47: Postpartum Fog

Today marks another day of navigating through the dense fog of my own mind. I woke up feeling like an empty shell, a hollow version of myself that’s supposed to be thrilled with every new milestone my baby hits. But instead of joy, there's this weird sense of disconnection and numbness.

The Zoloft was meant to help me get through it all smoothly, but it turned out to be more of a curse than anything else. The weaning process was hellish—like pulling teeth, except without the anesthetic. I felt like I was being torn in half every day, between the need to function and the desire for relief from this constant mental anguish.

The worst part is how distant I feel from my little one. There’s no denying that I love him more than anything, but there’s also a void inside me that keeps whispering: “You’re not enough.” It’s hard to care for someone when you can’t even connect with your own feelings.

I’ve been trying to push through it all, hoping that tomorrow might bring some clarity or at least the promise of better days. Today though, I just want to sleep and wake up feeling like a real mom again—someone who isn’t just surviving but thriving alongside her baby.

It’s scary how much power these little pills had over my life and mind. Now I’m left with this lingering sense that even without them, the battle is far from won. But for today, I’ll take small steps, breathe deep, and hope that tomorrow brings a little more light than darkness.

This entry feels like a snapshot of struggle but also a plea for some respite. Here’s to hoping for brighter days ahead.

Today marks three weeks since the birth of my little miracle, but I feel like a stranger in this new world we’ve created together. The days blend into nights without much distinction anymore. My body feels heavy and unrecognizable, as if it’s lost its identity in the process of bringing life.

I stare at myself in the mirror, trying to find some semblance of my pre-baby self, but all I see are circles under my eyes and a face that seems to have forgotten how to smile. The joy that I imagined would flood my heart hasn’t arrived yet; instead, there’s an emptiness that feels like it will never be filled.

I keep thinking about the beauty that used to radiate from within me—my confidence, my zest for life—but now all I want is to crawl into bed and pull the covers over my head until this feeling passes. But it doesn’t pass, not really. It lingers like a dark cloud hanging low in the sky, threatening rain but never quite letting go.

The exhaustion is overwhelming; there are moments when holding my baby feels too much to bear. Yet, every time she looks at me with those big, innocent eyes, I know how incredibly lucky I am. But luck doesn’t change the way I feel inside.

I’m scared that if I talk about these feelings, they’ll somehow become more real, more permanent. But I also know that bottling them up isn’t helping anyone. Maybe it’s time to reach out and ask for help, not just for myself but for my baby too.

Tomorrow is a new day, they say. But today feels like a never-ending loop of the same old struggles. Perhaps tomorrow will be different, maybe with some support, I can find a way through this foggy haze that has settled over me since she arrived.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and I'm supposed to be basking in the joy of it all. But instead, I feel like I'm drowning in a sea of fear and uncertainty. The exhaustion is relentless; even after sleeping for what feels like an eternity, I wake up still tired, with an emptiness that seems bottomless.

Every day, there's this constant voice in my head whispering nightmares—warnings of a past come to haunt me again. It's not just about the sleepless nights or the endless feedings; it’s the overwhelming dread that grips me at odd moments. What if I can't handle being a mother? What if I’m failing before even really starting?

I’ve always known my history with depression is tricky terrain, but now it feels like quicksand. Every time I catch myself thinking about self-harm, I feel paralyzed. The thought of another battle looms large and terrifying.

But amidst all this darkness, there are tiny moments of light—like when my baby smiles at me or reaches out for a cuddle. Those brief glimpses make me wonder if maybe, just maybe, I can find the strength to push through this time. It’s like trying to hold onto hope with hands that keep slipping away.

I know I need help, but reaching out feels impossible right now. Each day seems heavier than the last, and I’m scared of what tomorrow might bring. But for today, I’ll try to breathe a little deeper and reach out just one tiny step closer to support. Maybe there’s still hope after all.

Today marks a new chapter, one I wasn’t sure would ever come. The weeks since little Alex’s birth have been a rollercoaster of emotions and physical exhaustion that left me feeling more alone than I ever imagined possible.

I remember the day Alex was born with such clarity—it was like everything went into slow motion. The labor itself felt endless, but when we finally welcomed our child, it wasn’t just joyous. There were complications. As a result, I spent days in recovery, while Alex needed extra care for some lingering effects of that traumatic start.

In the midst of all this chaos and uncertainty, my body was also adjusting to the drastic hormonal shifts post-birth. It’s like my mind got caught up in this storm too, with waves of sadness crashing over me every hour or so. I would stare at Alex, marveling at how small they were, yet feeling utterly overwhelmed.

But here’s what I’ve come to understand: it’s okay not to feel okay all the time. The haze is lifting now, and while there are still days when everything feels too heavy, I’m starting to find moments of clarity and peace. It helps knowing that these ups and downs are part of the journey for many new parents, and talking about them can make a world of difference.

So today, as Alex sleeps peacefully beside me, I feel a bit stronger. Maybe it’s just another day in this beautiful chaos, but I’m grateful for every tiny step forward.

Today marks two weeks since I welcomed my little miracle into the world, and while everyone around me seems to be in a whirlwind of joy and celebration, I find myself grappling with an unexpected visitor: postpartum depression. It’s strange how life can take such dramatic turns so quickly.

The nights are long, and no matter how much sleep I try to catch up on, it feels like there's always something weighing me down. There are moments when I look at my baby and feel this overwhelming love, but right next to that is a profound sense of sadness and despair. It’s not because there’s anything wrong with him or the way we’re raising him; he’s perfect in every single way.

It’s hard to explain these feelings to anyone without sounding like a broken record. People keep saying things will get better, but they don’t understand how deeply I’m struggling beneath this veneer of happiness and gratitude. The dark cloud hangs over me, making even the smallest tasks feel insurmountable.

But today, as I cradle my baby while looking out at the rain-soaked world through a windowpane, something shifts inside me. Maybe it’s recognizing that these struggles are part of my journey too, or maybe it’s just realizing that I need help—and that’s okay. It’s okay to feel this way and to reach out for support.

I’m tired of pretending everything is fine when it isn’t, but I also don't want to give up on finding the light again. Maybe it starts with a single step forward, even if all I can do today is acknowledge my feelings rather than hide them away.

Today marks three weeks since Lily’s birth, and yet every day feels like a blur of exhaustion and confusion. I’m still struggling to find my footing in this new reality, one that seems far removed from the joyous excitement of becoming a mother for the third time.

Each moment with her is both precious and overwhelming. I know she needs me now more than ever, but there are days when it feels like an insurmountable challenge just to get out of bed. My previous pregnancies were filled with anticipation and hope, this one has been overshadowed by a constant fog of despair.

The weight of having another child while battling my own mental health is crushing. I keep comparing everything to how I felt during the first two, and it’s like night and day. Why can’t I just feel the same way now? It’s as if all the love and joy that came so naturally before are buried under a layer of darkness.

The hospital staff mentioned something about postpartum depression, but at the time, it all sounded clinical and distant. Now, here I am, grappling with these feelings every waking hour. How do you pick up your life when everything feels so wrong?

I’m trying to stay positive, telling myself that this too shall pass, but the truth is—it’s getting harder each day. I need help, more than ever before. But how do you ask for it without sounding like a failure? Can I really be a good mother while feeling so deeply lost and alone?

Today was particularly tough; tears fell freely as I held her in my arms, wondering if this will ever feel right again. I miss the ease of my previous pregnancies, the natural high that came with bringing new life into the world. This time feels like an endless struggle.

I need a lifeline, something to hold onto amidst all this chaos. Maybe tomorrow will be better, but for now, I’m just hoping to make it through another day without falling too far behind.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my baby home from the hospital, and it feels like an eternity. The joy of finally having our little one is overshadowed by a heaviness that won’t seem to lift. It’s hard to put into words just how much this journey has weighed on me.

The first few days after delivery were a blur, but as reality set in, so did the fog of depression I’d felt during my pregnancy. The fatigue, the mood swings, and now the constant worry—it’s all back with full force. There are moments when I feel like I’m doing okay, maybe even enjoying this new chapter, but then it hits me again.

Sleep is a rare luxury. Every time my baby wakes up for feeding or cuddling, so do I, only to find myself wide awake and staring at the ceiling, lost in thoughts that won’t let go. It’s exhausting beyond words. And with each passing day, the sense of not being enough grows stronger. Am I doing this right? Is it normal to feel like this?

I know there’s help out there, but reaching out feels too daunting. How do you explain to someone how much your heart hurts when all you want is to love your baby unconditionally? It’s a cruel twist that the very thing meant to bring joy can also be the source of such profound sadness.

I wish I could shake this feeling off like I would a bad dream, but it lingers, dark and persistent. The support from my partner and family is amazing, but sometimes their cheerfulness feels like another reminder of what I’m missing out on. They’re trying to help, but there are days when even the simplest tasks seem insurmountable.

I’ve been here before—during pregnancy, with similar feelings gnawing at me—and yet, somehow, it still feels unexpected and overwhelming now that everything has changed. The fear is constant: will I ever feel like myself again?

Today, more than any other, I’m pushing through the haze to find a way to ask for help. Maybe that’s my small victory amidst this storm.

Today marks my fourth week since giving birth to our little miracle. The days blend together in a haze of exhaustion and new emotions that swirl inside me like an unpredictable storm. There are moments of pure joy when I hold her, marveling at how small she is yet feeling impossibly connected. But then there are other times where the weight of everything feels suffocating—those quiet moments alone with my thoughts can be overwhelming.

I’ve always been someone who enjoys a clear mind and a straightforward approach to problems, but lately, it’s like trying to navigate through thick fog. I keep wondering if it's just the exhaustion or something more. Before I got pregnant, there were times when stress felt manageable with a quick fix from substances that never should have been part of our story.

The nurses mentioned some screening questions about my mental state during check-ups, but honestly, I didn’t know what to tell them. Part of me hopes they’re just being overly cautious because pregnancy can bring on these feelings out of the blue. Another voice inside wonders if there’s a deeper reason why everything feels so off right now.

I know it’s important to be honest about my history, even though admitting mistakes is hard. It’s like acknowledging that I didn’t have all the answers before, and that scares me. But as much as I fear what might come next, I also feel a glimmer of hope. Maybe talking about these things openly will help us move forward and ensure our little one grows up in an environment free from any shadows of my past choices.

It’s a daunting thought to face the possibility of depression alongside all this new parenthood stuff, but perhaps it’s just another chapter I need to write—honestly and with care.

Today marks three weeks since I brought our little one home from the hospital. The first few days were a blur of joy and exhaustion, but now, the reality is settling in. Every moment seems to be filled with love for this tiny human who has changed everything. Yet, beneath the surface, there's an emptiness that feels impossible to fill.

The house is quiet, too quiet for my liking. I stare at the baby monitor as if it holds the key to happiness, but all I see is a screen flickering back at me with no answers. How did we get here? Where are the blissful days of pregnancy, when everything felt perfect and the future was full of endless possibilities?

The nights are the hardest. My heart feels heavy like a stone in my chest as I lie awake, listening to the soft breathing of our baby. The thought of having another child terrifies me now. What if this emptiness never goes away? Can I really risk going through it all again?

I’ve been trying to stay positive, to believe that things will get better with time and support. But today, as I cradle my son in my arms, the weight of everything feels almost unbearable. Maybe it’s time for a change, a different path—one where I am not constantly battling this darkness.

Tomorrow, I’ll make an appointment with my doctor. It's about taking care of myself first, so I can be there for our little family. This isn’t giving up; it’s choosing to live again.

Today marks exactly one year since my daughter was born, and I find myself sitting here, staring at the calendar, feeling hollow inside. It's been a rollercoaster of emotions—joy, fear, anxiety, exhaustion—and now, an overwhelming sense of sadness that seems to seep into every corner of my being.

I thought by now it would be different. That the foggy cloud of postpartum depression would lift as time went on and I adjusted to motherhood. But here I am, still grappling with waves of despair, wondering if things will ever feel okay again. It’s hard to smile when everyone around me expects it; they don’t see the tears I cry in the shower or the nights where sleep is a luxury because worry keeps me awake.

I’ve tried everything—therapy, support groups, medication—but some days feel like an endless cycle of trying and failing. My husband says he sees progress, but I can't shake this feeling that something is fundamentally wrong with me, as if I’m not meant to be a mother at all.

Today, I took my daughter out for her one-year birthday photos. She was laughing, playing, utterly oblivious to the turmoil inside of me. And in those moments when she looks up at me with pure joy and adoration, it’s hard not to feel like I'm letting her down, that I’m failing at being the person who can bring light into her life.

But today, instead of focusing on my failures, I am choosing to acknowledge them, accept them. Because maybe, just maybe, this is a turning point where I start seeking help in ways I haven’t before. Maybe it’s time for me to stop trying so hard to fit someone else's idea of what recovery looks like and find my own path.

So here I sit, marking another year on the calendar, but also vowing to mark new beginnings for myself.

Today marks another day since little one arrived into this world. It's funny how my life has changed so drastically in such a short span of time. The nursery is finally complete with the last touch being a soft, cozy blanket that I knitted myself. But as much joy as there is, there’s an overwhelming sense of exhaustion and emptiness inside me.

I keep telling myself to be more positive and look at all the good things, but it feels like no matter how hard I try, my thoughts always drift back to those dark places. It's not just about being tired—it's a constant battle with myself to get out of bed in the morning. Every time I see that tiny little person looking up at me with such innocence and trust, I feel an enormous pressure to be this perfect mother figure.

I know from my previous experience that postpartum depression is sneaky like that; it creeps in when you least expect it. But here’s something else I’m proud of: despite the darkness inside me, I still manage to help others who are going through similar struggles. It feels like a small victory each time I make myself call a friend or send a message just to check up on them.

Sometimes, though, the weight of everything gets too heavy and it's hard not to feel completely lost in this new reality. But even when I’m at my lowest, there’s still that part of me that wants to find a way through. Maybe it’s a survival instinct or perhaps some leftover strength from days gone by—I don’t know—but I’ll keep fighting for us both.

One day at a time. That's what they say, right? So here we are today—another day in this journey. And even though the path is tough, there’s hope that tomorrow might bring something different.

Today is one of those days where the sun seems to mock me with its brightness. I can’t shake this overwhelming sense of sadness and fatigue that clings to my bones like a second skin. The baby’s first winter, and already everything feels so heavy.

Sleepless nights blend into sleepless days. My body aches from carrying around more weight than it ever has before—more than just the physical kind. The world feels quieter, duller, as if I’m listening to muted music through cotton balls stuffed in my ears. Even small tasks feel monumental; showering takes an effort that should belong to climbing Mount Everest.

I thought having a baby would be this magical moment where everything brightens up. Instead, it’s like living inside a gray cloud that refuses to disperse. Every time I try to talk about how I’m feeling, words get tangled in my throat. “It’s just the blues,” they say. But this isn’t just the blues; it’s a deep, dark chasm swallowing me whole.

I keep thinking, maybe if I smile enough, I’ll feel happy eventually. It’s exhausting pretending to be okay when you’re anything but. Today, I wish for something as simple as a moment of peace, where my heart and mind sync up and tell me everything will be alright.

Today feels like another battle in a war I never asked for. The sun is up and the baby is crying again, but instead of that familiar rush to soothe them, I feel this heavy weight dragging me down. It’s been weeks since I thought I was turning a corner, but here we are, back at square one.

Sometimes I wonder if anyone else experiences these waves of emotion. One minute, I’m feeling like I can handle everything—feed the baby, get some sleep, maybe even have time to brush my hair. The next minute, it all feels too much. Too loud. Too chaotic. My mind races with thoughts that don’t make sense: “Why am I here? What’s wrong with me?”

But there are moments of clarity, too. Right now, as I’m writing this, there’s a calmness in my chest. It’s like when you take a deep breath and everything slows down for just one second. In those seconds, I remind myself that I’m not alone. There’s a support group starting next week, and even though the idea of leaving the house feels daunting, I know it’s important.

Every day is different. Some days are better than others, but every time I think I might be getting somewhere, something else hits me hard. It could be a comment from someone, or just an overwhelming feeling that I’m not doing enough. But then, in those quiet moments when the baby sleeps and everything quiets down, there’s this little voice inside me that whispers, “You’re doing okay.”

So here I am, trying to find my way through another day. It feels like a never-ending journey, but I keep moving forward because even though it’s hard, there are small victories too—like when the baby smiles or when I manage to take a shower without feeling guilty.

I’m not sure what tomorrow will bring, but for now, I’ll focus on this moment. One day at a time, right?

Today was a mix of emotions, and I'm trying to hold on to the good ones because they seem few and far between lately. Holding my baby is still magical, but everything else feels like a blur. Talking to my friend earlier today really helped; she reminded me that it's okay not to feel okay all the time. Admitting to her that I might be experiencing postpartum depression was surprisingly liberating—I didn't know how long I'd been carrying this weight until I let it out.

Sleeping is a challenge, and every time my baby wakes up, I wonder if I can keep going without collapsing into tears or giving in to the exhaustion. But then there are moments when holding him feels like everything, and those moments are what keep me going. It’s hard not to feel guilty about these darker thoughts, but I'm trying to be honest with myself and seek help.

I’m planning on reaching out for support soon—maybe joining a postpartum group or talking to my doctor again. It's reassuring that there are resources available and people who understand what it feels like. For now, though, one day at a time feels more manageable than trying to figure everything out right away.

December 7, 2022

Today marks a low point unlike anything I’ve ever felt before. The weight of this darkness is crushing me in ways I never thought possible. It’s been a year of constant struggle and today feels like the culmination of all that pain. 

When I was pregnant last year, I had moments of joy mixed with anxiety about becoming a new mom. But now that my baby is here and growing every day, there's no happiness to be found in this moment. Instead, I’m overwhelmed by despair. The sadness is deeper than it’s ever been, even worse than when I went through postpartum depression after my first child was born.

Looking back, last year seemed filled with hope despite some rough patches. Now each day feels like a battle against an enemy that won’t leave me alone. I miss those times when life felt manageable and joyous. 

I’ve tried to stay positive, to lean on my support system, but it’s hard. My husband tries his best, but he can't understand the depths of this despair. Sometimes I wonder if things will ever get better or if this is just how life will be now.

The baby smiles at me and I want to love them more than anything, but the love feels distant. The exhaustion is relentless and every tiny problem feels insurmountable. 

I need help. I know that much. But right now, all I feel is lost in a sea of darkness with no hope of finding my way out.

Today feels like a blend of old fears and hopeful beginnings. As I hold my newborn for the first time, I can’t help but recall the dark days after my last child’s birth. The exhaustion, the loneliness, the overwhelming sense that something wasn’t right. But this time is different—I’m not waiting for postpartum depression to hit me like a freight train. This time, I’ve prepared.

I’ve been meeting with my therapist weekly and practicing mindfulness techniques daily. Every morning, before anyone else stirs in the house, I sit quietly, focusing on my breath and the warmth of the sun against my skin. It’s a small ritual that helps me stay grounded when everything around feels chaotic.

The hospital sent over a list of resources for new mothers dealing with mental health concerns, which is comforting to know they’re there if needed. But today, I’m just trying to savor this moment. The soft cry from the crib next door reminds me how fragile yet resilient we both are.

I’ve promised myself that I’ll take things one day at a time and reach out for help when I need it. For now, I’ll hold my baby close and whisper words of strength into their tiny ear. We’re in this together, fighting any darkness with every fiber of our being.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom. The days blend together in a haze of sleepless nights and endless feedings. Maybe because everything happens so quickly; you’re suddenly in the thick of it without time to dwell on fears.

There’s no denying the anxiety about postpartum depression. It wasn’t something I feared before, but it's hard to ignore now.

I worry more about my mental health than any physical pain. Am I just tired and adjusting, or is this deeper? The uncertainty scares me. How do you know when your feelings are normal versus something serious?

Today was a long day with little sleep again. My husband tried to help but felt helpless himself. It’s a strange feeling being in charge of someone else's life without knowing what you’re doing. I’m trying not to panic, but it’s hard.

I need to reach out for support. This isn’t just about me anymore; it’s about us and our little one growing up in this chaos. I’ll call my doctor tomorrow and see if there are resources available. Maybe talking can help clear some of the fog.

Today marks the start of a new chapter in my life, one that I didn’t see coming. The baby is just over a week old now, and everything feels so surreal. I’ve been waking up every few hours to feed her, and while it’s an incredible feeling holding her close, there are moments when all I want to do is curl up in bed and sleep.

The doctor prescribed me some medication for my postpartum depression and anxiety yesterday. It’s a bit of a shock, but also a relief knowing that help is on the way. Today was my first day taking it, and while I’m not jumping for joy about it, there’s a sense of acceptance. The pills sit on the nightstand now, a small reminder that things will get better.

I’ve been trying to focus more on self-care, even if it just means drinking enough water or eating something other than peanut butter straight from the jar. I feel like I’m treading water most days, but there are tiny moments of clarity and peace amidst the chaos. Today I sat outside in the afternoon sun with my baby for a bit, and that felt good.

I know I need to be more proactive about talking to people too—I haven’t reached out as much since the baby came. Maybe tomorrow will bring a new perspective or maybe just another day of figuring it all out. For now, taking one step at a time is the only thing I can do.

Today marks a week since I brought my baby home, and the joy of new life is overshadowed by an overwhelming sense of emptiness. It's like there's this dark cloud hovering over me, making every moment feel heavy and meaningless. The midwife said everything was normal during those first few days in the hospital, but she didn't see the tears that wouldn't stop, or the nights where I'd just stare at my sleeping baby without feeling any of the love they say you’re supposed to feel.

I've seen several doctors since then—pediatrician, OB-GYN, family doctor—but none of them have picked up on how badly I need help. They talk about breastfeeding and vaccinations but completely miss the desperation in my eyes when I try to smile at them. Each visit leaves me feeling more alone and misunderstood.

I'm not sure if it's okay to feel this way, especially as a new mom. Everyone tells you that postpartum blues are normal, but I think mine might be deeper than that. I've tried reaching out for support, but it feels like no one is listening. The baby is perfect, the house is messy, and there’s a constant pressure to be happy and grateful when all I want to do is hide under the covers.

I need someone who can see past the surface, who understands what this darkness inside me means. Until then, each day feels like an endless battle against my own mind.

I've been trying not to let any sadness or worry take over, but it’s sneaking in at unexpected moments. I’ve been reading about postpartum depression because something in me thinks maybe understanding it better will make the feelings go away. The numbers on those screening tests? Maybe tomorrow will be easier. Or maybe today was just one of those days where everything felt extra hard. Either way, I'm hoping that the more time passes, the better I'll feel about all this newness in my life.

March 14, 2023

Today marks the one-month anniversary of my baby’s birth. It feels like a lifetime ago when I was beaming with excitement and hope for our new life together. Now, the reality of it all hits me in waves. Being alone with this tiny human who depends on me completely is both overwhelming and daunting.

I’ve been trying to stay positive, but some days feel heavier than others. The walls seem to close in around me, and my heart feels heavy as lead. I can’t shake off the feeling that I’m doing it all wrong. Sleep deprivation hasn’t helped either; it’s a never-ending cycle of feeding, changing diapers, and trying to catch a few minutes of shut-eye.

The pandemic isolates us further. No visitors, no family support—just me and this little being who needs everything from me. There are moments when I feel like I’m drowning, yet somehow, amidst the chaos, there’s also an indescribable love for my child that pulls me through.

Tonight, as I hold him close while he sleeps, a glimmer of strength emerges within me. It’s not about being perfect; it’s about finding the courage to ask for help and cherish each tiny victory along the way. Tomorrow will be another day, and with every new dawn, I’ll keep moving forward.

What if my baby isn't reaching those developmental milestones because there's an underlying issue?

I can feel myself spiraling into that familiar dark place where hopelessness reigns and joy feels like a distant memory. I keep thinking about how laughter used to be the best medicine for me, but now it’s just another thing I don’t have.

But then again, maybe it’s okay if things are different this time around. Maybe my baby will find their own way of bringing light into our lives without needing to giggle first. I can't let myself fall down that rabbit hole again where worrying about every little detail feels like a full-time job. It's not healthy for me or my family.

I need to focus on the here and now, celebrate the small victories, and not rush things. After all, they say parenthood is a marathon, not a sprint. I just hope that by the end of it, we’ll still have our sense of humor intact.

Today marks one week since little Mia entered our world. I can’t help but feel a mix of joy and dread as I sit here in the quiet of the evening, holding her tiny hand. The hospital staff was kind, offering their support, but I couldn't shake this sense of unease.

Every moment with Mia is precious, but it’s also a reminder of my fragility. I want to cherish her and love her unconditionally, yet the fear lingers like an unwelcome guest. How do you push through when the shadows seem so vast?

I need to find ways to support myself through this journey, not just for me, but for Mia too. Maybe it’s time to lean on friends more, seek professional help earlier next time—whatever it takes to keep those clouds at bay.

Today is a new day, filled with hopes and fears, all wrapped in the tender love of a newborn. Here’s hoping I can navigate this beautifully complex chapter with grace and resilience.

March 15, Day 30

Lily, you’re my little miracle and my world. But for me, finding peace in these moments is a journey I’m willing to take one step at a time. Here’s to more days of growth, both for us and those who are struggling silently like I have been.

Today marks another day since my baby was born four years ago. It’s funny how time flies when you’re trying to stay afloat in a sea of emotions that just won’t let up. I’ve been here before, but this time feels different somehow. Maybe it’s the exhaustion, maybe it’s the reality setting in yet again that the world outside my home isn’t doing enough for mothers like me.

I wish there was an easy fix for what feels impossible. But I’m not giving up. For me and for everyone else out there who’s struggling in silence, I’ll keep fighting. One day at a time.

Today marks a week since little Emma joined our world. It's hard to put into words how mixed my feelings are right now. Maybe talking about these feelings with someone who understands could make a difference. For now, though, I’m holding on to hope that things will get better somehow.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world. But instead of feeling elated and grateful like those glossy mom blogs suggest, I feel hollow. Today marks a week since I brought our little miracle into the world, and yet it feels like an eternity. Today marks another day of this never-ending fog that seems to have settled over my mind since bringing our baby home. It's been a rollercoaster of emotions and physical exhaustion, but today was different—I actually felt a glimmer of hope.

I was always a skeptic about medical cannabis—thought it was only something used recreationally or for people who had given up on other options. Their stories felt like they could be mine if given half a chance. For the first time since my daughter's birth, I didn't feel so alone.

I'm still hesitant, but there’s something about holding onto this possibility that feels empowering. Maybe today wasn’t as bad because of the newfound information, or maybe it’s just wishful thinking. Either way, tomorrow is another day to face whatever comes next—armed with a little more knowledge and hope.

The sun is just beginning to peek over the horizon, casting a soft golden glow into my bedroom. It's one of those rare mornings where I feel a glimmer of hope, but it’s fleeting. I remember the day I broke down in front of my doctor—tears streaming down my face as I confessed that I couldn't keep up with the baby, let alone myself. She listened patiently and suggested trying medical marijuana. At first, I was hesitant, but desperation pushed me to give it a shot.

Now, four months later, there are days when I can actually sit through a book or take the time to enjoy a cup of tea without feeling like my heart might break at any moment. It’s not a cure, but it has been a lifeline. The relief is tangible, and for that, I am grateful.

There are still moments of despair, but they're fewer now. My doctor reminds me every visit that this too shall pass. She encourages psychoeducation, telling me it's important to understand what I'm going through and learn coping mechanisms. It’s a long road ahead, but today feels like a small step forward.
