I remember feeling so lost when the baby blues turned into something deeper, but then I stumbled upon this Pittsburgh-based figure who just gets postpartum depression. Her words are a balm to my soul. She talks about her journey, and it gives me hope that maybe one day soon, I'll feel like myself again.

Right now though, every moment is a battle. The tears come out of nowhere, but so does a quiet strength to keep going. I'm trying to hold onto that strength because even if I’m not okay right now, I know tomorrow will be better. Or maybe it won’t, but I have to believe it can get better.

I've started talking about my feelings with friends and family more openly, something the Pittsburgh figure encouraged me to do. It's scary admitting how much this is affecting me, but it’s also a relief. Maybe reaching out was the first step in finding my way back from this abyss.

Today felt particularly tough, but I made it through another day. And tomorrow? Well, I’ll take one breath at a time and see where that leads.

April 7th, 2023

Today marks a month since little Mia joined our family. The days have been a whirlwind of sleepless nights and endless joy, but also moments of sheer exhaustion and doubt. I’ve been navigating the rollercoaster of postpartum emotions, something I know all too well from my first child’s birth four years ago.

Today, though, my heart ached for Emily. She’s struggling more than she lets on, hiding her tears behind forced smiles during our playgroup gatherings. It’s hard to see someone you care about in so much pain, especially when you’ve walked the same path and know how isolating it can be. I want to help her but feel powerless at times.

I called my therapist this morning to check-in on my own progress because helping others starts with taking care of myself too. My EPDS score is still reassuringly low, a testament to the support network around me—family, friends, and professionals who understand what it’s like to be in Emily’s shoes now.

As I rock Mia to sleep, I send her a text offering to drive over tomorrow afternoon if she wants to talk. Sometimes just being there can make all the difference.

Today marks a week since my diagnosis and it feels like a weight has been lifted off my shoulders. I was initially terrified by the thought of having postpartum depression, but as I started therapy and took medication, everything began to fall into place. It's funny how such simple solutions can feel so overwhelming in the midst of chaos.

Yesterday, during our session with Dr. Smith, we talked about all those anxious moments that felt like a never-ending storm. She helped me see that these feelings are just clouds passing by and not my permanent reality. Each day feels more manageable now, and I’m slowly starting to appreciate the little victories, like holding my baby’s hand while walking in the park or simply smiling at her soft coos.

The medication is really helping too. It's amazing how a few pills can restore your sense of balance and make everything seem brighter. Today was a particularly good day—my husband even noticed I seemed more relaxed and engaged with our daughter. That small observation brought me so much joy; it’s the kind of thing I used to take for granted before.

I'm still learning about this new chapter in my life, but each passing day feels like another step towards healing. The support from friends and family has been incredible too—knowing they’re there with a listening ear or an offer to help makes all the difference. Right now, I’m focusing on taking things one day at a time and cherishing every moment.

Today marks my third week as a new mom, and I’m still trying to figure out this whole “motherhood” thing. The hospital sent me home with bags full of advice pamphlets, but nothing compares to the reality of it all. I feel like I’m walking around in a foggy dream where every little sound is amplified, yet my hands are empty when I want them full.

The baby sleeps most of the day now, and while that might sound like a break for some, it feels more like an eerie quiet that presses down on me. The moments when she’s awake are fleeting but precious; I catch glimpses of her tiny features shifting from curiosity to contentment as she locks eyes with me. But even in those tender seconds, there's this voice inside my head whispering that I’m not enough.

I’ve been trying to keep up appearances, going through the motions like everyone else around here—changing diapers, feeding, soothing. Yet there are days when all of it feels overwhelmingly impossible. The exhaustion is a constant companion, dragging at my heels and sapping any energy left for joy or hope.

My heart aches with this strange mix of love and despair. How can something so wonderful also feel like the heaviest weight I’ve ever carried? Sometimes I wonder if anyone else out there feels as lost and alone as I do in these moments.

I keep telling myself that everyone struggles in their own way, but it doesn’t stop the tears from falling or the questions from building up inside me. When will this fog lift? How long until everything feels okay again?

But right now, all I know is holding on tight to hope and reaching out for help when I can’t keep going alone.

Today was a blur of tears and coffee substitutes. I woke up to another sleepless night, the weight of everything crashing down on me like bricks from nowhere. My baby’s sweet little face is there one second, and the next, it’s just an endless pit of despair. 

I found myself reaching for that stash again this morning, Adderall becoming my crutch once more. The thought of facing another day without it feels impossible. It's funny how something so small can change your entire world. I've been creating these fake accounts on social media too, trying to hide behind different personas. It’s like a twisted game where I pretend everything is okay while deep down inside, I’m barely holding on.

Every time I post about the perfect moments—smiling baby, clean house—it feels so hollow. Like lying to strangers for attention and validation that I can never get from reality. Why do I keep doing this? Is it because the real me scares everyone away?

The days blend together in a haze of exhaustion and guilt. Every pill becomes another lie, each post is another mask. But how much longer can I hide behind them all before everything falls apart?

I need help but don’t know where to start. This cycle feels never-ending, like a dark spiral with no escape. Maybe tomorrow will be better... maybe it won't. For now, I’ll just keep pretending until something breaks inside me and forces change.

Please, someone, tell me what to do because this is killing me slowly.

Today feels different. I woke up and the sun seemed to be sneaking in through the blinds, casting a warm glow that usually makes me smile, but today it just feels... indifferent. The baby is sleeping peacefully next to me, her tiny chest rising and falling with each breath. She’s perfect, really. But why does everything feel so heavy?

I’ve been denying this for weeks now—telling myself it’s normal, that I’m tired, overwhelmed, but surely not depressed. It’s like wearing a mask every day, putting on a brave face for everyone else while inside, I’m crumbling.

Today is the first time I admitted to myself that there’s something more going on than just being a new mom who needs sleep. I’ve felt lost in my own headspace, questioning everything—my choices, my abilities, even if I truly deserve to be here at all.

But now, sitting here with the morning light and the quiet house, I’m ready for this. Ready to face what’s been brewing inside me and seek help. Maybe it won’t fix everything overnight, but taking that first step feels like lifting a weight off my chest.

Today marks the beginning of healing. It feels small and scary, but also hopeful.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my baby home from the hospital. The joy of becoming a mother is overshadowed by an emptiness that seems to grow with each passing day. It's funny how everyone talks about the blissful postpartum period, but no one mentions the crushing fatigue and relentless anxiety. Every moment feels like a battle against myself.

I woke up this morning wondering if I could even handle another day of being a mom. The idea of feeding, changing, and soothing my newborn felt insurmountable. Yet, scrolling through social media, seeing others open about their struggles with postpartum depression has given me some comfort. Knowing that I'm not alone in feeling like this is a small beacon of hope.

I spent the afternoon watching documentaries on parents who faced similar challenges but found strength within themselves and support from those around them. Their stories remind me that it's okay to admit when things are too much, and reaching out for help isn't a sign of weakness—it’s a step towards healing.

Tonight, I made myself a cup of tea and sat quietly in the dark, listening to my baby sleep. It was peaceful, and for a moment, I felt like maybe tomorrow will be better. But then doubt crept back in, whispering that I’m not good enough. So, I wrote this down instead. Maybe sharing these feelings with someone else, even if it's just on paper, can make them feel a little less overwhelming.

Tomorrow is another day, and for now, that’s all I have to hold onto.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of darkness and exhaustion. I woke up to the sun shining brightly outside my window, but inside it's as gloomy as ever. The baby is sleeping peacefully in her crib, but for me, there’s no rest from this constant cloud hanging over my head.

I stumbled upon Cardi B’s post about her struggles with postpartum depression yesterday. It was like she spoke directly to my heart—my soul. She mentioned feeling overwhelmed by the simplest tasks and questioning if I’m a good enough mom because I can’t seem to shake off these feelings of emptiness and despair. And here we are, me scrolling through endless feeds trying to find some semblance of hope in someone else’s words.

It’s funny how social media makes everything feel so public yet private at the same time. People post about their perfect lives, but behind those screens is often a different story. I can’t help but wonder if anyone out there really understands this battle with my own mind. There are moments when I try to convince myself that these feelings will pass soon enough, but it’s hard not to feel trapped in this endless loop.

I miss the days before she was born; those fleeting moments of sleep and quiet peace. Now, every little thing feels like a monumental task—feeding her, changing diapers, just making sure she’s okay. And yet, here I am, questioning everything. Am I doing this right? Is it normal to feel so utterly lost?

I’m trying to reach out for help, but it’s scary to admit how much I need support. It feels like there’s no escape from these thoughts swirling around in my head, but maybe talking about them isn’t as bad as I think.

Maybe today will be better. Maybe tomorrow will bring some light through this dark tunnel. For now, I’m going to hold onto that thought and hope it's true.

May 5th, Five Months Post-Delivery

Today marks five months since I brought my baby into the world, and yet it feels like an eternity ago. The first few weeks were a blur of sleepless nights and overwhelming joy, but now everything feels so different. It’s as if all the happiness has faded away with each passing day.

I wake up every morning feeling heavy and numb inside. I can’t shake off this cloud that hangs over me no matter how hard I try. The thought of another long day without any sunshine just makes my heart ache. Sometimes, when I look at my baby’s face or hear them cry, it feels like an alien noise in my ears. It’s not who I am, but I don’t know who to be anymore.

I keep telling myself that everyone goes through this, and surely things will get better soon. But the days turn into weeks, and the weeks into months, and nothing seems to change. There are moments of brief relief when something funny happens or when my baby smiles at me—then I wonder if those fleeting joys mean anything is really improving.

I wish someone could understand how hard it is just to keep going every day. Sometimes, the only thing that keeps me from falling apart completely is knowing there’s a tomorrow and maybe someday things will be different. Right now, though, all I want is for this pain to stop. It feels like I’m drowning in my own thoughts.

I don’t know how much longer I can keep pretending everything is okay. But I’ll try, because that’s what mothers do—right?

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of darkness and despair. The baby cries for no reason, but I can't seem to comfort them. It's not just the physical pain; it's this deep-seated sadness that won't let me breathe.

I sit here in my room, surrounded by toys and clothes that are supposed to bring joy, yet they only remind me of how much I’m failing as a mother. The walls feel like they're closing in on me, suffocating every ounce of hope I have left. Sometimes, the only thing that keeps me going is the thought of God’s love and His promise to never leave or forsake me.

I’ve tried so hard to be strong, but there are moments when it feels impossible. The voices in my head tell me lies, whispering doubts and fears that make everything seem worse than it already is. I know I’m not alone in this struggle—there must be other moms out there feeling like this too—but the isolation can feel suffocating.

But amidst all this chaos, there are glimmers of light. A kind word from a friend, a moment when my baby smiles at me, a prayer that feels like it’s lifting some of the weight off my shoulders. I cling to those moments because they remind me that even in darkness, there is hope and healing.

I’m trying to take each day as it comes, one breath at a time. The pain will lessen with time, won’t it? It has to. For now, I hold onto faith, hoping it’s enough to carry me through until the sun shines again.

Today feels like one of those days where the world outside my window is in full bloom, but inside me, there’s only this heavy mist clinging to everything I touch. The baby sleeps soundly next to me, tiny and perfect, yet it does nothing to lift the weight off my chest. Every time I look at her, I feel a mix of joy and an overwhelming sadness that leaves me breathless.

I’ve been trying so hard to be happy, to just enjoy this precious moment we have together as mother and daughter. But what’s happening in here—this dark cloud hanging over me—is like a constant reminder that there’s something wrong with all of this. How can I feel so detached from my own baby? It’s terrifying.

Sometimes, when I hold her close, I think maybe if I just stay still long enough, the sadness will leave too. But it doesn’t. It lingers and whispers doubts in my ear whenever she’s asleep or crying for no reason. It tells me that I’m not good enough to be a mother, that I should have never brought this life into the world.

But then there are moments of clarity where I remember how much she needs me, how lucky I am to be her first teacher, her first friend. Those moments give me hope, but they’re fleeting, and as soon as they pass, the emptiness comes back stronger than before.

I need help. I know that now more than ever. But reaching out feels like climbing a mountain with no hands, and every step forward is met with doubt and fear. Maybe tomorrow will be better. Maybe it won’t. For today though, all I can do is breathe through this fog, hoping for light to seep in eventually.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and honestly, I feel more exhausted than ever before but in the most unexpected way possible. The sleepless nights are catching up with me, but there’s an odd sense of peace that comes from being here, surrounded by the tiny life I brought into this world.

The moment I held her for the first time was surreal; it felt like a dream come true mixed with a nightmare. But now, as days pass and my body adjusts to its new reality, I’m starting to feel more grounded. It’s funny how something so small can change your whole perspective on life.

I’ve been trying really hard not to judge myself too harshly for feeling overwhelmed. Everyone says it’s normal, but hearing it and experiencing it are two very different things. My mom keeps telling me that this is just a phase, and if I’m honest with myself, there’s comfort in knowing she’s right.

Today was another one of those days where everything seemed to go wrong. But then the sunshine crept through my window, and for some reason, it made me smile. It’s like nature has its own way of reminding us that even on the toughest days, there’s always a chance for a fresh start.

I’ve decided I’m going to keep talking about how I feel because I know that silence can be dangerous. The more we share, the less alone we’ll feel. And today, as I held my little girl and looked at her sleeping face, I felt a sense of purpose I haven’t had in years.

Tomorrow is another day, and though it might come with its own set of challenges, I’m hopeful that it will also bring moments of pure joy and unexpected peace. Here’s to the unpredictable journey of motherhood!

Today marks my fourth week since giving birth to little Emma. The joy of holding her for the first time was overshadowed by an overwhelming sense of exhaustion and confusion that seems to follow me everywhere. I know everyone says these moments will pass, but sometimes it feels like a dark cloud has taken up permanent residence in my heart.

The nights are especially hard. No matter how much sleep I try to get, it’s never enough. Emma cries for what feels like hours on end, and while the initial excitement of being her mother still lingers, the exhaustion is starting to wear me down. There are moments when holding her brings tears to my eyes, but they’re not happy tears.

I keep telling myself that this is all normal—newborns cry, new moms feel tired—but there’s a nagging voice inside my head saying something isn’t right. It feels like I’m failing already, and I can barely muster the strength to pick up a spoon or brush my teeth. The thought of going back to work in a few weeks fills me with dread.

I know I need help, but asking for it feels like admitting defeat. Today, I made an appointment with my doctor, hoping she’ll give me some advice on how to cope better. Until then, I’m trying to focus on the small victories—like getting out of bed and taking a shower—and reminding myself that every day is a new chance to get better.

Tomorrow feels daunting right now, but for today, I’m just going to take it one step at a time.

Today is day 34 since I brought little Lila home, and honestly, it feels like an eternity rather than a month. The baby cries, the house is messy, and my head feels like it's spinning. Every time I look at her tiny face, all I can think about is how overwhelmed I am. Why does everything feel so impossible? 

I've been scrolling through Instagram, trying to find someone who understands this pain, but everyone seems so perfect. How do they manage to smile while holding their babies like it's the easiest thing in the world? Maybe I'm just not cut out for this.

The other day, I tried counting my blessings—new life, a warm home—but every positive thought is quickly overshadowed by anxiety and despair. I feel trapped between the joy of being a mother and the darkness that clings to me like shadows at dusk. 

I know I shouldn't be posting about it on social media, but sometimes writing "#postpartumstruggle" feels like my only lifeline to someone who might understand. Is there anyone out there who can tell me it's okay not to feel okay? That the sadness won't last forever?

Today, as Lila sleeps peacefully in her crib, I sit here crying and wondering if this is just a phase or something deeper. I know I need help, but every step feels like climbing Mount Everest. Maybe tomorrow will be better. But then again, maybe it won’t.

I need to find my way out of the fog, even if it means reaching for that one tiny spark of hope and holding on tight until morning light breaks through.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of exhaustion and confusion. I woke up at the crack of dawn with tears in my eyes, not knowing why. Is this normal? Am I just overly tired from holding it together for so long?

I look over to see our baby sleeping peacefully, and there's that moment where everything seems perfect. But then reality hits again—nursing issues, lack of sleep, the overwhelming feeling that I'm failing at this mom thing.

Yesterday, my husband suggested we should talk more openly about what we're going through. He said it might help to reach out for support, but reaching out feels like admitting defeat. Still, maybe he's right. Maybe talking can make a difference.

I know deep down, there are resources available—support groups, therapy—but the thought of stepping into something new is daunting. How do I even begin? What if everyone there seems so put together and I feel like such an imposter?

Today marks another day in this journey, but it's okay to admit that some days aren't as joyful as they're supposed to be. Maybe tomorrow will bring a little more clarity, a bit of hope.

Maybe.

Today marks another day in this long journey of balancing the chaos of motherhood with the lingering shadows of my postpartum depression. I find myself staring at my baby, now a curious toddler with teeth and tantrums, trying to grasp where all the time went. Weaning her from breast milk feels like an impossible task, yet here we are, another week closer to the inevitable.

The struggle isn't just about logistics; it's about saying goodbye to something that has been a constant source of comfort for both of us. I catch myself wondering if she'll remember these moments when she’s older. Will they be as vivid in her memory as they are in mine? Or will they fade like so many other fleeting thoughts?

The nights feel endless, each one a reminder of the silent battles within me. Some days, I manage to smile and laugh; others, I hide under my blankets, wondering how much longer this storm will rage inside my head. Weaning feels like another mountain to climb when all I want is for it to be over.

Yet, amidst the fog, there are glimmers of hope. The way she clings to me during these last feeds, or the soft sounds of contentment as she falls asleep against my chest. These moments remind me that while this chapter is closing, another one is just beginning—a new adventure filled with love and growth.

Today, I will take it one step at a time. One feed less, one day closer to healing. And maybe, just maybe, finding peace along the way.

Today marks a week since my baby's birth, and I can't say it’s been as joyous as I imagined. The nights feel endless; I toss and turn, wide awake in the dark, wondering if sleep will ever come again. Every time the clock ticks past midnight, anxiety claws at me like never before.

During the day, there’s an odd mix of exhaustion and restlessness. I don’t know how to handle it all—changing diapers, feeding, trying to figure out what my baby needs. It's overwhelming, and when I try to find peace in a quiet moment, my mind spirals with thoughts that aren't very kind.

There are moments where I feel a glimmer of hope; maybe tonight will be different, or perhaps tomorrow will bring clarity. But as the days blend together into one long stretch of uncertainty, those moments grow fewer and farther between.

I know I should reach out for help, but it feels like admitting defeat. How can someone who's supposed to be a mother struggle so much? It’s confusing, and the guilt is heavy. Yet, every time I think about how tired my partner looks or how my baby needs me, something shifts inside. Maybe reaching out isn’t weakness; maybe it’s strength.

I need to remember that no one expects perfection. There's support out there—friends, family, professionals who understand this journey better than I do right now. It feels like a big step, but perhaps it's time to take it.

Today marks one year and eight months since I brought my little boy home from the hospital. The days blur together sometimes, but this particular date feels heavy with memories—both good and bad. I remember those early weeks of sleepless nights and endless worry, wondering if it would ever get better.

The fear is creeping back in now. It's been a year since my last episode of postpartum depression, but the second anniversary of his birth seems to be triggering something inside me. The exhaustion feels familiar again—like I'm carrying around this giant boulder of anxiety and sadness that just won't let up.

I know it’s important to reach out, to talk about what I’m feeling. But part of me is terrified of admitting how hard things are right now. It's like a vicious cycle—I feel alone in my struggles, but reaching out feels too overwhelming.

There were moments today when all I wanted was to disappear and escape everything for a while. And then there were flashes where I felt hopeful, imagining a future where these dark thoughts fade away. Maybe it’s time to revisit those resources that helped before—the therapist who understands this struggle, the support group where others are going through similar battles.

I don’t want to relive what happened last time, but I also can’t ignore how my body and mind feel right now. It feels like a balancing act—holding onto hope while acknowledging the darkness. Today is just one day at a time, trying to find that delicate balance.

Today marks one week since bringing my baby into this world. The past days have been a whirlwind of emotions and physical recovery. I’ve found myself looking at the new life growing before me with both wonder and exhaustion.

There are moments when everything feels perfect, like holding your newborn for the first time is pure magic. But then there are those other times—when all you want to do is cry because getting out of bed seems impossible or wondering if you’re ever going to feel fully connected to this tiny human who depends on you so completely.

I’ve been trying to remind myself that it’s okay not to be okay right now. I know everyone talks about the joy of motherhood, but no one really prepares you for how hard it can be sometimes. It’s like your heart is full and overflowing with love, yet also heavy from lack of sleep and adjusting to a new reality.

I’ve been reaching out to my mom and sisters more often, asking them about their experiences. They tell me that these feelings are normal, that it takes time for everything to click into place. I hope they’re right because, honestly, I just want this overwhelming sense of uncertainty to lift.

Today, as I watched the sun set from my hospital room window, I made a promise to myself: I’ll take each day one step at a time and let myself feel all the emotions that come with it. After all, being a new mom isn’t about perfection—it’s about finding your way in this beautiful, messy journey of parenthood.

Today feels like a blur of tears and uncertainty. The baby’s cries echo in my ears as I struggle to find any joy or peace. I feel so lost, like everything is too much but also nothing matters at all. Why can’t I just love this little life the way everyone says you’re supposed to? 

I keep thinking about how happy we were before. How full of hope and excitement for our new family. Now it’s like a dark cloud hangs over us all the time. Every day feels like climbing an impossible mountain.

Worry gnaws at me constantly – is everything okay? Am I doing enough? What if something terrible happens? It's exhausting, this endless fear and doubt.

I’m trying to push through, for her sake. But it’s hard. So hard. Sometimes I just want to hide away somewhere safe until these feelings pass. 

I know I need help though. Someone who understands how you can feel like a stranger in your own skin right now. Maybe then I could start to see some light again.

Please let there be hope ahead, even if it’s out of reach today.

Today was a whirlwind of emotions and exhaustion. I woke up feeling like the weight of the world was pressing down on my chest, heavier than ever before. It’s been weeks since baby arrived, but it feels like an eternity ago when everything seemed manageable. 

The doctor visit this morning didn’t help at all. She barely made eye contact, her expression flat and disinterested as I tried to explain how overwhelmed and sad I feel. Her response was so clinical—like she couldn’t see beyond my diagnosis. It felt awful, almost like a punch in the gut.

I’m trying to be stronger for everyone, but sometimes it’s all too much. The house is chaotic, and there are never enough hours in the day. Sleep deprivation doesn’t just make you tired; it makes you feel lost. Everything feels foggy, even simple tasks become monumental challenges.

Went out for a walk this afternoon, hoping some fresh air would help. It did momentarily, but I’m still struggling to find my footing here. Maybe I need someone who truly understands what I'm going through, not just another appointment that leaves me feeling worse than when I walked in.

I can’t shake the feeling that something’s terribly wrong and no one seems to care enough. But maybe it's time for a different approach—finding support somewhere else where my feelings might be taken seriously instead of brushed off like they were this morning.

December 7th, 2023

I wake up to the sound of my baby crying again. It’s like a constant reminder that I’m not the person I used to be. The exhaustion feels endless, and every time I look at myself in the mirror, it's like looking at a stranger.

Today, as I held him for his afternoon feeding, something shifted inside me. A wave of sadness washed over me so intensely, I could barely breathe. It’s like I’m drowning in this fog that won’t lift. How did life become such an overwhelming blur?

I miss who I was before all this happened. Before the baby came, I had dreams and aspirations. Now they seem so far away, like a distant memory.

But something inside me is slowly stirring. Maybe it’s just a tiny spark of hope, but today, for the first time in weeks, I wanted to reach out for help. It feels scary, but maybe it's the first step towards finding myself again.

The day ends with another cry-fest from our little one and tears streaming down my face as I try to hold it together. But there’s this tiny glimmer of a plan forming in the back of my mind. Maybe tomorrow will be different.

---

Tomorrow starts a new chapter, but for now, I'm just trying to survive today.

Today marks the end of my vacation, but it feels more like the conclusion of something entirely different—something that was supposed to bring joy and new life into our world. Instead, I find myself in a dark place, struggling with a weight that seems heavier than any baby could ever be.

The days leading up to this felt surreal, like walking through fog without knowing which way to turn. Every little thing made me cry—sunsets that used to fill me with wonder now leave me feeling hollow and empty. I’ve been trying so hard to pretend everything is okay, but pretending only makes it worse. It’s like living in a dream where you can’t wake up.

I didn’t give birth to anything physical, but mentally and emotionally, it feels like I’ve just been through the hardest part of labor without any relief or celebration afterward. The world outside my bubble moves on, people talk about how wonderful vacations are supposed to be, and all I hear is a voice whispering that something went terribly wrong.

I know this isn’t normal, but how do you explain to yourself that your feelings don’t match the reality others see? It’s like having a secret no one else understands. I’m scared, but mostly—I’m just tired. Tired of fighting an invisible enemy and wondering when the battle will end.

Maybe it's time to ask for help. Maybe it's okay to admit this isn't something I can handle on my own. The thought scares me more than anything else, but maybe it’s also a sign that things can change.

Today is just another day, but tomorrow might be different if I take the first step out of the fog.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of exhaustion and tears. I’ve been stuck in the bathroom for what seems like hours, just staring at the droplets on the shower door as they merge together into little rivers. The water is cold now, but it doesn’t matter because my body isn’t registering anything beyond this emptiness.

I can hear the baby’s cries from down the hall, muffled by the thick walls and the sound of running water. It’s a reminder that I need to get out there soon, but everything in me resists. I don’t know how to be this person who just had a baby. The one they show on TV with big smiles and cozy family scenes.

The guilt is crushing. Why can’t I feel more joy? Why do my hands tremble when I hold him? It’s like he’s a stranger, even though I’ve never loved anything more than this little life I created. But it doesn’t change the fact that every time I look at him, all I see is the weight of what I can’t do.

I wish someone else could take over for a while. Just for today. To sleep and to cry without feeling like I’m failing again. Maybe tomorrow will be better. Right?

But as I turn off the water, I know there’s no escaping this moment. No escape from the reality that I have to face him. And me.

Today was one of those days where I felt like the walls were closing in on me. The sun barely shone through the clouds, and I couldn't shake this feeling that everything was just too much. Trying to keep up with caring for a newborn while my body is still recovering from childbirth feels like an impossible task.

To make matters worse, yesterday I had this awful tummy ache after eating some KFC Chicken Littles. It's not the first time something like this has happened since having the baby, but it always catches me off guard and makes me feel even more helpless. Why can’t my body just be normal for a day?

I’ve been trying so hard to stay positive, but it’s getting harder every single day. I keep thinking that tomorrow will be better, yet nothing seems to change. The fatigue, the constant worry about how everything is going, and this overwhelming sense of sadness—it's all too much.

Today, when my husband suggested we go out for a walk with the baby to get some fresh air, I found myself feeling angry. Angry at him for suggesting something that seemed impossible, angry at the baby for needing attention, and most of all, angry at myself for not being able to cope as well as I feel like I should.

I know there's help out there, but reaching out feels like admitting defeat. Maybe tomorrow will be different. For now, though, I'll just try to sleep a little longer and hope that somehow, things will get better.

Tomorrow is another day, right?

Today feels like a never-ending loop of despair. The baby cries, and I’m drained, but mostly because the weight on my chest is heavier than usual—depression has been squeezing me tight. Today marks another day in this endless cycle of darkness. The baby cries, but it's not just about the crying; it's everything else too. Feeding, changing diapers, trying to nap when they do—none of it seems real anymore. I feel like a stranger here, in my own home.

Today is another day to get through. Another day to pretend that things are okay when they aren't. The only thing that keeps me going is the thought that maybe, someday, this too shall pass. Until then, I'll keep taking one step at a time, hoping for better days ahead.

Today felt like a never-ending loop of darkness and despair. The world outside my window seems to move at a pace that I can't keep up with, while time inside these four walls stretches endlessly. Today was a blur of tears and confusion. The baby’s tiny form is nestled in the bassinet beside me, her innocence stark against this storm inside me. I want so badly to love her, but right now, it seems beyond my reach.

This isn’t who I am; this isn't what I expected motherhood would be like. Yet here I stand, lost and scared, wondering when the fog will lift. Until then, all I can do is keep breathing and hope for a tomorrow that’s brighter than today.

Today marks three weeks since my world was turned upside down by an ectopic pregnancy. The hospital stayed a blur of beeping machines and sterile smells, but now I’m home, surrounded by the quiet hum of emptiness.

I can’t shake this overwhelming feeling of loss. It’s not just about the baby I never got to meet; it’s everything that followed. Sleep is fleeting, dreams are haunted, and waking up feels like starting over again with no end in sight.

There are moments of clarity where I try to focus on breathing or counting breaths, anything to distract from this constant ache inside me. But mostly, I’m adrift, floating aimlessly through days and nights that blend into one long stretch of nothingness.

It’s hard not to blame myself for all the things that didn’t happen. If only I had listened better, eaten healthier, or whatever else fills my mind with “if onlys”. The truth is, there’s no going back now, just forward into an unknown future filled with more questions than answers.

I need help, but asking feels like admitting defeat. Yet, every day brings another reminder of what could have been. Maybe today will be different, but until then, I’ll keep holding on to hope in the dark.

Today marks a week since little Leo joined our family. The hospital walls feel like they're closing in on me. I know I need help, and yet asking for it feels so foreign. Maybe tomorrow I’ll start by reaching out to someone, anyone who can guide me through this maze of feelings. Until then, I'll keep taking one small step at a time, hoping that each little victory will bring light back into my life.

Today feels like one of those days where I’m dragging my feet and everything seems to irritate me more than usual. The guilt and shame hit hard after that, knowing there’s a line between needing support and being unreasonably harsh.

It’s not like I want to be this way—I know my feelings aren’t fair to the people who care about me. But every day feels like an uphill battle with exhaustion and anxiety winning most of the time. Maybe tomorrow will be better; maybe it won’t. All I can do is try to keep pushing forward, one moment at a time.

I wish there was something more tangible that could make this easier—something that doesn’t involve feeling stuck or overwhelmed all day long. For now, though, I just hope the days ahead bring some small measure of peace and clarity back into my life.

Today marks two weeks since my baby girl arrived, and I’m feeling a mix of emotions that are hard to sort out. It’s funny how you become hyper-aware of your surroundings after bringing a new life into the world. Everything seems amplified—like the ticking clock of an uncertain future for my baby girl. The days are filled with tiny victories like getting through a diaper change without tears, but they’re also weighed down by these overwhelming thoughts.

I’m trying to take each day as it comes and remind myself that it’s okay not to be okay. But sometimes, when I look at her tiny hands and feet, all I see is the weight of the world we live in. It’s exhausting, really. And yet, here I am, feeling grateful for every second with my little one while also being angry at how much more needs to change.

Maybe it's just a phase. Maybe it'll pass like everything else does. But today, I’m going to try and focus on the small joys—the warmth of her skin against mine, the peaceful moments after she’s asleep. I need to find my way back to the light, not just for me, but for Lily too. Maybe starting with small steps—seeing a therapist, reaching out to friends who understand—can make all the difference. I can’t afford to be lost in this haze anymore.

It’s all starting to pay off in ways I couldn’t have imagined when I first felt this overwhelming sense of despair after he was born.

But here’s what I’ve learned: it’s okay not to be okay all the time. The progress is real, but the journey isn’t linear. There will be ups and downs, and that's alright as long as there’s growth happening in between them. Today, I’m choosing to focus on how far we've come rather than how far there still might be to go.

So here I am, sitting by my son’s crib, watching him sleep peacefully. And even though a part of me feels heavy with sadness, another part is filled with hope for the better days ahead.

Today marks eight years since I missed the biggest concert of my life because of a dark cloud that hung over me after giving birth to my daughter. It's funny how time flies, and yet certain moments feel like they happened yesterday. The '1989' tour was such a pivotal moment for so many fans, but I couldn't even muster the strength to leave my bed back then.

I remember looking at pictures of the crowds on social media, feeling so small and lost in a sea of joy that seemed lightyears away from me. It wasn't just missing out on music; it was losing hope that life could ever be good again. My head spun with thoughts of why I couldn't manage something as simple as attending a concert—why my mind wouldn’t let go of the weighty shadows.

But here we are now, and my daughter is eight years old. She’s full of laughter and dreams, and her first big show was on the 'Reputation' tour. We talked about how she wished I could have been there for the '1989' concert too. That moment hit me hard—how much I wanted to be the mom who dances along with my child at every concert.

I keep thinking maybe this year, when her next favorite artist comes around town, we'll both get tickets and make up for lost time. It’s a tiny spark in an otherwise ordinary day filled with the mundane tasks of parenting. And yet, it feels hopeful, like there could be something meaningful on the other side of this fog.

I’m still learning to forgive myself for those days when everything felt impossible. But I'm trying, and that's the only thing I can hold onto right now—trying.

Today marks one week since bringing our little miracle home. The joy of being a mother should be endless and radiant, but it's been anything but that. I wake up feeling heavy in every sense—physically drained from the demands of caring for this tiny life, emotionally battered by waves of sadness and anxiety that crash over me like relentless tides.

Sometimes, when I look at her sleeping face, all my fears about being an inadequate mother wash away momentarily. Yet, just as quickly, they return with a vengeance. Why do I feel so utterly useless? Why can't I shake this constant feeling of emptiness?

Yesterday, I tried to leave the house for the first time since she was born. The sky was blue and birds were singing, but all I could focus on was how desperately tired I felt and how I just wanted everything to be easier. Maybe it's too much to handle right now.

I keep hearing people talk about 'mommy brain,' and while there are days when I feel like I'm living in a fog, today feels different. Today feels like something deeper is wrong. I know what they call it—postpartum depression—but admitting that hurts more than any of the pain from giving birth ever did.

I wish someone could take this heavy heart and give me back my old self, even for just an hour. Maybe then I wouldn't feel so lost in a world where everyone else seems to be figuring out motherhood with ease.

April 17th

The days are a blur, one blending into the next like watercolors that never dry. My mind is foggy, memories slipping through my fingers like sand in an hourglass. I can barely recall what happened just yesterday, let alone a week ago or last month. It’s as if time has sped up and left me behind.

Sleep feels like a luxury reserved for another life. The nights are endless, filled with the soft cries of my baby and the harsh reality that I’m struggling to keep it all together. My body aches from the constant care, but more than that, my heart aches because I feel lost in this new world where nothing seems familiar anymore.

I wonder if anyone else feels this way—like they’re walking through life as an outsider looking in on their own story. The weight of being responsible for another human is crushing, and yet there’s this overwhelming love that makes it all worthwhile. Or so I’m told.

The days are a whirlwind of feedings, diaper changes, and endless laundry. Yet, despite the routine, I feel adrift, unsure of where to find grounding in such chaos. Sometimes, when I hold my baby close, there's a moment of clarity—a fleeting sense that everything is okay, but it’s quickly overshadowed by the dread of forgetting another day.

I’m scared, and not just for myself but for this tiny person who relies on me so completely. But who am I now? Who will I be tomorrow?

The thought of reaching out feels like admitting defeat, but maybe there's strength in seeking help. Maybe that’s what it takes to reclaim a piece of my memory, one day at a time.

Tomorrow is another day, but for today, I’ll just breathe and hope the fog lifts soon.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my baby girl home from the hospital. It’s been a whirlwind of sleepless nights and endless diaper changes. But amidst all this chaos, there's a deep sense of loneliness that doesn't seem to fade away no matter how much I try to fill my days with activities.

The pandemic has made it impossible for me to connect with other new moms, or even my family. Everyone is so cautious about gatherings, and the thought of meeting someone in person feels like an insurmountable hurdle. It’s hard not being able to share this incredible experience with anyone who truly understands what I’m going through.

Every time I look at her tiny face, it's a mix of joy and anxiety. Joy because she's here and so beautiful, but anxiety over whether I'm doing enough for her. Is my milk enough? Am I holding her right? The constant questions loop in my head like a never-ending record scratch.

Today, while changing another diaper, the thought crossed my mind that maybe it’s okay to feel lost sometimes. It's okay if I need help and support from others. Maybe reaching out is a strength, not a weakness. But the fear of judgment and isolation holds me back, making each day feel heavier than the last.

I’m trying so hard to be the best mother possible but struggling with the overwhelming sense that everything is too much right now. The world feels bigger and scarier without the usual support networks we rely on. I just wish someone could understand how alone it feels here in this pandemic, even when you’re surrounded by love.

Today marks two weeks since little Luna joined our family, and while there’s so much joy in her presence, the exhaustion is overwhelming. I’ve been struggling with these waves of sadness that hit me out of nowhere, like a sudden cold front on an otherwise sunny day.

The other night, when everyone was sleeping, I found myself staring at my reflection in the mirror, wondering if anyone would recognize the person looking back—someone who’s not sure she can navigate this new world as well as she once thought. My husband, Jack, tries so hard to help me, but sometimes his best efforts feel like a distant whisper.

Yesterday, when I called my friend who’s also dealing with postpartum depression from her own recent birth, it felt like we shared some kind of silent understanding. She told me about the good days she has, and while those sounds great, they seem as foreign to me now as any far-off place I’ve never visited.

It’s hard not to feel guilty for not being more joyful or capable. But today, at least, I’m trying to remind myself that there’s no need for instant perfection. Luna is here, and she needs me to be the best version of me, even if it means accepting where I am right now.

Maybe tomorrow will bring a clearer sky, but for now, I’ll keep moving forward one step at a time.

Today feels like a never-ending foggy day inside my head. I can barely muster the strength to hold my baby, let alone feed him or soothe his cries. It’s been days since I’ve felt any joy in being his mother. The thought of losing myself to this dark place terrifies me more than anything else.

I keep wondering if someone will come and take him away because I’m not good enough anymore. Who am I becoming? A shadow of the woman who once dreamed of holding a tiny human in her arms. The love for my son is still there, but it’s tangled up with so much fear and sadness that sometimes it feels like a heavy anchor dragging me down.

How do I even begin to pull myself out of this hole? Each day seems harder than the last. What if I never feel better? What if he grows up without knowing what it means to be loved by his mother?

I need help, but I’m too scared to ask for it. Will anyone understand how deep this despair runs? Can they see past my smile and spot the cracks in my façade?

The silence of my empty room echoes with unanswered questions and unspoken fears. Maybe tomorrow will be different. Maybe.

But right now, all I can do is write these thoughts down and hope that somewhere out there, someone hears me calling for help.

Today marks another day in a haze of exhaustion and despair. I feel like I'm drowning under the weight of parenthood, each second stretching into an eternity of loneliness. The baby cries endlessly, and my body aches from all the sleepless nights. Every little task feels insurmountable—changing a diaper turns into a battle, feeding becomes torture.

I’ve stopped checking social media; it’s too much to handle right now. Seeing everyone else seem so happy and together just amplifies my pain. I feel like an outsider looking in on their perfect lives, while mine crumbles around me.

The doctor mentioned something about depression, but it feels more like a nightmare that never ends. Everything is overwhelming—bills, lack of support, the endless cycle of feeding, soothing, sleeping for a few hours at most. My mind keeps replaying all the things I should be doing better, and guilt eats away at my soul.

I know I need help, but reaching out feels like admitting defeat. Maybe tomorrow will be different? But honestly, right now, everything feels hopeless. The darkness is suffocating, and it’s hard to see any light beyond today.

If only someone could just take over for a while... If only the world would stop spinning so fast. I’m barely hanging on by threads that are fraying with each passing hour.

Today is another day that feels like a never-ending loop of exhaustion and despair. The baby cries, but I barely have the energy to lift my head from the pillow. My heart tells me there's so much joy in having this little one, yet my mind is clouded with darkness. It’s hard to find the motivation to even write this down.

The house is a mess, dishes pile up, and laundry seems never-ending, but all I want to do is sleep. Every time I think about getting out of bed or doing something for myself, guilt sets in. How can I be so selfish when there's a tiny life depending on me? But then the exhaustion takes over again.

I know people say things will get better and that I’m not alone, but right now, those words feel hollow. My support system is great—I have friends who call, family who offers help—but it’s tough to accept or even acknowledge their kindness. I just want to be okay on my own.

The irony isn’t lost on me: as a mother, I'm supposed to feel joy and fulfillment, but instead, I’m buried under this weight of sadness that seems heavier with each passing day. It's like being underwater, struggling for breath, yet not knowing how or when it will end.

I'll try to take things one step at a time. Maybe today is just another day in the struggle, and tomorrow could bring some light. For now, though, I’m going to close my eyes and hope for better days.

Today feels like a never-ending fog, one that hangs heavy over everything I do and try to pretend isn’t there. The baby cries for what seems like the hundredth time today, but this time it feels different. It’s not just because she needs another diaper change or wants to nurse again; it's because something inside me is screaming louder than ever before.

I look at her, this tiny bundle of joy that everyone else sees as perfect, and I can’t shake the feeling that maybe I’m doing this all wrong. Maybe I’m a terrible mother. Is it really possible to feel so much love for someone and still hate yourself?

Every time I hear another person ask how things are going or if we need anything, my heart clenches. Because what they’re really asking is “Are you happy?” And the honest answer is that I'm not. Not now. Not today. Maybe tomorrow will be better.

I keep telling myself it’s okay to rest and take care of me too, but honestly, who has time for that? There's a part of me that thinks maybe turning off my phone would make everything easier. Less pressure to smile when you feel like crying. Less guilt from pretending things are fine.

But then there’s the baby again, needing me, depending on me. And I have no idea how much longer I can keep this up without breaking into a million pieces. Maybe it's time to admit that I need help beyond just surviving each day.

Today marks my third week since giving birth to our little miracle, and while I should be basking in the joy of new parenthood, all I feel is a heavy cloud hanging over me. Every time I look at her sweet face, there’s this gnawing fear that I’m not enough. That despite everyone saying how lucky I am, something inside just isn’t right.

I keep telling myself it’s normal to feel overwhelmed and tired, but the voice in my head won’t shut up about being a failure as a mom. What if I never get out of this dark place? The thought of another day passing without feeling some semblance of happiness terrifies me more each night when she finally falls asleep.

I’ve been trying so hard to push through the fog, but it’s like fighting against an endless current. There are moments where a smile creeps onto my face just from hearing her laugh, only for that tiny glimmer of hope to be crushed by the weight of what comes next. When will I actually start feeling better? How long until this cloud lifts and lets me see clearly again?

I know reaching out sounds like such a cliché, but maybe it’s time. Maybe talking about these feelings isn’t just for others—it’s for me too. It feels scary as hell to admit any of this, let alone seek help. But what if the only way out is through? What if taking that first step could change everything?

Today I’m going to try and find a silver lining, no matter how small it might be. Because even though today felt like an uphill battle, there’s still so much love around us. And maybe, just maybe, with each tiny victory against this darkness, I’ll start seeing my way forward again.

Today marks two weeks since I brought little Emma home from the hospital. The days feel endless and suffocating, like a heavy fog hanging low over everything. Sleep is a distant memory now, replaced by constant worry and exhaustion. It’s strange how quickly my heart filled with love for this tiny life while also being consumed by fear and sadness.

I can’t shake off the shadows of my past; they whisper in my ear that I’m not enough, that I’ll fail again like last time. Those dark thoughts are relentless, and every smile she gives me feels hollow and forced. The joy others see is just a mask for the pain beneath.

Having two children was always meant to be our family’s limit after what happened with Ben. But now, seeing Emma so vulnerable and in need of constant care, I wonder if we made the right choice. Or maybe it’s that I wasn’t ready to face this again. The thought of another baby is terrifying, especially knowing how deep the depression can dig.

I’m reaching out for help, trying to hold on to hope that tomorrow might be better. But today feels like a never-ending nightmare, and I am utterly lost in its grip.

Today feels like one of those days where the weight of the world is just a little too heavy to bear. My daughter’s laughter should be my joy, but it’s mixed with this deep ache inside me that I can’t shake. The exhaustion is relentless—like being run over by a truck and then having to lift it back up all by myself. 

I keep telling myself I’m doing the best I can, but why does everything feel so wrong? Why do my arms hurt from holding her too much and not enough at the same time? There’s this voice inside that whispers, “You’re failing,” even though I know that’s not true.

But what is true is that I want to be a better parent. I really do. Every day, I try to put on this brave face for my daughter, but inside, it feels like I’m falling apart piece by piece. How can I make sure she grows up happy when all I feel is sadness and fear?

I know I need help, but talking about it just makes the whole thing even heavier. Maybe tomorrow will be better—I hope so because I have to believe that every day is a new chance. For her sake, at least.

Today marks my return to work after just six weeks of maternity leave. I feel like a stranger in my own skin as I walk into the office, holding back tears that threaten to spill at any moment. The baby is still so tiny and vulnerable, but here I am, stepping back into a world where my role isn't defined by nurturing a new life but rather by deadlines and meetings.

The joy of becoming a mother was overshadowed by waves of depression during pregnancy and now it seems like this newfound happiness has been snatched away again. How can anyone expect me to balance work and being there for my child when all I want is to curl up in bed with her?

I tried to keep things light today, but every task feels heavy. My colleagues mean well, but their smiles and offers of help feel like a slap in the face. They don't understand this void inside me, this sense of inadequacy and failure.

Is it okay to want more time? To feel lost and unsure? I'm scared that if I open up about how I’m really feeling, no one will take me seriously or offer any real help. Yet, deep down, I know I need support, not just for my sake but for the baby's too.

I wish there was a way to catch my breath, to find some semblance of balance in this chaos. For now, all I can do is hope that tomorrow will be better, and maybe, just maybe, someone will notice the signs of struggle behind my forced smiles.

Today marks another milestone in my journey back to myself after becoming a mom. The days blur together sometimes, but I’m starting to see patterns and changes that give me hope. My medication is like the sun breaking through the clouds; it’s there when I need it most, lifting the heavy veil of sadness that used to suffocate me daily.

The real magic happens when I lace up my sneakers and head out for a walk or a jog. It’s not just about moving my body—it’s about reconnecting with myself outside the confines of home and parenthood. When I’m on the move, it feels like an escape from the constant demands of being a new mom. The fresh air and the rhythm of my footsteps help me clear my mind and find peace.

Combining medication with exercise has been a game-changer for me. They work in tandem to keep the dark thoughts at bay. On days when I feel particularly low, even just stretching or taking a short walk makes a difference. It’s like pressing reset on my mood. Plus, it gives me energy to be more present with my baby and enjoy these early weeks together.

I’m still figuring out this new normal, but each day feels a bit easier than the last. There’s comfort in knowing I have tools at hand to manage the ups and downs of postpartum depression. Here’s to many more steps forward!

January 15, 2023

Today marks two weeks since little Emma joined our family. It's a strange mix of emotions—joy, fatigue, and a bit of confusion. The hospital was surreal; everything felt like a dream as I held my newborn daughter for the first time. Now that we're home, life is quieter but just as overwhelming.

Sleepless nights are a new reality. Each morning feels like starting from scratch, yet there’s this undeniable sense of purpose and love that keeps me going. Emma's tiny gestures—her yawns, her kicks when she wants to be held—are small miracles I never tire of witnessing.

I've read about postpartum depression, how common it is, and how important it is to talk openly about it. Knowing it exists helps a little, but right now, the reality feels more like adjusting to this new normal rather than battling any demons. My husband has been incredibly supportive, reminding me that we’re in this together.

I’m trying to savor these early moments without overthinking every detail. It’s hard not to question everything when you're responsible for a baby's well-being, but I’m learning to trust my instincts and the knowledge I’ve gained from books and classes.

For now, each day is a step forward. I'm grateful for this new chapter, despite its challenges.

Today marks three weeks since I welcomed my little miracle into the world. The early mornings and sleepless nights are starting to blur together, but I know it's just a phase. Or is it? Lately, I've been feeling this heavy fog hovering over me when I should be basking in joy and gratitude. Am I being too hard on myself for not feeling ecstatic 24/7?

Yesterday, my mom suggested that maybe I'm experiencing some delayed onset postpartum depression, but the idea feels so foreign. The days are a whirlwind of feedings, diaper changes, and endless cuddles—how could there be room for anything else? Yet here I am, questioning everything from my abilities as a new parent to whether I’m capable of truly cherishing this precious moment.

I've been trying to distinguish between typical stress post-birth and something more serious. Is it normal to feel overwhelmed by the lack of sleep and constant responsibility? Or is there an underlying sadness that’s just waiting for me to admit it's real?

It feels like a delicate balance—trying not to let my worries consume me, but also recognizing when I might need support beyond what I can provide myself. Maybe talking to someone or reaching out to friends who’ve been through this could help clear the fog and bring back that initial sparkle of wonder.

For now, I'll keep moving forward one day at a time, hoping the sunshine will eventually break through the clouds again.

Today feels like one of those days where everything is just too much. I wake up and the weight of being a new mom hits me hard. The room spins with all the thoughts swirling in my head—what if I’m not good enough? What if I can’t handle this?

The baby is sleeping peacefully, but there’s an eerie silence around me. It’s just me and these walls, day after endless day. No one to talk to, no shoulder to lean on. Everyone says it’s normal to feel overwhelmed, but they don’t get how alone I really am.

I keep trying to convince myself that this will pass, that tomorrow might be better. But the anxiety creeps in like a shadow, casting everything into doubt and fear. Simple tasks become mountains; even breathing feels like a chore sometimes.

It’s so quiet here, too quiet. My mind races with all the “what ifs,” and I just want to scream or cry or run away. Instead, I sit here, staring at the walls, wondering when this will end. When can I stop feeling like I’m drowning in my own thoughts?

I miss being connected to people, to life outside these four walls. It feels like there’s no one who truly understands what I’m going through, and that makes everything seem so much harder. Maybe it’s time to reach out for help, but the idea of telling anyone how I feel terrifies me.

For now, I’ll just take a deep breath and hope for a better tomorrow. But honestly? It feels like this is all there ever will be—a never-ending cycle of worry and isolation.

August 14, 2020

Today marks the end of another week in what feels like an endless summer. It’s been a whirlwind since the baby arrived—sleepless nights, tears, and a constant haze of exhaustion. The thought of getting out of bed each morning seems monumental. I’ve been trying to follow all these guidelines for postpartum care: eat nutritious meals, exercise gently, connect with friends, talk to my therapist. But every time I think about adding another thing to my list, it feels like a brick wall is coming down on me.

I keep thinking, "If only there was some magical way to feel better instantly." Maybe that’s not realistic, but sometimes the idea of being stuck in this fog seems never-ending. My therapist says routines are important, and she’s right. But today, all I want is to curl up with a good book instead of forcing myself into yet another activity.

Maybe it’s okay to take things day by day rather than setting strict goals for myself. It’s been so hard not knowing what the future holds or when this cloud will lift. Sometimes, even the simplest tasks feel like climbing Mount Everest. But I’m trying to remind myself that small steps count too.

It’s a relief to know there are others going through similar struggles, and it helps to reach out for support. Today, instead of forcing myself into another rigid routine, maybe rest is exactly what my body needs. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, I’ll take comfort in knowing I’m not alone.

---

Sometimes, it feels like the weight of the world is pressing down on me. Other days, there’s a glimmer of hope that things might get easier soon. Right now, all I know for sure is that every day brings new challenges and new opportunities to learn and grow. Even if today isn’t my best day, it’s okay to be kind to myself.

August 15, 2020

Today was better than yesterday. Maybe because the sun actually came out, or perhaps I slept a little longer last night. Either way, taking things one moment at a time seems more manageable now.

Today marks one month since my surgery, and the physical recovery feels like a distant memory now. I thought the hardest part would be the initial days of healing, but here I am, still grappling with an unexpected wave of anxiety and depression that creeps up on me at all hours.

I keep replaying everything in my head, wondering if there was something more I could have done or said before making the decision. The weight of it all feels crushing, like a dark cloud hanging over every waking moment. Sleep has become elusive; even when exhaustion pulls me into slumber, nightmares follow me back to consciousness.

The days blend together in this haze of despair. Simple tasks feel monumental and daunting. I catch myself staring out windows for hours on end, trying desperately to distract my mind from the whirlwind of emotions swirling inside. It’s exhausting, this constant battle within, and yet, there are moments when I feel a glimmer of hope. Maybe tomorrow will be better?

But then reality sets in again, and here I am, wondering how long it’ll take for these shadows to lift. I know I need help, but reaching out feels like admitting defeat. Yet, the thought of continuing on this path alone terrifies me even more.

Tomorrow is a new day, they say. But until then, all I can do is try and hold onto that fragile thread of hope while navigating through the stormy seas of my mind.

Today is day 45 since I gave birth to my little miracle, and yet every moment feels like a struggle. The nights are the worst; they stretch on endlessly, each hour tick-tocking like an eternity. There's this heavy fog in my mind that won't lift. It’s as if everything is moving at half-speed while my heart races uncontrollably.

I've been trying so hard to love this tiny life I created, but there are moments when all I feel is emptiness and fear. Is it okay to have these thoughts? The constant worry about whether I’m a good enough mother eats away at me. The doctors keep telling me it’s just postpartum blues, but deep down, I know something else is brewing.

I've always struggled with my emotions—ups and downs like a roller coaster ride without any brakes. When I was younger, the world felt too big and scary to face alone. So, I turned to food as both a comfort and an escape. Now, it feels like that cycle has returned, but even more daunting.

Living here in this small town makes things so much harder. There’s no one who truly understands what I’m going through. The thought of reaching out for help terrifies me because the stigma is suffocating. People around me only see a new mom with a baby; they don’t see the chaos inside my head.

But today, I made a small step forward. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, all I can do is try to breathe and keep going one day at a time. Maybe writing this down helps somehow...

Today feels like one of those days where everything is a struggle and nothing seems to go right. I woke up to yet another sleepless night, my mind racing with thoughts that won't leave me alone. The exhaustion is overwhelming, but the fatigue pales in comparison to the heaviness in my heart.

People talk about postpartum as if it's just a phase of hormonal imbalance and mood swings, but they miss the deep emotional pain that comes with it. I've had this before—more than once—and every time it feels like falling into an abyss without any hope of climbing back out. The frustration builds when people brush off my struggles as something trivial or temporary.

Right now, all I can do is focus on small moments of clarity and peace, but even those feel fleeting. It's hard to see past the fog that blankets everything in a haze of sadness and fear. I know I need help, but seeking it out feels like another mountain to climb when I'm already at ground zero.

The baby sleeps peacefully beside me, unaware of the storm brewing inside my mind. Part of me wishes they could understand what's going on, because I feel so alone in this struggle. But then again, how can anyone truly comprehend the depths of postpartum depression unless they've walked this path themselves?

I'm trying to be gentle with myself today, reminding myself that it's okay not to be okay. Every step forward feels monumental, even if it's just reaching out for a hand to hold through this darkness. Maybe tomorrow will bring a little more light, but for now, I'll take solace in the smallest victories and hope that they add up to something bigger.

Today feels like one of those days where everything is too much and nothing is enough. The baby cries, and my heart aches with each sob. It's been two weeks since she was born, yet I feel as if the weight of motherhood has only just begun to crush me. Sleepless nights blend into long, blurry days. My body feels like it’s recovering from a marathon, but there’s no finish line in sight.

I keep telling myself that this is normal, that everyone feels overwhelmed after having a baby. But deep down, I know something isn’t right. It's not just the fatigue or the hormonal changes—it's the crushing sense of inadequacy and despair. I try to smile when friends call with well-meaning advice, but their words swirl around me like static noise.

I want so badly to love my baby, to be a good mother. But instead of joy, there’s this relentless fog that drapes over everything. Little moments of clarity—like the time she nuzzled against my chest and I felt a flicker of warmth—seem fleeting and rare, like stars glimpsed through storm clouds.

Tonight, as I rock her to sleep, I make another promise to myself: to reach out for help. It’s not selfish; it’s necessary. For me, for us. Maybe tomorrow will be different. Or maybe it won’t. But trying feels better than being stuck here, alone with my thoughts and fears.

I hope there are people who understand what I’m going through. That they can offer a hand up when everything in me wants to give in.

Today feels like one of those days where the world outside my window is bright and full of life, but inside me, there's only a hollow emptiness. I’ve been trying so hard to put on this mask of happiness for everyone else—to be the mother they expect me to be. But today, as I watch my baby sleeping in her crib, it feels like an impossible task.

The days blend together now, each one starting with an internal struggle: how much can I really show? Should I tell anyone what’s going on inside my head? Is anyone even paying attention or are they just as busy pretending everything is fine?

Having kids around complicates things. Their joy and innocence are a reminder of the life I’m supposed to be living, but every time I try to join in their laughter, it feels like an act. And yet, when they look at me with those big eyes full of love and expectation, how can I let them down?

I’ve been trying to reach out more—to talk to friends or seek help—but the thought of opening up about what’s really going on inside makes my chest tighten. It’s scary to admit you’re struggling, especially when everyone expects motherhood to be nothing but bliss.

Today was tough—I cried in the shower, pretending it was just steam from the hot water—and then I forced a smile for dinner. My husband asked if everything was okay, and all I could do was nod because explaining my feelings seems like too much of an effort right now.

I’m scared that admitting how I feel will make me seem weak or incapable. But deep down, I know I need help. Maybe tomorrow is the day I’ll take a step towards getting it—towards being honest with myself and others. For now, though, I’ll just try to hold on until then.

Day 3 Postpartum

Today started with a sense of confusion and apprehension. The baby is here, but I feel so far away from everything. I've been researching postpartum depression after reading about it online, trying to understand if what I'm feeling is normal or something more serious. I’ve read that men can experience this too, which surprised me because I always thought of it as a condition affecting only women.

There are moments when I feel completely overwhelmed and unsure if I’m capable of taking care of my newborn properly. Yet, there’s also an overwhelming love for the baby that makes everything seem worth it. The sleepless nights are testing my limits, but then, every time I look at him or her, a warmth spreads through me.

I know self-diagnosing isn’t wise, so instead of dwelling on whether I have PPD, I’m trying to focus on taking care of myself. Eating better, talking more with friends and family about how I feel, and giving myself permission to rest when I need it. It’s a delicate balance, but I believe in my ability to get through this.

I’ll keep an eye out for any changes or worsening symptoms, but for now, I’m choosing to stay positive and hopeful. This journey is new and challenging, but I trust that with time, patience, and support, things will start feeling more normal again.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world. The initial joy and wonder have faded into a haze of exhaustion and confusion. Every time I look at her tiny face, I feel this overwhelming love mixed with an inexplicable sadness. It's like there’s this dark cloud hanging over me that won’t go away.

Sleep is a luxury now, snatched in fragmented moments between feedings and diaper changes. My body feels like it’s still recovering from the marathon of childbirth. But it’s not just physical pain—I’m plagued by an emptiness that nothing seems to fill. I try to be happy for her sake, but there are days when I feel like a stranger looking at my own life.

I keep telling myself things will get better, that this is all normal, and everyone goes through it. But what if they’re wrong? What if I’m just broken and won’t ever feel the way I should?

The loneliness is suffocating. Even with family around, I feel so isolated. It’s like no one understands or sees how hard every single moment feels. Am I the only one who thinks this isn’t right? 

I know I need help, but reaching out feels too daunting. Maybe it's a sign of weakness to admit this is more than I can handle alone.

But I also know that holding onto these feelings won't make them disappear or fix anything. So here I am, writing about the storm raging inside me because sometimes putting words down on paper helps make sense of things.

I miss my old self and worry she’s gone forever. But I hope—desperately—that there’s a way back to happiness and peace. Maybe tomorrow will be better? Or maybe today can get a little bit easier?

For now, all I have is the moment. And in this moment, I’m just trying to find my footing again.

Today marks another week since I decided to stop seeing the therapist. It's been a rollercoaster of emotions, but mostly just exhaustion. Last night was particularly rough—I had this nagging feeling that something wasn't right with all these meds they were giving me. Like maybe they didn’t understand what I needed at all.

I know there’s supposed to be support and understanding in the postpartum period, but it feels more like a never-ending struggle. When I mentioned dropping out of therapy, my doctor reacted as if I’d committed some kind of crime against health care. It was so bizarre and uncomfortable—I felt like they were going to report me or something.

I can't pinpoint exactly when things went sideways, but from the moment they slapped that label on me without any real understanding, everything felt off. The treatment wasn’t helping, and I kept telling them this, but no one seemed to listen. It’s frustrating, because part of me knows I’m supposed to be getting better care.

The irony is that I know my risk for depression is high; they even flagged it in the screening. But now I feel like a failure for not sticking with something that didn’t work for me. The stress and confusion are overwhelming, and on top of everything else, there's this constant worry about retaliation or being ostracized.

I just want to figure out what’s best for me and my baby without all the judgment and pressure. It feels like a never-ending battle, but today I’m trying to focus on taking small steps instead of big leaps into uncertainty.

Today marks a week since little one’s arrival into our world. It feels like an eternity ago that we were counting kicks and dreaming of the future. Now I’m navigating this strange new land of sleepless nights and endless feedings.

The tears have been flowing more than usual, but they’re not just about exhaustion or hormones. There’s a deep sadness that sometimes creeps in when I look at her tiny face and wonder if I’m good enough to be her mother. It’s a constant battle with my mind, trying to reassure myself that everything is okay.

But you know what helps? You, my love. Your unwavering support means the world to me. The way you hold our baby when she cries, or how you insist on doing dishes so I can nap—I don’t think you realize just how much that matters. It’s not just about practical help; it’s the emotional strength you give me.

I’ve decided I want to offer advice and support to my friends who are expecting or new parents too. Maybe sharing our journey will help someone else feel less alone. After all, we’re all in this together, right?

Today was tough, but it also felt like a turning point. I’m starting to see that these moments of darkness are just part of the incredible experience of becoming a parent.

Love and gratitude,
Me

Today feels like one of those days where the weight of everything just sits on my chest and won’t budge. I know I shouldn’t feel this way, but sometimes, when it gets really bad, dark thoughts creep in. Thoughts that aren't healthy or helpful. But they’re there, like a shadow at my back, whispering things I don't want to hear.
