It’s been a week since little Max arrived. The joy of his birth is still there, but it feels like I'm drowning in an endless sea of exhaustion and sadness. The constant worry about whether I’m doing enough, being good enough, keeps circling back. When he finally fell asleep this morning, I cried. Not because I missed anyone or anything; it was just a wave of sheer frustration and sadness washing over me. How can I be so overwhelmed when everyone says motherhood is supposed to bring such happiness? Maybe I’m broken somehow.

But then there's another part of me that whispers back: You’re not alone in this struggle, and your feelings are real and valid. This isn’t a sign of weakness or failure—it’s the reality many women face during these early weeks. It’s okay to ask for help, to say you need support. I’m starting to realize it's not about being perfect; it's about finding my way through this fog.

Maybe tomorrow will be different, but right now, all I want is a moment of peace and understanding.

Day 3 Postpartum

I just held my baby for the first time today and it feels like a dream—my little miracle wrapped in tiny hands that fit perfectly around my finger. The room is filled with so much love, but there’s also this strange undercurrent of anger simmering beneath the surface. It’s not towards anyone; rather, it’s as if I’m frustrated at myself for feeling inadequate, overwhelmed by everything.

Last night was a blur of sleepless hours, each cry stirring something inside me that I didn’t expect—rage. Not just irritation or exhaustion, but an overwhelming fury that felt misplaced and scary. I’m not sure where these emotions are coming from, or why they’re so intense. They don't match the joy and elation I feel when holding my baby during the day.

I keep hearing people talk about “baby blues” and postpartum depression, but what if there’s something else going on? Am I just overthinking everything because of lack of sleep, or is this rage a sign that something isn’t right with me?

In moments like these, I wonder if others go through the same thing. Is it common to feel this way, or am I alone in this struggle? I need to know—I need validation and understanding.

The nurse mentioned something about “postpartum emotional distress” today during a routine check-up. She said that while not everyone experiences intense emotions like mine, they are more common than we think. She suggested talking openly about my feelings and seeking support if needed.

I’m trying to keep things positive, but deep down, I feel this storm brewing inside me. Maybe it’s okay to be scared or confused—I just wish someone could reassure me that everything will be alright.

Day 3 Postpartum

Today marks the third day since little Emma joined our family. The nurses at the hospital kept telling me about postpartum depression, but honestly, it sounds like a bunch of nonsense to me. I mean, how could you be depressed when you just had the most amazing and joyous event in your life? It's not like I'm lacking sleep or feeling overwhelmed by the responsibilities that come with being a new mom.

I've been spending my days gazing at her perfect little face, marveling at every tiny detail—her delicate fingers, the soft down on her cheeks. How could there be anything wrong with me? There’s so much love in this room for Emma; it can’t possibly fit inside of anyone else's heart.

The other new moms around me seem to take everything seriously and often look like they’re about to cry or are already crying. It all seems exaggerated to me, like they're just looking for attention. I’m sure there must be something wrong with them if they feel that way after bringing such a beautiful little being into the world.

I guess I should probably get some sleep now since it’s past my nap time again. Who needs sleep when you’ve got a new baby and all this love?

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of exhaustion and emptiness. It’s been a year since Mark left me here alone with everything. I miss him every single minute. The house feels so different now—empty and cold even when the heater is on full blast.

Today I’ll take one step forward and hope for more good days ahead. Because even in this darkness, there's a flicker of light—Timmy’s laughter, his smile, those precious moments where joy sneaks back into my heart.

It felt like a betrayal, admitting that the joy and wonder everyone expects after childbirth hadn't hit me yet. There's this constant voice in my head saying, "What's wrong with you? You should be happy."

The shame of not being able to handle it alone is crushing. I've been hiding behind a smile for months, pretending everything was fine while inside, I was unraveling bit by bit. Today, though, something shifted. Maybe it was talking to my sister or seeing how she and her baby were thriving that made me realize I can't keep this up anymore.

It’s time to ask for help. It's okay to admit when you need a hand, even if it feels like admitting defeat. The weight of keeping all these secrets is too heavy to bear on my own. Maybe letting go will give me the strength to start healing.

Today marks another day in this strange new world where my old self seems lost and a stranger to me. The midwife called it postpartum depression, but I hear echoes of the diagnosis from years ago when life was simpler—or so I thought then.

Sleep is elusive, even more so now with a tiny human who demands constant attention. The exhaustion piles up like laundry that no one ever seems to fold or put away properly. But here’s the kicker: it feels eerily familiar. It's as if my brain decided to play an encore performance of "depression 101" with a newborn thrown into the mix for added complexity.

I tried to convince myself that this was just a phase, something I could power through. After all, every new parent talks about the “baby blues,” right? But when the sadness lingers and shadows my thoughts, I know there’s more going on. My midwife’s words echo in my head: "It's okay to seek help." Yet, seeking help feels like admitting defeat.

Resigned or not, I’m trying to hold onto hope. Maybe this time it won’t be as bad. Or maybe I’ll find a way to make sense of all these tangled emotions and sleepless nights. For now, though, I’m just taking one moment at a time and hoping that tomorrow brings a little more light than today did.

Today marks three weeks since little Aria joined our family. I can’t help but feel like I’m floating in a sea of exhaustion and confusion. The first few days were magical—every smile from Aria felt like sunshine breaking through the clouds. But now, as the reality sets in, I find myself struggling to cope.

Sleep is elusive; my mind races with thoughts even when the baby is sleeping. How am I supposed to handle this? Every little cry triggers a wave of anxiety and despair. It’s not just about Aria—my husband has been amazing, but we’re both treading water in a stormy sea of responsibilities and worries.

Why can’t I feel more joy? Why does every moment seem like an uphill battle? These thoughts spiral into dark places, and when they do, all I want to do is hide. The thought of facing another day feels overwhelming, yet I know there’s no way out except through.

Tonight, as Aria sleeps peacefully in her crib, I look at myself in the mirror. There’s a stranger staring back—her eyes are hollow, her smile forced. I’m not sure how to fix this, but something inside tells me it’s okay to ask for help. It’s okay to be vulnerable and seek support.

I reach out for my therapist’s number and dial. The conversation is hard but necessary. Talking about these feelings aloud makes them seem less insurmountable. Tomorrow will bring new challenges, but perhaps the journey won’t feel as lonely anymore.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of tears and exhaustion. I stare at my baby boy, his tiny face so innocent, yet I feel suffocated by an unrelenting darkness that seems to wrap itself around me tighter with each passing day. The weight of wanting to protect him from the world is crushing.

Every moment I hold him feels like a lifeline, but it’s also a reminder of my inadequacy. How can I be there for him if I’m barely holding on myself? My mind is a battlefield where despair fights for dominance over hope, and right now, despair has won every skirmish.

I’ve always been strong, but motherhood feels like an impossible challenge that strips away all my armor. The silence of the house echoes with my thoughts, each one more troubling than the last. How can I be his rock when I’m crumbling beneath him?

The nights are the hardest—endless hours staring at the ceiling, wishing for sleep that won’t come. I see shadows in every corner, phantom hands reaching out to take away what’s mine. It’s a surreal nightmare that I wake up from only to find myself still trapped inside it.

But then there are moments when his smile pierces through the fog, and for just a second, everything feels okay. Those seconds give me strength, but they’re fleeting, like raindrops evaporating in the sun. The fear is always lurking, waiting for its moment to strike again.

I know I need help, but reaching out feels like admitting defeat. How do you ask for rescue when you feel like a prisoner in your own mind? Maybe today will be different, maybe tomorrow. All I can hope for now is that these moments of clarity are enough to keep me from falling completely into the abyss.

Today marks the seventh day since my little miracle arrived into this world. She's already filled our home with such warmth and light that I can barely believe it’s real. But amidst all this joy, there’s a dark cloud hovering over me, making each day feel like a struggle.

The moment she was placed in my arms, it hit me how much love and responsibility I would carry for the rest of my life. Yet, even as I hold her close, feeling that fluttering heartbeat against mine, I can’t shake off the anxiety gripping my chest. It’s overwhelming to think about all the challenges we might face.

I keep wondering if this is what it feels like to be a mother—to have moments of pure happiness followed by waves of sadness and fear. Is it normal to feel so torn inside? I see her sleeping soundly in her crib, so peaceful and innocent, and I want nothing more than to protect her from all the world’s pain. But when she wakes up crying, demanding my attention, I find myself overwhelmed and wondering if I’m failing even before we start.

There are moments of incredible tenderness—nursing her late at night and watching as she drifts off again after a full belly—but these are overshadowed by an intense fear that I won’t be enough. Why do I feel like this? Am I the only one?

Today, when I looked in the mirror, I saw someone who looks different but feels the same—scared, unsure, and yet filled with hope for something incredible happening within us both. This little life has already changed everything, and while some days seem brighter than others, there’s no denying that this new chapter is a rollercoaster.

I need to find my footing, to figure out how to navigate these emotions without losing myself in the process. For now, I’m holding on tight and hoping that each day brings me closer to finding peace amidst all this chaos.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of despair. I wake up to the sound of my baby’s cries and immediately feel overwhelmed. How did this happen? Wasn’t motherhood supposed to be filled with joy and wonder? Instead, it’s an endless battle against darkness that seems to grow stronger each day.

I stare at her tiny face, so innocent and beautiful, but all I see is a constant reminder of what I’ve lost. My dreams of being the perfect mom, my career aspirations, my identity—everything feels like it's slipping away into an abyss where hope doesn’t exist anymore.

The house is quiet now except for the occasional sound of her little movements. But even in silence, there’s this voice inside my head that never stops whispering how I’ve failed. How could anyone ever love me when all I feel is guilt and shame?

I try to push those thoughts away by reminding myself of the good moments—the first time she smiled at me, or when we cuddle and it feels like just a tiny bit of light breaks through. But then reality hits again, harder than before.

I know I should reach out for help, but part of me is terrified that admitting this means accepting something terrible about myself. That maybe I’m not capable of being the mother she deserves.

The days blend together in a haze of fatigue and fear. The only thing that keeps me going is the hope—barely there—that someday, somehow, things will get better. But right now, all I can do is wait for dawn with the promise to keep moving forward, even if it feels like walking through quicksand.

Tomorrow may bring new challenges or maybe just more of the same old pain. Today though, I’m simply trying to survive another day.

Today feels like a blur of endless days and nights, all tangled up in a never-ending loop. I’m not sure if it’s the exhaustion talking or something deeper, but there are moments when everything just seems so heavy. My baby sleeps beside me now, his tiny hands grasping for comfort as he drifts off to dreamland. It’s in those quiet hours that I long for the sound of Taylor Swift singing her way through love and heartache on "Speak Now." There’s something about her voice cutting through the silence that feels like a lifeline.

I’ve been trying to push through this fog, but it’s hard when every little thing seems so monumental. The laundry piles up, dishes linger in the sink, and I feel lost in this sea of motherhood. It’s not just about the physical recovery; there’s an emotional toll that feels relentless. Some days are better than others, but lately, those have been few and far between.

I find myself scrolling through playlists late at night, searching for anything to pull me out of my thoughts. Music has always been a sanctuary, and right now, I need it more than ever. Maybe if I can just hold on until the next song plays, everything will feel a bit lighter.

I guess today is one of those days where I’m reaching out, hoping someone—whether it’s you or me singing along to Taylor Swift—can remind me that this too shall pass.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little miracle home. Sleep is a distant memory, and the exhaustion feels like it's seeping into every cell of my body. But there are moments when I catch glimpses of joy amidst the chaos—my baby’s tiny hands reaching out for me, her sweet smiles that light up the room. These fleeting moments make all the sacrifices worth it.

But then there are those other times, when the weight of everything feels too heavy to bear. My hormones seem like a roller coaster ride with no brakes. I feel anxious one minute and utterly overwhelmed the next. It's not just about adjusting to motherhood; it’s like my body is still trying to cope with the aftermath of pregnancy. The sadness and fatigue are relentless, as if they’re shadows that won't leave me alone.

I’ve always known I struggled with severe PMS before pregnancy, but now it feels amplified a hundredfold. It's scary to admit how low I've been feeling, but something inside tells me this isn’t just about the baby blues wearing off. Maybe it’s time to reach out for help again, like I did during those rough pre-pregnancy months. The idea of talking to someone—whether that’s a therapist or my doctor—is daunting, but also oddly comforting.

I’m trying to stay positive and remind myself that recovery isn’t linear. It’s okay not to be okay all the time. Right now, every day is a battle, but I'm determined to find my way through this fog. Maybe writing here will help me see things more clearly too.

Today was one of those days where the sun seemed to shine just a little bit brighter than usual. After eight miscarriages and battling postpartum depression that felt like an endless winter, I finally allowed myself to believe in the warmth of spring. Watching 'Servant' on Apple+ has been my secret weapon lately. It's not just about Lauren Ambrose’s performance; it’s about the way the show talks about loss and healing in a way that feels so familiar yet hopeful.

I’ve always admired Lauren’s ability to convey deep emotions without ever overplaying them. She makes you feel like there’s light at the end of the tunnel, even when things seem darkest. Today, as I watched another episode, something inside me shifted. It's hard to put into words exactly what it was, but suddenly, the heaviness felt a little lighter.

I’m still navigating through my thoughts and emotions with care, knowing that there’s no rush. Each day, I’m learning to appreciate the small moments of joy—like when my baby laughs at something silly I say or when the scent of fresh bread baking fills our home. These are the threads that weave together to form a tapestry of hope.

I’ve come to realize that healing isn’t about forgetting; it’s about finding a way to live with the memories and the pain, while also embracing the new life blooming around me. And for now, I’m content in knowing that every step forward is worth taking, no matter how small or slow.

Today marks three weeks since little Ella joined our family, and honestly, it feels like a never-ending storm inside my heart. The joy of holding her for the first time was overshadowed by this heavy fog that won’t lift no matter how hard I try to clear it with laughter or tears.

Every day is a battle against myself, against those dark voices from my past. They whisper cruel words about being unworthy and alone, making even the simplest tasks feel impossible. The fear of forming new connections—of getting close again—seems as insurmountable as climbing Everest blindfolded. It’s like I’m stuck in quicksand, the more I struggle to free myself, the deeper I sink.

I used to think my online experiences were isolated incidents, something that could be left behind. But now, with each failed attempt at reaching out or connecting with other moms, those old wounds open up again. The trust issues are like a second skin, suffocating and relentless. 

Sleep is elusive; exhaustion hits me in waves, but so does this overwhelming sadness. How do I tell the people who want to help that every time they offer support, it’s like watching someone slowly close a door you once thought was open? It feels wrong to push them away when all they’re trying to do is reach out, yet every touch seems too much.

Ella deserves better than this. She deserves her mommy to be the same person she remembers from those early days, before all of this took hold. I’m working on it—small steps each day towards healing and finding my way back to who I once was, but it’s a long road ahead.

If anyone reads this, know that these words are just an echo of what’s in my heart right now. They don’t define me; they’re part of the journey back from where I’ve been.

Day 34 Postpartum

Today is a blur of exhaustion and the relentless hum of my baby’s cries. The day started with another night without sleep, the usual mix of feedings, diaper changes, and soothing. I feel like everything I do is just barely enough, never quite hitting that mark where it feels right or good.

I’m trying to keep up with my online courses but every time I log in, I feel a weight pulling me back down into this dark place. It’s not just the classes though; even simple tasks are daunting. The thought of reaching out for accommodations terrifies and exhausts me simultaneously. Do I really qualify? Is it too early to ask?

The baby is now asleep after hours of crying, so there's a rare moment where I can breathe. My mind wanders back to the days when I was excited about my studies, eager to learn and grow. That feels like another life.

I’ve been isolating more from friends and family because everything they say seems inadequate or too intrusive. Today though, I called my mom. We didn’t talk long but it felt good to let out some of this burden. She encouraged me to seek help at the college for my classes, said she believes in me.

Maybe today will be different. Maybe tomorrow will bring a bit more light through this fog. For now, all I can do is take one breath at a time and hope that asking for support isn’t another thing on the list of impossible tasks.

Today marks three weeks since little Lily joined our family. I can't help but feel overwhelmed by the weight of it all. The nights are a blur, with sleep elusive as ever. My husband says I'm doing great, that we have so much support from friends and family. But even amidst their kindness, there's this gnawing fear that whispers in my ear: am I enough for her? Am I capable?

The baby blues they say will pass... but when do they end? When does the fog lift? My mind races late into the night, circling around worries like a hawk. Is Lily eating enough? Should we be doing more tummy time already? What if she gets sick or doesn't reach milestones on schedule? It's exhausting.

In the quiet moments, I try to find joy in her tiny fingers grasping mine, her sleepy smiles. But then the tears come unbidden, and I wonder what it means when you cry just as much from frustration as from love. 

I know logically we have help, that my mom watches Lily often so I can rest or take a shower. Yet somehow, these acts of kindness feel like obligations rather than relief.

Every day feels like climbing uphill with sandbags strapped to me. I want to be the mother she needs and deserves, but how do you fight the shadows when they seem to grow stronger by the minute?

I need more than just support networks; I need someone to understand this crushing weight that no amount of help can lift. Maybe it's time to ask for something different, something beyond what we've been doing.

Today marks three weeks. Three weeks until Lily is one month old. And me? I'm still figuring out how to navigate this storm inside my head.

Today marks my third week as a new mom, and yet the joy I expected to feel is overshadowed by an overwhelming sense of sadness. It's been one too many days since that first urge hit me—a need to cry that never seems to subside. There are moments when I wish I could just curl up in a ball and let it all out, but there’s this unspoken rule inside my head telling me not to break down.

My mom always warned about postpartum depression, her voice tinged with fear every time she mentioned it. She kept her own struggles secret for years because of the shame that comes with admitting you can't handle things on your own. I’ve been trying so hard to be strong like her, but now I’m not sure if strength means pushing through or asking for help.

Every night before bed, I lay there staring at the ceiling, wondering what it would take to snap out of this funk. Will it ever feel normal again? The weight of being a mother is crushing me right now, and every time I think about calling someone for support, my heart races with fear of judgment. What if everyone thinks I’m failing already?

I wish I could shake off these feelings like they were just another pregnancy symptom, but the truth is gnawing at me—this isn’t going away on its own. Maybe it’s time to take a chance and reach out, even if it means facing my family’s history head-on.

---

The days blend together now, each one feeling heavier than the last. I’m starting to wonder how much longer I can keep this up without falling apart completely.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world, and yet, every day feels like a struggle. The exhaustion is overwhelming—I barely have energy to lift myself out of bed let alone hold down conversations about how wonderful this all is supposed to be. My phone buzzes with well-meaning messages from friends asking how things are going, but honestly? I just want to scream into my pillow and tell them it’s not as rosy as they think.

I’ve been trying so hard to stay positive for the sake of everyone around me—my partner, family members who can’t quite understand why this isn’t perfect already—but sometimes it feels like a battle within. The nights are endless, with feedings that never seem to end and the constant worry gnawing at my soul. I find myself staring out windows, watching others go about their day as if nothing has changed for them, wondering when those moments will return to me.

There’s this nagging voice in the back of my head telling me I’m not cut out for this, that maybe having a baby was too much, but I push it away because I know deep down there are others who have faced even harder challenges and come through on the other side. Still, it’s tough to keep going when every step feels like an uphill climb.

I’ve read countless articles about postpartum blues and all the ways to cope, yet none seem to hit home or offer any real relief. I’m at a crossroads where I need to acknowledge my struggles without losing sight of what brought me here in the first place—love for this tiny person who needs me more than anything.

Tomorrow is another day filled with sleepless nights and tiny victories, but maybe if I can just get through one moment at a time, things will start looking up. Until then, I’ll keep holding on to hope that there’s light at the end of this long tunnel.

Today was one of those days where everything feels heavy, like the world is pressing down on me and there's no escape. I called Mom to talk about how I've been feeling lately—tired, hopeless, overwhelmed with this new life we've created together—and she didn't get it at all. She told me I'm just tired because of the baby and that everyone feels like this after having a child. But isn’t that exactly what postpartum depression is? It’s not about being tired from lack of sleep; it's about feeling like there’s no point in getting out of bed.

I guess I shouldn't be surprised. Mom has always been practical, never one for emotions or deep conversations. She’s tough and believes in pulling yourself up by your bootstraps. But right now, those words cut deeper than she could ever know. It's hard enough dealing with the guilt of not being as happy as everyone expects you to be after having a baby. To have my own mom invalidate these feelings is like a knife twisting in my heart.

I wish someone understood that this isn't just about adjusting to new parenthood or hormones—it’s real, it's valid, and it hurts more than I can express. If only there was someone out there who could see past the stereotype of postpartum depression and recognize me for what I'm going through. Today felt like a step back, but maybe tomorrow will bring something different. For now, though, all I have is this moment, these feelings, and a growing sense that I’m alone in my struggle.

Maybe it's time to reach out for help beyond our little family bubble. Maybe talking to someone who gets it could be the start of finding a way through this darkness.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of sleepless nights and blurry mornings. My head is heavy with exhaustion, every task feels insurmountable. The baby cries softly in the background; it’s been hours since I’ve slept properly. Each time my eyes flutter open, I’m met with the daunting reality that there's no respite from this endless cycle of care.

The days blend together in a haze of fatigue and despair. There are moments when I feel a glimmer of hope—that today might be better—only to have it crushed by another fitful night of interrupted sleep. The weight of responsibility is suffocating, but there’s no one else to turn to. It's like carrying the world on my shoulders without even having the energy to lift them.

I know I should reach out for help, that I shouldn’t struggle alone with these overwhelming feelings. But somehow, the thought of asking anyone for support feels impossible. Maybe it’s fear, maybe it’s pride, or perhaps just sheer exhaustion taking over every ounce of motivation. All I can do is put one foot in front of the other and hope that tomorrow will bring a little more clarity.

Tonight, as the baby drifts back to sleep, I’m left staring at the ceiling, wishing for rest that never comes. It’s hard to keep going when it feels like everything inside me is crumbling. But even in this darkness, there's an unspoken resolve to fight through it, one day at a time.

Day 8 Postpartum

I woke up this morning feeling like a volcano about to erupt. Everything irritates me: the sunlight streaming through my window, the sound of the baby crying (why won't she stop?), even the soft whirring of the ceiling fan seems too loud and annoying. I feel like yelling at everyone who comes near, but I know that's not okay.

Then there are these moments when I just... break down. Tears come out of nowhere, streaming down my face like a never-ending waterfall. It's embarrassing, really. How can someone cry so much? What if people think I'm weak or crazy?

I hate how this all makes me feel about myself. Like I can't handle anything, like I'm not good enough to be a mom. But then the baby smiles at me, and it feels like everything is okay again—until something small sets me off, and I'm back in my own personal storm.

Why do I have to cry over stupid things? Why am I so angry all the time? Is this just part of being a new mother? It's exhausting. But what can you do?

Tomorrow seems daunting already, but maybe it'll be better. Or not. Who knows? Right now, I'm stuck in this weird mix of love and hate for everything around me.

I wish someone could understand how I feel without judging me. Maybe talking to someone would help...

Today marks two weeks since I welcomed our little miracle into the world. The days are a whirlwind of diapers, bottles, and endless love that I never knew existed. Yet, as much as my heart is brimming with joy and gratitude for this tiny human who has completely changed my life, there’s also an undercurrent of exhaustion and sadness that lingers in the background.

I wake up feeling like I’ve aged ten years overnight. My mind feels foggy, and sometimes it takes everything out of me just to get through the day. But then, there are moments when I hold her, and all the worries melt away. She’s perfect, and so is this moment, even if it only lasts for a second.

I’ve been trying to push through the dark thoughts by reminding myself that everything will fall into place with time. It’s not easy to admit that I’m struggling, but talking about my feelings has helped me realize that many others go through similar experiences. Maybe that’s why I decided to jot down these thoughts today—to remind myself that I am not alone in this.

So here I am, in a room filled with love and chaos, trying to navigate the unpredictable tides of motherhood. It’s overwhelming at times, but also incredibly rewarding. Each day is a new challenge, but it’s also an opportunity to grow stronger. And for now, that feels like enough.

Today feels like a whirlwind of emotions and paperwork. I woke up to my little one’s cries yet again, but this time there was something different—there was an exhaustion that settled deep within me, not just physically but mentally too. Every day since bringing her home has felt like walking through fog, unsure of what lies ahead. The constant worry about being a good mom and the overwhelming tasks of my fellowship application are piling up.

But amidst this chaos, there's been one beacon of light: my mentor’s unwavering support. She calls just when I need it most, offering words that feel like lifelines in a stormy sea. Her advice isn’t always what I want to hear, but knowing someone believes in me is grounding. It’s strange how something as simple as a message or phone call can make such a difference.

Today, after another exhausting night, I managed to complete one section of my fellowship application. It's small progress, but it feels like an achievement. Taking time off for mental health hasn't been easy, especially with the looming deadlines and expectations. But here’s hoping that every little step forward is worth it. For me, for my baby, and for all those who believe in me.

I’m trying to hold on to hope and trust that each day gets a bit better than the last.

April 14th

Today marks three weeks since the birth of our little miracle. I know that sounds cliché, but it’s true—my daughter is a wonder. Yet, every time I look at her, I feel like a failure. The birth was everything you dread and more. It was violent, painful, and left me feeling utterly shattered.

The hospital staff did what they could to help me recover physically, but the emotional toll is another beast entirely. I find myself drifting into dark thoughts often, questioning if this was all worth it. There are moments when I hold her close, and a wave of love washes over me, only to be replaced by fear that I won’t be able to protect her from the world—or even my own mind.

I miss who I used to be before any of this began. Before we started planning for another child, before I thought about being a mom. Now, I’m not sure if I want to ever go through it again. The idea of carrying and giving birth to another baby makes me feel like I’ll break in two.

I’ve been trying to keep up with the support groups and online communities, but it’s hard to talk when all you see is a reflection of your own pain staring back at you. Today, I’m going to reach out for help. I need to find my way out of this darkness before it swallows me whole.

Maybe then, just maybe, I can start to believe that the future holds more than fear and despair.

Today was a whirlwind of emotions, but building Lego sets with baby has been my saving grace. I wake up feeling like the weight of the world is pressing down on me, and every tiny sound sends anxiety spiraling. Yet, when we sit together to construct little worlds out of colorful blocks, something shifts inside me. The focus needed for each piece fitting perfectly into place helps distract from all the worrying thoughts swirling around in my head.

I've been trying really hard not to let this dark cloud consume me completely. Every time I finish a project with the baby, no matter how small, it’s like hitting pause on everything else. A sense of accomplishment washes over me, and for that moment, I feel like maybe there’s hope after all. The pieces clicking together are so therapeutic; they remind me that order can emerge from chaos if you just take things one step at a time.

It's funny how something as simple as playing with Lego sets can provide such profound relief. Maybe it sounds silly to others, but in these moments, I feel like I’m giving both myself and my baby the gift of focus and calm. It’s not about curing anything overnight, but those small victories are crucial for keeping going one day at a time.

Tonight, after putting baby down for the night, I might try building something just for me. No pressure, no expectations, just the quiet satisfaction of creating something beautiful amidst all this chaos. This little hobby feels like a tiny anchor in an otherwise stormy sea—something to cling onto and find peace within.

April 4th

The days feel like a never-ending cycle of diaper changes and sleepless nights. Today marks four months since little Lily arrived, but it feels like an eternity ago when I was basking in the initial glow of motherhood. The reality is starkly different.

I tried to be grateful for everything that's come my way—my beautiful baby girl, the love from family and friends—but something still feels off. It's been four months since I walked out of the hospital with a tiny bundle wrapped in swaddling clothes. Four months since I left behind those sterile walls filled with medical staff who knew me by name. And now, it’s just me, trying to figure everything out on my own.

The six-week check-up was the last official visit from my healthcare providers. They said I'd be fine and that postpartum care ends here, despite the Employment Insurance benefits extending for another five months. It feels like they handed me a baby and waved goodbye without any proper handover or plan in place.

I’m struggling to find support. The transition back home was supposed to bring relief from hospital routines, but instead it’s left me feeling lost and unsupported. There are moments of sheer joy watching Lily grow, yet those are overshadowed by the constant exhaustion and overwhelming anxiety. 

Why does this feel so isolating? Why am I not given more guidance or help during such a critical time?

I miss the days when I felt strong and capable. Now, I feel weak and alone, questioning everything. It’s hard to ask for help when you’re supposed to be the one who knows it all.

Tomorrow is another day, but today feels like too much to bear.

Today marks seven long weeks of relentless pumping sessions that have left me feeling utterly depleted and lost in a haze of exhaustion. The nights stretch on endlessly as I struggle to catch even an ounce of REM sleep amidst the constant demands of my newborn. It feels like every moment is a battle against my own body, my mind screaming for rest while my hands mechanically work the pump.

I can barely keep up with the demands—feeding tubes, bottles, and endless burping sessions that never seem to end. I thought I was doing what I needed to do, pushing myself beyond any reasonable limit in an attempt to provide everything for my baby. But it’s taken a toll on me more than anything else.

I’ve reached out to a doctor who understands the signs all too well and has advised me about seeking help for postpartum depression. They say it’s urgent, but how can I when every moment feels like climbing an insurmountable mountain? The support is there, but right now, even talking about it seems like another task on my already overloaded plate.

Tonight, as I lie awake again, staring at the ceiling, a part of me whispers that this isn’t okay. That maybe, just maybe, it’s time to listen to what my body has been trying to tell me all along: I need rest, support, and understanding. It’s not selfish; it’s survival.

Tomorrow is another day, but tonight, as the darkness envelops me once more, I’m going to try and find a sliver of hope that tomorrow can be different. For me, for us, for everything we’ve been through and will face together.

March 17th

It's been exactly two months since little Luna arrived, and today I decided to write this down before I forget how I feel—or maybe just because I want to remember it all. There are days when the newness of motherhood feels like a dream, beautiful but somehow out of reach. Today is one of those days.

I've been trying really hard to enjoy these moments, and I do—seriously. Luna's tiny hand gripping mine, her sweet yawns after waking up from a nap; it’s all so precious. But there are also times when everything feels heavy, like the joy is just below my skin but can't break through. It's strange, because I love my baby more than words can describe, but sometimes I feel hollow.

I've been reading about postpartum depression, and while some of it doesn’t quite fit what I’m experiencing, other parts feel too familiar to ignore. The constant fatigue, the struggle to find motivation for even simple tasks, the overwhelming sense that something is wrong when everything looks perfect from the outside—these are real things that keep whispering in my head.

Today, after changing Luna's diaper and feeding her again (for what feels like the hundredth time), I felt a deep urge to just sit down and cry. It’s not because she's not good or beautiful; it's something deeper than that. And then there are days when I’m okay, really okay, laughing with my partner about silly things, feeling connected and happy.

But now here I am, writing this on what might be the hundredth night of interrupted sleep. Am I alone in these thoughts? Do other new moms feel like they’re hiding behind a mask of happiness?

I think it’s time to talk more openly about not just the joy but also the shadows that sometimes come with being a new parent. Maybe there are others out there who need to hear that it's okay not to be perfect, and that seeking help isn’t a sign of weakness.

Maybe tomorrow will feel different. For now, I’ll try to rest a bit more tonight—Luna included—and see if that makes a difference.

Today marks my third week as a new mom, and the reality of it all is starting to sink in. I never expected to feel so overwhelmed. My baby's crying triggers an unexpected surge of anger rather than comfort. It’s like this dark cloud has settled over me, making everything seem pointless.

I’ve tried to be positive, really I have. But every time someone tells me how beautiful my baby is or offers unsolicited advice, it just makes me want to scream. Why do they think it's okay to come into our home and say things that cut deep? It’s not that I’m ungrateful for the help—it's more like a constant reminder of all the things I can’t handle on my own.

Sleep is still an elusive dream, and every time I wake up in a cold sweat, I know something isn't right. The thought of going through another night alone with this tiny person feels terrifying. But then again, maybe it’s just me being irrational.

I’m not sure if anyone understands the depth of my struggle, or whether they even care enough to try. Maybe that’s why I feel so isolated and misunderstood. It's like everyone sees a new mom full of joy and wonder, but inside, there's this void where happiness should be.

It seems silly to worry about something when my baby is perfectly healthy, but the way I’m feeling isn’t just sadness—it’s a relentless emptiness that drains every ounce of energy from me. And if it doesn't change soon, I fear it will consume everything else.

I guess today was one of those days where I felt like I needed to write this down before my head explodes. Maybe talking about it, even in these pages, is the first step towards finding some peace.

Today marks another step forward in this journey of postpartum depression recovery, but the path is still strewn with challenges that feel like obstacles I must overcome alone. The sun rises and sets, bringing a sense of time passing, yet each day feels eerily similar to the last. It’s been hard, harder than I ever imagined it could be.

I’ve noticed some improvements—I can now get out of bed without needing an extra push from my partner or myself. That little victory is something worth celebrating. But there are still those moments when everything seems too heavy, too overwhelming. The idea of having another child terrifies me because the early stages of PPD were so consuming and painful.

I keep telling myself that it’s okay to feel this way right now. It’s okay to acknowledge my fears and doubts about future pregnancies while also focusing on healing from this one. I’m trying not to let the fear dictate my choices, but it’s tough when every thought about having another baby is clouded by memories of struggling through PPD.

It’s a delicate balance between moving forward and acknowledging how hard everything still feels. Right now, all I can do is take each day as it comes and hope for clearer skies ahead. Maybe one day soon, the fear won’t feel so suffocating, and having another child might be something to look forward to rather than dread.

For today though, I’ll just focus on this moment and keep moving, even if it’s at a snail’s pace.

Today was a whirlwind of emotions and pain. I woke up feeling like my head was underwater, everything felt heavy, and the baby’s cries only added to the chaos in my mind. My partner came in with breakfast and what seemed like good intentions, but it quickly turned into something else.

He mentioned abortion casually, as if he had any right to talk about it like that after all I’ve been through. The way his eyes lit up when showing me pictures of our little one was supposed to be a reminder of how lucky we were, but instead, it felt like a cruel joke. His insensitivity cut deeper than words can describe.

I didn’t stay for the rest of the confrontation; I couldn’t bear being there any longer. The thought of dealing with him right now is too much. The weight of postpartum depression and his lack of understanding are suffocating me. I need a moment to breathe, to process, and to figure out where we go from here.

Today was a whirlwind of emotions, a rollercoaster ride through the darkest corners of my mind and heart. The baby is sleeping peacefully in her crib, her tiny hands curled into fists, unaware of the turmoil happening within me. I feel like I'm drowning in this sea of sadness that has swallowed me whole since she arrived. Every day feels like a never-ending struggle, trying to find joy or even contentment in my new role as a mother.

Alex is here with me, holding my hand and whispering words of encouragement. He's been nothing short of amazing, always there to listen when I need someone to talk to or simply hold me close during the sleepless nights. But no matter how much he tries to help, it feels like an unending battle against a shadow that refuses to lift.

There are moments when I can see glimpses of happiness through the haze—like when she smiles for the first time, or when her little fingers grasp mine tentatively. Yet these fleeting joys are quickly overshadowed by overwhelming despair and anxiety. The guilt is suffocating; why am I not overjoyed to be a mother? Why does every tiny task feel like an insurmountable challenge?

I know I need help, but talking about it feels like admitting defeat. Every day seems longer than the last, filled with questions without answers and tears that never seem to stop. Alex is my rock right now, keeping me grounded when everything else feels like it’s spinning out of control.

Tomorrow will be a new day, or so I keep telling myself. But until then, I’ll cling onto his strength and hope that the darkness eventually fades away.

Today marks another milestone in my journey back to myself. The weight of the past eighteen months feels like a distant shadow now, one that I have finally managed to step away from. It's been a long road filled with peaks and valleys, but I’m stronger for having walked it.

The first year was a blur of tears and doubts, days when every breath seemed like an effort. I questioned everything, my decisions, my strength, my capacity as a mother. But there were moments too, brief glimmers of clarity that whispered encouragement into the darkest corners of my mind. Those whispers grew louder with time.

The second year was marked by slow but steady progress. I found comfort in routines and small victories. A good night's sleep here, a smile from my child there—these tiny triumphs began to stack up, creating a foundation of resilience beneath me. The fog lifted gradually, revealing glimpses of the sunlit path ahead.

Today feels like one of those days when everything seems possible again. I’m not just surviving; I’m thriving. It’s a quiet kind of happiness, knowing that I’ve weathered the storm and come out the other side with a clearer sense of who I am and what I want for myself and my family. The road ahead is long, but I walk it now with confidence and hope.

I can't help but feel grateful for this journey, painful as parts of it were. It has taught me so much about myself and what true strength looks like. And though the days are still sometimes tough, they're no longer overwhelming—I am.

Day 3 Postpartum

Today was a blur of tears and sleepless nights. I feel like I’m drowning in a sea of despair, yet somehow managing to feed this tiny human who’s completely dependent on me. It’s all so surreal. The baby sleeps for what feels like minutes at a time, but it’s the longest stretches I can bear being alone with my thoughts.

I can’t shake off the feeling that something is terribly wrong with me. Is this really what motherhood looks like? Wasn’t it supposed to be beautiful and peaceful? Why do I feel so utterly lost?

The anxiety that had been a constant companion during pregnancy has morphed into this deep, dark depression that refuses to let go of my heart. Every time I try to focus on the baby’s needs or even take a few moments for myself, the fear creeps back in—will I be able to keep it together? Can I really provide what she needs?

The nights are especially hard; every little noise sends me into panic mode. It’s like my mind is stuck on replay, reminding me of all the things that could go wrong. But then there are these fleeting moments where everything feels okay—her tiny hands wrapped around mine, her eyes looking up at me with such innocence.

Those moments give me hope, but they’re overshadowed by an overwhelming sense of failure. How did this happen? I thought I was prepared, emotionally and mentally ready for motherhood. Now, it’s like I’m lost in a foggy forest without a map or compass.

I need help, but how do you ask for help when every part of you feels broken beyond repair? Maybe the first step is acknowledging that these feelings are valid and that I’m not alone in this struggle. It’s okay to be scared and unsure—I just hope I can find my way back to a place where I can truly embrace this beautiful, complicated journey called motherhood.

Tomorrow feels like an eternity away right now, but I’ll take it one day at a time. For her sake, if not for mine.

Today marks a month since I welcomed my little bundle of joy into the world. It feels like an eternity ago that we were still in the hospital. The nights are long and exhausting, but there's this incredible sense of purpose that keeps me going.

I've been struggling to keep up with everything—cooking, cleaning, even just getting dressed sometimes feels like a monumental task. I’ve had moments where I burst into tears for no reason at all, but it’s not the kind of sadness that lingers; more like these sudden outbursts followed by relief as quickly as they come.

I know new parents often talk about the exhaustion and feeling overwhelmed, and while I hear those stories, I can't say I fully believed them until now. But there are also fleeting moments of pure joy when our little one smiles at me or sleeps peacefully in my arms. It’s these tiny glimpses that remind me why it's all worth it.

I’m trying to be patient with myself and take things day by day, hour by hour even. There’s a part of me that feels like I should be more put together, but seeing other moms online, reading about postpartum struggles, helps normalize what I'm going through. It’s okay not to have it all figured out yet.

Today was particularly tough—I had to nap in the middle of the afternoon because there's just no other way around this constant fatigue. But then again, every time our baby wakes up with a smile and a coo, my heart melts. This journey is hard but incredibly rewarding, and I’m slowly learning that it’s okay to ask for help.

I hope tomorrow brings more sleep and maybe even a bit of sunshine through the clouds.

Today marks three weeks since little Luna joined our family. It’s been a whirlwind of emotions and sleepless nights, but as the days stretch out before me, I find myself sinking into a fog that feels harder to escape from than ever before.

Sleep is elusive, even more so with each passing day. But I know it's not just about lack of rest; my body has changed in ways that feel foreign, like a hormonal storm brewing inside me. The fatigue hits hard and often, but there’s something deeper, darker—something pulling at the edges of my joy.

I keep telling myself this too shall pass. My previous experience with postpartum depression serves as a stark reminder. It feels daunting, knowing it could hit again, harder perhaps, but I also know recovery is possible. Nutrient deficiency seems like a plausible explanation for some of these feelings, so I’m trying to focus on nourishing my body more intentionally.

It’s hard to find the energy or motivation to reach out right now, but I know that’s not helping either. Luna deserves to see her mommy smile and laugh again soon. Today, I'll start with small steps: sunlight, a walk, maybe even a phone call to someone who gets it.

Tomorrow is another day, and I believe this cloud will lift sooner rather than later.

January 15th, 2023

Today was another day of trying to keep my head above water. The baby is sleeping peacefully in the crib, her tiny fists curled up tight like little knots. I sit here feeling so small and overwhelmed by everything.

I want to be better for her. Every time she looks at me with those wide eyes, all I see are my shortcomings. Why can't I smile back as brightly as she does? Why do I feel like a fraud when I try to care for her?

The guilt is suffocating. It’s there every single moment, whispering that I’m not enough. But then I remember why I started this journey—because somewhere deep down, I believe in us. In me becoming the mom she needs.

I’ve been reading about postpartum depression online and it’s reassuring to know I'm not alone. Talking with my partner has helped a bit too. He reminds me that healing takes time, but we’re moving forward together.

Today felt hard, but there was one tiny moment of joy when I caught myself humming along with her coos. It was brief, but enough to prove that even in the darkest moments, there can be glimmers of light.

I’m not going to give up. Tomorrow might bring new challenges, but it also brings hope for growth and healing. One day at a time—no matter how small those steps seem.

---

The days blend together sometimes, but I’ll keep writing here, holding onto the bits that feel good. It’s like threading tiny beads on a string—I’m building something with this, piece by piece.

Today marks one week since little Alice joined our family. The nurses in the hospital kept telling me I’d feel like a superhero after giving birth, but nothing could have prepared me for how hard it is to be this tired and confused all at once.

I can’t shake off the feeling that everyone around me expects me to bounce back immediately. My mom keeps calling with advice on breastfeeding, as if I haven’t tried everything she suggested already. Even my husband, who’s been supportive throughout, sometimes looks at me like he wishes I could just snap out of this fog of sadness.

I feel so frustrated when people tell me I should be happy or that I’m not trying hard enough to feel better. It’s exhausting being responsible for your own happiness while dealing with something you can’t control. Postpartum depression isn’t a choice; it’s a wave that crashes over you no matter how much you try to paddle away from it.

I wish there were more people who understood this. I’m not blaming myself, but sometimes it feels like everyone else is. It’s hard to feel accountable when all I want to do is cry and sleep, even though I know that’s not what a “good” new mom does.

Maybe tomorrow will be better. Maybe I’ll find the strength to laugh again instead of just feeling overwhelmed by everything. For now, I’m going to take it one minute at a time and hope for small victories like getting through the day without breaking down completely.

It’s okay not to be okay right now. It really is.

Today marks a week since I brought my baby home. The joy of holding him for the first time is overshadowed by the nagging feeling that something isn't right. My heart aches when I think about how tired and overwhelmed I am. It feels like everyone around me understands what's going on except for one person who just doesn't get it.

There’s this woman, let’s call her Sarah, who was in a relationship with my partner before we started dating. They broke up over a year ago, but she seems to have kept quiet about their status ever since. I found out recently that they’re still communicating and seeing each other behind closed doors. It's like every time I need support or just someone to listen, this secret comes back to haunt me.

I know I should be focusing on my recovery and our new baby, but the thought of Sarah undermines everything. How can she not see how disrespectful it is? She knows about us now, so why continue with these games? It’s frustrating because when I try to talk about it, everyone tells me to just move past it and focus on the positive.

But moving past it seems impossible when someone else is still actively involved in my partner's life. My mind races with all sorts of scenarios: how they meet up, what they talk about. Every little noise makes me jump, thinking maybe this time I’ll find out for sure. The exhaustion feels heavier knowing that there’s another person involved who isn’t even trying to make things better.

I’m scared and confused, but mostly I feel like no one truly understands the strain of balancing a new baby with all these complications. Maybe it's just me being too sensitive, but sometimes it feels like the whole world is against me in this moment. And here I am, trying to be strong for my family, but also feeling so utterly alone.

Tomorrow will hopefully bring some clarity or at least more sleep. For now, I’m going to try and rest, hoping that tomorrow brings a little less of this emotional turmoil.

March 3, 2023

Today marks two weeks since I welcomed our little bundle of joy into the world. People keep telling me how common it is to have postpartum depression and that I should watch out for signs like feeling overwhelmed or disconnected from my baby. Honestly, it's starting to feel a bit overblown.

I remember talking to a mom at the hospital who has bipolar disorder but still manages to be such an amazing mother. She showed me how being aware of your condition can actually help you parent better rather than hinder it. It made me question why everyone jumps on this bandwagon about postpartum depression as if it's a foregone conclusion for all new moms.

Today, I held my baby and felt overwhelming joy and love. The moments when I look into her tiny eyes, they sparkle with wonder. How can anyone think that feeling content and grateful is something to worry about? Of course, there are challenges, but isn't parenting always full of those?

I'm going to keep enjoying this beautiful time instead of fretting over what-ifs. After all, every day feels like a new chapter in our story.

Today was one of those days when everything felt too heavy to carry. I woke up feeling like the weight of the world was sitting on my chest, and it just didn't feel right. The baby slept longer than usual, but that extra quiet time did nothing to soothe me.

I couldn’t help but stare at myself in the mirror, seeing someone who doesn’t recognize herself anymore. It’s hard to believe this is what they call a "new chapter." I felt so lost and alone, like there's no hope for getting back to where I was before all of this began.

In moments of despair, my hands found scissors. I cut my hair short, almost too short—like an attempt to erase something from within me. It’s not the first time I’ve turned to that kind of release, but it always feels like such a mess afterward. Now every reflection shows evidence of my struggle.

I know my partner is upset with me. They avoid me because they don't want to deal with this dark side of me. We've been through so much together, and now there’s a wall between us that seems impossible to break down. I can see the worry in their eyes when they think I’m not looking, but it doesn’t change how alone I feel.

I'm trying to hold on to hope that things will get better, but sometimes it feels like all that's left inside of me is this emptiness and pain. I don't want to be like this forever, but right now, every day seems like a battle I might not win.

Day 7 Postpartum: A Second Chance at Grace

Another day has passed and I find myself looking back on the last two weeks with a mix of exhaustion and gratitude. Bringing home baby number two was an overwhelming experience; it's almost like the initial shock hasn't fully worn off yet.

The house feels different now, but not in a bad way. There’s this quiet sense of calm that comes from knowing I’m not alone. My friend Lisa has been a constant presence since our son was born—cooking meals, doing laundry, and simply holding my hand when all I wanted to do was cry. With my first child, I felt so isolated during the postpartum period. It's funny how those dark moments can shape your perceptions of support in ways you don't anticipate.

This time around, I've been more open about my struggles with postpartum depression. Lisa’s understanding ear and unwavering encouragement have made a world of difference. She’s helped me see that it’s okay to take things one step at a time. Her presence is a reminder that recovery isn’t linear; sometimes you’re taking two steps forward, other times just trying not to fall.

I’m still processing everything, but having Lisa here has been like holding onto a lifeline. It's hard to describe the weight it lifts off my shoulders knowing there’s someone who truly understands and cares. Maybe this time will be different because I'm surrounded by love, even from those who aren't blood-related.

Today marks one month since bringing little Emma into the world. It feels like an eternity ago that I was full of joy and anticipation for her arrival. Now, each day drags on with a heaviness I can't shake. The exhaustion is overwhelming—every night is a battle to get any sleep at all. Yet when I do manage to close my eyes, dark thoughts flood in, leaving me feeling worse than before.

The tears are constant now, whether it’s frustration or sadness or just pure confusion. Sometimes I feel like I’m going crazy. My mind races with worries about being a bad mother, about failing Emma somehow. It’s hard to remember the love and excitement when all I can think is that this is too much. 

I know something isn’t right. The weight of it all feels suffocating, but I keep trying to push through for Emma's sake. I want to be strong, but honestly, I’m not sure if I am anymore. It’s like everything I thought was possible and beautiful has been replaced by a haze of doubt and fear.

I know I need help, but the thought of reaching out feels exhausting in itself. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, I’ll just try to keep going, one day at a time.

Today marks one week since little Ellie arrived. I can't believe my life has changed so much in just seven days. It's amazing how everything feels both completely different and oddly familiar at the same time.

The first night was tough—so many alarms, feedings, diaper changes. But seeing her tiny hands grasp my finger with such strength? Priceless. She’s a fighter from day one.

I’ve been feeling more tired than I ever have before, but there's this incredible energy too—a mix of exhaustion and exhilaration that keeps me going. It’s strange how every small achievement feels monumental: getting dressed without forgetting something essential, making breakfast without burning the house down. These little wins are my new badge of honor.

The hormonal changes? Well, let’s just say I understand why people talk about mood swings now. One minute I’m elated over tiny victories, the next I’m questioning if I can actually do this parenting thing. But then she smiles at me and all those doubts melt away instantly.

I’ve heard about these rare sympathy pregnancies—men growing a baby bump and experiencing some of what women go through during pregnancy. Maybe it’s just my imagination, but sometimes I feel like my heart is doubling in size with each passing day. It sounds silly, but there's this overwhelming sense of being connected to Ellie that feels both physical and emotional.

Overall, though, the joy far outweighs any challenges. Watching her discover her fingers or cooing at me fills me with a warmth that’s hard to describe. I never knew love could be so intense and all-encompassing until now.

Today marks two weeks since little Sophia joined our family. It's been a whirlwind of sleepless nights and endless diaper changes. The exhaustion is real, but there’s this nagging feeling that maybe it's more than just being tired. I keep telling myself it's normal, but the sadness and anxiety are starting to feel overwhelming.

Yesterday, I broke down in tears while feeding Sophia because she wouldn't stop crying. My husband looked at me with concern, but all I could think was how I should be better. Shouldn’t this be a time of joy? Am I failing as a mother already?

I've been trying to stay positive and focus on the good moments, like when Sophia smiles or falls asleep peacefully after nursing. But it’s hard not to feel lost in these early days. Everyone talks about how wonderful having a baby is supposed to be, but what if you're struggling and don't know how to express it?

I’ve been doing some reading online and realized that maybe I’m not alone in feeling this way. There are resources available for new moms who need support, like therapy or support groups. Maybe reaching out isn’t so bad after all.

So today, I’ll take a deep breath and try to keep moving forward, one moment at a time. Maybe tomorrow will be better.

Today marks a week since I brought my baby home from the hospital. The joy of holding him for the first time is still fresh in my mind, but it's overshadowed by an overwhelming sense of dread and sadness that seems to settle over me every morning when I wake up.

I thought being a new mom would feel like something out of a fairy tale — pure happiness and endless cuddles. But instead, there’s this constant voice inside my head telling me that I’m not good enough. That maybe I shouldn’t be the one raising him at all. It’s scary to think about what that means for me as a person, let alone a parent.

I know I should talk to someone — friends have suggested it and even my partner has urged me to get help. But the thought of telling anyone how I feel just makes everything worse. What if they see me as unstable? Or worse, take our baby away from us because I can’t handle this?

There are moments when I catch myself staring at him sleeping peacefully in his crib, and a part of me wonders if it’s okay to leave. But then another voice whispers back that I’m the only one who can love him like no one else ever will.

I feel so alone with these thoughts, but I know I need to find a way out of this darkness before I hurt myself or someone else. It’s terrifying to even consider what might happen if things don’t get better soon.

Today marks another day since I gave birth to my little bundle of joy. As I sit here in the quiet of our apartment, surrounded by baby paraphernalia and the soft sound of her snores from the bassinet next to me, a wave of sadness washes over me like a cold, relentless tide. It's not the love for my newborn that feels absent; it’s everything else. The excitement I had imagined is replaced with a heavy blanket of fatigue and an overwhelming sense of loneliness.

I’ve been trying so hard to be happy—after all, isn’t this supposed to be one of life’s greatest joys? But lately, even small tasks feel like climbing Mount Everest. Making dinner feels impossible, getting dressed is too much effort. And the guilt—that gnawing feeling in my chest for not being more joyful—is suffocating.

Yesterday I talked to Dr. S about how I’ve been feeling. Her words were gentle but clear: postpartum depression is a real thing, and it’s okay to ask for help. It's comforting to know that there are others out there who feel the same way—like me—but part of my brain keeps whispering, "What if this isn’t just about hormones? What if something’s wrong with me?"

I’m scared, but I’m also hopeful. Talking it through with Dr. S was a step in the right direction. Tomorrow we start therapy sessions and she's prescribing some medication to help me find balance again.

For now, though, all I can do is take one breath at a time and remind myself that tomorrow might be better. It’s okay not to be okay today.

Today marks one week since little baby arrived, and I’m still not sure if I know how to be a mom. Everything feels so big and overwhelming. The sleepless nights are wearing me down; there’s no respite from the constant worry about whether I’m doing enough, being enough.

When he cries, it’s like my heart is breaking into pieces. Sometimes I want to hold him close, but other times, all I can think of is how tired and alone I feel. I miss who I was before this happened, and every time I look at the baby monitor, there's a part of me that just wants to hide.

The days blend together in a haze of feedings, diaper changes, and endless staring into his tiny face, wondering when the joy will come back. Friends say it gets easier, but right now, nothing feels easy. There are moments where I feel so much love for him, but then there are others where all I want is to disappear.

I’m scared that if anyone looks too closely, they’ll see how lost and unsure I am. What if this feeling never goes away? What if I can’t find my way back to happiness?

Tomorrow feels like a mountain to climb, and yet, another day passes by before I know it. I wish someone could just tell me what comes next because right now, all I have is this heavy, hollow ache inside that won’t go away no matter how many times I try to push it down.

Maybe tomorrow will be better. Maybe not. For now, though, I’m just going to try and breathe through today.

October 17th

Today marks the end of my hospital stay. Three weeks have flown by in a haze of confusion and exhaustion. The days bled into one another with no clear beginning or end. I wake up feeling like I’m still dreaming, but this dream is filled with darkness rather than light.

The nurses were kind, but their endless questions made me feel trapped inside my own mind. Why do I feel so numb? Why can’t I shake the despair that clings to me like a second skin?

I’ve been writing everything down – scribbling notes in the margins of my hospital journals. It’s a way to hold onto reality, even if it feels far away at times.

The room is quiet now except for the hum of machines and the occasional murmur from the hallway. I look over at the bassinet where my babies sleep peacefully. They have no idea about the storm raging inside me. How do I tell them when I don’t understand myself?

It’s hard to believe that just a few months ago, I was brimming with excitement for this moment. Now it feels like an endless void.

I’m scared, but there’s also a glimmer of hope. The therapists say they can help. Maybe I’ll find my way back someday soon.

For now, I’ll keep writing, even if the words seem to slip through my fingers as quickly as they come.

---

Sometimes sentences are short and choppy, reflecting disorientation and fatigue. Other times, longer streams of consciousness capture the complexity of emotions during this challenging period.

Today marks a new chapter in my life, but the weight of it feels heavier than ever before. I finally tested negative for COVID-19 after weeks of isolation and anxiety. It was like a breath of fresh air to know that the virus no longer has its grip on me. But as the joy faded, reality hit hard. My newborn is growing by leaps and bounds, yet I feel more lost with each passing day.

The exhaustion never leaves; it’s as if my body can’t find rest even when sleeping. The nights are filled with worry about everything from feeding schedules to whether he’s getting enough sleep. But the real struggle comes during these quiet moments in the early morning or late at night, when there's no one around and all I hear is silence.

I keep telling myself that it’s normal to feel overwhelmed after having a baby, but sometimes it feels like more than just adjustment fatigue. The thought of going out and meeting people who are "excited" for me fills me with dread rather than joy. Even the little things—like folding laundry or cooking breakfast—seem impossible when all I want is for someone to hold my hand and tell me everything will be okay.

There’s this constant tug-of-war between feeling like a good parent and questioning every decision. Is it normal to feel so inadequate? When did life become this series of endless tasks without room for rest or self-care?

I know talking about these feelings might help, but there's also an overwhelming fear that I'll be seen as weak. Maybe admitting struggle means accepting failure. But I’m starting to realize that asking for help isn’t a sign of weakness—it’s a sign of strength and resilience.

So here I am, on day 30 postpartum, trying to find my footing in a world where the only constant is change. The journey feels long and lonely, but I have hope that with each step forward, things will get easier. For now, though, it’s okay to acknowledge the storm inside and ask for a lifeline.

December 13, 2023

The days feel like a never-ending blur of sleepless nights and endless worries. I thought holding my baby would be the happiest moment in my life, but here I am, feeling more lost than ever before. The weight of being a new mother is crushing me. 

I wake up every morning with an overwhelming sense of dread. The house feels too quiet, too empty. I can't shake this constant sadness that seeps into everything. Even the baby's smiles and coos don’t lift my spirits anymore.

Why do I feel so alone? Why does every little task seem insurmountable? I keep telling myself it’s just postpartum blues, but it feels like something deeper is going on. I struggle with even basic things—changing diapers, feeding the baby, taking a shower. It's all too much sometimes.

Today was especially hard. The crying didn’t stop for hours and every time she cries, my heart breaks into pieces. No amount of rocking or soothing seems to work. By evening, exhaustion had me lying on the couch, tears streaming down my face. I’m so tired of feeling this way.

Every day, I tell myself this is temporary, that things will get better soon, but today feels different. It's a constant battle inside—am I being too hard on myself? Am I really struggling more than others with something as normal as having a baby?

I know it’s not healthy to just bottle everything up, but talking about my feelings seems like one more thing to add to the endless list of tasks. Maybe I need to reach out for help, even if that means admitting how lost and overwhelmed I feel right now.

I’m trying to stay positive, hoping tomorrow will be better. But today, all I can do is hold on tight and hope the storm passes soon.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and the reality of it all feels both exhilarating and daunting. The sleepless nights are turning into blurry mornings, but there’s an undeniable joy that comes with every smile from my little one. It’s hard to believe I’ve been through so much already.

I can’t help but worry about postpartum depression creeping in. Everyone keeps telling me it's normal to feel overwhelmed and exhausted, but those words don’t really ease the anxiety gnawing at me. What if I start feeling lost or disconnected? What if my love for this tiny life isn't enough?

Today was rougher than usual. The baby cried endlessly, and even though they’re still so small, it’s hard to shake off the feeling that something is wrong. But then I looked down at their little face, all soft skin and tiny hands, and felt a warmth in my chest that reminded me why we did this.

I’m trying not to dwell on fears too much but sometimes it’s hard to silence them. Maybe talking about it more openly with family or friends will help ease the tension. For now, I’ll take each day one step at a time, cherishing every moment and learning how to navigate this new world we’ve entered together.

Perhaps it's worth reaching out for some support too—there’s no shame in seeking guidance when you feel lost. After all, being a parent is about growing and learning along with your child.

Today feels like a day I'm barely making it through. The baby's been fussier than usual, and every time she cries, my heart clenches with this overwhelming sense of failure. It’s hard to believe that just weeks ago, I was brimming with excitement about motherhood.

I’ve started attending counseling sessions, something that feels both daunting and essential. Talking about these feelings is a relief, but it also dredges up emotions that feel impossible to manage. The counselor recommended some grounding techniques, like focusing on my breath or the sound of the rain outside my window when things get overwhelming.

Spiritually, I’ve been trying to find peace in the small moments—like lighting candles at dusk or saying a quick prayer before bedtime. These little rituals offer me a sense of stability amidst chaos. But despite these efforts, there are days when the world feels too heavy, and all I want is to curl up and disappear.

Taking things one step at a time seems like an impossible task right now, but it’s also my best hope for finding some semblance of normalcy. Baby steps—literally and figuratively—are what keep me moving forward.
