It’s a testament to just how incredible new mothers are when we navigate this uncharted territory together. I find myself smiling more often now, marveling at each little milestone, no matter how small it may seem.

There have been moments of sheer exhaustion, but they’re fleeting compared to the joy that swells within me every time I look at her. I’m still learning what my new normal looks like, and while there are challenges, they pale in comparison to the love I feel for Ellie.

I’ve heard stories about postpartum depression from other mothers, and it’s definitely something on my radar. But so far, nothing feels out of the ordinary besides being really, really tired. It’s important to stay mindful and aware, but right now, there are more days filled with wonder than worry.

Today I’ll focus on taking care of myself while caring for Ellie—maybe a long shower or some quiet time in the evening. These little moments add up and help me keep things balanced. As we move forward, I’m confident that even the toughest parts will be met with gratitude and resilience.

Love,
Mom

Today marks my third week as a new mom, and it feels like an eternity since I last felt anything but overwhelmed. The days blur together with feedings, diaper changes, and endless sleepless nights. My little one is beautiful and sweet, but the joy of holding her doesn’t quite match the exhaustion that seeps into every waking moment.

I’ve been trying to stay positive, reminding myself that this too shall pass, but sometimes it feels like a never-ending tunnel with no light at the end. I worry about how I’m going to manage everything without getting help from anyone else. It’s not just physical fatigue either; my mind is foggy and heavy, almost as if there’s an invisible weight sitting on my chest.

Yesterday, I felt like crying for hours over something so trivial—a dirty dish in the sink—that it scared me. This isn’t how I want to be feeling. I know from past experiences that depression can sneak up when I least expect it, especially after childbirth. But this time, there’s no safety net of medication to fall back on.

I miss my old self—confident and capable—who could handle life’s challenges without breaking down. Right now, even a simple task feels insurmountable. Maybe it’s time to reach out for support again. I’ve been so independent that asking for help seems like admitting failure. But maybe it’s the first step towards getting better.

Tomorrow, I’ll call my therapist and see what resources are available. It won’t be easy, but sometimes you need a little push to move forward. And for my baby’s sake, as well as mine, this is one push I’m willing to take.

September 14, 2023

The world has never felt so quiet yet so loud at the same time. Today marks two weeks since little Emma joined our family, and while I still can't believe she's really here, there are moments when everything feels like a blur.

I've been trying to take things one day at a time. The exhaustion is overwhelming, but every time I look into her eyes or hear her tiny coos, it all melts away. Today, my husband suggested we try a new approach for those late-night feedings—instead of rushing and stressing over everything, he said let's just snuggle and enjoy the moment.

It worked. We stayed up later than planned, but I felt something shift inside me. The darkness that had been looming started to lift a bit, replaced by warmth and peace. It’s hard to describe, but there was this sense of connection that filled us both as we held her close.

I know there are days ahead where things won’t feel so good, but for now, I’m cherishing these moments. Talking about it with my support group has been a game-changer too; knowing others are going through similar struggles helps normalize the ups and downs.

So here’s to finding joy in unexpected places—like late-night cuddles—and remembering that even when things seem tough, there is always light at the end of the tunnel.

August 7th, Day 3 Post Birth

Today marks the third day of my life as a new mother. The hospital room is still filled with that sterile scent, but it’s beginning to feel more like home. The nurses are kind and helpful, even if I’ve lost count of how many there have been since I arrived.

The baby’s name is Lily; she's so small and perfect, yet her presence feels overwhelming. Every time she cries or needs a diaper change, my heart races with anxiety. Are these normal feelings? Am I supposed to be this nervous?

I keep hearing about postpartum depression in the news and on social media, but when it comes down to it, I just feel tired and confused. Shouldn’t I be more joyful right now? Maybe it’s okay to feel a bit lost—I’ve heard many moms say they felt the same.

Lying awake at night, watching Lily sleep, I wonder if I’m doing enough or too much. The doctors say everything is fine, but that doesn't stop my mind from wandering to worst-case scenarios. It's exhausting just thinking about it all!

Tomorrow we go home. Will things get better? Or will this feeling of being in over my head stay with me? For now, I’ll focus on the small moments—like when Lily smiles for the first time. Those moments are what make everything worth it.

I'm trying to remind myself that I’m doing okay, despite these uncertainties and fears. It’s a new beginning, after all. And maybe, just maybe, with each day that passes, things will become clearer.

Today marks another day of feeling utterly lost and alone. It’s been three months since Emma was born, and I can’t shake this overwhelming sense of sadness that clings to me like a shadow. The joy I felt when she first wrapped her tiny fingers around mine feels like it happened in a different lifetime.

I’ve tried so hard to be the mom I imagined before all of this happened—before the sleepless nights and constant worry began to weigh on my mind. But now, every moment is a struggle. Even holding Emma sometimes leaves me feeling numb and disconnected from her tiny, perfect existence. How did it come to this? I feel like a failure, a fraud.

The doctor’s words about postpartum depression echo in my head like a broken record: “It’s common,” they say, but that doesn’t make it easier to accept. Every day feels like a battle against myself, and I’m tired of losing. There are moments when I want to reach out for help—when I wish someone could understand the depth of this darkness—but those same moments leave me feeling too ashamed to do anything.

I miss my old self—the one who felt capable and hopeful about the future. Instead, here I am, trapped in a cycle of despair that seems to have no end in sight. What if these feelings never go away? What if I’m stuck like this forever?

But today, as I watched Emma’s little hands reach for me with such innocence and trust, something inside of me cracked open just a tiny bit. Maybe there is still hope for us—maybe tomorrow can be better. For now, though, all I know is that I need to find my way back to myself before it’s too late.

Today marks a week since little Eleanor joined our world. I can barely remember what it was like to have a life outside of the constant need for sleep and attention that comes with being a new mother. It's been such a whirlwind of emotions—so much love, so much joy—but also an overwhelming sense of exhaustion and sadness.

I wake up each day thinking everything will get easier, but instead, it feels like I'm drowning in tasks without ever making any real progress. The room spins with the ADHD fog, and I feel lost and alone even when surrounded by family and friends who are trying to help. Sometimes I catch myself staring at Eleanor, wondering if she’s okay, and other times, I just want to curl up in a ball and cry.

The postpartum depression is like a dark cloud hanging over me, suffocating the happiness that should be there. I know it’s normal to feel tired and overwhelmed, but something feels deeply wrong when even holding my baby makes my heart heavy with sadness.

I’m trying to stay positive, really I am. But today was particularly tough. It felt like everything went wrong in one breath—missed a feeding, forgot to change the diaper, didn’t shower—and here we are at 2 PM and all that’s left is this nagging feeling of failure.

It’s hard to believe it's been only a week, yet somehow feels like an eternity. I’m holding on by a thread, hoping tomorrow will be better. But for now, I just need to close my eyes and try to find some peace in the chaos.

Today marks another step forward in my journey of healing. It's been a whirlwind since little Emma arrived, and I find myself struggling to keep up with the constant demands and changes. Some days are better than others, but today felt like one of those 'just getting by' kind of days.

Morning started off with tears—those inexplicable ones that seem to come out of nowhere. I know it's part of postpartum depression, but it feels so isolating sometimes. Yet, there’s a small voice inside me reminding me that each tear is also a step towards finding my way back to myself and to the joy in being Emma's mom.

I tried to focus on little moments—like when she looks at me with those big eyes filled with wonder, or how soft her skin feels against mine. These glimpses of love are what keep me going. I'm doing better than last week though; that’s something to celebrate, right?

I made it out of the house today for a walk in the park. It wasn’t easy—just taking those steps felt monumental—but being outside under the sun did wonders. People smiled and offered kind words, reminding me that there are others who care.

The hardest part is probably feeling guilty about needing help so much, but I'm learning to lean on my support system. Therapy sessions have been incredibly helpful too; talking it out with someone who understands makes a difference.

Tomorrow feels like an endless mystery right now, but for today, just holding Emma and knowing she needs me gives me the strength to face whatever comes next. One day at a time, I'm taking this step by step towards healing.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of grey skies and heavy hearts. It's been nearly four years since my son was born, yet the shadows of postpartum depression still linger like an unwelcome guest. Some days, I feel like I'm suffocating under the weight of these dark thoughts, but there are other moments when a glimmer of hope shines through.

I remember holding him for the first time, feeling this overwhelming love mixed with fear and uncertainty. It was as if my heart had been split in two—filled with joy at being his mother, yet plagued by an eerie sense of isolation. The weeks turned into months, then years, but those initial feelings never quite faded away.

People say time heals all wounds, but it hasn't exactly worked that way for me. Instead, each day feels like a battle against the darkness inside my head. It's exhausting to keep putting on a smile when everything feels so hollow from within. But there are moments of clarity too—moments where I catch glimpses of his innocence and wonder, and they remind me why we fight.

I know I'm not alone in this struggle, but sometimes it feels that way. It’s hard to reach out for help; admitting you're struggling can feel like a failure. But maybe today will be different. Maybe today is the day I take another step forward instead of sinking deeper into this abyss.

Today marks one month since little Ella joined our family. I can barely believe how fast time is flying by. Some days are just so beautiful and filled with joy, like when she smiles at me for the first time or when my partner and I watch her sleep peacefully. But then there are other times that leave me feeling completely lost and alone.

I keep having these moments where everything feels too overwhelming to handle—like the sound of a crying baby sets off fireworks in my head. It's hard to understand why it should be this way because on paper, my life looks perfect. I love Ella more than words can describe, but there are days when that feeling gets lost under a wave of sadness and anxiety.

I find myself thinking about old memories too—like the time I was just 17 with so many questions and no answers. It’s strange how one concern from such a long time ago can resurface in my mind right now, as if it's trying to tell me something important. Maybe it's just my brain's way of reminding me that life is full of uncertainties and challenges.

The hardest part is feeling like I'm failing at this most amazing job ever. How do you navigate the storm when all you want is a sunny day? It’s tough not knowing how long these feelings will last or if they'll get better. But I know I can’t just sit here in the dark. I need to reach out and ask for help, even though it feels like admitting defeat.

So today, as Ella giggles in her sleep, I decide that tomorrow morning, I’ll talk to my doctor about these feelings. Maybe she can give me some tools to help me navigate this unpredictable sea we're sailing through together. For now, all I know is that I’m not alone in feeling lost and scared—there’s a whole world out there full of people who understand what it's like to feel this way.

Tomorrow will be the day I start fighting back against the shadows.

Today feels like one long stretch of gray clouds without a glimmer of sunshine to break through. My body aches from the relentless demands of caring for my newborn daughter, and every time I close my eyes, exhaustion whispers in my ear that I should sleep more. But there’s always something demanding attention—another diaper change, another feed, another cry that needs soothing.

I haven’t cried since she was born, but right now, there are moments when I feel like a dam is about to break. Sometimes, I wish for just one person who truly understands. Someone who can listen without judgment, who can offer support or simply sit with me in this quiet struggle. But mostly, I fear that if I let the tears fall, they might never stop. And what kind of mother am I then?

I know there’s a world outside these walls, filled with people and laughter and life. Yet, it all feels so far away from here—stuck between sleepless nights and dreams of simpler times before this tiny human arrived.

Maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe today is just another day in the long marathon of early motherhood. I’ll keep pushing through, one breath at a time, hoping that eventually, the light will pierce these dark moments.

Today marks my third week as a new mother, and while I should be brimming with joy and excitement, all I feel is an overwhelming sense of emptiness and dread. The days blend together in a haze of tired eyes and restless nights. Every time I look at the baby, this gnawing feeling eats away inside me—I don’t know if it’s guilt for not being happy or fear that something isn’t right with me.

My husband keeps asking how I’m doing, but all I can say is “okay” because anything else sounds too dramatic or too sad.

Tonight, as the baby cried again through another sleepless hour, it hit me: this isn’t normal. I’ve been so busy taking care of everyone else that I completely forgot to take care of myself. The thought of going back to work next week feels like a cruel joke—how am I supposed to fake being okay when I feel this way?

I need help, but admitting that feels like giving up. Maybe tomorrow will be better, but what if it isn’t?

Today feels like a heavy weight is pressing down on me, and not just because of the baby. The exhaustion hits hard, wrapping around me like a thick blanket I can't shake off no matter how much sleep I try to get. Just getting out of bed seems like climbing a mountain. And with little Grayson crying again, the urge to curl up into a ball and disappear is overwhelming.

I know I’ve been here before—after my first two babies—and it’s scary. The thoughts swirling in my head are dark and relentless: what kind of mother am I? Why can’t I do this better? It feels like I’m drowning in these feelings, and no matter how hard I try to swim towards the surface, I just keep sinking.

The house is a mess—dishes piled high, laundry spilling over everywhere. But even getting up to clean feels like an impossible task. My thyroid isn’t helping either; it’s as if my body is working against me every step of the way. The energy that should be there to power through just isn't there.

I wish I could feel better for Grayson, but right now, all I want to do is lie in bed and disappear into a dreamless sleep. But I know I can’t give up on myself or him. This is hard, but it’s not forever. Maybe tomorrow will be different. For now, though, I just need to hold on tight and hope for some relief.

Today marks two weeks since bringing my second child into this world, and the weight of it all feels crushing at times. The sleep deprivation is brutal, but that’s just a small part of the struggle. Today feels like a never-ending shadow that refuses to lift. I've been trying so hard to be the mom my kids deserve, but it's like an invisible force is holding me back at every turn. The what-ifs are endless, and they all lead to this overwhelming fear that I’m not enough.

I’ve been trying to push through it for their sake, but today was just too much. All I wanted was a little kindness and understanding, some acknowledgment that being a new mom is hard enough without adding my own mental battle into the mix. But instead of support, all I got were more obstacles thrown in my way.

I need help, but how do you ask for it when every time you reach out, you feel like you’re failing even more? Maybe it’s okay to not be okay, right?

Tomorrow feels like a mountain too high to climb today. But I’ll try. For them, if nothing else.

Today was a mess, and it started with a simple spill of breast milk. Tears just wouldn’t stop flowing, and I felt so overwhelmed by something that seemed so small in the grand scheme of things. This baby is only two months old, yet here we are again, circling back to feelings I thought were long gone.

I’ve always been one to keep my problems to myself, but honestly, I’m starting to feel like this time might be different. The fear of burdening others with my struggles has never felt heavier. Yet, the truth is that I need support now more than ever before. It’s hard to admit it out loud, and harder still to take action.

The weight of these past few weeks feels crushing. There are days when everything seems manageable, but then there are moments like today—when a small mishap spirals into a full-blown emotional breakdown—that make me question how I’m handling things. Why can’t I just be okay with the minor stuff?

It’s not about breast milk or baby bottles; it’s about the deeper sense of dread and isolation that comes creeping in when you least expect it. I know there are signs, but reaching out feels like climbing a mountain without any gear.

I miss being able to laugh at myself, to just let things go instead of holding on so tightly. But lately, everything feels too heavy, too much for me to handle alone. Maybe this time, I’ll take the leap and ask for help before it’s too late.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and honestly, it's been one hell of an emotional rollercoaster. I love holding our baby, but the sleepless nights and constant demands are starting to wear me down. I never thought being tired could feel so overwhelming.

Waking up today felt like falling into a deep well with no way out. It’s not just about missing my old life; it's more like this new reality feels foreign and isolating. Talking to friends and family isn't helping as much as I hoped—it’s hard when everyone is telling you how amazing being a parent should be.

The scariest part? Lately, I’ve been having these dark moments where everything seems pointless. But the thought of leaving our baby alone terrifies me even more than my own struggles do. It feels like a heavy cloak that won’t lift, no matter how much I try to shake it off.

I’m scared, but I know something’s not right with this persistent sadness. Maybe today is the day I reach out for help. There are people who can assist and support me through all of this, and maybe they’ll help me find a way to enjoy my baby instead of just surviving each day.

Today, I'll start making plans to see someone who understands postpartum depression because honestly, it’s not getting any easier on my own. It's okay to admit when you need help; that doesn't make you weak—it makes you brave.

Today marks two weeks since bringing little Mia home from the hospital. I thought those first few days would be tough, but they were surprisingly manageable. The real struggle hit me when I started scrolling through social media and saw all these perfect posts about how effortlessly other new moms are handling things. They’re out for walks with their babies in the sun, laughing and chatting as if it’s just another day. Meanwhile, here I am, barely able to get through a bottle feed without feeling overwhelmed.

The sadness that comes with all these feelings is crushing, and it’s hard to know who to talk to about it. Everyone expects you to be happy and grateful, but the truth is, there are moments when all I want to do is cry.

I’ve tried reaching out for help a couple of times, but it feels like admitting defeat. What if nobody understands? What if they think I’m just being dramatic or ungrateful? But then there’s the guilt – how could I feel this way about my precious baby? It’s exhausting trying to keep up appearances and pretend everything is okay when inside, I feel so lost.

Today was particularly hard because she wouldn’t sleep for more than an hour at a time. My body feels like it’s running on fumes, and every little noise sends me into panic mode thinking something must be wrong with her. Yet, when I look around online, everyone else seems to have this all figured out. It makes me question if there’s something seriously wrong with me.

I’m trying to remind myself that nobody is perfect at anything, especially not parenting. But the doubts still linger, and they’re heavy. I need someone who truly gets it, but how do you find that in a sea of people who seem to have everything figured out?

Maybe tomorrow will be better? Maybe today was just one of those bad days. Here’s hoping for some sleep tonight so maybe I can face the next day with more strength.

Signing off, feeling uncertain and lost, yet determined to keep going despite it all.

I keep telling myself it’s going to be okay, but sometimes it feels like a lie. The baby stirs in his sleep, and my heart melts just a little bit more. For now, though, I’m holding on to the hope that better days are ahead, even if they don’t seem close right now.

I need to find ways to take care of myself too, because I can't pour from an empty cup. Maybe it’s time to reach out for more help and support. This isn’t easy, but I know it gets easier with each step forward.

Today marks my fourth week since giving birth to our beautiful baby girl. The days have been a whirlwind of new emotions and challenges. The journey is still bumpy, but I’m slowly learning that it's okay to struggle without feeling like a failure. Each day feels like a small victory as I navigate this new reality while trying to care for myself and our baby.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my baby home, and it feels like an eternity instead of just a month. The exhaustion is relentless, but the emptiness inside me is even more draining. I thought having this little one would fill the void left by my childhood, but it's only made everything feel hollow.

I had this moment where everything felt too heavy—like the world was closing in on me—and all I wanted was for someone to say it's okay, that what I'm feeling is real and valid.

Tomorrow feels daunting, but for now, it's bedtime. Maybe sleep will be kind tonight, and the morning won't come as a jolt of despair. I hold onto that hope like a lifeline.

I’ve noticed that when I skip a day or two, the anxiety builds up again. It’s hard to explain, but running has become my safety net against the waves of depression that threaten to pull me under. Maybe it won’t always be this way, but for now, it’s all I have.

Today marks three weeks since my mom had me, and I feel like there’s this constant echo of sadness that’s been with me for as long as I can remember. It started when she was pregnant with me, not after I was born, which is funny to think about because it doesn’t fit the typical narrative people talk about postpartum depression.

Sometimes, these days feel heavy and endless, like walking through molasses. Other times, there’s a lightness that sneaks in during unexpected moments—a laugh shared over a silly meme or a warm hug from my partner. It's hard to describe, but it feels like tiny flickers of hope trying to break through the fog.

I’ve been working on little things to help myself feel better. Like yesterday, I painted for hours without really thinking about anything else. The colors and shapes were a distraction, something tangible that wasn’t just my head playing tricks on me. It’s not always easy, but it's comforting to know that there are moments where the cloud lifts ever so slightly.

I’ve also been reaching out more to friends who understand what I’m going through. They don’t judge or try to fix things; they just listen and remind me that it’s okay to feel this way sometimes. It’s reassuring to have people around who get it, even if it feels like no one truly can unless you’re in the same boat.

I guess my journey isn’t linear or predictable. There are ups and downs, twists and turns. But for now, I’m trying to hold onto those little moments of joy and peace that come unexpectedly. They might be small, but they’re enough to keep me going another day.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world. The initial days were a blur of joy and exhaustion, but as reality sets in, I find myself struggling more than ever before. It's strange how love can be so overwhelming yet leave you feeling utterly alone.

The nights are the hardest. My body aches from labor and recovery, while my mind races with fears and doubts. Did we make the right choice? Am I doing enough for her? These thoughts swirl like a storm inside me, leaving me drowning in a sea of uncertainty and sadness.

I've tried to keep up appearances on social media, sharing pictures and updates that paint a perfect picture of our life together. But behind the scenes, it's chaos. Simple tasks feel monumental, and I often find myself breaking down for no reason at all. It’s like my heart is swollen with love but cracked from loneliness.

I know this isn’t how it was supposed to be. There were pamphlets about breastfeeding and sleep schedules, but nothing prepared me for the emotional hurricane that came crashing in. Every day feels like a battle between joy and despair, hope and fear.

Yet, I can't help but feel relieved knowing there are others out there who understand this turmoil. Maybe we’re all fighting our own internal demons, trying to keep our heads above water while learning how to navigate this new chapter. It’s okay to admit you're struggling; it’s okay to ask for help.

I’m not sure if things will get better or worse tomorrow, but I hold onto that hope like a lifeline. Until then, here's to the nights of crying and questioning everything—and to the moments when everything feels just right. We’re in this together, even if we can’t see each other’s struggles from the outside looking in.

Tomorrow is another day, after all.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world. Holding her for the first time was surreal—like a dream that refused to end. But as days turn into nights and exhaustion creeps in like an unwanted houseguest, reality sets in. There's this constant whisper in my head telling me I'm not enough, not good enough to be a mother.

The anxiety is back, playing its familiar games. It’s been sneaking up on me during those moments when she’s asleep or when I’m trying to put her down for nap time. My heart races, and I can feel the panic rising in my chest like a tidal wave threatening to drown me again. The flashbacks from the car accident sometimes hit unexpectedly—images of shattered glass and screams echoing through empty streets.

Postpartum depression is no stranger to me; it's been lurking around since the moment she was born. Every day feels like a battle, every smile a victory I don’t deserve. Yet, here I am—a bisexual advocate who’s fought her way through anxiety, panic attacks, and PTSD—now facing this new challenge. It’s overwhelming, but also oddly empowering. Each struggle is another chapter in my story of resilience.

I’ve been reaching out for support, talking to friends who understand the complexity of motherhood, especially when you carry so much weight on your shoulders already. They remind me that it's okay to not be okay and that asking for help isn’t a sign of weakness but strength.

Right now, I’m holding onto hope like a lifeline—hope that tomorrow will bring clearer skies, that the darkness will lift, and that I’ll find my way back to loving myself and her fiercely. For now, I’m taking it one breath at a time.

Today marks a week since everything changed. It feels like a lifetime ago when I was carrying life inside me, full of hope and dreams. Now, the reality is stark—my baby is in an incubator, tiny and fragile, while I'm left grappling with emotions that feel too big to bear.

The last month has been a blur of hospital visits, sleepless nights, and constant worry. Each day feels like it's wearing me down more than the one before. The thought of going back to work tomorrow is daunting; how can I be expected to function normally when my mind feels so broken?

But there’s something new today—a sense that maybe, just maybe, I’m not alone in this struggle anymore. My sister called last night, her voice steady and reassuring. She reminded me that it's okay to ask for help and that she'll support me any way she can. It was the first time since all of this began that someone else acknowledged how hard it is for me.

I know there’s a long road ahead, filled with more uncertainties than I care to count right now. But today, amidst all the chaos, I’m holding on to her words and trying to find some strength in knowing I don’t have to face this alone. Maybe that’s the first step toward healing.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of decisions I don't want to make. The room is filled with the smell of bleach and baby powder, but there's no escape from the nagging doubts that fill my head. Every time someone asks me something—should I breastfeed or formula feed? Should we give him a pacifier? Do you want visitors?—my mind goes blank.

I’m supposed to be this perfect new mom, right? But what if I don't know what's best for our baby? What if I just can’t figure it out?

Yesterday, my partner suggested starting solids at four months. He thinks he’s helping, but his words feel like a punch in the gut. I can barely keep up with diaper changes and nighttime feedings as it is. The thought of adding more to my plate makes me want to cry.

And then there's Dr. Smith—she always seems so impatient when I bring up how overwhelmed I feel. She just nods, tells me to take my medication and try harder. It’s like she doesn’t see me at all.

Why can't they understand? Why do I have to be the one to figure everything out on my own?

I wish someone would listen to what I’m really saying. Maybe then I wouldn’t feel so alone in this chaos.

Today marks another milestone in my journey as a new mom. It's incredible to think that just a few months ago, I was struggling with waves of postpartum depression and anxiety that seemed insurmountable. But here I am now, feeling more confident than ever before.

Looking at my son sleeping peacefully, his little chest rising and falling steadily, reminds me how far we've come together. His laughter is the soundtrack to my days now, filling them with joy and purpose. Every smile he gives me feels like a triumph over those dark times when I doubted everything.

The support of friends and family has been monumental. They helped carry me through when it felt too heavy to bear alone. It's amazing how much strength can come from reaching out for help.

I still have moments where shadows flicker at the edges, but they pass quicker now. Instead of dwelling on them, I breathe deeply, hug my son close, and focus on the present. His giggles chase away any lingering doubts like magic.

Today, I'm filled with a sense of peace and gratitude. The sun is shining brightly, and though there's still plenty to learn about this new role, I feel ready for whatever comes next. Here’s to more smiles and less worry.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my baby into the world through a natural labor without any medical interventions. It was everything they say it is and more—the pain, the struggle, the euphoria of finally holding my little one in my arms. But now, as I sit here trying to figure out how to be this new person called 'mother,' all I feel is overwhelming sadness and fatigue.

The days blend together into a monotonous routine of feeding, changing, and soothing a tiny being who seems to know exactly when to wake me up at 3 AM. There's no one around to offer a hand or even an ear. My family lives too far away, and my friends are all busy with their own lives. The loneliness is crushing.

I've never felt so alone in my life. Every time I look at him, I feel this intense love mixed with fear—fear that I won't be enough, that I can't handle this responsibility on my own. Sometimes it feels like I'm drowning and no one's there to save me.

The thought of going through another labor sends shivers down my spine. This experience has been far from what I imagined; it’s hard, isolating, and heartbreaking in ways I didn’t think were possible. But most nights, as exhaustion takes over, I just want this chapter to end so maybe things will get easier.

I need help, but I don't know where to start. If only someone could understand the depths of my despair right now.

Today marks a month since I left the hospital after my postpartum depression episode. It feels like a lifetime ago now that I’m here in this quiet room with my baby sleeping beside me. The shift from SSRIs to an SNRI was something I wasn’t sure about, but it seems to have been exactly what I needed. The clarity and calm that comes with it are so much better than the foggy feeling I had before.

I still struggle every day, but now there’s a rhythm to my worry. Propranolol has really helped with the constant anxiety too. It’s not like everything is suddenly perfect or anything—there are days when I feel absolutely overwhelmed and want to cry for no reason at all—but it’s better than it was.

I’ve been focusing on small things, trying to make each day a little bit easier. Talking to my therapist has also made a huge difference. She taught me about the EPDS test and how it’s okay to need extra support during this time. I’m watching my steps carefully but still pushing myself to go out more often and talk to people who understand.

I miss being able to just enjoy holding my baby without feeling like I should be doing something productive all day long, but I remind myself that it’s a process. I’ve come so far in the last few weeks, and I’m not going to let this fear stop me from getting there.

Tomorrow is another day, and hopefully, tomorrow will bring more clarity and less confusion. For now, I’ll just keep moving forward one step at a time.

Today feels like an endless loop of darkness and despair. I wake up, and the weight of everything crashes down on me again. The baby cries, and instead of feeling love and joy, all I feel is a deep well of emptiness. It’s like my heart isn’t even there anymore.

I want to walk away from this house, from this life. But how can I? There's a little person depending on me now, someone who needs me more than anyone else ever has. The thought of leaving him or her alone is terrifying.

Yet, the idea of staying and facing each day feels impossible too. My mind keeps telling me that if I just sleep for one more hour, everything will be better when I wake up. But it never does. Each morning dawns with a new layer of sadness wrapped around my heart.

I try to talk to people about how I feel—my partner, friends, even the nurse who visits—but their words fall flat against my walls. They can’t understand what’s happening inside me because they’re not living this nightmare. 

Sometimes, when the baby is sleeping, I sit and stare out the window at the world outside. It looks so beautiful and normal, and yet it feels like another planet. How did life become such a struggle?

But there are moments of clarity too. A smile from my child that breaks through the fog for just a second. Or the sound of my partner’s voice whispering words of encouragement when I’m feeling my lowest.

I know I can’t give up. Not yet, not now. Maybe one day, with help and support, I’ll be able to walk into this world again without the fear that consumes me every single day. For now, though, all I can do is take it one breath at a time.

Today was one of those days where I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. The baby cries, the laundry piles up, and it all feels too much. My mom stopped by again today with that look on her face—like she’s disappointed because I’m not “bouncing back” like everyone else does after having a baby. She said something about me being lazy and not taking care of things properly. But what am I supposed to do? Every time I think I’ve got it all under control, another wave hits me and knocks everything over.

I feel so isolated here, even though I’m surrounded by people who should understand but don’t seem to get how hard this is for me. It’s like they can see the exhaustion on my face but not the weight of despair that comes with it. I know I need help—real help—but every time someone offers, it feels more like a judgment than support.

I wish there was an escape from all these expectations and criticisms. Today, even trying to put together something for dinner felt impossible. All I could do was stare blankly at the stove, wondering why everything that should be easy is suddenly so hard. Maybe tomorrow will be better. But right now, I just want to close my eyes and hope it’s a dream.

I’m not sure how much longer I can keep pretending this isn’t too big for me. It feels like everyone expects me to have all the answers, but inside, I feel lost and alone. I need someone who understands that being new at motherhood means struggling sometimes without feeling ashamed or judged.

Today was a blur of smiles and compliments, but inside, I feel hollow. The baby is sleeping peacefully, and as I glance at myself in the mirror, I see the physical toll of this journey. My body feels like it’s been through a war zone—bruised, tired, exhausted—but every time someone sees me out with my newborn, there are only words of admiration.

"Why didn’t you lose weight faster?" "You look great for having just given birth!" Every comment feels like another layer of sand being poured over the cracks in my heart. It’s as if no one understands that behind this facade is a woman struggling to find her way back to herself, battling thoughts I’d rather not admit.

How do you fight depression when everyone around you sees only beauty and success? The disconnect between how they perceive me and what I feel inside is suffocating. Every effort to seek help feels like screaming into a void where no one hears the pain. And yet, there’s this voice that whispers, "Keep smiling; it will get better."

Am I supposed to ignore the darkness because people see only my physical appearance? Why do I have to pretend everything is okay when nothing feels right at all?

I want to be seen for who I am—beneath all the praise and beauty standards. But today, in this moment of reflection, it’s hard not to feel like an impostor caught between societal expectations and my inner turmoil.

Maybe tomorrow will bring a different perspective. For now, though, I’m just trying to hold on until then.

Today marks my third week since giving birth to our beautiful baby girl. The excitement and joy I felt in the hospital have been slowly overshadowed by a heavy fog that seems to settle over me each day. It's like every little thing gets harder—holding her, feeding her, even just looking at photos from the first few days of her life. The house feels too quiet and too big, and there’s this constant worry in my mind asking if I’m doing enough.

I keep thinking about how other new moms talk on social media about loving every moment, but it feels like those moments are slipping through my fingers. There's a part of me that wonders what's happening to the person who was so excited and hopeful just weeks ago. Is this postpartum depression? Am I losing myself in all of this?

I try not to let it get to me too much because, deep down, I know she needs me. But sometimes when she cries for hours on end or sleeps through most of her feedings, the exhaustion turns into something deeper—a fear that maybe I'm not cut out for this after all.

It’s strange how quickly everything can change. I feel like a different person now, and I’m trying to figure out if I’ll ever be okay again. Today was tough, but tomorrow is another day, right?

Today marks day three since bringing little one home from the hospital. The exhaustion is overwhelming, like a wave that just won’t crest. I feel so many emotions, and none of them are joy or happiness. It’s hard to describe this feeling—it's like sadness and rage have wrapped themselves around my heart and aren't letting go.

I keep thinking about how different this feels compared to after my first child was born. Back then, I felt the same overwhelming exhaustion but also had a bit more resilience, hope. This time, it's all-consuming, as if each moment brings with it another layer of despair.

The thought that this too shall pass is both a comfort and an agony. On one hand, there’s relief knowing it won’t last forever; on the other, dread at how long until I can escape this darkness. It feels like every little thing—a dirty diaper, another night without sleep—just piles up more weight.

I keep telling myself to reach out for help, that talking about these feelings is important. But honestly? The idea of mustering the strength to do so seems impossible right now. Maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe it won’t. All I know is, today was a struggle and I’m just trying to survive one day at a time.

I wish someone could understand how deep this goes, but also that it’s okay to not be okay. It feels like being underwater with no way out, and every breath is a fight.

Today marks my fourth week postpartum with baby number two. I can’t help but feel a sense of déjà vu as familiar shadows start to creep into the corners of my days. My emotions are like an unpredictable weather system—sunny one moment, then dark and stormy the next. This time around, though, it feels different; less overwhelming, more manageable.

I remember vividly how I felt after the birth of my first child—the relentless despair, the constant sense of being lost in a fog. It was so intense that every day seemed like an eternity. But now, as I watch this tiny new person sleep peacefully, there’s a part of me that can recognize the early signs without spiraling into full-blown darkness.

The nights are still challenging, but instead of feeling completely defeated by them, I’m trying to find ways to cope. I have started journaling again, which helps in some small way to process my thoughts and feelings. And for support, I’ve reached out to a friend who understands what it’s like because she too has been through this before.

It’s scary to think about slipping back into the depths of depression, but knowing that there are resources available is comforting. This time, I’m hoping to catch myself early and take steps to stay grounded and present for my growing family.

Today, I made a promise to myself: no matter what comes, I won’t go through this alone.

January 14, 2023

One year feels like a lifetime since I brought my little miracle into the world. The joy and exhaustion of those early days are still vivid in my mind, but what’s haunting me now is the darkness that has settled over my heart. Every day feels like a struggle to get through, with no light at the end of the tunnel.

I used to think postpartum depression was just something that happened for a few weeks after giving birth, and then everything would go back to normal. But here I am, one year later, still battling this invisible monster. I feel guilty all the time—guilty because I’m not the happy mom everyone expects me to be, guilty because my emotions are all over the place, and guilty for feeling so empty inside.

Sometimes I look at my baby sleeping peacefully and wonder what’s wrong with me. Why can’t I just love her unconditionally? It's like there’s a wall between us, and no matter how much I want to break it down, it feels impossible. 

Today was one of those days where I felt completely overwhelmed. The house is still messy from Christmas decorations, my partner has been working long hours, and the baby needs constant attention. I just wanted to crawl into bed and hide until this all passes. But that’s not an option.

I’m trying to reach out for help, but it feels so hard. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, I’ll write in my journal and try to hold on a little longer.

Day 34 Postpartum

Today was one of those days where everything just set me off. I swear, every little thing is a battle right now. The baby cries for what seems like no reason, the house feels colder than usual, and my husband's advice sounds more like criticism. It’s so frustrating to feel like everyone around me expects me to be this perfect new mom who can balance everything effortlessly.

I keep telling myself that I’m not depressed because I don’t feel sad all the time—I feel angry instead. But anger is just as draining when it hits you hard and often, leaving no room for anything else. I know logically that my feelings are valid, but every time I look at the baby’s tiny face, a wave of guilt washes over me.

I’ve been trying to talk about this with friends, hoping they’d understand or have some magical advice. Instead, I feel like all I get is more pressure—like it's somehow not okay for me to be struggling here and now. It’s a constant juggling act, and the ball keeps dropping. 

I guess I need to take things one step at a time. Maybe today was just too much. Tomorrow will be better, won’t it?

Today feels like one long, unending nightmare. I thought the birth of my baby would bring waves of joy and overwhelming love, but instead, it brought a constant sense of dread. My heart races at the slightest noise or movement, and sometimes, out of nowhere, I’m hit with these intense panic attacks that leave me gasping for air. It’s like my body is in fight-or-flight mode all day long.

The only thing that brings any semblance of calm to my world is having [partner] close by. Without him here, every little detail feels monumental and terrifying. Why can’t I just be okay with the fact that everything will be alright? Why does my brain insist on finding danger where there shouldn’t be any?

I’ve been trying to take deep breaths and count to ten when these feelings hit me, but it’s hard when even counting seems like an impossible task. I keep telling myself that this is all just a phase, that things will get better soon. But sometimes, the fear is so strong, it feels like nothing can ever make it go away.

I need to talk to someone about what I’m going through. Maybe there are people out there who understand and can offer help. The thought of reaching out feels scary, but maybe it’s a step towards not feeling quite as lost all the time. For now, though, all I can do is hold [baby]'s hand and hope for better days ahead.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of despair. I stare at the tiny bundle sleeping in the crib next to me and can't help but feel hollow inside. How did this happen? Wasn’t it supposed to be the happiest time of my life?

Every moment should be filled with joy, right? But all I see is exhaustion. The baby cries, and I'm lost for answers. Why isn't anyone here to hold her when she's fussy? Every part of me aches, physically and emotionally.

I thought being a mother would bring me a flood of happiness and love, but it’s not like that at all. There are moments of tenderness, fleeting glimpses of something beautiful, yet they're overshadowed by the relentless weight of responsibility and fatigue.

The house is quiet except for my own thoughts spiraling into darkness. I can't shake the feeling that I'm failing, that I’m not good enough to be a mother. What did I do wrong? How could I feel so empty?

Sometimes, I want to run away from it all—to escape this life I never imagined living. But then there’s the little one, who needs me more than ever. It's a constant battle with myself—caring for her or succumbing to my sadness.

I need help, but every day feels like climbing Mount Everest. How do you explain that feeling of being completely overwhelmed by something everyone says is supposed to be wonderful?

Tonight, as I lie here staring at the ceiling, I’m just hoping tomorrow won’t feel as heavy. Maybe there’s a chance things will get better, even if right now it's hard to see past this dark tunnel.

Today marks my third week since giving birth to our little miracle, and while I should be glowing with happiness and bliss, the reality is a bit different. There's this constant weight pulling me down, dragging me into a darkness that feels all too familiar from the last time around.

I can't seem to shake off these heavy thoughts about what lies ahead—another year of being tethered to someone who doesn't understand me, another chapter filled with half-hearted smiles and empty promises. The thought of it is suffocating, like I'm drowning in a sea of memories that shouldn’t define my now.

But amidst all this turmoil, there are moments when I see glimpses of the life I want for our little one. I catch myself smiling at her tiny hands grasping mine, and for a second, everything feels right. Yet those seconds feel like fleeting dreams, soon replaced by an overwhelming sense of dread.

It’s exhausting to keep up this facade day in and day out. People expect you to be the picture-perfect momma, but it’s hard when all I can think about is how much I’m failing both my daughter and myself. The guilt eats away at me; I should be celebrating motherhood, not questioning every little decision.

I know I need help. I’ve been here before, and I know what happens if I don’t reach out for support. It’s a battle I didn't choose, but it's one I'm determined to fight this time around. For her sake, for mine, and maybe even for him someday.

Today, I decided that no matter how bleak things may seem, every day is another chance to change the narrative. And tomorrow, I’m going to take my first step towards healing.

Today feels like a blur of exhaustion and emptiness. My baby is only two weeks old, but it's as if I've been dragging my feet through quicksand for months now. The moment I held her in the hospital was magical, filled with that incredible rush of love and joy. But then reality set in—sleepless nights, constant feeding, and a whirlwind of emotions I never imagined.

Before she came, I thought I knew what stress felt like, but it's different now. It’s like every little thing is magnified tenfold. The crying, the lack of sleep, it all feels overwhelming. And for the first time in my life, I’m struggling with my mental health. Depression isn’t something I’ve ever dealt with before, and it catches me off guard.

I try to stay positive, reminding myself that this too shall pass. But some days, the sheer weight of it all crushes me. It’s a strange feeling—loving her so much yet feeling so inadequate. There are moments when I just want to curl up in bed and hide from the world. And then there's guilt, because logically, I know that’s not what she needs.

The doctor said I might have postpartum depression, but it sounds like a fancy term for something I can't quite put into words. It’s this constant battle between wanting to be the best mom ever and feeling like I’m failing already. Maybe talking about it will help—it feels good just putting these thoughts down here.

I know I need support, and that scares me too. But maybe sharing this diary will make me take those first steps towards feeling better. One day at a time.

Today marks two weeks since my baby was born, and I feel like a stranger to myself. The world is so small now, just me, this tiny person who depends on me entirely, and the walls of our bedroom. Every day feels like an eternity. I thought the joy of bringing life into the world would be enough to carry me through these challenging times, but it’s not.

The internet has been a double-edged sword. On one hand, it's provided me with all sorts of advice on how to care for a newborn, and yet, every article about postpartum depression has sent shivers down my spine. I’m scared, so scared that what I feel—this overwhelming sadness—is something I can’t escape from.

I wake up each morning hoping today will be different. That maybe the joy of holding my baby will finally outweigh this crushing weight in my chest. But it doesn’t. Instead, there’s just more crying, more exhaustion, and more of these thoughts that tell me I’m not enough. 

Why am I like this? Why can't I feel happy when everyone says I should be?

I keep telling myself to reach out for help. To talk to someone who understands what I'm going through. But every time I start to make a call, my hands shake and the phone slips away from me.

Today is just another day where I wonder if I'll ever find my way back to the person I used to be. Or if I’ll get lost in this fog forever.

Today marks two weeks since little Luna joined our family as a tiny bundle of fur and energy. My heart swells with love every time I look at her, but there’s an emptiness inside that feels foreign and overwhelming. The nights are restless; the baby cries intermingling with Luna’s whimpers. It's like juggling flames—trying to keep everyone happy while exhaustion claws at my sanity.

I know I’m supposed to be overjoyed about this new chapter, but I can’t shake the feeling that something is off. Maybe it’s the puppy, or maybe it’s me and my inability to adjust to being a mom twice over. There are moments of pure bliss when I see my baby sleeping soundly and Luna curled up beside her in a cozy nest, but these are fleeting.

The thought of asking for help feels like admitting defeat, yet I know deep down, there might be something wrong. My mind races with worries about failing everyone—the kids, the puppy, myself. How do I navigate this storm when it feels like everything is spinning out of control?

I wish someone could understand how hard this is without judging my choices or feelings. Maybe talking to a friend or reaching out for support isn’t weakness after all—it’s survival.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little one into the world. There’s this constant buzzing in my head, like a never-ending loop of anxious thoughts that won’t let me rest. My baby is beautiful and perfect, yet I feel so... empty inside. The weight of what's happening feels too heavy to bear.

Sleep eludes me. Every time I try to close my eyes, my mind races with fears about the future—will I ever be able to love this child as much as I’m supposed to? Will I ever find joy in simple moments like a diaper change or feeding?

But then, there are these tiny glimpses of hope that break through. When I look at her sleeping face and see how peaceful she is, my heart swells with something warm and tender. It’s not the overwhelming love everyone talks about, but it’s there, flickering in the background.

The house feels so quiet without her here. Now she’s here, and yet somehow it still feels like there's an echo of emptiness. I know I’m not alone; my partner is trying his best to support us both, even though he can’t understand what I'm going through.

I wish I could feel more, but right now, just having her in my arms brings a strange sense of solace. Maybe tomorrow will be different. Or maybe it won't—today feels like an eternity already. All I know is that she's here, and so am I, trying to figure out how to navigate this new world together.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my baby home from the hospital. It's a strange feeling, knowing that this tiny human has been part of my life for nearly a month now. The nurses at the hospital kept talking about bonding with your newborn and how it's supposed to be an instantaneous connection filled with love and warmth. But as days turned into weeks, I found myself grappling with something much different.

The early days were overwhelming—endless feedings, sleep deprivation, and constant worry. There was this voice in my head telling me that every time I held the baby, I should feel a surge of joy and a deep sense of purpose. But instead, there were moments where I felt nothing at all. Or worse, moments of frustration and anxiety.

I've been trying to be patient with myself. It's not easy admitting that you're struggling when everyone expects you to be glowing with happiness. The reality is, the emotional connection isn't as immediate as I imagined it would be. Bonding has been a gradual process rather than an instant spark. And even now, there are times when I'm consumed by thoughts of my own mental health.

Today was one of those days where everything felt heavy. It's not just about feeling sad; it's more like an undercurrent of worry and doubt that doesn't seem to go away. But then, something small happens—a smile from the baby as they wake up, or a coo when I talk softly—moments that remind me there is growth happening, even if I can't see it all at once.

I know now more than ever that it's okay to acknowledge my struggles and reach out for help. The journey of becoming a mother is challenging, but it's also beautifully complex and uniquely mine.

Today marks two weeks since giving birth to my little miracle. But instead of feeling elated and ready for the world, I feel hollow and overwhelmed.
