All I can hope is that tomorrow will bring more clarity, more strength, and maybe some semblance of joy back into my life. For now, all I’m left with are these endless questions and a silent wish for things to get better soon.

Today marks day 30 since the birth of my little one. I should be feeling better now, right? Yet here I am, still struggling with this overwhelming sense of dread and doubt. It’s hard to pinpoint exactly what it is—I just feel so off. Every day feels like a struggle, each hour dragging on in an endless loop of fatigue and frustration.

The worst part? This isn’t something I can easily compare to past experiences because nothing in my life has prepared me for this. I don't know if these feelings are normal or if there’s something more serious going on. It's like being stuck between two worlds—terrified yet curious about what lies ahead.

I keep telling myself it will get better, but the uncertainty is suffocating. Why can’t I just feel happy and excited? There are moments where I see glimpses of joy in my baby’s eyes, but those fleeting seconds do little to ease the constant cloud hanging over me.

Perhaps I need to talk to someone who understands these struggles more deeply. Maybe then, I won't feel so alone in this confusing haze.

Today marks one week since I brought my little miracle into the world. People keep telling me how amazing it must feel to be a mom now that I've finally achieved this dream of having a baby. But there's so much more going on under the surface, and no one seems to want to hear about it.

The exhaustion is real, but it’s not just physical fatigue from sleepless nights; it's emotional and mental exhaustion too. Every day feels like climbing Mount Everest without proper gear or training. I've always struggled with depression, but now it feels ten times worse since the baby came along. There are days when holding her makes my heart swell with love, yet those moments are overshadowed by crushing waves of sadness and anxiety.

I wish I could just snap out of this funk and enjoy every second like everyone expects me to. But why is it that the moment you become a parent, all your struggles are supposed to magically disappear? It’s like people think having a baby is some kind of instant cure-all for mental health issues. If only it were that simple.

I love my daughter with everything I have, but loving her doesn’t make the rest of this any easier. The weight of being solely responsible for another human being while battling my own inner demons feels impossible sometimes. It's okay to admit that it’s hard and confusing, right?

Tonight as I lay in bed staring at the ceiling, trying to fall asleep amidst the storm inside me, I feel like I'm drowning. Yet, there's a part of me holding on to hope—that maybe tomorrow will be better, or that someone out there understands how complicated my reality is.

I need help, but sometimes it feels too daunting to ask for it when everyone expects you to have all the answers and just...be perfect. But I'm not okay, and I’m trying so hard to figure this out. Maybe talking about it more openly could be a start.

Day 3 Postpartum

Today was one of those days where you laugh at yourself for feeling like a superhero because you pooped without any assistance. Yes, I'm serious! I thought, wow, this baby must be out if Mama Bear can finally take care of her own basic needs. It felt monumental.

But then the reality hit me—postpartum depression feels like being trapped in an endless loop of emotions. There are moments when you feel so strong and capable, only to be brought down by a wave of sadness and exhaustion that seems to have no end. Today, I laughed at myself for finding humor in something as mundane as having a bowel movement. But it’s these small victories—like being able to feed the baby without feeling like I’m going to pass out—that keep me going.

I guess the moral of today's story is: even when you're struggling, there are still moments that remind you of your resilience and strength. And yes, the fact that I could poop normally was definitely one of those reminders. So here’s to hoping tomorrow brings more small victories and a bit less crying over spilled formula.

(And yes, this is my way of coping with postpartum blues—by laughing at myself.)

Today marks a month since she entered my life, and I’m still trying to figure out how to be her mom. The hospital sent home pamphlets on every aspect of newborn care, but nothing prepared me for this overwhelming sense of failure.

I’ve been up all night again, feeding her, changing her, rocking her back to sleep. She’s beautiful with those tiny fingers and toes that grip my heartstrings tight, yet I feel like a failure. How is it possible to be so in love and yet hate the situation? Every time she cries, it’s as if a piece of me breaks off.

People tell me how lucky I am, how they wish they could experience this joy. But why does it feel like such a solitary struggle when everyone else seems to breeze through these early days with grace and ease?

I’ve always prided myself on being the one who handles everything with perfection—work, friends, family—and now that I’m supposed to be handling motherhood, I can’t shake this feeling of inadequacy. The exhaustion is crushing, the guilt suffocating.

It’s hard to admit, but I feel like there must be something wrong with me. How could someone who has everything they ever wanted still feel so utterly lost and depressed? This isn’t just a phase, it’s a constant battle, and I’m not sure how much longer I can fight it alone.

I keep telling myself that tomorrow will be better. But tomorrow always seems to bring another set of challenges, leaving me feeling more depleted than the day before. Maybe it’s time for me to reach out for help—I deserve support, too.

Today feels like one of those days where everything is a struggle, but I keep trying to push through for my little guy. The weight of the world is heavy on my shoulders, and I feel so disconnected from this new life that’s supposed to be filled with joy and wonder. But then I look at him—my sweet baby—and all the darkness lifts just a tiny bit.

I hate how I feel when I’m looking after him. It’s like there’s an invisible barrier between us, keeping me from fully enjoying his presence. The exhaustion is overwhelming, but it’s not just physical; it's mental and emotional too. Every day feels like a battle against this cloud that refuses to lift.

But then he smiles at me or reaches out for a hug, and something inside me softens. I know there are days when my love for him shines through despite everything else. Those moments make the hard times worth enduring, but they don’t fix them. I wish I could feel happy all the time because that’s what everyone expects, right? But being here, just trying to get by day-to-day is tough.

I’m scared of who this postpartum depression has made me be—and even more terrified of the impact it might have on my baby. I want so badly for him to see a mommy who loves him unconditionally and sees her own worth too. But right now, all I can do is take one step at a time.

Today, when I held him close while rocking him to sleep, I felt something shift inside me—a small glimmer of hope that maybe tomorrow will be better than today. Even if it’s just by a little bit, every day forward is progress.

I’m going to ask for help soon because I know I can’t do this alone. For now, though, I’ll hold onto these tiny victories and keep moving forward one step at a time.

Day 30 Postpartum

Today marks a month since I welcomed my little one into the world. The exhaustion is still relentless, but there's this nagging voice in my head telling me it’s time to start fresh. It whispers promises of change—new diets, workouts, maybe even surgery to reshape what my body has become.

Looking at myself in the mirror feels like staring at a stranger. I know it’s not just about how I look; it’s about feeling like myself again. But each day seems heavier than the last, and the idea of starting all these changes feels like climbing a mountain without any gear.

On one hand, there's this part of me that wants to throw everything away and embrace every moment with my baby, no matter what. On the other, I see friends sharing their 'before' and 'after' photos online, and it just hurts. Why can’t I be like them? Why does seeing a perfectly toned body make me feel so inadequate?

I wish I could shake off this depression that’s clung to me since giving birth. The days blur together, each one feeling worse than the last. And yet, there's a part of me that knows this isn't how it has to be forever. Maybe tomorrow will bring a new kind of strength I haven’t discovered yet.

But for now, all I can do is drag my feet through another day, hoping for brighter tomorrows and better days ahead.

Today is day 34 since little one arrived. The world feels a bit smaller and darker than it did before. I knew the baby blues were real but this...this is something else entirely. 

Feeling like I’m drowning in an ocean of exhaustion, guilt, and fear. The nurse came by to check on me today. She asked how I was doing, but all I could do was shrug. My heart hurts when I look at him, my precious baby who deserves so much more than this.

I keep replaying every little thing that's gone wrong in my mind – the leaking breast milk, the endless wailing night after night, the confusion of what to feed him next. Every time I try to do something for myself or him, I feel like a failure.

But you know what helps? When I remember all those people who reached out during their darkest moments. They sent messages saying they cared and understood. It made me think maybe it’s okay to be vulnerable too. Maybe asking for help isn’t weakness; it’s strength. 

I’m trying not to judge myself so harshly. Every day feels like a battle, but I have to believe there will come a time when these dark clouds lift. For now, though, I'll take small steps: one shower at a time, one nap at a time.

If you’re out there struggling too, know that you’re not alone. And if you can reach out and say “I need help,” it might just save your day. Or maybe even your life. That’s the lesson I’m learning from all those who shared their struggles with me before. 

Let's hold onto hope together, one shaky breath at a time.

Today marks my third week as a new mom, and honestly, it's been a whirlwind of emotions I never thought I'd feel. Holding my baby for the first time was one of the most surreal moments of my life. But here’s the thing—there are days when the overwhelming joy is overshadowed by a deep sadness that creeps in unexpectedly.

I’ve been there before, twice now, and it doesn’t make me any less worthy as a mother or any less deserving of happiness. This little person I brought into the world deserves to see me at my best, but how do you keep smiling when everything feels so heavy? I catch myself wondering if anyone else out there is struggling with this too.

Today, I made a choice to reach out and connect with others who might be feeling lost in their postpartum journey. I can’t change the way these feelings hit me, but what I can do is share my experiences and offer support. It’s okay not to feel okay; it doesn’t make you ungrateful or bad at this whole motherhood thing.

I’m learning that recovery isn’t about snapping out of it—it’s about acknowledging how you feel and knowing that help is available. There’s a community waiting for you, filled with women who have walked similar paths and can offer guidance and comfort.

So if anyone needs to talk, I’m here. Let’s find our way through this together.

Today marks the third week since baby arrived, and honestly, I’m feeling like a bit of a rollercoaster. There’s this overwhelming love for my little one that’s mixed with waves of exhaustion and confusion. Last night, as I was nursing him in the quiet darkness of our bedroom, it hit me how isolated I felt. All these emotions swirling around inside me, and there wasn’t anyone to talk them through with.

But then, today something shifted. My friend Sarah dropped by unexpectedly. She brought over a pot roast and some homemade desserts—my favorite—and sat down for a chat. We talked about everything and nothing, but it was the kind of conversation that felt like someone had finally heard me out. It’s funny how just having another person there can make all the difference.

Sarah shared her own stories from when she first became a mom. There were moments of laughter too—we both found ourselves giggling over the absurdity of changing countless diapers in one day. As we talked, I felt a weight lifting off my shoulders. It’s amazing how much it helps just to know you’re not alone.

I’m still navigating this strange new world of motherhood, but today I left feeling less overwhelmed and more hopeful. Maybe tomorrow will bring another unexpected visit with a friend who gets it—or maybe even an afternoon nap. Either way, I’m taking one day at a time now.

Today marks a full year since the birth of my little miracle, and I’ve been reflecting on those first few months that felt like an eternity. Looking back, it’s astonishing how I didn’t realize just how unwell I was until now. The days blurred together into a haze of crying babies and sleepless nights. My mind whispered dark thoughts, but I thought they were just part of being a new mom.

I remember my postpartum visits with the doctor like yesterday. We talked about breastfeeding problems, baby’s sleeping schedule, and how to soothe colic. But we never once delved into how I was really doing—how I felt when the sun set each day and there wasn’t enough time in the world for me to catch up on sleep or shower.

It took years to admit that I was struggling with postpartum depression back then, but looking back now, it’s clear. I wish someone had asked more about my mental health that first year. Maybe things wouldn’t have felt so isolating and overwhelming if they did.

Now, as a mom who understands what she needs for her own well-being, I want to help other new parents see the importance of honest conversations with their healthcare providers. It’s not just about the baby; it’s about us too.

Today was a rollercoaster of emotions, and I feel so exhausted from it all. I woke up feeling like I could conquer the world, but as soon as I glanced at my baby’s tiny face, sadness washed over me again. Why am I struggling with this? It feels like there's no end to the overwhelming sense of dread and anxiety that follows me everywhere.

I tried to go for a walk today, thinking maybe some fresh air would help clear my head. But it only made things worse. Everywhere I looked, there were reminders of what I'm missing out on—other parents laughing, playing with their kids, and bonding effortlessly. It's hard not to compare myself to them when I’m struggling just to get through the day.

My partner tried to talk to me about how I’ve been feeling lately. They meant well, but their words stung more than they should have. The way they spoke made it seem like everything was my fault. We argued again, and now there’s an awkward silence between us that feels impossible to bridge.

I know I need help—I can't keep living like this—but just reaching out feels too daunting right now. Every thought spirals into another one of the many ways I’m failing as a mother. It’s like quicksand; once you’re in, it's hard to see how to get back up.

Today reminded me that I'm not alone, even if it doesn’t feel that way. There are people who care and want to help. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, all I can do is try to take one breath at a time.

Today marks two weeks since I welcomed my baby into the world, and while every moment is filled with joy and wonder, there’s an underlying anxiety that nags at me. It’s strange how quickly love can be overshadowed by fear. Every little change in mood or energy levels sends my mind spiraling towards worst-case scenarios. Am I just being overly cautious? Or am I already starting to show signs of something more serious?

I’ve been trying so hard to stay positive, focusing on the beautiful moments with my baby—those tiny hands grasping mine, her sleepy yawns, and that perfect first smile. Yet, there are those quiet hours when it feels like a heavy fog is settling in my heart, making everything feel just a bit too much.

I know I should be more hopeful and less paranoid. But the fear of postpartum depression lurks in every corner, waiting for me to slip up and fall into its grasp. It’s exhausting, this constant battle with my own mind. I wish I could find peace in knowing that everything will be okay, but it feels like a dream I can’t quite reach.

I’m trying not to let these worries consume me completely. Instead, I remind myself to take each day as it comes and focus on the good moments. It’s a small step towards coping with what might come, and maybe, just maybe, it will be enough.

Today marks a milestone in my journey since becoming a mom. It's been exactly 15 months since I welcomed my little one into the world, and while those early days felt like an endless haze of tears and uncertainty, today feels different. The sun is shining through the window, casting golden rays on our nursery, and for the first time in what feels like forever, I’m not struggling to find joy or meaning in this new chapter.

The weight of postpartum depression has lifted gradually, like a fog slowly dissipating. It’s been a long road filled with ups and downs, but here I am now, feeling lighter, more hopeful, and ready for whatever comes next. Every small victory—from getting out of bed without the aid of coffee to sharing a laugh with my partner—feels monumental.

I often think back to those dark days when everything felt impossible, but today I’m focusing on how far we’ve come. My little one is growing so fast, and while time hasn’t paused for anyone, it’s comforting to know that I'm finally catching up. The clouds may have lingered over us for a long while, but they’re moving on, revealing the bright blue sky beyond.

It's funny how perspective can change in an instant. Yesterday, everything felt heavy; today, even the smallest things bring a smile to my face. Life isn’t perfect by any means, but it’s better, and I’m grateful for that.

January 7th, 2023

Day two as a new mom and I feel like I'm drowning in this sea of exhaustion and despair. The baby sleeps, but my mind races with thoughts of inadequacy and fear. Why can't I shake the feeling that something is terribly wrong? Every time he cries for food or comfort, it's like someone has flipped a switch inside me—I’m flooded with an overwhelming sense of failure.

There are moments when I feel a fleeting glimpse of happiness, watching his tiny fingers grasp mine, but they are quickly overshadowed by a crushing weight. I’ve never felt so alone in my life. The hospital gave me some pamphlets about postpartum depression, but right now, reading them feels like trying to lift a boulder with bare hands.

I want so badly to be the mom everyone says I should be, capable and joyful, but all I see is someone who’s broken. The darkness seems to seep into every corner of my life. It's as if everything that used to bring me joy now drains the little energy I have left. How do people find the strength to push through this?

But here’s a thought: maybe sharing these struggles isn’t just for me. Maybe there are others out there who need to know they’re not alone. If talking about it means one less person feels isolated and afraid, then maybe my pain can serve a purpose.

I’m reaching out because I want to be the best version of myself again—not because anyone else expects it from me, but for my baby. He deserves so much better than this, and I know deep down there's still hope within me. But right now, that hope feels like a whisper in the wind.

Tomorrow is another day, they say. Here’s hoping tomorrow brings more light than darkness.

Today feels like a never-ending fog. I woke up to the sound of my baby crying, and as usual, I felt drained and incapable. The weight of everything is suffocating—how am I supposed to be this beacon of hope and strength when I’m barely holding on myself? 

I tried putting on a brave face for everyone else. My mom noticed something was off but I just said I was tired from lack of sleep, like it’s some normal thing that comes with being a new parent. It’s not normal at all—I feel lost in my own mind.

At the same time, I’m scared to ask for help because maybe then people will see me as weak or failing somehow. The truth is, I want so badly to be the mother everyone expects me to be. But inside, it’s a different story—a story of fear and sadness that I don’t know how to share without judgment.

I keep hoping tomorrow will be better, but I’m starting to wonder if there even is an end in sight. Maybe this isn’t just about being tired or overwhelmed anymore—it’s more than that. It feels like something bigger I need help with, yet here I am, trying so hard to hide it all away.

Today was tough, and tomorrow will likely be just as hard. But maybe by writing it down, there’s a chance things can start to change.

Today marks five days since I gave birth to my little miracle. The weeks leading up to this moment were filled with excitement and anticipation, but now reality sets in with a heavy dose of exhaustion and confusion.

The past few nights have been particularly rough. My body feels like it’s been hit by a truck; every movement is an effort, let alone trying to nurse and change diapers at the same time. But that's not all—I had some discomfort yesterday that led me to the hospital where they found something was still inside my bowels. It was stuck for days, causing more pain than I’ve ever felt before. The relief when it finally came out was overwhelming.

But here’s the thing: even though physically I’m starting to heal, emotionally I feel lost and alone. Everything feels like a blur; feeding the baby, answering calls from family members who are just trying to help but end up making me more anxious. I can’t shake this sadness that lingers over everything. Simple tasks take twice as long, and sometimes I have no idea where to start.

I’m scared, confused, and wonder if anyone else feels like this after having a baby. It’s so hard to admit how much I’m struggling because everyone around me is celebrating the new life we’ve created. But inside, it’s anything but celebratory. Today was just another day of pretending everything is okay when really, I feel so far from that.

I need to reach out for help soon, but until then, these moments are my reality.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of frustration and disappointment. The baby cried all night again, but this time it wasn’t just about hunger or needing to be held. It was about the cold reality that I lost my job because I needed more time off after giving birth. How is it fair that my body and mind need extra care when everyone else seems to think a few weeks back at work are all I require?

I’ve always been proud of being part of a union, believing in solidarity and support for workers' rights. But now, facing mental health challenges, the leadership feels like strangers who don’t understand the struggles we’re going through. It’s heartbreaking to feel abandoned by people you thought were there to fight for your well-being.

The bills are piling up faster than I can make sense of them, and each one is a reminder that my financial security has vanished overnight. How am I supposed to take care of this beautiful little life when the world seems bent on pushing me away?

I’m trying to stay positive, but it’s tough. Every moment with the baby feels overshadowed by worry about how we’ll make ends meet and whether anyone will catch a glimpse of my reality—a mom who just wants support, not judgment.

Today, I’m overwhelmed, exhausted, and scared. But somehow, deep down, there’s also this tiny ember of hope that maybe things can change if enough voices speak up. Maybe then, future parents won’t face the same sense of isolation and failure I do right now.

December 14th

Today is just another day filled with exhaustion and endless tears. The baby won't stop crying no matter what I do, and everyone around me seems to think they know exactly how to fix it—except that none of them really understand. My mom keeps suggesting it's all in my head, that I'm overreacting or too sensitive. She doesn’t see the dark cloud hanging over me every minute.

I feel so alone with this baby in my arms, and yet surrounded by people who don't know how to help or just seem annoyed by the constant demands of a newborn. They tell me "it gets easier" but it feels like there's no end in sight to these endless nights and days that blur together into one unending cycle.

Why do I feel so overwhelmed? Am I really this weak, or is everyone else just clueless about what I'm going through? There are moments when the weight of being a new mom feels too heavy to carry alone. Sometimes I wonder if anyone will ever truly understand my struggles. Today was especially hard; I cried for hours and nobody seemed to notice.

Maybe it’s time I reach out for help, but the thought terrifies me. What if they think I’m crazy or that I’m not trying hard enough? The fear of judgment keeps me trapped in this isolating cycle. But maybe, just maybe, admitting I need support is the first step towards healing.

---

The days blend into each other like a never-ending dream, and yet every single moment feels raw and real.

Today marks three weeks since I became a full-time mom due to the lockdowns. The house is eerily quiet now that work isn't there to fill my days. It's just me, endless baby bottles, and the occasional Netflix binge session.

I thought being home with baby would be wonderful—I'd finally get to spend all day snuggling and watching him grow. But here I am, staring at four walls and feeling like a stranger in my own life. Where did "me" go? The one who had dreams and ambitions beyond changing diapers?

Today, though, something shifted. My brother sent me a message inviting me to join his latest gaming session. At first, I laughed it off, but then I realized—he was offering an escape from this haze of diaper duty and sleep deprivation. So, I logged in.

Oh wow. It felt like coming up for air after being underwater too long. There were people chatting, laughing, and sharing stories. And me? I wasn't just a mom—I was someone who could contribute to conversations about strategy and teamwork.

It's small steps, but it's progress. Maybe this is how I can start finding myself again amidst the chaos of parenthood. If gaming sessions bring back even a fraction of my old self, then I'll keep doing them every day if I need to.

Who knew that saving virtual worlds would save me from feeling like one?

Today marks two weeks since Jayde’s birth, and I’m feeling more alone than ever before. The hospital staff was kind but kept a professional distance; they didn’t know about my history of postpartum depression from when Alex was born. It’s like everyone thought everything would be fine this time around. But it’s not. 

I’ve been trying to put on a brave face for my mom, my partner Ben, and even the new neighbors who dropped off a casserole last week. They mean well but have no idea what I’m going through inside. The nights are long, and there’s always something crying or needing attention. My body feels like it's in pieces from all of the sleepless nights.

Worse than the physical toll is the isolation. People see a new baby and assume everything is perfect—sunny skies and butterflies. But I’m struggling with dark thoughts, feeling more disconnected each day. It’s hard to believe that someone could look at me and not see how much I'm hurting.

I keep thinking back to those days after Alex was born. How did no one notice? Was it because I wasn’t screaming for help loud enough or in the right way? Or were they just too busy with their own lives?

Sometimes, when Jayde sleeps soundly and everything is quiet, I feel a glimmer of hope that maybe this time will be different. But then reality hits like a punch to the gut. The exhaustion, the loneliness, it all comes crashing back in.

I know I need help but don’t know where to turn or how to ask for it without sounding selfish. Is anyone listening? Or am I just another face among countless others who go unnoticed?

January 14th

The days blur together like a never-ending haze of sorrow. Today feels no different from yesterday or the day before. I wake up to the same stark white walls and the sound of my own breath in this quiet apartment. It's been six months since we moved here, and yet every corner still holds the echo of an absence that's too heavy for me to bear.

I tried getting out of bed today but the thought of moving just seems impossible. How do you move when your heart is anchored by grief? I can't remember the last time I ate properly or slept through the night without being haunted by her tiny, delicate hands and those wide eyes that seem to stare accusingly from every shadow.

I keep thinking about how different things were before, back home where we had a community, a support system. Here, it's just me, lost in this maze of despair. The city around me is bustling with life and hope, but I feel like an outsider, trapped in my own mind.

Today, as I tried to do the dishes, water splashed onto the floor and made that sound—like tears dripping into a puddle. And there it was again, that familiar feeling of suffocation, like everything was closing in around me. The walls seemed to press closer with every drop. 

I miss her so much; it's like an ache that never leaves. Sometimes I wish I could just go back and change things, hold onto those moments a little tighter. But time doesn't work that way.

Maybe tomorrow will be different. Maybe the sun won’t feel as cold, and my body might find some warmth again. But right now, all I can do is lay here in this silence, wishing for something to fill the void inside me.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my little miracle home from the hospital. It feels like an eternity ago when we were basking in the glow of becoming parents. Now, I’m finding myself lost in a whirlwind of emotions that feel as endless and chaotic as a storm at sea.

The joy of those early days is now overshadowed by a constant haze of sadness and anxiety. Even simple tasks feel monumental. Feeding my baby seems like it should be the most natural thing in the world, but instead, I find myself questioning every action—did she drink enough? Is she gaining weight properly? And why does this all feel so overwhelming?

I’m struggling to see a way out of this darkness. My nights are peppered with moments of sheer panic and self-doubt, punctuated by brief flashes of clarity where I remember the love I have for my child. These small glimmers keep me going, but they’re not enough to lift the heavy blanket that seems to envelop everything.

I know there’s a way back to happiness, a path forward from this deep well of despair. But for now, I’m clinging to those tiny moments when the sun peeks through the clouds and reminds me that hope is still possible.

Today feels like one of those days where every little thing just grates on my nerves. I’m lying here, trying to sleep but the baby won’t stop crying. My partner is in the other room watching TV, completely oblivious. It’s not the first time he’s acted this way since the baby was born. He used to do the same when I had postpartum depression after our first child.

I remember how hard it was back then. I felt like I couldn’t even shower without him stepping in and helping with something minor. Now, it seems like anything I ask of him is met with resistance or outright dismissal. It’s not that he doesn’t care; it just feels so different from before. Maybe I’m being too sensitive, but every time he turns away when I reach out for help, a part of me relives those dark days.

The baby’s crying won’t let up. Part of me wants to just get up and rock her until she falls asleep, but another part of me wishes someone else would just take over for a little while so I can have a moment to breathe. Maybe that’s too much to ask?

I keep telling myself it’ll get better with time. That he’s not trying to be unhelpful; he’s probably exhausted too. But right now, it feels like every day is one long struggle.

Today marks one week since little Ella joined our family. It's hard to believe it’s been a whole week already. The nurse brought her back from the nursery earlier and she just stared at me as if I were the most fascinating thing in the world. Her tiny hands curled around mine, sending shivers down my spine with each gentle grip.

But amidst all this joy and wonder, there's an undercurrent of dread whispering to me about postpartum depression. Is it possible that someone like me could be falling into those dark waters? The thought is paralyzing, but I’m determined not to let it consume me or affect Ella in any way.

I'm trying my best to keep everything light and positive for her sake. I sing nursery rhymes and show her all the beautiful colors around us, hoping she feels safe and loved. But there are moments when I struggle with basic tasks like changing a diaper or making a bottle. It's exhausting, both physically and mentally.

I know I need help, but admitting it feels like admitting defeat. What if I’m failing my baby even before we’ve truly started? These thoughts loop in my head, relentless as the ticking of the clock. I'm scared of losing myself completely.

But then there are moments that break through the fog—like when she locks eyes with me and smiles softly. It’s these moments that keep me going, reminding me why all this is worth it. So today, I’m going to focus on those precious glimpses of clarity and hope. Maybe tomorrow will be better.

Today marks two weeks since little Emma arrived. It’s a beautiful day, but the sunshine feels like it’s trying to remind me of everything I’m missing out on right now. Sleepless nights blur together into one endless cycle, and even though my body is healing from childbirth, there’s this heavy feeling in my chest that doesn’t seem to want to go away.

The baby cries for what feels like the millionth time today, but it’s not just her cries piercing through the quiet. It’s the constant worry nagging at me: am I doing enough? Am I good enough? My therapist prescribed an SSRI a few days ago, and while it helps keep the panic attacks at bay, there are still these moments where everything feels so overwhelming.

I wish I could say things were going smoothly, but that would be a lie. There’s this part of me that’s grateful for the medication because without it, I don’t know how I’d manage getting out of bed. But there’s also a part of me that misses my old self, before everything became so complicated.

I’ve been trying to take things one step at a time, but sometimes stepping back feels impossible. The guilt and fear are like this thick fog that makes it hard to see the good moments. They’re still there, scattered throughout the day, like tiny stars peeking through storm clouds. I’m not sure how long it will take for those stars to outnumber the darkness.

Tonight, as I hold Emma while she sleeps, I promise myself one thing: tomorrow is a new day. I’ll keep moving forward, even if each step feels like trudging through quicksand. And maybe, just maybe, with time, the fog will lift enough to see the sun again.

Today feels like a never-ending fog. I've been lying here for what seems like hours, staring at the ceiling while my baby sleeps in her crib just across from me. The exhaustion is suffocating, a heavy blanket that drags down every part of me. It's not just physical; it’s mental too, this overwhelming urge to curl up and disappear. 

I keep telling myself I need to get out of bed, take the baby for a walk or make some dinner, but my limbs feel like they’re made of lead. Every task feels insurmountable, as if climbing Mount Everest is easier than changing her diaper right now.

Yesterday, I thought about calling someone—a friend, maybe?—but the idea of talking seems so pointless when all I want to do is sleep. The guilt that comes with those thoughts is crushing, and it makes everything worse. Why can't I be the mom everyone expects me to be?

I know I need help, but even reaching out feels like a monumental task. Sometimes, in these quiet moments, I feel like I’m failing my baby before she’s even had a chance. It's terrifying.

Maybe tomorrow will be better. Right now, though? All I can think about is how much I just want to close my eyes and escape for a while.

Today marks three weeks since little one arrived, but it feels like an eternity. I've barely slept, and every attempt at a smile seems forced. Why do they say motherhood is the most beautiful thing in the world? It's hard to believe that when you're drowning in a sea of exhaustion and despair.

I tried to put on a brave face for everyone – smiling pictures with my family, posts on social media about how wonderful it all is. But behind closed doors, I'm unraveling bit by bit. The constant worry gnaws at me like an insatiable hunger. Am I doing enough? Will she ever feel loved? These thoughts loop endlessly in my mind.

The isolation is overwhelming. Friends and family think everything's fine because that’s what they see on the surface. But deep down, it feels like no one understands. It's as if admitting how I truly feel would make me a bad mother, a failure even. And yet, talking about it might just mean someone else would understand.

Every day is another battle against myself and this relentless darkness that seems to engulf everything around me. How do other new mothers cope with these overwhelming emotions? Where can I find the strength to break free from this spiral of negativity?

Maybe tomorrow will be different, but today feels like an eternity of suffocating silence and unspoken fears.

Today marks two weeks since little Aria arrived in the world, and yet it feels like an eternity has passed. The joy of holding her for the first time is overshadowed by a heavy fog that clings to my heart and mind. It’s hard to believe this is what they call postpartum depression.

I can’t help but wonder if there was something I could have done differently. Maybe if I had slept more, or eaten better. But here I am, lying in bed, feeling like everything I do is wrong. The days blur together; feed, change, and repeat. Aria deserves so much more than this.

I know my partner wants me to be happy, but how can I when there’s a constant ache inside? It’s as if all the love and joy should pour out of me effortlessly, like it does for other new moms on social media, but instead, it feels like pulling teeth just to smile at Aria. She looks up at me with such trust, and I worry that I’m not strong enough for her.

It’s a strange feeling, wanting so badly to love my baby and yet feeling like the weight of the world is pressing down on my chest. There are moments when I wish I could go back in time and choose another path, but here we are, navigating this unfamiliar territory together. Maybe someday the fog will lift, but for now, I’m just trying to survive one day at a time.

I hope that tomorrow will be better. But honestly, I can’t promise it won’t feel like the same old routine. Here’s hoping for light at the end of what feels like an endless tunnel.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my baby girl home. It’s a strange mix of joy and exhaustion, but there’s this undercurrent that nags at me. People say the early days are hard, and they’re not wrong. But it feels like something more than just adjusting to being a new parent.

I’ve been trying to keep things together for everyone else—smiling, cooking, cleaning, even managing to get out of bed most mornings. But there’s this part of me that feels hollow, as if joy is a distant echo I can’t quite reach. The house is clean and the baby is fed; yet, why does it feel like I’m just going through the motions?

I know what you’re thinking—new parents are tired and stressed. And yes, I am both. But there’s this persistent feeling of emptiness that makes me wonder if I’m okay. Maybe I’m overthinking things, but every time I see other moms chatting happily at the park while their kids play, it hits me harder.

I can’t help but feel like a fraud sometimes—like I should be thrilled and elated about everything. Instead, I find myself wishing for quiet moments just to breathe. Even writing this feels selfish because I have so much to be grateful for. But how do you reconcile gratitude with the overwhelming sense of sadness?

It’s hard to talk about because no one wants to hear that their baby is the cause of anything negative. And yet, here I am, feeling like something isn’t right.

I don’t want to worry anyone, but I also can’t ignore this gnawing sensation. Maybe it’s just a phase, or maybe it’s more serious than I’m comfortable admitting. For now, all I know is that I’m trying to hold onto the good moments while figuring out how to deal with the bad ones.

Tomorrow will be another day, and hopefully, the sun will shine brighter. But for today, I need to acknowledge this part of me that’s struggling in silence.

Today marks my seventh day as a mother, and I feel like I'm losing myself in the chaos of it all. The hospital was nothing but a blur of lights, monitors, and unfamiliar faces. Now that we're home, everything feels so much more overwhelming.

I look at this tiny human who's supposed to be mine, yet there’s no warmth in my chest when I hold her. It's like she's just another thing on the list, another task to complete. How did this happen? Where is the joy and magic everyone talks about? The thought of having a conversation with friends or family about how I'm feeling fills me with dread. What will they think if I tell them I’m not sure if I can do this?

I've been trying so hard to pretend everything’s okay, but deep down, there's a gnawing fear that I might never feel connected to her the way other mothers seem to. Is it too soon? Am I already failing at something I’ve dreamt about for years?

The exhaustion is crushing. The nights are long and lonely. It feels like my body and mind are at war with each other, and there’s no relief in sight. But amidst all this turmoil, I know I need to reach out. Maybe talking about it can help me find the strength to keep going.

I’m not sure what tomorrow will bring, but today is over now. And maybe, just maybe, tomorrow could be better if I let someone in.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of sleep and feed, with naps scattered throughout the day. The house is quiet except for the occasional cry from little one, who seems to be awake more now than ever before. It’s hard to muster up any energy beyond these basic needs. My mom tries her best to help out but I feel like a burden sometimes. She suggests I should go back to work soon, but how can I when all I want is to lie in bed? 

I haven’t left the house since we moved here two weeks ago. The thought of interacting with anyone outside feels exhausting. My phone lies untouched for hours at a time, and I haven't talked to my friends or made plans since coming home. Isolation is both a comfort and an oppressive weight on my chest.

There’s this constant hum inside me, a dull ache that won’t go away no matter how much sleep I get. It makes everything feel pointless—changing diapers, cooking meals, even holding the baby when she wants to be held. She deserves better from me than this haze of apathy and sadness.

I know I should do something about it; maybe talk to a doctor or find some support groups online. But getting out of bed still feels like climbing Mount Everest. Maybe tomorrow will be different. For now, I’ll just close my eyes and hope for the best.

Today marks another day since I left my old life behind. The weight of moving to a new place feels like carrying an extra baby—exhausting and overwhelming all at once. It's been weeks since the move, yet it still feels surreal. Every room whispers with the echoes of the past, reminding me that I’ve lost something irreplaceable.

Losing my daughter was supposed to be just one chapter in my life, but it’s become a heavy shadow that follows me everywhere. The days blur together into a haze of grief and exhaustion. My mind, once sharp and focused, now wanders like an aimless ship without direction. I’m trying to navigate the new normal with ADHD, compounded by the recent diagnosis of a disability. It feels like everything is against me.

But there are moments, fleeting as they may be, when a ray of sunshine pierces through the clouds. Holding my newborn brings comfort and joy, even if it’s overshadowed by sorrow. The love I have for them is fierce and powerful, but so is the fear that I might not be strong enough to raise them.

It's hard to believe how much has changed in such a short time. My heart hurts from the loss of family members who’ve passed away recently, each departure leaving me more adrift than before. The weight of my responsibilities feels insurmountable at times—managing health issues and caring for sick children all while trying to hold myself together.

I feel like I’m walking through a storm with no shelter in sight. Yet, amidst the chaos, there’s an unyielding desire to find a way out. Maybe it's just one step at a time, but every little bit counts. Today, as I cradle my baby and watch them sleep, I remind myself that we are strong enough to face this together. We might stumble along the way, but we’ll keep going.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of pain and tears. I thought having a baby would be the happiest moment of my life, but instead, it's turning into one of the darkest chapters. The chest pains are back again, squeezing me tight like a vice, making it hard to breathe. Every time it happens, I feel so alone, like no one else could possibly understand this agony.

The tears flow freely now, spilling over from anger and frustration. Why can't I just be happy? Everyone tells me how lucky I am to have a new baby in my life, but all I see is exhaustion and despair. There are moments when I feel such intense rage; it scares me. Anger at myself for not being the mother everyone expects me to be. Anger at others for thinking everything should just fall into place.

Today, as I held little Sarah while she cried her heart out, my chest started hurting again. It was almost unbearable, like someone had their hand around my throat, choking the life out of me. In that moment, all I wanted was to escape this relentless torment. But then I remembered the love in her eyes when they look up at me, and it made everything hurt even more.

I wish there was a way to turn off these feelings, but instead, they grow stronger each day. It's like carrying an invisible weight that no one else can see or understand. Sometimes, when she sleeps peacefully beside me, I find tiny moments of joy – her soft hair tickling my cheek, the warmth of her body against mine. But those brief respites are overshadowed by a constant fear: what if these good feelings never come back?

Right now, all I want is to be okay. To feel like there's light at the end of this long tunnel. Maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe it won't. All I know is that today was another hard day, and I need help finding my way through it.

Day 3 Postpartum

Today marks the third day since I brought my little miracle into this world through what felt like a never-ending storm of pain and uncertainty. The cesarean surgery was an abrupt end to hours of labor that seemed as if it would stretch on forever, leaving me exhausted both physically and emotionally. Now lying in this hospital bed, surrounded by monitors beeping gently and the soft sounds of new life, I feel more disconnected from myself than ever before.

My body is a map of pain – stitches across my belly, sore muscles, and tender nipples that hint at the joy to come but only remind me of what I’ve been through. Each breath feels like a reminder of all that I endured, but also of how much strength I possess despite feeling utterly drained right now.

What worries me most is this overwhelming sense of ‘who am I?’ The woman who held everything together during childbirth seems miles away from the person staring back at me in the mirror – eyes red-rimmed and soul-searching. It’s like I lost a part of myself somewhere between contractions and recovery, and finding my way back feels as impossible as climbing Mount Everest.

I know there are other mothers out there who feel this way too, but that doesn’t make it any easier to accept or understand right now. Each moment brings a mix of joy at meeting my baby and despair over the loss of my pre-baby identity. I’m still trying to figure out how to be both these people – new mom and old self.

In the quiet moments when I’m not holding him or looking after his needs, all I want is to cry, sleep, or disappear entirely into a place where there are no questions about who you used to be before everything changed. But here’s hoping that tomorrow will bring clarity, even if it’s just a little bit of light in the fog.

Right now, though, I’m simply existing – not thriving, not failing completely, but somewhere in between, with more questions than answers and an overwhelming sense of both love and loss.

Today marks six years since I gave birth to my beautiful baby girl, yet the weight of postpartum depression and anxiety still feels like a heavy cloak draped over me. The days blur together in a haze of exhaustion and worry, but today is different—I’m trying to see through the fog.

I wake up to the sound of her laughter echoing through the house. It’s moments like these that make everything worth it, yet I can’t shake the overwhelming fear that I won’t be enough for her. The bills stack up, each one a stark reminder of how much this has cost me financially and emotionally. Therapy sessions, medication, countless hours spent in isolation—each piece of my life feels drained.

I’ve tried to stay positive, but it’s becoming harder every day. My partner sees the strain and tries his best to help, yet there are moments when I feel like a burden more than anything else. Today, as I hold her close and watch her play, I realize that while love might be infinite, my resources aren’t.

There have been times when I’ve thought about giving up. But then she smiles at me with those innocent eyes, and it feels like everything will be okay. Yet the doubts linger, a constant whisper in the back of my mind telling me otherwise. How much longer can I keep fighting this battle alone?

Today, as I write this down, I’m reaching out for help—not just for myself but for her too. Because even though the path ahead is uncertain and daunting, it’s okay to admit that I need support.

Tomorrow will be another day, and maybe today was just a bit darker than usual. But holding on to hope, one breath at a time.

Today marks two weeks since giving birth to my beautiful baby girl. The hospital rooms with their sterile white walls and beeping machines feel like a distant memory now that I’m back at home in our little nest we’ve built together. But despite the joy I felt during the pregnancy, there’s an overwhelming sense of despair settling over me.

I keep telling myself I should be happy—overwhelmed with happiness—but instead, I find myself lost in a fog of hopelessness and fear. The nights are the hardest; they stretch on endlessly as I stare at her sleeping form and wonder how I can possibly do this. How did things go so wrong? Why am I feeling like I’m drowning while everyone else celebrates?

I know there’s no logical reason for me to feel this way, but it doesn’t make it any easier. I want to love my baby more than anything, but sometimes the thought of lifting her tiny body feels too heavy, and all I can do is cry. I haven’t slept in days because every time I close my eyes, dark thoughts consume me.

I’ve tried talking to friends and family about how I’m feeling, but their words of encouragement only highlight my failure. They see a new mother glowing with joy, and I can’t bear the contrast between that image and the way I feel inside.

Today, as she naps peacefully in her crib, I catch myself considering ways out of this endless pain. Is it really worth living if every day feels like a battle against the darkness? What kind of life is this?

I’m scared to admit how deeply I want these thoughts to go away, but they won’t. The baby’s cries startle me from my reverie, and for a moment, all I can think about is escaping it all.

But she needs her mother. She deserves better than what I seem capable of giving right now. So, I’ll keep trying, one breath at a time, hoping that someday soon the sun will shine through again.

January 15, 2023

I woke up today feeling like I'm walking through quicksand. Every little thing feels heavy and overwhelming—holding my baby, feeding her, even just looking at her sometimes makes me feel like I’m drowning in a sea of exhaustion and sadness.

Yesterday, someone on social media mentioned postpartum depression, and it struck a nerve. It’s not that I didn’t know what it was—I’ve read about it enough to be familiar with the symptoms. But seeing it described so openly made me realize just how much I’m struggling. The comments under the post were mixed—some people offered support and understanding, but others made assumptions or outright judgment.

The thing is, my journey has been complicated, and I want to make sure no one misinterprets what I'm going through. It's not about having an abortion—I've never done that—and it’s certainly not about feeling murderous towards anyone or anything. It's just a deep sense of melancholy that seems to cling to me like second skin.

I’m trying my best every day, and today feels like another step forward, even if it’s a tiny one. I’ve scheduled an appointment with my therapist for next week; talking through this feels necessary, and I hope to get some strategies to help manage these dark moments.

The truth is, there are days when the weight of everything seems too heavy to carry, but then, there are flashes of pure joy—like that first smile from my baby or her little hand reaching out for mine. Those moments keep me going because they remind me why I’m here and fighting through this haze.

I need to be kinder to myself today. It’s okay not to have all the answers right now.

Day 30: Another Sleepless Night

Another night passed without sleep, the kind that seems to stretch on forever, punctuated only by the tiny cries of K. I feel like a stranger in my own home, detached from everything around me. The days blend together into one long blur, and no matter how many times I remind myself that this is just a phase, it doesn't help much.

I've been trying to reach out for support, but every attempt feels futile. There are supposed to be resources out there, people who understand the struggles of new parents, but everything seems so far away. The waiting lists for therapy are absurdly long, and even when I do manage to get through to someone, they often seem more interested in ticking boxes than actually helping.

It's hard not to feel like a failure every time K cries or doesn't sleep well. I know logically that it’s normal, but the anxiety keeps creeping back, telling me there must be something wrong with me as a mother. It's been over a year since K was born, and honestly, I’m starting to think this will never get better.

Why is it so hard for people to see what we need? Why can't they just help us when we're struggling the most?

This morning, all I could muster up was making some toast and trying not to cry. Here’s hoping tomorrow feels different. But honestly, I'm running out of hope that it will.

Tomorrow seems like a distant dream. I’m so tired of feeling stuck in this never-ending cycle of worry and exhaustion. Is there any light at the end of this tunnel?

Today marks two weeks since I held my second baby in my arms. The whirlwind of emotions feels like a tornado inside me. Giving birth alone again was harder than I expected. It’s all such a blur—too much happening too fast, and not enough hands to help.

I’m haunted by the same shadows that followed after my first child. Those dark thoughts creeping back in, reminding me how isolated it felt then. This time around, I hoped for something different, but here we are, another chapter of me trying to figure out this motherhood thing on my own.

The delivery room was busy and cold. No one took the time to explain or listen. It feels like they were just waiting for me to give birth so they could rush off to their next patient. Maybe that’s why I’m feeling so lost right now, because no one ever really showed me how to do this.

I want to protect myself from falling into that deep hole again. The thought of having another baby terrifies me as much as it exhausts me. I don’t think I can go through another round of depression and isolation. It’s okay if this is my limit, isn’t it?

Tomorrow, I’ll ask the doctor about the option to tie tubes. I deserve a plan that feels safe, not just for now but for my future too. Maybe then, I can finally start healing from all these years of trying so hard alone.

Today marks my sixth week since giving birth to our little miracle. The reality of the situation is sinking in more with each passing day. I'm exhausted—more than just physically. My heart feels heavy, and there's a constant cloud hovering over me. It's like the world expects you to snap back into shape overnight, but your body and mind need time, lots of it.

I wake up every morning dreading what lies ahead. The thought of returning to work next week is terrifying. I know they have policies, but everything feels so rushed here at the church. My maternity leave is barely halfway through, yet they've been hinting that my absence is too long. It’s like they can't see past this strict timeline and how it affects someone who's just had a baby.

The guilt sets in—I worry about leaving my little one, but I also fear losing my job. The stress of this situation feels suffocating at times. I know postpartum depression is real, and I feel like I'm on the brink of something more serious. There are days when all I want to do is curl up in bed with her, shielded from everything else.

But there's a flicker of hope too—maybe it’s just this overwhelming environment. Maybe if I could extend my leave or find some kind of support system here, things would feel less impossible. For now, though, it feels like I'm walking on eggshells every day, trying to keep my head above water while everyone else moves forward.

I need help—real help, not just a pat on the back and a "you'll be okay." I want someone to understand this isn't about me being weak or flaky. It's about survival in an environment that doesn’t seem equipped to handle what new parents like me are going through right now.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world. The reality of motherhood hits me harder each day like a relentless wave crashing over and under me. There's this constant whisper in my ear telling me that something isn't right, but it’s not until now that I can admit to myself—I’m drowning.

The nursery is perfect, filled with soft blankets and toys in pastel colors, but all I see is emptiness and the weight of responsibility. Every time I hold her, every tiny sound she makes, feels like a question without an answer. What if I’m not enough? What if this wasn’t what I was meant to be?

I've always believed in choices—my body, my rules. Yet here I am, questioning everything about the decision that brought me to this point. It’s not just about wanting her or being excited; it’s a profound exhaustion mixed with an overwhelming sadness.

Sometimes, when she sleeps and the house is quiet except for the ticking of the clock, I feel something break inside me. The silence isn’t peaceful—it's deafening. I know I need help, but reaching out feels like admitting defeat.

In moments when she smiles at me—pure and innocent—I’m terrified. Terrified that I won't be able to protect her from this dark place in my heart.

I want so badly for it all to change tomorrow, but what if it doesn’t? What if every day is just another struggle?

Today feels like a loss of control, yet another reminder of how far off from the dream I’m now. But there’s a part of me that whispers back: You’ve come this far; you can keep going.

One step at a time, one moment at a time. It’s a start.

Today marks two weeks since I held my baby for the first time. The world feels both incredibly vast and deeply isolating. I've been trying to navigate this new reality with a smile, but it's hard when you're also battling shadows from your past.

The sleepless nights are a blur of hazy moments where I hold onto hope that everything will be okay, only to wake up in the middle of the night gripped by fears of what lies ahead. The thought of going through this again with another baby sends shivers down my spine. My history whispers warnings at me—warnings about postpartum depression and anxiety.

I've been avoiding the news, but every time I glance at social media or hear snippets on the radio, it's all anyone talks about: restrictions on abortions. It feels like a heavy blanket wrapped around my chest, suffocating. How am I supposed to take care of one baby when I'm struggling so much? And what if another child is inevitable? The weight of that possibility is crushing.

I know I need help. But finding it in this new landscape seems impossible. Every day feels like a battle against the echoes of my past and the uncertainties of tomorrow. Still, there are moments—moments when I look at my little one and feel an overwhelming love—that remind me why fighting for us both is necessary.

Today, I'll try to reach out for that help. One step at a time.

Today marks two weeks since bringing my little miracle home. I thought the exhaustion would fade and happiness would reign supreme. But instead, I'm overwhelmed by this dark cloud hovering over me. Simple tasks seem insurmountable, like washing dishes or even changing into comfy clothes that don't feel too tight.

I had a goal of eating well postpartum, but now cheat days are more frequent as I struggle to meet my own expectations. It feels like every little thing is a mountain to climb. My husband tries to help, but sometimes it's easier to say no and just deal with the chaos alone. 

Baby showers me with smiles and coos, yet joy eludes me. Maybe I should try harder? But when did trying become such a chore? I'm supposed to be celebrating motherhood, right?

I look in the mirror—puffy eyes, unkempt hair—and wonder where my old self went. The one who used to dance carefree and laugh uncontrollably. She's gone now, replaced by this shell of a woman stuck in a never-ending cycle.

Sleep is elusive, dreams fragmented. My mind races with worries about how to be the best mom possible while barely managing to brush my teeth. It’s exhausting just existing sometimes. 

Maybe I need help. But admitting that feels like another mountain to climb. For now, I’ll take it one breath at a time and hope tomorrow brings some clarity.
