Today was better—I actually got out of bed without feeling completely drained. Small wins, right?

Today marks two weeks since little Lily joined our family. I thought the days would be filled with joy and excitement, but instead, they've been a blur of exhaustion and confusion. It's like everyone around me is living in this perfect bubble where everything makes sense and smiles are endless. But inside, it feels like I’m drowning in a sea of loneliness.

I see other new moms posting on social media about how wonderful motherhood is, sharing their glowing photos with no hint of the struggles they might be facing. They paint these beautiful pictures that feel so far from my reality. How do you tell someone you’re scared? That you're overwhelmed and unsure if you're doing a good job?

I've always felt like I was supposed to have it all together, but now I'm not sure where the real me went. The person who could handle anything life threw at her seems lost in the haze of sleepless nights and endless feedings. How do you explain that feeling when no one else around you is admitting they’re struggling too?

I know I need to reach out for help, but it’s hard to break through this isolation. Maybe today will be different. Maybe reaching out won’t feel as scary anymore.

I’m not sure how tomorrow will look, but at least there’s the promise of a new day. And maybe, just maybe, one step closer to feeling like myself again.

Today marks my first week as a new mom, and it’s been quite the whirlwind of emotions and unexpected turns. I walked into this chapter with fears looming large, particularly around postpartum depression. My earlier experiences had painted a rather bleak picture for me, but something shifted dramatically when our little one arrived.

The birth was nothing short of miraculous—a serene blend of pain and triumph that left me in awe more than anything else. As I held my baby for the first time, surrounded by love and support, all the anxiety about what comes next just seemed to melt away. There’s still a part of me holding onto some residual fear, but it feels much smaller now.

What surprises me most is how natural this transition has felt so far. Sure, there are moments of exhaustion and confusion, but they’re peppered with these incredible moments of joy and wonder that I never imagined possible. It’s as if my baby’s presence has cast a soothing spell over everything else.

I’ll be honest—I’m still learning to navigate these uncharted waters without the heavy cloud of dread hanging over me. But for now, I’m choosing to embrace each day with open arms, grateful for this unexpected shift in perspective and hopeful that it will continue as we move forward together.

Today marks two weeks since giving birth to my beautiful little girl, and yet the weight of this world feels heavier than ever before. Sleep is a luxury I can barely afford, and every time I close my eyes, another wave of anxiety washes over me. The joy of being a new mom should be so much more than this endless cycle of worry and doubt.

The scales are tipping again, both literally and metaphorically. My clothes feel tight, not because of love handles or maternity weight but because of the emotional turmoil that seems to have taken up permanent residence in my body. I can see the same struggle mirrored in my mom's eyes and hear it in the hesitations of my friends who have also faced their own battles with postpartum depression.

Support is there, but sometimes it feels like a distant shore when you're drowning in these waves of despair. The phone calls from well-meaning family members don't always soothe as they intend; instead, they highlight how far I am from feeling okay. But I know, deep down, that reaching out for help isn’t weakness—it’s survival.

I’m not sure where this road will lead me, but I do know one thing: it's okay to feel this way. It doesn't make me less of a mother or less deserving of happiness. Today, as I hold my baby and watch her tiny fingers curl around mine, I whisper promises to myself that I'll be strong enough for both of us, even if the road ahead feels dark and uncertain right now.

Today was a blur of tears and frustration. The baby’s cries seem to echo in my head like an endless siren, piercing through the haze that covers every moment. I tried so hard to hold it together, to be the mother everyone expects me to be, but this morning everything just broke.

I wanted to leave, run away from all of this—just for a minute—to breathe and think clearly. But there’s no escaping it; he needs me here, right now. The guilt is suffocating. I keep telling myself that things will get better, but every second feels like an eternity. Why can’t someone understand how desperately I need help? It’s not just about the baby; it’s about finding my way back to being okay.

The doctor said this was common, that many women feel overwhelmed after giving birth. But hearing it doesn’t make it easier. Today, looking at myself in the mirror, I saw a stranger—a sad, lost woman who needs more than words of comfort. She needs real support, and soon. This can’t be my reality forever.

I’ve been trying to document this journey, hoping that someday I’ll look back and see progress. But right now, it’s hard to find the strength for even small victories. Every little step feels monumental. I’m reaching out today because I know I won’t make it alone; there has to be a way through this darkness.

Please, if you’re reading this—understand that asking for help doesn’t make me weak. It makes me brave enough to face what’s ahead.

Today marks two weeks since my little one arrived, and while the joy of holding her for the first time still feels like a miracle, there's this nagging feeling in the back of my mind that I can't quite shake off. It’s not exactly postpartum depression; it's more like what you'd call “postpartum sideburns.” You know, when your reflection stares back and whispers, “Did anyone else notice these new additions?”

The exhaustion is real—I don’t even remember the last time I got a full night’s sleep. And yet, there are moments of pure bliss that make it all worth it. Watching her tiny fingers grasp mine with surprising strength, or listening to her soft coos as she tries to mimic my voice—it’s magical.

But then there's this odd sense of disconnection from myself. Like I’m looking at a stranger in the mirror and thinking, “Wait, who is this person?” It’s more than just the physical changes; it’s everything that’s shifting inside me. I used to have these sideburns as an emblem of my rebellious youth, but now they seem out of place amidst all this new motherhood.

I keep reminding myself that recovery from a C-section takes time, and so does adjusting to being a mom. Maybe those sideburns are just a funny way for me to express how different I feel right now. They’re not going anywhere anytime soon, but neither is my joy in this little life I’ve brought into the world.

I’m trying to find balance between these conflicting feelings—celebrating each milestone while also allowing myself room to grieve what’s been left behind. It’s a journey, and it’s okay if some days are harder than others.

Day 30 Postpartum

Today feels like an eternity of sleepless nights and endless to-do lists. I look at my baby, this tiny miracle who has taken over our lives, and I can’t help but feel a mix of love and dread. Everyone talks about the joy and bliss of having a newborn, but no one mentions how hard it is to balance everything.

I wake up every hour for feedings, then struggle to get back to sleep when I have the chance. My husband tries to help, but we both seem lost in this new world where there are more questions than answers. Why does he cry so much? How do I know if he’s okay? When will I feel like myself again?

I’m supposed to be happy, right? But all I feel is overwhelmed. The house feels cluttered and chaotic, not peaceful and serene as the books say it should be. Laundry piles up, meals are a blur of quick microwave dinners, and my phone lights up constantly with notifications from apps and well-meaning friends asking how we’re doing.

Sometimes I think maybe I am depressed, but that’s just silly. How can someone who has everything to live for feel this way? It’s just exhaustion talking. Or is it more than that?

I’m supposed to be a superhero mom, handling all of this with grace and poise. But here I am, barely able to get through the day without feeling like I’m drowning in responsibilities. Maybe I need to take a deep breath and remind myself that everyone feels overwhelmed sometimes. It’s okay to ask for help.

I’ll try to focus on one thing at a time today—just getting through this moment is enough. One hour, then another, until it adds up to something manageable.

Today marks three weeks since I had my surgery, but it feels like an eternity has passed without the presence of a tiny life to hold and nurture. The hospital staff was kind enough to remind me every day that everything went smoothly during the procedure, but somehow, that doesn’t make me feel any better.

I’ve been sleeping more than usual, but still wake up feeling exhausted and overwhelmed by even simple tasks. My appetite has taken a nosedive; I can barely muster the energy to heat up a cup of tea, let alone cook anything substantial. And then there’s the inexplicable sadness that sneaks in at odd moments—when I’m trying to watch a movie or scroll through social media posts featuring happy families.

It’s strange because everyone around me seems to think I should be ecstatic about my decision. They tell me how lucky I am not to have all the responsibilities of caring for an infant, but it doesn’t make sense to me why I feel so lost and anxious without ever having held that baby in my arms.

I’m aware these feelings are unusual, but it’s tough to talk openly about them when no one else seems to understand. Maybe talking to someone who does would help clarify things. For now, though, all I can do is try to be gentle with myself and hope for a bit of clarity soon.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of tiredness and tears. The baby's cries echo through the house, piercing my heart with each wail that turns into sobs. I can't seem to catch a break, not even for a minute to breathe or rest. My eyes burn from lack of sleep, but every time they start to close, it’s as if an alarm goes off in my mind—my baby needs me.

The room is quiet now, the house still under a blanket of darkness. I lie here, exhausted and alone with thoughts that haunt me. The weight of this new responsibility feels crushing, like I'm drowning in a sea of diapers and bottles without a lifeline. Why isn't it getting easier? Why am I not happier?

I try to remind myself that I've been here before—postpartum depression rearing its ugly head once again. But the memories from last time are hazy, lost under waves of exhaustion and anxiety. How do I fight through this foggy haze when every day feels like a battle just to stay awake? The darkness creeps in around the edges, threatening to consume me entirely.

I need help. I know that now more than ever. But reaching out seems like an impossible task when all I can muster is a whisper of fear and uncertainty. Will it be different this time? Can I find the strength within myself, or do I need to rely on others for support?

The baby stirs in her crib, and my heart skips a beat—another day begins.

Today was one of those days where the sun seemed to mock my struggles with its bright rays streaming through the window. I held my little one, staring at her tiny hands and wondering how they will someday grasp the world in ways that are impossible for me right now. The weight of this responsibility feels overwhelming sometimes, like a heavy blanket draped over my shoulders.

Moments of pure joy do punctuate these days, though. Like when she smiles up at me with that toothless grin or giggles as I tickle her tiny toes. Those moments make everything feel worthwhile, but then the doubt creeps in again. Why am I not feeling more love? More happiness?

I know it’s common to feel this way after giving birth, and people tell me often how wonderful motherhood is supposed to be. Yet here I am, questioning if I’m good enough, if I’ll ever truly enjoy being a mom.

Today, I tried calling my therapist for the first time since the baby was born. Just hearing her voice on the other end reminded me that I’m not alone in this struggle. Maybe reaching out isn’t such a bad thing after all. 

I decided to take today’s small victories as signs of progress—like managing to get us both dressed or making dinner without burning it to a crisp. These little wins are crucial, even if they don't feel monumental.

Tomorrow is another day, and maybe the sun will smile brighter on my efforts. For now, I’m taking one step at a time.

Today marks exactly one year since the birth of my twins, and I can’t help but feel a wave of gratitude wash over me as I reflect on how far I’ve come. It wasn’t always easy; there were days when exhaustion felt like an unshakable shadow, and postpartum depression loomed large in my mind. But now, looking back, those dark moments are just that—moments that have passed.

The turning point came with the support of a community I found online through fitness influencers who shared their own struggles. Their posts became my daily dose of inspiration, reminding me that it’s okay to lean on others and prioritize self-care. I started attending virtual workout sessions which gradually transformed into in-person classes as we safely navigated lockdowns together.

Now, here I am, one year later, feeling stronger than ever—both mentally and physically. The bond with my twins has grown exponentially, and so has my confidence in my ability to care for them while taking care of myself too. It’s a beautiful balance that keeps me grounded and hopeful about the future.

Today was a good day, not just because it’s been a year since their birth, but also because I celebrated this milestone with friends who understand what it means to navigate parenthood after a stormy start. Here’s to many more years of growth and joy ahead!

Today marks two weeks since little Lily joined our family, and honestly, I feel like a complete failure. The exhaustion is overwhelming—constant feedings, diaper changes, and trying to figure out what she needs when all you want to do is sleep. It’s been such a whirlwind of emotions, from the initial joy to the crushing reality that parenting isn’t as easy as it looks on Instagram.

I keep thinking about how every new mom seems so confident and happy. They post pictures with perfect hair and glowing smiles, but inside, I feel lost. There are moments when I just want to run away because all I see is a baby who needs me constantly, and I’m not sure if I can handle it. Is this normal? Am I supposed to feel like such an inadequate parent?

The nights are the hardest. Sleep deprivation makes everything seem impossible. I’ve cried more in these two weeks than I ever have before. I thought love would be enough, but there’s so much more to being a mom than just loving your child. There's constant worry about whether you're doing it right or failing somehow.

I know this isn’t supposed to be easy, but sometimes I feel like giving up because the struggle feels too big. Maybe it's just exhaustion talking, but what if it’s something else? What if I’m not just tired, but really, truly depressed?

Today felt particularly rough, and I’m trying my best to keep things together for Lily, even though all I want is a break from everything. It’s okay to admit that it’s hard right now. Maybe tomorrow will be better, but until then, I need to find the strength to push through another day.

Maybe reaching out isn’t such a bad idea after all.

Today marks three weeks since giving birth to my little miracle, and while the joy of being a mom is overwhelming, there’s this dark cloud that seems to hover over me constantly. I wake up each day thinking about how much I want to feel like myself again—how I wish I could go back in time and just be that girl who was comfortable with her body and felt confident enough to throw on a little black dress without feeling self-conscious.

The hardest part is the way I look at myself now. There are stretch marks, extra pounds, and my body feels like it’s completely unrecognizable. It’s strange because even though I’ve always thought of myself as someone who could handle most things with grace and poise, right now, I feel so fragile and exposed.

I miss the way I used to socialize—going out for drinks with friends, attending weekend brunches where everyone was lively and chatting about their lives. Now, all I want is to stay home, cocooned in this bubble of exhaustion and anxiety. It’s like there’s a part of me that feels so detached from the world outside my four walls.

I’ve tried talking to people about how I feel—my husband notices the changes but doesn’t really understand because he hasn’t experienced what it means to go through all these hormonal shifts and physical transformations. The only way I can think of feeling better is by doing something that makes me feel like a woman again—something that helps me reconnect with who I was before this major life change.

I’m trying hard not to let this dark cloud take over completely, but it’s tough. I’ve been thinking about signing up for dance classes or even just getting dressed up once in a while to go out and grab coffee somewhere new. It feels like such a small step, but maybe starting with baby steps will help me find my way back to feeling good about myself again.

Maybe tomorrow, I’ll put on something that makes me feel beautiful and brave enough to face the day. Today, though? Today, I’m just going to rest and hope for better days ahead.

January 7th, 2023

The nights are the hardest. It feels like a never-ending cycle of exhaustion and despair. I sit here, staring at my baby’s peaceful face, wondering how this tiny human can make me feel both so full of love and so utterly lost.

Why is it that when everyone else thinks you should be glowing with happiness, you’re just drowning in tears? Tonight was one of those nights where all I wanted to do was cry. The darkness seemed to seep into my bones, pulling me down into a deep well of sadness. But there’s no time for tears; the baby needs feeding again.

I know I’m not alone. I’ve heard stories from other new moms about these dark moments, but it doesn’t make them any easier to bear. The isolation is suffocating—like you’re trapped in your own head, unable to reach out for help.

But I’m going to try. I need to find a way through this fog. Maybe talking to someone will help. Or perhaps it’s time to lean on my partner more and not feel guilty about needing support. Tomorrow is another day, and maybe the sun will shine brighter then. For now, though, all I can do is keep breathing.

And then tomorrow comes around, and it feels like everything starts anew. But deep down, I know the darkness might be waiting just beyond the light. I’m not giving up on myself or my baby. We’re going to get through this together, one day at a time.

Today marks one and a half months since I last took my antidepressants. It’s been an emotional roller coaster, but there are moments when I feel like I’m truly beginning to heal. The baby sleeps soundly in the next room, his breathing steady as ever. I wonder if he can sense how uneasy I’ve felt recently. Sometimes, the quietness of the house feels too much; other times, it’s a welcome respite from the chaos.

I remember those dark days after my middle son was born. The weight of new motherhood seemed insurmountable, and the only thing that brought me some semblance of peace was the medication. Now, I’m navigating this uncharted territory without it, trying to find balance in a world that feels both too big and too small.

I’ve been reading about postpartum depression and learning how to recognize signs in myself. It’s scary but also empowering to know there are ways to cope beyond pills. Therapy sessions have become my lifeline, offering a safe space to express what I’m feeling without judgment. Each conversation feels like a step forward, even if progress isn’t linear.

There are moments when the past whispers loudly, threatening to pull me back into its shadows. But then I think about how far I’ve come—how I’ve managed this long without medication—and it gives me hope. It’s not easy, but every day is an opportunity to grow stronger and more resilient.

Tonight, as I tuck my baby in, I hold onto the belief that tomorrow will be better than today. And even if it isn’t, there are people who care and can help guide me through the darkness.

Today marks my fourth day as a new mother, and the exhaustion is like nothing I've ever felt before. Every moment feels amplified—my heart beats harder for the smallest things, yet everything feels too heavy to manage. The baby sleeps so peacefully, but every time she does, it triggers something inside me that's terrifying.

I keep having these thoughts... dark ones. Violent images that scare me more than they would ever hurt her. I know they're not real, but they feel so vivid and intrusive. How can my mind do this to me? It’s like a cruel joke played by some twisted part of my psyche.

The nurse said something about postpartum depression during one of the check-ups. At first, it sounded like an excuse for how I was feeling, but now... well, now I see pieces fitting together in ways that are both unsettling and somewhat reassuring. It’s not just me losing my mind; there's a name for this, a reason why I feel so off.

I want to hold her close and love her fiercely, but the fear of what might happen if these thoughts take over... it paralyzes me. Maybe talking to someone about them could help. Or maybe that’s just another dark thought trying to pull me down.

Tomorrow feels like an eternity away right now, but I have to find a way through this. For her sake and mine.

Today marks two weeks since little Emma joined our family. The joy of holding her for the first time is overshadowed by a constant fog that won’t lift. I feel like I’m floating outside my body, watching everything happen to someone else. Did the doctor’s words about postpartum depression really describe me? Or am I just exhausted and overwhelmed?

I’ve been trying to stay positive, but it’s hard when even changing a diaper feels like climbing Mount Everest. My husband is wonderful and supportive, but he can’t fix this for me. Part of me thinks if I could get something permanent inked on my skin, maybe that would solidify everything in place—I’d have a reminder that life isn’t just about diapers and sleepless nights anymore.

I don’t know how to shake off these feelings. Is it normal? Am I really depressed? I need answers, but talking feels like more work than anything else right now. Maybe the tattoo will give me something tangible to hold onto while I figure this out.

Today marks three weeks since bringing little Elsie home. The house is a whirlwind of diapers and laughter, but there's an emptiness inside me that I can't shake. Being at the hospital was like being in a dream; everything felt surreal. Now that we're back, reality hits hard.

I catch myself staring out the window, wondering if this feeling will ever lift. Sometimes, my heart is so full of love for these little ones, but other times, it feels heavy and hollow. The exhaustion is real, and there are moments when I want to scream or cry. I know that's not okay, but what else can I do?

Looking at Elsie sleeping peacefully in her crib, I feel a surge of guilt. How can I be thinking these things about the baby? She's innocent, just like my other boy. But here’s the thing—I need help. I need to talk about this and figure out how to move forward without feeling so lost.

It's early morning now, and Elsie is still sleeping. James, my almost four-year-old, woke me up at 5 AM, wanting his breakfast. I smiled through it all but felt like I was holding back tears instead of joy. Maybe today will be different. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, though, I'm just trying to get through one day at a time.

I know I need to reach out for help soon. Talking about these feelings isn't easy, but I can’t keep pretending everything is fine when it’s not. The thought of being strong enough to support both my kids and myself feels daunting. But today, I'm going to make the call. It's a start, at least.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and it feels like the longest month of my life. The first few days were filled with overwhelming joy and disbelief that I’m actually holding this tiny bundle of love. But then reality started to set in, along with an emptiness and exhaustion that nothing could fill or fight against.

I know everyone says it's normal to feel tired after having a baby, but there’s something different about how I feel now. It's like this heavy fog has settled over my thoughts, making everything seem so distant and difficult. Even when I see the smile on my baby’s face or hear their little coos, it doesn't quite reach that place inside me where love should be.

I try to tell myself that this is just postpartum blues, but deep down, I know something else might be going on. The sadness creeps up at strange times—like when I’m changing a diaper or rocking the baby to sleep—and it hits me hard, making my chest feel tight and my eyes sting.

It’s funny how being a new parent can turn you into someone you never thought you’d become: tired, confused, overwhelmed, and lost. But here's what scares me most—I worry I might not be good enough for my baby because of this cloud hanging over my head. What if all these feelings mean there’s something wrong with me?

I know I need to talk about it more openly, but admitting that feels like a betrayal somehow. Am I supposed to feel this way? Is it normal to question everything so intensely? I wish someone could just tell me what's going on and assure me that things will get better.

Today, as I’m writing this, the sun is shining outside, and the air smells fresh after the rain. Yet all I can think about is how much harder every day seems compared to everyone else’s stories of joy and excitement. Maybe it’s time for me to stop pretending everything is okay and start looking for help.

I need a hand pulling back the curtain on this fog, even if it means facing some tough truths.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of failure. I thought bringing in extra help would make things easier, but it’s just been one thing after another. The baby cries, and no matter how hard I try to soothe them, nothing seems to work. Even when the sitter is here, she looks so overwhelmed that it feels like a burden to hand over my child.

I’m trying so hard to be okay, but every time I look at myself in the mirror, all I see is someone who’s falling apart. The exhaustion, the tears, the sheer desperation—it’s all too much. Why can’t I figure this out? I’ve tried reaching out for support, but it feels like everyone is just passing me around like a hot potato.

I know I’m not alone in these struggles, but that doesn’t make it any easier to face them every day. Today was especially tough; the baby wouldn’t sleep no matter what we did, and my mind kept wandering back to all the things I should be doing instead of just being here with them. It’s a constant battle between wanting to be present and needing a break.

I miss who I used to be before this all started. Where is that confident, capable woman? She feels like she vanished into thin air when the baby was born. Maybe it’s time for me to reach out again, find someone who can really listen and understand what I’m going through. Until then, I’ll just keep putting one foot in front of the other, hoping tomorrow will be better.

This is hard, but I have to believe there’s a light at the end of this tunnel. For now, though, it feels like being stuck in an endless dark cloud, with no clear way out.

Today marks another day since bringing home the tiny bundle of fur and fluff that’s supposed to bring joy into my life. But honestly, I feel more lost than ever. The kitten is cute, don’t get me wrong—those big eyes, those soft paws. But now there are so many things to worry about: Is she eating enough? Is the litter box clean? Do I have time for her while trying to take care of a baby?

I wake up in the middle of the night more often than not, and it’s usually because the kitten is making noises or needs something. There's no escape from this little life that depends on me now. It’s overwhelming. Sometimes, I feel like I’m drowning in all these new responsibilities.

But here’s the thing: I can’t bring myself to be upset about the kitten—I just can't muster up any real emotion towards her at all. And that feels wrong. Like there should be something more, right? Shouldn’t I be happy? But when my husband talks about how cute she is and how grateful he is for our new little family member, it’s hard to find a response other than a tired nod.

I feel like everyone around me sees the kitten as this amazing addition that brings light into dark places. They don’t see my tears or my exhaustion. Or the way I stare blankly at the walls, wishing everything would just be easier.

Today was rough—I barely got through diaper changes without breaking down. And now, I’m writing this in a dimly lit room with nothing but a cup of cold coffee for company. Maybe tomorrow will be better, but right now? Right now, I don’t know how to keep going.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and let me tell you, it’s been one heck of a ride. I’ve had moments where everything feels like a haze—exhaustion, confusion, and this gnawing feeling that something isn’t quite right. There are times when all I want to do is scream at the top of my lungs or just curl up in a ball and cry forever. The baby cries non-stop, which triggers an endless cycle of chores, changing diapers, and worrying if I’m doing any of it correctly.

But then there’s this little voice in my head saying, "Hey, maybe you’re having postpartum depression." And that scares me even more because I worry people will look at me like I’m crazy or incapable. So instead, I smile through the tears and pretend everything is fine. It’s exhausting just to keep up appearances.

I keep thinking about all those moms who seem so put together on social media. How do they manage to balance a screaming baby with a perfectly clean house and a healthy lunch every day? And here I am, surviving on black coffee, feeling like I’m barely holding it together.

But you know what? Today was also the first time my son smiled at me. It was brief, but when those chubby little arms reached out to grab my finger, something inside me softened. Maybe this isn’t all bad after all. Maybe tomorrow will be better, or maybe it won’t be, but I’m going to try and find the strength to keep moving forward.

I don’t want anyone to think I’m broken because being a new mom is hard work, and sometimes it’s okay to admit that you’re struggling. It’s just not okay to give up on yourself in the process.

Today marks two weeks since my daughter's birth, and the reality of motherhood feels like an endless loop of exhaustion and doubt. The baby cries non-stop, and I'm left wondering how this tiny life will ever understand that I am doing everything in my power to care for her. My body aches from the aftermath of childbirth, but my mind is spinning with anxiety.

It's hard not to compare myself to those perfect Instagram posts where new moms glow with happiness and confidence. In reality, I feel lost. The weight gain is overwhelming, and my ADHD seems more chaotic than ever before. Simple tasks become mountains, and I find myself snapping at everyone—my partner, the baby, even strangers.

Sleep has been a rare luxury. Every time I close my eyes, images of failure swirl in my head: dropping the baby, forgetting to feed her, missing out on all the milestones because I'm just not good enough. I know deep down that these thoughts are irrational, but they're relentless.

Yesterday, I tried to take a shower while holding the baby, only to find myself paralyzed by fear of slipping and hurting both of us. It’s like my body is betraying me in every possible way. The doctor mentioned postpartum depression, but hearing it doesn’t make it any easier to cope with.

I miss who I used to be—confident, capable, strong. Now, all I want is a break from this constant struggle. Maybe I'll try calling my therapist tomorrow and asking for some help. For now, though, I'm just going to hold on tight and hope that the sun comes up again tomorrow, bringing with it a chance at something better.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of darkness and silence. The weight of the world feels heavier than ever before, pressing down on my shoulders with each passing moment. Despite the months that have gone by since bringing little Olivia into our home, the shadows of despair still linger like an unwelcome guest.

The joy I thought would fill every corner of my heart has been replaced by a constant ache, a hollow void that seems to grow larger with each breath. Simple tasks feel insurmountable; even changing a diaper feels like climbing Mount Everest. My partner tries to help, but his presence only highlights the distance between us, a chasm carved out by isolation and sorrow.

I remind myself daily of the love I have for our daughter and the promise I made to be her rock. Yet, it's hard to hold onto that when everything inside me screams to retreat into a quiet corner and hide from the world. The nights are especially brutal, as the stillness amplifies every thought and feeling until they become overwhelming.

I know I'm not alone in this struggle, but sometimes it feels like no one truly understands the depth of my pain. My mind races with questions—when will these dark clouds lift? Is there light at the end of this tunnel?—but answers remain elusive.

Today, I made a pact with myself: to reach out for help, to not bear this burden alone any longer. It's time to break free from the shadows that have been consuming me and seek the support I desperately need. Maybe tomorrow will be different, or maybe it won't—but taking action feels like a step towards reclaiming my life.

The days blur together, but tonight, as I hold Olivia close and whisper promises of better tomorrows, I vow to fight this battle with every ounce of strength I have left.

Today marks exactly one week since I brought my little bundle of joy into the world. The past seven days have felt like an eternity. My heart aches every time I look at her tiny face and all I can think is, "How did this happen to me?" 

Sleepless nights are killing me. I lie awake for hours after she's finally asleep, my mind racing with thoughts of failure and inadequacy. Why am I like this? Other moms seem so happy and fulfilled. It’s just overwhelming.

I keep telling myself to snap out of it. The support from friends and family is amazing—I have no right to feel this way. But every day feels like a struggle, an endless loop of tears, anxiety, and self-doubt. My partner says I’m doing great but I can see the worry in his eyes.

I need help. Talking about it only makes me cry more, but I know I can't keep hiding behind smiles and small talk forever. The exhaustion is crushing my spirit. When will this end?

Tomorrow is another day, I guess. But today ends with a plea for understanding and compassion from those around me who might be in the same boat. We aren’t weak; we’re human.

Today marks two weeks since little Mia joined our family. I was so excited to meet her, but the reality of it all is overwhelming. Sleepless nights and endless feedings have me feeling drained beyond words. 

There are moments when I'm just happy to be a mom, watching her tiny fingers grasp my finger or hearing her coos in her crib. But then there are other times... times when I feel like I’m drowning under the weight of it all. My mind races with dark thoughts and worries that I can’t shake off.

Last night was particularly hard. I had one of those fits again, where everything just feels too much. Tears streaming down my face as I tried to calm Mia, feeling so alone despite being surrounded by love. It's scary how these feelings come out of nowhere, but they're real and they hurt.

I know I need help, but talking about it still feels like admitting failure. How can someone who wanted this more than anything now feel this way? Yet here we are, another day starting with coffee and hope that today might be a little better.

It's okay to struggle, isn't it? To want support without feeling guilty for not being the perfect mom right from the start. I'm trying to take it one moment at a time, reaching out when I can, and hoping for brighter days ahead.

August 14th, 8 months postpartum

Today is just another day. The same old routine: wake up early, work non-stop until exhaustion pulls me back to bed at night. I keep pushing forward, trying to make ends meet for my little girl and me. But sometimes, it feels like no matter how hard I try, the weight of everything keeps piling on.

I miss those fleeting moments when all I wanted was to hold her close and forget about the world outside. Now, even that seems impossible. My heart aches with an unexplainable sadness that won't go away. It’s been eight months since she arrived, but it feels like forever has passed by in this endless cycle of work and despair.

I need help. I know I do. But telling people how I really feel is so hard. What if they think less of me? What if they see me as weak or incapable? Deep down, though, I fear being alone with my thoughts more than facing the judgment. Can anyone truly understand what it’s like to love someone fiercely and yet be consumed by a darkness that threatens to suffocate all those feelings?

Today, while looking at her sleeping face, something inside broke open. The tears came unexpectedly, a mixture of joy and sorrow overwhelming me in this quiet moment. Maybe it's time to ask for help before I lose myself completely.

I want to be there for my baby, but how can I when I’m struggling just to breathe? There has to be another way forward, even if that means stepping back from the relentless pace for a bit and focusing on healing. It’s scary, but it feels necessary now more than ever.

Maybe today is when things start to change. Maybe tomorrow will bring clarity and strength. For now, all I can do is hope.

Today marks a full month since Lily was born. I sit here with her in my arms, the tiny bundle of joy who has completely upended my life. It's been a rollercoaster of emotions, sleepless nights, and endless diaper changes. But amidst all this chaos, there have been moments of pure bliss. Her first smile, her first gurgle—I could listen to those sounds for hours.

But it's not all sunshine and rainbows. Some days are harder than others. There are times when the weight of being a new mother feels too much to bear. I feel like I'm drowning in responsibilities and uncertainties. It’s scary, really. I catch myself questioning if I’m doing everything right, wondering if this feeling will ever go away.

The thing that keeps me going is the love and support from my family and friends. My mom has been a rock, offering to help with night feeds and holding Lily when I need some rest. My best friend texts me daily, checking in and reminding me that it's okay to not be okay. These small acts of kindness are like lifelines pulling me through the rough patches.

Today, I decided to write this down. To acknowledge my struggles but also celebrate the incredible support system around me. Every day is a new chance to get better, to grow stronger. And for every step forward, there’s someone cheering me on from the sidelines. For that, I am truly grateful.

April 3rd, 2023

Presli is now three weeks old, and the days are blurring together in a haze of sleepless nights and endless feedings. There’s an overwhelming sense of love for this tiny human who has taken over my heart and home, but it's mixed with something else—an ache that doesn't quite feel right.

I’ve been isolating myself more often than not. The thought of stepping out into the world seems daunting, almost terrifying. It’s like there’s a thick fog in my mind that makes everything feel heavy and hard to manage. But Presli needs me, so I push through it.

Today was better though. My friend Lily stayed with us for two days. She cooked, cleaned, and just talked to me about anything but baby stuff. We laughed, we reminisced, and for a moment, the fog lifted. It’s moments like these that remind me I’m not alone in this.

I know it's important to reach out when I need help—especially since there’s history here with postpartum depression. Lily is one of my safe spaces right now, but I also want to start reaching out more broadly—to family, friends, and professionals who can offer support without judgment.

Presli smiles at me today as if to say "Thanks for being here." And in that moment, the weight feels a little lighter, even if it's just for now.

Day 3 Postpartum

I woke up to the blinding light of a new day, or what feels like an endless loop of days since my baby arrived. It's hard to tell if it’s morning, noon, or night anymore. My body hurts in ways I never thought possible—aching muscles, soreness between my legs that refuses to fade—and there’s this constant, throbbing headache nestled deep behind my eyes. Oh, and the crying. The non-stop wailing that echoes through every corner of our home.

I barely sleep now. Every time I close my eyes for a few minutes, it's like someone is ripping me out of bed and thrusting me back into reality. Night after night, it’s been this vicious cycle. No relief in sight. And with each day, the exhaustion seeps deeper into my bones, making even the smallest tasks feel monumental.

Why does everyone say that motherhood is beautiful? They must have a different definition of beauty because from where I'm standing, it looks like an endless sea of pain and fatigue. The joy they talk about feels so far away, maybe on another planet or in someone else’s life story.

Today, I tried to smile when people congratulated me on being a new mom. But those smiles feel forced, hollow. Inside, I’m screaming for help but no one can hear my silent cries through the mask of happiness society expects me to wear.

I miss my old self. The one who laughed easily and wasn't weighed down by sleep deprivation or physical pain. I want her back desperately because this new person staring back at me from the mirror scares me. She looks lost, broken even.

But there’s still hope. There has to be. Maybe tomorrow will bring a glimmer of that promised beauty they speak of. Until then, though, all I can do is keep pushing forward one day at a time, hoping for better days ahead.

Today marks a week since I started my antidepressants for postpartum depression. Honestly, it's been a rollercoaster of emotions and self-discovery. The pills have helped stabilize me, making the overwhelming sadness slightly more manageable. But here’s the thing—I’ve realized that medication alone isn’t enough to fix everything.

Therapy has become an essential part of my routine. Talking to someone about what I’m going through feels like a weight off my shoulders. It's not just about crying and venting, though; it's about understanding why these feelings are there in the first place. The support from my therapist is invaluable, and I can already see small changes in how I cope with stress.

There’s this moment every day when I hold my baby and everything feels right. But then, out of nowhere, a wave of sadness hits me hard. Those moments remind me that I need all the tools—medication and therapy—to navigate through them. It’s okay to acknowledge my struggles openly and seek help actively.

Life with a newborn is nothing like what movies or TV shows depict. It's chaotic, exhausting, yet beautifully rewarding. Today, as I rocked my baby to sleep, I made a promise to myself: I won’t give up on finding the balance that works for me. Each day is another step forward, no matter how small.

Today feels like an endless loop of emptiness and fear. The baby's cries echo through the house, a constant reminder that I'm not coping well at all. My mind swirls with doubts—will I ever be able to care for this tiny life? It’s hard to shake off the feeling that something is terribly wrong.

I've been avoiding my husband's gaze, knowing he can see right through me. He tries his best, but it feels like a losing battle. The weight of postpartum depression sits heavy on my chest, suffocating any joy or hope left in me. It’s like being trapped in a dark cloud that refuses to lift.

Sometimes I wonder if having guns around is too dangerous for someone with my mind. That thought scares me more than anything else. I’m not sure what’s real and what isn’t anymore. The world feels unpredictable, threatening at times. How can I protect us from the shadows creeping into every corner of our lives?

I need help, but where do I start? It seems like everyone is too busy or too distant to understand what it's truly like. Each day feels like a struggle, and tonight feels especially hard. But maybe tomorrow will be different.

I’m trying to hold on, hoping that someday soon, the sun will shine again through this stormy sky. Until then, I’ll keep putting one foot in front of the other, praying for strength and clarity.

Today marks one month since little Emma joined our world. The days blend together in a haze of feedings, diaper changes, and endless sleepless nights. Yet amidst this overwhelming love and joy, there's an undercurrent of something far more sinister—loneliness.

Everyone tells me to focus on the positives, but how do you feel positive when everyone seems distant? I see posts from friends about their adventures and achievements, and all I can think is that they've forgotten me. It’s not just them; even family members who used to visit daily now text less often or send vague messages. I know I’m being overly sensitive, but it feels like no one cares anymore.

The doctor suggested avoiding negativity, which sounds great in theory. But how do you stay upbeat when everything seems so bleak? Every time I look at Emma’s tiny face, I worry about the future instead of marveling at her beauty. The weight of this responsibility is crushing me, and it feels like no one understands.

Sometimes I dream about talking to someone who truly gets what I’m going through, but when I try to reach out, words get stuck in my throat. It’s a vicious cycle—I want support but push people away because I fear they won’t understand or will judge my struggles as selfish.

I need help, but admitting that feels like failure. Why can't I be the perfect mother everyone expects me to be? Maybe tomorrow things will change, but for now, it's just another day of feeling lost and alone in this new life.

Today feels like a never-ending struggle. The sun is up but the weight of yesterday’s exhaustion still clings to my bones. I’ve been told to just have more self-control, to be stronger. As if that’s all it takes.

The baby cries again and I feel myself cracking under the pressure. Every time I try to express how overwhelmed I am, I’m met with disappointment or silence. Why can’t they understand? Hormones rage through me like a storm, but no one sees past the tired smiles.

I’m alone in this. Or so it feels. Each day is a battle against my own mind, trying to find some semblance of peace amidst chaos. But it’s hard to hold on when everyone expects you to just “be better.”

It’s been weeks since I’ve felt truly okay. The world outside seems normal, but inside, I’m drowning in uncertainty and fear. Why can’t they see the depth of my struggle?

I miss being seen, truly understood. But here I am, another day lost in thoughts that won’t leave me alone. Maybe tomorrow will be different, but for now, I just need to survive this moment.

Another day goes by, and I’m still searching for a lifeline.

Today was a tough day. I woke up feeling like there wasn't enough sleep in the world to fix this foggy exhaustion that clings to my bones. The moment we walked through our front door with baby in arms, tears started streaming down my face for reasons I can’t quite pinpoint. It's not just about being tired—I feel it deep in my heart and mind too.

The last few months have been a rollercoaster of emotions and fears. My postpartum depression has been relentless, pulling me under waves of sadness that drown out everything else. Despite the overwhelming love for our children, the worry about their health adds another layer of anxiety. Each time I catch myself second-guessing whether they're breathing right or if there's something wrong with them, it hits me hard.

I know logically that these fears are part of my depression, but that doesn't make them any less real or scary in the moment. My kids mean everything to me—they’re my whole world—but today, I felt so far away from being able to enjoy that. It's exhausting to fight this battle every single day and keep pushing forward.

But they're also the reason I try harder each morning. Tomorrow might be better. Maybe it will just take one small thing—a smile, a cuddle—to remind me why all of this is worth it. Right now though, I'm just trying to get through tonight without falling apart completely.

Today marks three weeks since Lily's birth. The joy and overwhelming love I feel for her is indescribable, yet it’s intertwined with a nagging anxiety that seems to grow each day. I worry about everything from whether she’s getting enough tummy time to ensuring she has the best education possible when she grows up. It’s as if the weight of the world rests on my shoulders now.

James tries his hardest to support me, but sometimes it feels like no matter what he does, it isn’t quite enough. He reminds me that I’m doing a great job and encourages me to focus more on myself. It’s hard to believe in myself when all I can think about is making mistakes.

I’ve been trying to read up on postpartum depression and have talked with my doctor about how I’m feeling. Knowing others go through this helps, but it doesn’t make the fear any less real. Today I took a long walk by myself to clear my head—maybe I should do that more often. It’s funny how sometimes just being alone can feel like such a luxury.

I know Lily is okay and we’re both doing well, but there are moments when it feels like everything could fall apart at any second. I’m trying not to let these thoughts consume me completely, though. James keeps reminding me that taking care of myself isn’t selfish; it’s essential. Maybe he’s right. Maybe finding a balance will help ease some of this anxiety.

For now, I’ll keep focusing on the small steps—like getting enough sleep and eating better—and hope for clearer days ahead.

Today marks the third week since giving birth to our beautiful baby girl. I've been struggling with so much more than just physical recovery; there's this dark cloud hanging over me, threatening to take everything away. The idea of stopping my medication sends shivers down my spine—what if it all comes crashing back? Bipolar disorder is no joke, and I know firsthand how quickly things can spiral out of control.

I feel like a ticking time bomb, waiting for the moment when everything falls apart. My mind races with worries about being a good mother while battling my own mental health demons. It's overwhelming, to say the least. The midwife mentioned something about going off meds postpartum, but it feels impossible. How am I supposed to face this new chapter without the safety net of my medication?

There are moments when I feel so incredibly grateful and in love with our little one. Those moments are few and far between though, overshadowed by a persistent sense of dread. It’s hard not to wonder if I’ll ever truly find joy again. The thought of reaching out for help feels like admitting defeat, but maybe that's exactly what I need.

Tonight, as I hold her close, I pray for strength and clarity. There has to be a way to navigate this tricky terrain without losing myself in the process. Maybe tomorrow will bring some answers or at least a glimmer of hope. For now, all I can do is take it one breath at a time.

Today feels like a never-ending spiral of chaos. The baby cries incessantly, and my head is spinning with the constant demands and expectations. It's as if all the joy from those early days of pregnancy has been replaced by this overwhelming sense of dread and sadness. I can't seem to shake it off no matter how hard I try.

The breakdown came unexpectedly, a sudden burst of tears followed by an eerie silence. Afterward, everything seemed muted, like the world around me had faded into grayscale. My partner tries to help, but there's this unspoken tension between us. He means well, but sometimes his attempts only add fuel to my anxiety fires.

Family members mean well too, yet their advice often feels like a barrage of unsolicited opinions and pressure. They don't understand the depth of my struggle or how utterly alone I feel in it all. It's a daily battle just trying to keep up with basic tasks without breaking down completely.

Tonight, as I hold our newborn while everyone else seems busy or distant, I'm left grappling with these conflicting emotions—love and despair intertwined like a twisted ribbon. I know I need help, but where do you even begin when the world feels this heavy?

Tomorrow might bring a glimmer of hope, or it might not. For now, I'll just take one breath at a time and try to find my way through this dark tunnel.

Today feels like a never-ending shadow of darkness and sadness. I woke up to tears rolling down my cheeks again, just like every morning since... well, forever it seems now. Holding this tiny, precious life in my arms should be the most joyful thing ever, but all I feel is emptiness.

The weight of everything is crushing me. My mom's attempts... the hospital visits, the waiting rooms full of worry and fear—it’s all too much to bear. And then there's me, a new mom who can barely hold it together, let alone care for my little one with any semblance of joy or strength.

How do you smile when your heart is breaking? How do you laugh when tears are the only thing that come out? Every day feels like a battle against this overwhelming sadness. I try to be there for my baby, but honestly, some days it's just too hard. Too exhausting.

I know I need help, but reaching out seems impossible right now. I’m stuck in this dark place, and every little sound or movement from the baby sends me into another spiral of tears and despair. Why is this happening? How do I make it stop?

Please, if anyone out there can hear my cries for help, please don’t let me drown in this abyss any longer.

Today marks one week since my baby arrived, and it feels like an eternity. The exhaustion is relentless, a heavy blanket draped over me at all hours of the day. But it's not just tiredness that weighs on me—it’s this deep, bottomless despair that seeps into every corner of my heart.

The fear is overwhelming too, a constant shadow lurking behind closed doors and whispering in the darkness when everyone else sleeps. I feel like I'm failing at everything—feeding him, soothing his cries, just being there for both of us. Every time he wakes up, it's as if the world stops spinning and reality fades into this awful haze where nothing makes sense anymore.

I keep telling myself that things will get better, but when you're in the middle of a storm like this, hope feels like a distant memory. I look at him and love him so fiercely, yet there’s also this overwhelming fear that I won’t be able to protect him from all the pain out there—and maybe even the pain within me.

This is supposed to be one of the happiest times in my life, but it's been the worst nightmare I never imagined. If only someone could understand how lost and alone I feel.

Today feels like one of those days where I just want to hide under the covers and pretend everything is okay when it isn’t. Holding my baby is supposed to be magical, but all I feel is a heavy weight in my chest, dragging me down into this black hole where hopelessness reigns.

I haven't slept properly for what feels like weeks. Every time I close my eyes, there are these nagging thoughts whispering in the back of my mind, telling me that I’m not good enough to be a mother. But then, when I open them again, there’s this tiny little person staring back at me with those big curious eyes, and all I want is for her to be happy.

Writing has become my lifeline lately. It's like talking to someone who won't judge or give advice; just a place where I can pour out everything that's swirling around in here. Maybe it’s just a way to get some of the bad stuff out so I don’t drown in it completely.

Today, as I’m cradling my baby, I’m also holding onto this notebook on my phone. It’s our secret little conversation, and even though I know things won't be perfect, having this space makes me feel a bit more human again.

I hope that tomorrow is better because today has been rough. But for now, I’ll just keep breathing and writing until the sun comes up, or at least until my eyes can’t stay open any longer.

Today was one of those days when it felt like everything was slipping away from me. The baby’s cries echoed in my head all day long as I tried to focus on work tasks that seemed impossible to complete. It's not just the stress; it's this overwhelming feeling of failure because my milk supply is dwindling, and every time I look at him, I feel like a disappointment.

Breastfeeding was supposed to be a bond between us, something special and nurturing. Now it feels like an unattainable dream. The workplace environment here is just not supportive for mothers trying to pump. Every minute away from my desk means more work piling up on me, and every ounce of milk I miss pumping seems like another step backward.

I know logically that there are options—formula can fill in the gaps—but it doesn’t change how badly I want this connection with him through breastfeeding. It's like a void no amount of formula can close. And then there’s my headspace; postpartum depression is a beast I didn't see coming, and every day feels like climbing a mountain.

Tonight, as I hold him to nurse, the thought crosses my mind that maybe it's okay not to be perfect, but knowing that doesn’t make this easier. It feels isolating, like no one truly understands unless they’ve walked this path themselves. Maybe tomorrow will be better, or maybe not—but either way, I’m here, trying my best amidst everything.

It’s hard to keep fighting when the battle seems endless and unyielding. But then there are moments, brief glimmers of light—like seeing his sleepy smile, or watching him explore the world in those tiny hands. These moments remind me that this journey is worth it, even if I'm not sure how to make every day a little brighter right now.

Tomorrow will come with its own challenges and maybe some unexpected joys. For now, all I can do is keep trying to find balance amidst chaos, hoping that support and understanding are just around the corner.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my baby girl home. It's like walking through a fog that never lifts. The exhaustion is so profound, it feels like the weight of the world presses down on me every second of every day. There are moments when I can’t shake this feeling that something is terribly wrong with me because all I want to do is sleep or cry.

I remember sitting in my OB-GYN's office a few weeks ago, discussing our future plans. The thought of having more children feels like a distant dream now. My heart aches for the little girl who used to think about expanding her family without hesitation. It’s scary how quickly things can change when you’re struggling with your mental health.

But there are glimmers of hope too. I’ve been reaching out, talking to friends and family about what I’m going through. They’ve been incredibly supportive, which is something I need right now. Therapy sessions have started, and while they're tough, I feel a little less alone each time we meet. It’s a journey, and it’s okay that I don’t know where this road will lead yet.

I am proud of myself for taking these steps, even if progress feels agonizingly slow. For now, I’m focusing on getting through one day at a time. Today was just another tough day, but tomorrow is another chance to breathe easier and maybe even smile a little more.

Today marks another day in this journey of recovery from postpartum depression. It’s been almost a year and a half since I gave birth to my little miracle, yet it feels like an eternity has passed. The days were long, the nights even longer, as I battled with feelings of inadequacy and isolation. There were moments when everything felt overwhelming, but looking back now, I see that those dark clouds have started to lift.

I’ve learned that reaching out for help is not a sign of weakness; it’s an act of strength. My husband has been my rock, offering unwavering support whenever I needed it most. Friends and family too—each one played a vital role in helping me navigate through the storm. Therapy sessions have become a sanctuary where I can speak freely about what I’m going through without fear of judgment.

The shift began subtly at first—a gentle breeze on an otherwise windy day. It started with small victories, like successfully cooking a meal for my family or simply getting out of bed in the morning. Each triumph was celebrated internally, building momentum and confidence. Slowly but surely, those clouds are thinning, allowing glimpses of sunshine to penetrate through.

I’m learning to embrace each moment as it comes, cherishing the good days while acknowledging that there will still be tough ones ahead. But now, I know how to face them with a stronger mindset and a supportive network by my side. This is a journey of growth, resilience, and hope.

Today marks a year since I welcomed my baby into the world, but it feels like a lifetime ago. The initial joy of becoming a mother quickly gave way to something darker and more overwhelming than anything I could have imagined. Every day is a struggle, filled with tears and pain that never seem to let up.

Breastfeeding was supposed to be this beautiful bond between us, but instead, it's become the source of my deepest agony. My breasts ache constantly, and every feeding session feels like torture. The constant discomfort makes me dread each mealtime, knowing what's coming. I've cried more times than I can count over the past year—over the pain, over the frustration, even over something as simple as a passing glance from someone who seems to have it all figured out.

The isolation is suffocating. It feels like no one truly understands the depth of my despair. Even my partner and family mean well, but their words of encouragement feel hollow when I'm drowning in this abyss of sadness. I know deep down that I need help, but reaching out seems impossible right now. Maybe tomorrow will be different, or maybe it won't matter at all.

Today, I just want to hold on a little longer. To keep going even though everything hurts so much.

Today feels like a never-ending battle. The exhaustion is overwhelming, and the weight of two tiny lives resting on my shoulders feels insurmountable. I've been trying so hard to breastfeed them, but it's just not happening. Hospital-grade pump, lactation consultant—none of it seems to be making a difference. The guilt is suffocating.

Sleep? A luxury from another world. My mind races through the night, filled with thoughts that don't make sense in the light of day. How can I care for these precious babies when I feel like I’m unraveling at the seams?

The lactation consultant visits again tomorrow. I hope she has something new to offer because right now, it feels like everything is falling apart. The tears are constant, and my heart aches with each failed attempt to feed them.

But there's also this overwhelming love for my babies that keeps me going. They need me, even when I don't feel capable of being what they need. It’s terrifying, but in those moments, I’m filled with an unbreakable resolve to figure it out.

Tomorrow is another day, and maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe not. But for now, I’ll try again because that's all any of us can do—try again.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of worry and uncertainty. I woke up to the same anxious thoughts that have been swirling around my head for weeks now—will I be okay if I get pregnant? The idea sends chills down my spine, not just because of the physical changes but the mental ones too. My meds feel so necessary right now, yet every time I think about continuing them during a pregnancy, fear grips me tight.

What if the side effects hurt the baby? What if stopping them means losing control again, like last time? It’s exhausting, this constant balancing act between protecting my mental health and worrying about the repercussions. The thought of going off my meds fills me with dread, but staying on them feels equally terrifying.

I’ve been trying to stay strong, to push through these thoughts, but it’s getting harder every day. There are moments when I feel like I might be losing myself all over again, that same creeping darkness from before is starting to edge its way back into my life. The idea of facing this alone feels impossible, and yet reaching out for help feels like admitting defeat.

I keep telling myself that everything will be okay, that I’ll find a way through this. But the doubts linger like an unwelcome guest in every corner of my mind. It’s times like these when I wish there was someone who could just hold all the answers for me, but mostly, it’s about finding strength within myself to navigate this uncharted territory.

Today, as I sit here holding the book that once belonged to my mom and flipping through its pages, trying to find comfort in her words from years ago, I feel a strange mix of hope and despair. The thought of having another chance at motherhood is beautiful yet terrifying. There’s no simple way out, only a path paved with difficult choices and uncertain outcomes.

I need support right now, but more than that, I need to believe that I can handle whatever comes next. It’s just one day at a time for me, trying to stay present in the moment rather than getting lost in the future's uncertainties.

Today was one of those days where every moment felt heavy with unspoken words and judgment. I woke up to the sound of my newborn's cries, a reminder that life has changed forever, but not in ways I might have hoped for. The mirror isn’t as kind today; it shows me a body that feels foreign, swollen, bruised—everything but beautiful.

Someone close told me recently that I should be over being nervous about how I look now that the baby's here. They said women who get postpartum depression shouldn't even have kids in the first place. It was like a punch to the gut. How can anyone think it’s okay to say something so cruel and dismissive? I’m struggling enough as it is, without feeling guilty for being human.

I tried to push those thoughts away while changing diapers and feeding this tiny person who depends on me. But every time I looked in the mirror, their words echoed back at me. Why am I even here if this is how they feel?

It’s hard not to spiral into a dark place when you’re already teetering on the edge of something worse. I know I need help and support, but sometimes it feels like nobody understands or cares enough.

Today, all I want is someone who will listen without judgment, offer a kind word, maybe even hug me through this chaos. But for now, I’ll just take one step at a time, hoping that tomorrow brings a little more clarity and compassion.

Today marks three weeks since I gave birth to my little miracle. The days are a blur of sleepless nights and endless feeds. But amidst the chaos, there’s this nagging feeling that lingers like an unwelcome guest. It started small—a quiet whisper in the back of my mind—but now it feels louder with each passing day.

Why can’t I shake this? Why does every tiny task feel like climbing a mountain? The weight of everything is crushing me, and the baby just keeps growing and demanding more from me.

Yet, amidst these dark thoughts, there’s a glimmer of hope. When I first held my child, I was terrified about breastfeeding. But with support from friends and online resources, I learned that formula isn’t the enemy. My kids are now healthy young adults, proof that love and nurturing come in many forms. Today, as I prepare a bottle for my newborn, I feel a sense of calm wash over me. It’s okay to take this one step at a time.

Every day is new, every challenge is an opportunity to grow stronger. I’m not alone in this journey; there are so many resources out there that can help us mamas through the toughest moments. And as for my little bundle of joy? He’ll be just fine—maybe even healthier because of it.

Today marks another week since little one arrived, and while I’ve felt a glimmer of hope in my mood lately, the physical pain is relentless. It’s as if my body has forgotten how to rest, let alone heal properly after everything it went through. The sleepless nights are turning into hazy days where time blurs together like an endless cycle of feeding, changing diapers, and nursing.

I’ve been trying to keep busy with baby stuff—slinging up a comfy spot for night feeds, learning all sorts of soothing techniques—but the nagging sense that something is off still lingers. It’s hard not to compare this moment to my last pregnancy when I felt so lost in the fog of postpartum depression. This time around, there's an undercurrent of fear mixed with a strange calmness.

The support from friends and family has been amazing, but sometimes it feels like everyone is tiptoeing around me, unsure if they’re saying or doing the right things. I’ve started to talk more openly about how I’m feeling, which helps in small ways. There’s this weird mix of gratitude for each day my mood seems a bit steadier and frustration that healing isn’t as swift as I’d wish.

I keep reminding myself it's okay not to be okay all the time. It’s just another chapter in the journey, one where self-care feels like a luxury rather than a necessity. But today, I’m going to try and find a moment for myself—a warm bath or maybe some gentle stretches—because taking care of me is crucial right now.

Tomorrow will bring its challenges, but for now, there’s this quiet comfort in knowing that each day is another step forward.

April 3rd, 2002

Today marks the one-month anniversary of my son's birth. I've been navigating through waves of emotions that feel like a rollercoaster ride. The euphoria of holding him for the first time is still fresh in my mind, yet it’s mixed with overwhelming exhaustion and sadness.

The baby blues have hit hard; I’m struggling to find joy in anything. There were moments when all I wanted was a break from the constant feedings, diaper changes, and sleepless nights. But then I remember how beautiful he looks as he sleeps peacefully beside me, and it makes everything feel worth it again.

My OB mentioned postpartum depression after my last visit and suggested medication. I was hesitant at first but decided to give it a try. The pills have helped ease the sadness and anxiety, but they’ve also brought about this weird sensation of dizziness. It’s like standing on an invisible roller coaster; everything feels off-balance.

Today, I felt more grounded than usual—maybe because I finally had some time alone with my husband or perhaps it was just one of those good days where everything fell into place effortlessly. Either way, it made me think about how important it is to talk openly about these feelings and not suffer in silence.

I hope sharing this helps others who might be going through the same thing know they’re not alone. Postpartum recovery isn’t linear, but with support and understanding, there’s light at the end of the tunnel.

Today marks another day since giving birth to my little one. The exhaustion is overwhelming, and I find myself questioning every decision I've made over the last few months. One of those decisions was choosing to breastfeed again—something that felt right in theory but has turned out to be a constant source of stress and anxiety.

Breastfeeding seems like it should be natural and easy, but the reality is far different. My body feels sore, my mind feels foggy, and my emotions are all over the place. I keep thinking back to my previous postpartum experiences when breastfeeding left me feeling inadequate and overwhelmed. Now, as I hold my baby close, I can't help but wonder if this time will be any different.

The weight of responsibility feels crushing sometimes. I worry about not being a good enough mother, not providing the best start for my child. My thoughts are consumed by doubts and fears that seem to grow with each passing day. It's hard to feel joy when everything feels like such an uphill battle.

I know I need support and help, but reaching out feels like another challenge. Maybe tomorrow will be better—I hope it will be. For now, all I can do is take one breath at a time and try to find some peace in the chaos.

Today marks three weeks since I welcomed my baby into the world. The nights are long and filled with a relentless cycle of feeding and changing diapers. But what should be a time of joy feels more like an endless tunnel without light at the end.

I’ve always known that life has its ups and downs, but this is different. I can’t shake off the heavy fog that settles over me every morning. The fear gnaws at my heart when I try to imagine how I’ll manage all of this on my own. My history whispers in my ear, a constant reminder of what’s lurking beneath the surface.

I struggle with words when people ask how I’m doing. It feels like a lie to say everything is okay because it isn’t. Inside, I’m screaming for help but can’t find the voice to let anyone know that something is seriously wrong. There’s so much stigma around mental health in our community, and I feel trapped by it.

I wish I could just snap out of this, push away these dark thoughts and be the mother everyone expects me to be. But trying harder only makes me crash harder. The guilt eats at me like a hungry beast. How do I navigate this when everything inside screams that there’s something seriously broken?

Today was rough. It started with another sleepless night, followed by a morning of crying more than my baby did. I felt so small and alone. The world seemed to revolve around me but not for the reasons it should.

I need someone to understand without judgment. I’m scared and sad and tired all at once. Yet, here we are, another day with no sign of sunshine breaking through the clouds that笼罩在我心头。我不知道这条路会通向哪里，但我知道我不能独自面对这一切。也许今天我可以试着迈出第一步，寻找那个可以理解我的人。

Day 34

Today marks the end of my fourth week as a new mom, and it's been an exhausting journey. The days blend together in a haze of sleeplessness and overwhelming emotions. I knew something wasn't right from day one, but I just couldn't put my finger on what exactly was wrong. Everyone kept telling me how wonderful it is to have a baby, that the exhaustion and mood swings are normal parts of motherhood. But as days turned into weeks, I started feeling this crushing weight of sadness that wouldn’t go away no matter how many times I held my little boy.

It's funny how much joy he brings, yet there’s still this dark cloud hanging over me all day long. Some moments when I look at his innocent face and hear him cooing, it feels like a ray of sunshine breaking through the clouds for just a second. But then reality sets in again with another wave of despair.

My husband has been amazing, trying to help as much as possible. He noticed my struggles early on but couldn’t really understand what I was going through until he read about postpartum depression. Now we talk more openly and it helps knowing that I’m not alone. There are times when everything feels too heavy and I just want to curl up in bed, hoping the next day will be better.

Today I made an appointment with a therapist who specializes in maternal mental health issues. It’s scary stepping out into the unknown like this, but I can’t keep pretending that everything is fine. Maybe it won't solve all my problems overnight, but maybe—just maybe—it'll help me start to feel like myself again soon.

In the meantime, every time my son smiles at me, I remind myself why fighting through these dark moments is worth it. He’s the only thing that truly brings light into my days right now.

Today marks my third week since I gave birth to our little miracle, and while the world around me seems to be spinning in a whirlwind of joy and excitement, I find myself feeling adrift. The hospital staff had me enrolled in a postpartum depression support group without any real indication that I needed it. It's been more of a reminder of what I'm missing out on rather than an aid.

Sitting here in my room surrounded by baby books and toys, I can't help but feel like an imposter. Everyone around me is talking about their traumatic birth experiences or their ongoing struggles with the blues, while I just sit there feeling guilty for not having a story to share. The program isn’t tailored to someone who hasn't experienced any of it. It’s like being forced to wear shoes two sizes too small.

I keep telling myself that this is all part of the process, but the disconnect between my reality and what everyone else seems to be going through is starting to wear on me. I just wish there were more options out there for moms like me who are just trying to figure things out without feeling lost in a sea of problems they don’t have.

Today's challenge was navigating the stack of advice from well-meaning friends, all geared towards women who feel overwhelmed or alone, but not me. It’s hard to find resources that speak to my experience when everything seems to be about overcoming struggles I’ve never had.

So here I am, trying to navigate this new world with a baby in tow and a sense of isolation growing inside me because no one understands what it's like to feel fine yet not quite right.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of exhaustion and confusion. Just when I thought the baby was finally sleeping through the night, another wave of anxiety hits me hard. My doctor suggested more self-care, but honestly, how am I supposed to care for myself when I can barely keep my eyes open? 

I threw away my medications yesterday. The idea of relying on them just felt like giving up, and somehow, I thought I could handle this alone. But here’s the thing—I’m not handling it at all. Every day feels like a battle against sleep deprivation and a cloud of sadness that won’t lift.

The nurse who visited today tried to reassure me about my choices, but her words washed over me. Right now, all I want is to be okay without feeling trapped by these pills or overwhelmed by the advice everyone keeps throwing at me. But as I look around this messy room and see endless bottles of discarded medication, I can’t help but feel like I’ve lost control.

Maybe tomorrow will be different, but right now, all I can do is hope for a moment where everything doesn’t seem so heavy.
