Today was one of those days when everything feels like a struggle. The camera flash went off, and the image it captured is etched in my mind—a blurry snapshot of our family's pain. My baby wouldn’t stop crying; every snap seemed to punctuate her distress. It’s hard to look at that photo without feeling overwhelmed by how tough this period has been.

I never expected to feel so much anguish after bringing a new life into the world. But here I am, grappling with the reality of postpartum depression. The tears fall silently now as I think about how I should be cherishing every moment instead of dreading them. 

Every day feels like climbing another mountain just to get by. Yet, there are glimmers of hope too—a warm hug from my partner or a fleeting smile when my baby stops crying long enough for me to catch it. Those moments make everything else bearable.

I know I need help and support, but reaching out seems like such an effort. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, I’ll hold onto those tiny glimpses of happiness and hope they’ll grow into something stronger.

This is my struggle today—a battle against the shadows that threaten to consume me. And yet, there’s a small part of me that refuses to give in. Maybe tomorrow won’t be perfect, but maybe it will be better than today.

Today marks exactly one week since little Ava joined our family. The nursery is finally homey with her soft toys and pastel blankets. I've been trying to embrace each moment but it feels like a constant uphill battle against my own insecurities.

It’s day seven, and while everyone says this is the beginning of a beautiful journey, all I feel is overwhelmed and unsure if I’m doing enough. The baby books suggest that new parents should be in awe, yet here I am, feeling more inadequate with each passing hour. Sleep deprivation aside, there's just so much to do—feedings, diaper changes, figuring out her cues.

I keep telling myself to take it one day at a time, but my mind races ahead. Am I supposed to know exactly what she needs? Is it normal to doubt everything from when to feed her to whether I’m holding her too tightly or not enough?

I’ve been trying to stay positive and proactive about my mental health because I know postpartum depression is no joke. I've started a small routine of stepping outside for fresh air, talking with friends who are also new parents, and reminding myself that every mom gets the blues sometimes.

So today, instead of feeling like a failure, I’m going to focus on the tiny victories: getting dressed without forgetting my phone in the baby’s room, remembering her bath time, and even just managing not to fall asleep while nursing. Baby steps, right?

Here's to hoping tomorrow brings more clarity and less questioning if I'm cut out for this role. For now, though, I’m okay with it being a messy start because life isn’t always neat and tidy anyway.

Today feels like an eternity in a single day. I woke up to the sound of my baby’s cries and it struck me hard: why did I think this was what I wanted? The weight of responsibility is suffocating. Every moment, every decision—it's all on me now.

My partner and family are amazing. They help with everything they can. But no matter how much support there is, the thought that any mistake could harm my baby hits me like a freight train. I feel so alone in this fear, even surrounded by love.

Sometimes I envy those who seem to glide through parenthood effortlessly. It’s not fair—I know all these people are struggling too. But it doesn’t make it easier when you’re the one crumbling under the pressure.

I try to remind myself of the joy and love my baby brings into my life, but sometimes it feels like a distant dream I can’t reach. Today was another day of trying to navigate this new reality with a heart full of fear and hope.

Maybe tomorrow will be better? Or maybe just one hour at a time. One breath at a time.

January 3rd, Month Four

I can't believe it's been four months since little Luna arrived. I still remember the overwhelming joy mixed with terror when she first wrapped her tiny hands around my finger in the hospital. But that bliss quickly gave way to a darkness that took over every corner of my mind and heart. The sleepless nights, the constant fear that I wasn't enough for this new life I created—these feelings were suffocating.

Months have passed, but it feels like an eternity since the days when all I wanted was to escape from reality. Even now, there are moments when the weight of what I've been through is too heavy to bear. But today, as I watched Luna's little fingers grasp a rattle with such determination, something inside me shifted. It dawned on me that I am more than my depression; I'm her mother, and she needs me.

I often wonder if others are going through what I did, silently suffering without the support or understanding they need to heal. My journey was long, but it’s not lost on me how fortunate I am to have made it this far. There were times when giving up felt like a relief, but today, as I hold Luna and look into her curious eyes, I feel a glimmer of hope.

Recovery is a marathon, not a sprint. Each day brings new challenges, but there are also small victories worth celebrating. I'm learning to be kinder to myself in this process, acknowledging that healing takes time and effort. For now, I'll focus on the present, cherishing every smile and coo from Luna, and knowing that with each passing day, I’m getting better.

I’m still here, still fighting, and for that, I feel incredibly lucky.

Today marks another day in this never-ending cycle of exhaustion and despair. The baby sleeps peacefully beside me, a stark contrast to the turmoil inside my head. I know there's supposed to be joy, but all I feel is numbness. It’s like I’m watching someone else go through these motions—changing diapers, feeding, soothing—but I’m detached from it all.

The idea that everyone talks about—the instant love for your newborn—is a foreign concept to me. Instead of elation, there's this overwhelming sense of failure. People talk about the “baby blues,” but what if it’s more than just sadness? What if it's something deeper, darker?

I keep telling myself I should be stronger, that I can pull through this on my own. But the truth is, every day feels like a battle against an unseen enemy. My mind races with thoughts of inadequacy and worry. How am I supposed to take care of this tiny human when even basic tasks feel insurmountable?

There’s also the stigma—people are quick to judge those who struggle after childbirth. They think it’s all about hormones or that you just need to “snap out” of it. But it’s not that simple. My brain feels like a heavy, immovable object, dragging me down.

Tonight, I’m reaching out for help. It’s scary and feels wrong somehow, but maybe there’s hope in admitting I can’t do this alone. Maybe tomorrow will be different.

Today marks three weeks since little Maya entered our world. Some days feel like a dream, others like a nightmare I can't escape from. The joy of holding her for the first time has been overshadowed by an emptiness that just won’t go away.

Sleep is a distant memory. I lay awake wondering if I’m doing this right. Is it okay to still feel so lost? My body aches, and my mind races with thoughts of inadequacy and failure. It’s like there's no off switch in my brain—constant worry about everything from feeding her properly to whether I’ll ever laugh again.

I’ve tried to reach out for help but the shame keeps me silent. When everyone congratulates me on this ‘wonderful’ moment, I feel like an imposter. How can they not see that there’s darkness here too?

Yesterday, my mom came over and tried her best to take care of everything. She told me she could tell something wasn’t right but didn't know how to help. It made me cry harder than I have in a while.

The guilt is crushing. For months before Maya was born, I prepared for this day. Read every book, took the classes, imagined my perfect moments as a mother. But now that it’s real, it feels like a setup. Maybe there's something wrong with me.

I need to be strong for everyone else but tonight, I’m letting myself feel. This isn’t okay, and I can't keep pretending it is. It’s time to ask for help before this darkness consumes us both.

Today marks two weeks since I welcomed my little miracle into the world, and yet I can’t shake this overwhelming sense of emptiness. The days blur together in a haze of sleepless nights and endless feedings, but instead of feeling joy and excitement, there’s just an eerie calm that settles over me.

I keep telling myself it’s normal to feel tired after giving birth. But deep down, something feels off. I’ve had postpartum depression before with my first child, so the signs are all too familiar: a persistent sadness that clings to me like a heavy cloak, making every small task seem insurmountable.

I’m scared this time might be worse. The anxiety creeps in when I least expect it—wondering if I’ll ever feel connected to my baby, questioning whether I have what it takes to be a good mother again. It’s hard to admit these thoughts out loud, especially since everyone expects you to be the happiest person alive right now.

I keep pushing through, forcing myself to smile and act happy for those around me. But inside, I’m drowning in a sea of doubts and fears. The guilt is suffocating; why can’t I just snap out of this? It’s not like my baby deserves a mother who feels nothing but despair.

Tonight, as I lay here holding her tiny hand, I promise myself to reach out for help. Maybe it’s time to talk to someone about these feelings—someone who understands that sometimes you need support even when everything looks perfect from the outside.

Today marks another day of feeling utterly lost. The baby cries, but I don’t feel anything. It’s like there’s a wall between us, and no matter how hard I try to break it down, it just stays stubbornly in place.

I thought this was supposed to be the happiest time of my life. Instead, I wake up every morning dreading what lies ahead. The fatigue is relentless, but sleep feels unattainable. It’s a vicious cycle that seems to have no end.

There are moments when I feel like a terrible mother for feeling this way, and then those feelings disappear as quickly as they came because the emptiness inside never leaves me. My husband tries his best to help, but it feels like everything is falling apart regardless of what he does.

I miss being happy before the baby arrived. Everything was so full of promise back then. Now, all I see are days stretching out ahead with no end in sight. How did things get this bad? And more importantly, how do we turn them around?

The doctors said it’s just postpartum depression and that I’ll feel better soon. But when will “soon” be? It feels like every day drags on longer than the last.

I know I need help, but reaching out seems too overwhelming right now. Maybe tomorrow I'll try again. For now, though, I’m just going to hold on tight and hope that something shifts in my heart soon.

June 15, Week 6

Today marks the six-week mark since little Emma’s arrival, and while I’ve had moments of pure joy holding her close, there are also days when the weight of new motherhood feels unbearably heavy. The exhaustion is relentless, and no matter how much support I receive from my family and friends, some days it still feels like too much.

I remember distinctly the conversation with my therapist last week about postpartum depression creeping in earlier than expected. It’s scary to admit that sometimes, even when I’m surrounded by love and help, there are moments where everything seems overwhelming and a bit hopeless. But knowing there are people who understand and want to see me through this gives me a tiny sliver of comfort.

I often think about what it would be like if I had been forced into carrying Emma against my will. The thought alone is suffocating, making the struggles I face now seem insignificant in comparison. It’s hard not to dwell on how different things might have been—how much harder everything could have been without that support network.

Each day, I’m trying to find tiny victories: a decent night of sleep, a moment where Emma smiles at me instead of crying, or simply taking time for myself. These little wins are what keep me going, despite the shadow of postpartum depression looming over my new life as a mom.

Today feels like one of those days where everything is just a bit too much. The baby cries, and it's not just the usual hungry cry or the sleepy cry—it’s this deep, almost pained sound that makes me want to cry right along with him. I've been feeling so lost lately, wondering what happened to all those dreams of being a perfect mother. Now, there are moments when I wish we could go back in time and choose another path.

I thought having a child would bring joy and love into my life, but it's more like an endless cycle of sleepless nights and constant worry. The guilt is overwhelming. Every time he looks at me with those big, innocent eyes, it feels like the weight of the world presses down on my chest. How did I let myself believe this was going to be easy? 

Waking up every two hours just to feed him again has left me feeling drained and hopeless. And when he finally sleeps, exhaustion still clings to me, making even the simplest tasks feel monumental. I can't shake off these dark thoughts; they whisper in my ear that maybe it would have been better not to bring this little life into mine.

There's a part of me that wants to scream out loud and ask for help, but another part is terrified of what people will think if I admit how hard it all feels. It’s like everyone expects you to handle everything with grace and ease, as if having a baby is some kind of magical transformation instead of a challenging reality.

Every day feels like an uphill battle, and tonight is no different. But maybe tomorrow will be better? Maybe one day I'll wake up feeling hopeful again instead of drowning in this sea of regrets. For now, though, I just need to find the strength to keep going for another day.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of regret and sorrow. The baby's cries seem to echo through the walls, a constant reminder of my mistake. I've been on antidepressants for over a year now, yet nothing changes. Every moment feels like an eternity, every smile from the baby brings me closer to breaking down.

Why did I do this? Why didn't I listen when my gut told me something was wrong? It's not just the exhaustion or lack of sleep—it's the deep-seated knowledge that I should never have brought another life into this world. No one deserves to be forced into parenthood, least of all someone like me who struggles with postpartum depression.

The antidepressants are supposed to help, but they don't fix what's broken inside me. Sometimes, when I look at the baby, I see a stranger—a tiny being that demands so much from me without understanding my pain. Other times, I feel nothing at all, just emptiness and despair.

I want to talk about this with someone, anyone who can understand. But every time I try, it feels like another failure. Am I really this weak? Is there no hope for a life beyond this darkness?

Today, I will reach out again. Maybe, just maybe, talking will help me find some semblance of peace. Or at least, not feel quite so lost in the shadows anymore.

Maybe tomorrow will be better.

Day 30 Postpartum

I woke up this morning feeling like the same heavy weight was sitting on my chest as it has been for weeks now. The room is a blur of baby toys and clothes that feel foreign to me, even though they're supposed to be mine. How did I get here? Where did the joy go?

Today, all I wanted to do was cry. It's hard to explain this feeling of emptiness that just won't let up. My husband brought over coffee and tried to talk about something, anything, but I couldn't bring myself to engage. The baby napped, and for a moment, there was silence. But the silence only amplified my thoughts—negative ones, like "Am I really cut out for this?"

I miss being pregnant when everything felt hopeful and filled with promise. Now, it's just one day after another. Each morning feels like a repeat of the last. There are moments where I feel guilty for not wanting to be happy. What’s wrong with me? Why can't I enjoy this as much as others seem to?

I know there must be something out there that could help. But how do you seek help when just getting up from bed feels like climbing a mountain? Maybe today, instead of hiding in my room, I'll try reaching out. Just a text or an email. A small step forward.

Maybe tomorrow will feel different. Today was hard enough as it is.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and it’s been one rollercoaster of emotions. The joy of holding my baby for the first time was overshadowed by an eerie sense of isolation that crept in soon after. I thought it would be different, more like those blissful moments when you gaze at your child with overwhelming love and gratitude. But there are days when I feel so drained, both physically and emotionally, that even a simple smile feels like an impossible feat.

I’ve been trying to tell myself that this is normal, that it’s okay not to be okay all the time. The sleepless nights blur into one another, and every little cry can set off my anxiety in ways I never expected. It’s hard enough to cope with these feelings without the added pressure of feeling like a failure as a mother.

Thankfully, I have my partner who is incredibly supportive. We talk about our fears and hopes for this new chapter, which helps a bit. But sometimes, when the weight feels too heavy, it’s comforting to know there are resources out there, people who understand what we’re going through. It’s important to reach out and not suffer in silence.

Today, I’m trying to focus on small victories—like getting dressed, having a shower, and taking a few moments for myself. Each tiny step feels like climbing the highest mountain. But I know it’s okay to be where I am right now, as long as I keep moving forward, even if just by inches.

Tomorrow is another day, filled with new challenges but also new chances to find joy in this incredible journey of becoming a parent.

Today marks two weeks since baby arrived, and I'm starting to feel like I’m drowning in a sea of confusion and fear. The joy from the moment they brought her home has been overshadowed by an overwhelming sense of anxiety. It's hard to focus on anything except how tired I am—sleep is a distant dream when she cries every two hours.

I keep wondering if this feeling will ever fade, or if it’s just another symptom of motherhood I need to endure silently. The thought that maybe something more serious could be going on haunts me. Is this postpartum depression creeping in? It's scary to think about but also feels like the only explanation for why everything feels so heavy and hard.

I tried talking to a friend, who said it’s just part of adjusting to new life. But deep down, I know there are times when it feels too much—like no matter how many naps or cups of coffee, my brain won’t stop spinning with worry and exhaustion.

Trying to find balance between taking care of the baby and myself is a daily battle. I’ve promised to go see someone if this feeling doesn’t lift soon. Until then, I’ll keep pushing through each day, hoping tomorrow will be better.

Today marks another day of feeling more like myself again. The sun is shining through the window, casting a warm glow over my desk. I can't help but smile as I remember how different things felt just last year when I was struggling with postpartum depression. It's funny how much your surroundings can affect your mood.

The office has been a sanctuary for me since I started here. My coworkers are supportive and understanding, which is more than I could have asked for after coming back from maternity leave. Every morning feels like a new beginning when I walk in through the doors, and that alone helps ease my mind.

I still catch myself wondering if this happiness will last, but today, as I sit here surrounded by reminders of how far I've come, I feel hopeful. The work environment has been crucial to my recovery, giving me purpose and a sense of belonging. It's not just about the job anymore; it's about being part of something bigger that helps me stay grounded.

Life is good right now, and I'm determined to keep nurturing this feeling. Maybe tomorrow will bring new challenges, but for today, I'll bask in the glow of progress and contentment.

September 23rd

Today marks the seventh day since I brought home our little miracle. The nights have been a whirlwind of fear and exhaustion. I keep waking up in cold sweats from nightmares where something terrible happens to him. It’s an endless cycle, these thoughts that consume me all day long.

I don’t know how much more of this bed rest I can handle. My body feels like it's not my own anymore, heavy and numb. Every time I close my eyes, I see the worst-case scenarios playing out in vivid detail. How am I supposed to be there for him if I’m too scared to even leave his side?

The joy that was supposed to fill every moment is overshadowed by a deep, dark cloud of sadness. It’s like there’s this constant void inside me, and nothing can fill it up anymore.

I know I need help, but the thought of reaching out feels impossible right now. Maybe tomorrow will be better? I hope so, because today has been the hardest yet.

Today marks a milestone in my journey as a new mother to my second child. The early days were a whirlwind of emotions and exhaustion, much like they had been after the birth of our first. But there was something different this time around; I found myself slipping into that familiar dark place again.

The nights felt endless, filled with worry and self-doubt. How could I possibly do this twice? The weight of it all was suffocating. Yet here we are, weeks later, and things feel a bit brighter. My days aren’t perfect, but they’re manageable. There’s laughter sprinkled in now, moments that remind me why I wanted to be a mother.

I’ve leaned on my support system more than ever before—friends who understand the struggle, family members who offer respite when needed. It’s been a slow climb out of that foggy haze, but each step forward feels like progress. The little victories matter so much right now: finishing a load of laundry without breaking down, or just taking a moment to enjoy a cup of coffee alone.

I’m still learning how to navigate this new reality with grace and patience, but I can feel the strength growing within me. Today, I’m more hopeful than I’ve been in weeks. And for that, I’m grateful.

Today marks the third week since little Emma joined our family. The hospital staff warned me about postpartum blues, but I thought I was ready. Boy, was I wrong.

The days blend together now—a blur of changing diapers and soothing cries that seem to never end. My head feels foggy, my body aches from carrying the weight of sleep deprivation and exhaustion. And yet, there's so much love for this tiny human who depends on me. It’s such a paradox—it should be joyous and fulfilling, but it’s also a constant struggle.

I feel like I’m drowning in a sea of responsibilities and emotions. The support is here—my mom, my partner, friends offering help. Yet, even with all the hands that reach out to lift me up, there's an overwhelming sense of isolation. Why can't I just feel happy? It’s as if everyone sees this perfect little bubble of new life while I’m stuck under water.

Mom tried to talk to me yesterday; she said something about how things will get better soon. But I don’t know—when? How? I see all these posts on social media, mothers celebrating every milestone, and it feels like a cruel joke. Maybe I’m the only one who's not okay.

But today, I'm going to start small. Take a deep breath. Call someone. Ask for help. Because no matter how alone I feel, there are people around me who care. And maybe, just maybe, reaching out is the first step toward finding my way back.

Today marks three weeks since my heart swelled with the arrival of our little miracle. I should be floating on a cloud of joy and love, but instead, I'm tangled in shadows and whispers that only I can hear. The baby cries, and it's not just for milk or a diaper change; it’s a symphony of sorrow echoing through my ears.

I've been watching my friends navigate the same rocky waters. They look so fragile, like they're holding their breaths, waiting to see if they'll survive this thing called motherhood. I want to tell them that it's okay to feel lost, but I can't seem to find my voice. 

Every time I think about what happened after Alex was born—those long nights of tears and loneliness—I wonder if there’s a way to stop this cycle from repeating itself. I try to be the rock for others, offering words of comfort that I’m not fully feeling myself.

The doctor's appointment is tomorrow. Maybe it’s time to ask for help again. It feels selfish, but isn’t caring for my mental health just as important? The baby monitor hums softly in the background. In another hour, he’ll wake up and need me. Right now, all I can do is hope that sleep will bring a little respite.

I’m tired of pretending everything’s fine. It's time to lean into the darkness and say out loud: I need help.

Today was a rollercoaster of emotions. Waking up to the sound of my baby’s first cry of the day is always a mix of love and dread. I’m so grateful for the support from friends and family—they really keep me going through the hardest moments. But it’s tough, especially when I’m at work helping other young moms who are struggling with postpartum depression too. Sometimes I feel like I should be stronger, more together, but there are days when even getting out of bed feels impossible.

The exhaustion is real. It’s not just physical; my heart feels heavy all the time. Simple tasks, like making dinner or taking a shower, take monumental effort. But there are moments too—like when I catch my baby looking at me with those big, curious eyes—that remind me why this journey is worth it.

I’ve been trying to keep up with therapy and support groups, but sometimes it feels like the same old advice: sleep more, eat better, exercise regularly. Easier said than done, right? But today I tried something new—I wrote a letter to my future self, promising to remember how far I’ve come when the darkness seems overwhelming.

It’s hard work being a mom and fighting depression at the same time. But as I look down at my baby sleeping soundly next to me, I know there are better days ahead. For now, though, I’m going to take this moment of peace and breathe it all in.

Today marks two weeks since little Emma joined our family. The doctor said it's normal to feel tired and overwhelmed, but for me, it feels like there’s a fog that won’t lift. I look at her tiny face, so serene and innocent, yet all I can think about is how hard everything seems.

Sleeping through the night? Not happening. Every time she cries, my heart races, and I feel like I’m failing as a mother. But then, there are moments—brief glimpses of clarity where holding Emma makes me forget all the worries for just a second.

I keep telling myself that this is okay, that other new moms must feel the same way, but it’s not easy to believe those words when your brain feels like mush and every little thing seems impossible. I know I need help, but asking for it feels like admitting weakness, which is so unlike me.

Yesterday, I tried calling my friend who had a baby last year, hoping she’d offer some advice or just listen, but even making that call drained all my energy. Maybe today will be better. Maybe tomorrow will bring a change. But right now, the only thing keeping me going is the thought of snuggling Emma in her crib and knowing I’m not alone—she needs me as much as I need support.

I wish I could just feel happy like everyone says you should after having a baby, but instead, it’s this constant struggle to stay afloat. I hope things get easier soon, for both our sakes.

Today marks two weeks since little Sophia arrived. It feels like an eternity since I was pregnant with anticipation and joy. Now, it’s just endless diaper changes and late-night feedings. People keep asking how I’m feeling, but honestly, I can’t get a grip on my emotions.

I overheard someone talking about postpartum depression at the baby store yesterday. They were complaining about not being able to bond with their child. Bond? What is that supposed to mean? It’s been two weeks since I held her for the first time, and every time she cries in my arms, it feels like a punch in the gut. But hey, I’m strong—I don’t need any counseling or therapy.

I’ve noticed some friends are struggling with their partners’ behavior too, but everyone seems to have this idealized vision of what love should look like post-baby. My partner is nowhere near the prince charming they all seem to think he should be. He’s not there to hold my hand and offer endless support. Maybe I expected too much. But it feels like every day is a battle, and that’s just how it is.

I wish others would stop patting me on the back and telling me everything will get better soon. It doesn’t help when they dismiss my frustration with their own struggles. They think I’m being dramatic about my partner’s lack of attention, but deep down, I know something isn't right. Yet every time someone suggests I might be experiencing postpartum depression, a part of me feels offended and defensive. Maybe it's just normal to feel off after bringing new life into the world.

But then again, maybe there is more to this than meets the eye. Maybe I need to stop pushing away the help before I can see where my emotions are leading me. It’s hard to admit that I might be struggling in ways I don’t fully understand. But for Sophia's sake and mine, I think it’s time to take a closer look at what’s really going on inside my head.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of exhaustion and confusion. The baby cries incessantly, the house is a mess, and I can't seem to get anything done right. My head spins with worry; every little sound makes me jump, every task seems insurmountable. Why did this have to be so hard? 

Sleep eludes me, leaving dark circles under my eyes that mirror the shadows in my mind. The fear of what tomorrow might bring is overwhelming. I can’t shake off the feeling that everything will fall apart before Monday hits. It’s like living in a constant state of panic, unable to find any respite.

The thought of going back to therapy on Monday gives me some comfort though. Talking to someone about this chaos inside feels necessary. But until then, how do I just breathe through each second? How can I keep it together when everything feels so out of control?

Today was supposed to be a fresh start, but instead, it’s another day lost in a haze of anxiety and depression. The love for my baby is there, somewhere deep down, but right now, it’s overshadowed by the weight of these feelings that won’t let me breathe. Maybe tomorrow will bring something different.

I need help finding the way out of this dark place before Monday comes.

Today marks a significant milestone in my journey as a new mom and person. I’ve been grappling with the shadows of postpartum depression for months now, but something shifted this week. It started with a chance conversation at the playground where another mother mentioned her plans to go back to school after years away from academia. The idea resonated deeply within me.

I remember feeling lost in a sea of uncertainty and despair, unable to see a way forward. Yet here I am, contemplating reengaging with education as a means to find my purpose again. It’s funny how something as simple as a conversation can light the spark needed for profound change. The thought of returning to studies feels daunting but also exhilarating. There's an undercurrent of hope that has been missing for what seems like forever.

I’ve always loved learning and now, amidst the chaos of motherhood, it provides me with clarity and direction I never imagined possible. It’s a journey fraught with challenges, yet every step forward feels like a victory against the darkness that once consumed me. Here’s to new beginnings and rediscovering my identity beyond just being a mom.

Today is not just another day in the life of a postpartum woman; it's a declaration of intent to reclaim what I’ve lost and embrace whatever lies ahead with courage and grace.

Today marks one week since we moved to our new home. The weight of the world feels a bit lighter here, but there are moments when I feel like everything is crashing down again. Adjusting to motherhood has been an exhausting journey, and dealing with postpartum depression made every day feel like climbing Mount Everest.

The decision to move was hard, but necessary. My old house held too many memories of those dark days, each room a reminder of how far I’ve come—and how far I still need to go. Here, the air is fresher, and there’s an inexplicable sense of hope in every sunrise. It’s not that everything is perfect; it’s just different.

I find myself talking to our baby more now, sharing my thoughts and fears with them as if they understand all the complexities of what I’m going through. Sometimes it feels like a game of catch-up, trying to make up for lost time and missed moments. But then there are these quiet hours when everything falls into place, and I hold our baby close, feeling grateful for this fresh start.

It’s tough admitting how much I still struggle, but moving here has shown me that recovery isn’t linear. It’s okay to have good days and bad days, and it’s okay to ask for help along the way. Here in our new home, there’s room to breathe and space to heal.

Today feels like a never-ending maze with no exit. I woke up to another day where the walls of my room feel thicker and heavier than ever before. The nursery next door is a constant reminder of how much there is to do yet again. Each creak of the floorboards echoes in my mind, taunting me with a list of uncompleted tasks.

Every moment feels suffocating. Just like the woman in "The Yellow Wallpaper," I feel trapped by invisible chains. The room used to be just another space, but now it's a prison filled with swirling patterns and shadows that grow more menacing every day. 

I try to smile at my baby, but all I see is this relentless cycle of exhaustion and despair. How did we get here? Wasn't this supposed to be the happiest time in our lives?

The phone rings constantly, people asking if everything is okay. It's a question I can't answer because even I don't know anymore. My body feels like it’s run over by a truck, but my mind races with worries about what tomorrow will bring.

I'm scared and alone. This isn't the life I imagined for myself or my child. Yet here I am, stuck in this cycle of darkness, hoping that somewhere there's a light at the end of this tunnel. If only someone could show me how to find it.

Today feels like a never-ending nightmare. Tomorrow, I'll try again.

Today marks one week since I brought my little miracle into the world, and while I can't help but marvel at how small and perfect she is, there's this constant fog weighing down on me. The pregnancy itself was a whirlwind of emotions and challenges that stretched over four long years, filled with countless appointments, tests, and more than my fair share of hope and despair. Now, as I hold her close in the quiet hours of dawn, all I feel is exhaustion, both physical and emotional.

There's this odd sense of disconnect between the joy I should be feeling and the heaviness that lingers inside me. I catch glimpses of myself reflecting back at me from the mirror—someone who looks like they've just run a marathon but hasn't crossed any finish line. The tears come easily, sometimes for no reason at all, leaving me questioning whether it's okay to feel this way.

I keep telling myself that I'm lucky—I have an amazing support system of family and friends who love us unconditionally. But there are moments when even their presence feels like too much. Late nights with a sleeping baby are my solace; those quiet hours give me the space to breathe, to think about tomorrow without the weight of today's burdens.

I've started watching some TV shows that others recommended—something different from my usual routine. It helps distract me for a bit, but it doesn't erase the underlying sadness. I know it’s okay not to be okay right now; every day feels like a battle, and sometimes winning just means making it to bedtime without breaking down completely.

Tomorrow is another day, they say. Maybe someday this fog will lift, and the sun will shine through once again. Until then, I'll take one step at a time, reaching out for help when I need it most.

Today marks a week since I welcomed my little bundle of joy into the world, and while there's an undeniable sense of wonder and love, there’s also this overwhelming sadness that seems to consume me. The exhaustion is real, but it’s not just physical; it feels like everything inside me is drained. I keep wondering why I can't shake off this cloud hanging over my head.

But you know what? There are moments when the fog lifts just enough for a glimpse of sunlight to seep in. My mom dropped by with some homemade soup and a comforting hug today, and that did wonders for my spirits. It's these small acts of kindness from her and others around me that give me hope and strength.

I've been trying hard to keep things together, but the weight is so heavy sometimes. I feel like everyone expects me to be this perfect mother right away, and it’s just not happening. The tears come out of nowhere, and my head spins with all these thoughts about what I'm doing wrong or whether there's something seriously wrong with me.

But then I remember that it takes a village, and I’ve reached out for help. Therapy sessions have become a lifeline, and talking to someone who understands is incredibly soothing. The support from friends and family has been invaluable. It’s okay not to be okay all the time, isn’t it? Today was tough, but there's also gratitude, because these moments of light remind me that I’m not alone in this.

Tomorrow is another day, and though the path ahead feels long and dark at times, I know I have people who will walk beside me. That thought alone helps a little bit more than yesterday.

Today marks another milestone in my journey as a new mom. The days feel longer now, filled with the endless yet soothing sounds of my baby’s soft coos and giggles. There are moments when I find myself overwhelmed by the sheer amount of work that goes into raising a child, but then there are those beautiful times when everything feels perfectly still.

The past few months have been like stepping stones leading to this point where I feel more stable than ever before. It’s as if the fog that once clouded my mind and heart has lifted, revealing the sunshine I so desperately needed. I’ve started to appreciate the little things—like how he reaches for me with a smile or how his eyes light up when I read him a story.

There are still days when I feel a bit off, like a small shadow creeping in on the sunniest of afternoons, but these moments are fleeting. They pass as quickly as they come, leaving behind an assurance that things will be okay. My support system has been incredible—friends and family who always know just how to lift my spirits when I need them most.

Today, I’m taking a deep breath, grateful for each moment of peace and joy that comes with being his mother. The future feels bright, and while there may be bumps along the way, I’m confident in my ability to navigate them all.

July 14th

Another day in this endless cycle of exhaustion and despair. Seven months have passed since the birth of my son, but it feels like a lifetime ago when I was filled with joy and hope for our future together.

The early days were surreal—a whirlwind of hormones and sleepless nights that blurred into one another. But now, amidst the pandemic's shadow, even those hazy memories seem distant. The world outside seems to revolve around uncertainty and fear, and it feels like I’m caught in a storm with no safe harbor.

Today was particularly tough. I tried to go for a walk, but everything felt wrong—too quiet, too empty. My son’s cries echo through the house, mingling with my own silent screams inside. It’s hard not to blame myself for being this way, for not being enough, but what else is there?

I’ve been filling out these standard surveys about postpartum depression, but they feel like a joke now. They ask if I’ve had moments of joy or laughter, as if that’s supposed to be normal right now. The pandemic has brought its own set of challenges, isolating us from our usual support systems and amplifying every fear.

I need more than just the same old questions about my mood swings. I need someone to listen to me without judgment, to understand how deeply intertwined my mental health is with this new reality we’re living in. Until then, these surveys are like a bandaid on a gaping wound—I can feel it barely touching the surface.

I’ll keep trying to smile through each day for my son’s sake, but today felt impossible. Maybe tomorrow will be better? Or maybe not. But I’m still here, and that feels like something worth holding onto right now.

Today marks one year since I brought my little miracle into the world. It’s funny how time flies when you’re trying to survive day by day. A year ago, I was overwhelmed with joy and hope for the future, but now, as I look back, all I see is a relentless haze of sadness that just won’t lift.

I thought things would get better after a few months, like everyone said they would. But here I am, still feeling this heavy weight on my chest every single day. It’s exhausting, trying to keep up with the constant demands of parenting while battling this dark cloud in my mind. Sometimes, it feels like there’s no way out.

Yesterday was particularly rough. I had a moment where I just wanted to escape everything—just a few hours away from the endless chores and crying. But then I remember why I’m doing this. My baby needs me, but honestly? Sometimes I don’t feel like I can be what she needs right now.

I keep telling myself that it’s okay to ask for help, but it feels so hard to reach out. Maybe today will be the day I make a call, just like everyone says you should. But then again, maybe tomorrow...

Today is another day of trying to find a sliver of light in this dark tunnel. Here’s hoping there are brighter days ahead, even if they feel far away right now.

January 14th

The sun is shining through the cracks in my curtains today, but it feels so distant from where I am—sitting on this couch with a tiny bundle of warmth and vulnerability sleeping peacefully beside me. It's been six weeks since the day everything changed, yet here I am, feeling as if I've been swallowed by an endless sea of exhaustion and doubt.

I knew before my little one arrived that postpartum depression was a possibility, maybe even likely given my history with anxiety. But somehow, deep down, part of me hoped that this time would be different. That the love for my child would shield me from the darkness I’ve feared so much. Now, as I look back on these past weeks filled with sleepless nights and constant worry about every little thing, it’s hard to shake off the feeling that everything is going wrong.

The joy of holding a newborn for the first time was exhilarating, but it didn't last long. Every day feels like an uphill battle—trying to navigate basic tasks while juggling hormones and emotions that seem out of control. I can't help but wonder if there will ever be light at the end of this tunnel. The idea of seeking help seems daunting when all I want is to feel better on my own.

I know I need support, and yet pushing myself through the day-to-day feels like a triumph in itself right now. But as much as I try to soldier on, there are moments—like holding my baby while watching sunlight dance across the walls—that offer brief glimpses of hope. It’s these fleeting instances that remind me why this journey is worth it.

Today, I resolve to reach out for help. My daughter deserves a mother who can be fully present and joyful, not just surviving but thriving alongside her growth. This isn't about giving up; it's about fighting back against the inevitable with every tool available to me.

Today was one of those days where everything feels too heavy to carry. I've been watching 'Fleabag' again and again, and it's like she speaks directly to me through the screen. Her pain is mine, her confusion is mine, but there’s a part of her that keeps going, even when she doesn’t want to. That strength in her weakness somehow makes me feel less alone.

I cried harder this time than I have before. The laughter and tears mixed together like they always do in the show. It's not just about what she says; it’s about how she feels, those raw moments of vulnerability that cut deep into my own soul. Every episode ends with a breathless exhale, as if letting go of all the air I've been holding since morning.

I keep thinking about why this show resonates so much right now. Maybe it's because Fleabag is fighting her demons just like me. She’s tired and scared, but she doesn’t give up. It’s a reminder that even in my darkest moments, there’s a part of me that wants to survive too.

I’m scared, though. Scared that I won't find the strength she has. But for now, watching 'Fleabag' feels like a lifeline. A way to connect with someone who understands what it's like to be lost in this sea of motherhood and darkness. Maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe not. But today, I’ll just hold on tight and watch her again.

Today feels like one of those days where everything is a struggle. The baby won't sleep, the house seems to get messier by the second, and my head just can’t keep up with all the tasks. It’s been a rollercoaster since the moment we brought our little one home. I knew there would be ups and downs, but this feeling of being lost in a fog is new. My heart aches knowing that everything inside me feels heavy and unyielding.

I’ve tried to be proactive about my mood; reaching out for support, trying different self-care routines, even setting aside time for myself when I can. It’s hard though, because every time I make progress, something small but significant derails my efforts. Like today, I wanted to take a walk in the park but ended up canceling at the last minute because it was too chilly and my feet hurt.

But amidst all this mess, there are glimpses of joy that remind me why we’re doing this. When she smiles at me or reaches out for cuddles, these moments feel like small victories against the storm inside me. I want to be okay for her sake, but also because I deserve it too. It’s a daily battle, but one I’m fighting with everything I have.

I’ve decided that tomorrow will be better, and I’ll keep pushing forward. Even if I can’t fix everything right now, just acknowledging my feelings is the first step towards healing. This isn’t easy, but it’s not impossible either.

Today marks the fourth week since giving birth to our little angel. I thought I'd feel more joy and less like a zombie trapped in a dream. The nights are endless, and every sound from her room makes my heart race with fear that something is wrong. How can love and dread be so intertwined?

The days blend together like a never-ending loop of feeding, crying, and changing diapers. I barely have time to shower or eat properly. My husband tries his best to help, but I feel like a failure every time he steps in. When will I get my life back? When will the exhaustion end?

I know something is terribly wrong with me, but no one seems to understand. They tell me to sleep when she sleeps and drink plenty of water. Easy advice for someone who hasn't had a full night's rest since before she was born.

Today, I cried harder than ever just over a lost pacifier. Guilt eats at me like acid, and I feel like a monster for not being the perfect mother everyone expects. My head tells me to seek help, but my pride holds me back.

I need to talk to someone who understands this pain. Maybe then, I can start feeling like myself again.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of sleepless nights and never-ending worry. The baby is so small, so utterly dependent on me for everything. But as the days stretch into weeks, I feel like less and less of a mother. How can someone who loves their child so deeply also feel completely inadequate and overwhelmed?

The guilt is overwhelming. I know that what I'm feeling isn't my fault, but it's hard to shake off the constant fear that I’m not good enough for this baby. What if I fail? What if I snap one day? Those thoughts are terrifying, especially when they're followed by images of worst-case scenarios.

I try to push those thoughts away, but they come back like a stubborn weed in my garden. It’s hard to explain how it feels—like being stuck underwater with no way out. The world moves on around me, but I’m trapped under this heavy weight that I can’t lift.

But here's the thing: I know now is not the time for silence. I’ve learned from others who've been through this; they talk about their struggles openly and find help. And so will I. It’s okay to admit when you need support, even if it feels like admitting weakness.

I’m going to reach out tomorrow. Maybe it'll be my OB-GYN first thing in the morning or a close friend. Whatever it takes, I’m not going to let this consume me any longer. The baby deserves so much more than what I can give when I'm drowning in darkness.

It’s time to break free from the shadows and seek the light.

Today marks another day that feels like just another chapter in this never-ending story of postpartum depression. The sun is shining through my window, casting a warm glow over the nursery where baby sleeps peacefully—yet another reminder of the gap between what should be joy and what I actually feel.

I've been struggling for so long now; it's hard to count the days without slipping into a dark place. Each moment brings new challenges: getting out of bed feels like climbing Mount Everest, every smile forces its way through gritted teeth. Yet, when my baby smiles back at me with those innocent eyes, I'm reminded that there's no escaping this role—no matter how hard it seems.

Friends and family are wonderful. They shower me with care, but their hugs can feel more like pressure sometimes. "You're doing great," they say. But am I? Is surviving day to day really all there is?

I've tried everything—therapy, medication, yoga, meditation. Yet here I stand, still grappling with the weight of my thoughts. The nights are the worst; each one a battle against the demons that whisper doubts and fears.

But today, as I look at my baby sleeping soundly, I make another promise to myself: tomorrow will be better. Maybe not perfect, but better. And maybe, just maybe, those whispers will grow quieter if only for a moment.

I hope so anyway.

December 7th

I woke up to another night of broken sleep, my heart heavy and my eyes stinging from exhaustion. The baby is just not sleeping well, and it’s taking a toll on me more than I ever imagined. It’s been weeks now, but every day feels like groundhog day—no matter how much rest I try to get, there never seems to be enough.

I keep telling myself that this too shall pass, but sometimes the dark thoughts creep in, whispering that maybe it won’t. Maybe I’m not cut out for this after all. The guilt is suffocating; every time I lay down next to him or her (it’s hard to tell anymore), hoping for a few moments of peace, my mind races with worry and fear.

But there are glimmers of hope. My mom called earlier today, offering to stay over tonight so that maybe, just maybe, I can catch up on some proper sleep. It feels like such a small thing, but it’s also a lifeline right now. Talking to her helps too; she tells me stories about how rough the nights were when my dad was born and reminds me that every new parent struggles in their own way.

I’m trying so hard not to let this consume me, but some days are harder than others. I’m hoping that with more support from family and friends, maybe things will start to get a little better soon. For now, though, all I can do is one day at a time—and tonight, I’ll hand over the reins to someone who can help me catch my breath.

---

Sometimes it feels like I’m drowning in this sea of sleepless nights and endless worry, but there’s also an unshakable belief that light will come. Today was better than yesterday; tomorrow might be even brighter if only I believe in myself a little more.

April 4th, 2023

I woke up today feeling like I'm drowning in a sea of exhaustion and sadness that stretches beyond my reach. It's been just over two months since little Emma joined our family, and while she’s beautiful and perfect in every way, holding her feels more like a weight than the joy it should be. My days are a blur of feeding schedules, diaper changes, and endless laundry. I'm supposed to feel fulfilled by this, but all I feel is numb.

Last night, as I was nursing Emma, my mind wandered back to that moment when the nurse placed her in my arms for the first time. There was an overwhelming sense of love mixed with anxiety—I wasn't sure if I could do it again after battling postpartum depression twice before. But now, here we are, and every day feels like a struggle.

The pressure from family and friends to keep having kids is suffocating. They see the new baby as something positive, but all I see are shadows of what my life used to be before she was born. I want them to understand that each child brings more joy than anything else in this world, but it also comes with an ever-growing list of challenges and doubts.

I'm tired of pretending everything is okay. It's not fair to hide behind a smile while inside I’m crumbling. Today, I decided to reach out for help—maybe talking to someone will give me back some semblance of my former self.

---

Sometimes, writing these entries feels like the only way to breathe freely. It’s an odd comfort knowing that maybe, just maybe, tomorrow could be better than today.

July 18th, 7 months post-delivery

Today marks seven long months since I welcomed my little miracle into the world. But as the days blur together and the exhaustion never seems to fade, something feels off. It's not just fatigue or adjusting to a new normal—it’s this heavy cloud hanging over me, weighing down every moment of joy.

I've been trying so hard to be the perfect mom, but it feels like I'm failing miserably at everything. The house is a mess, meals are skipped, and my once vibrant spirit feels dull and drained. There's this constant voice in my head telling me that something isn't right, but what exactly that is remains elusive.

It’s been hard to admit, even to myself, that postpartum depression hit seven months after delivery instead of the usual few weeks or months. But here I am, struggling with waves of sadness and anxiety that don’t seem to want to let up. Every time I think about reaching out for help, guilt creeps in—guilt for not being strong enough, for not having it all figured out.

Insurance has been a lifeline, providing access to therapy and medication that have helped me manage the overwhelming feelings. It’s scary how much I rely on these resources just to keep going day by day. Yet, despite my fears and doubts, there's also hope that with continued support, I can start finding my way back.

Maybe today will be different. Maybe tomorrow, too. For now, it's one step at a time, one breath at a time.

Today marks another day in this roller coaster of motherhood. The sun rose with a soft whisper, and as it bathed our tiny nursery in golden light, I felt a warmth spread through me, despite the fog that often settles over my mind. Holding our baby for the first time was like falling in love all over again, but today, the joy is tinged with moments of overwhelming fatigue and doubt.

Praying has become my sanctuary; each morning, I ask God to guide me through another day, reminding myself that even though some days feel heavy, they are also fleeting. I've learned to embrace the tough days without letting them define who I am or what kind of mother I can be. It’s a journey, and while there have been times when I’ve felt lost in a sea of exhaustion and anxiety, I know now that these feelings won’t last forever.

Every day is a new beginning, and even as I write this, the baby snores softly beside me, reminding me to take one breath at a time. With each prayer, each smile from our little one, my heart fills with hope for tomorrow.

Today marks another day of feeling like I’m walking through thick mud. It’s been five years since my son was born, and yet the weight of postpartum depression hasn’t lifted. The exhaustion never seems to end; it sneaks up on me when I least expect it, leaving me breathless.

I keep telling myself that this time will be different, that I’ll find a way out of this darkness. But every day feels like a struggle. My anxiety is always just under the surface, waiting for something small—a missed call from my husband, a forgotten item on the grocery list—to spiral into something overwhelming.

There are moments when I wonder if there’s more to it than just depression and anxiety. The way my mind races, how hard it is to focus even on simple tasks… It feels like ADHD, but who am I to know? All I can do is keep going, one foot in front of the other, hoping that tomorrow might be a bit brighter.

I wish there was something more concrete for me to hold onto. A plan, an answer, anything. For now, though, it’s just this endless loop of trying and failing and starting over again. I’m tired, but I can’t give up. Not on myself, not on my family. Maybe one day, things will start to shift.

Today was a hard day, but there are always tomorrows ahead. That’s all I have right now—tomorrow and the hope that it might be better than today.

Today marks a week since little Lily arrived in our world, and while I’m overjoyed to be her mother, the reality of this new life is overwhelming me. My days are filled with diaper changes, feedings, endless laundry lists, and sleep deprivation that leaves me feeling like a ghost haunting my own home. The exhaustion is not just physical but emotional too; every moment feels like an uphill battle.

Yet, amidst the chaos, there’s something incredibly grounding about turning to prayer. I find solace in opening up to Jesus, pouring out my fears, my struggles, and my hopes for Lily. It’s comforting to feel His presence wrapping around me with unwavering support. Sometimes, it feels like a quiet whisper reminding me that I’m not alone.

I’ve started setting aside moments just for myself—little corners of peace in an otherwise hectic day. Whether it's lighting a candle and praying or simply sitting quietly in the sun, these brief escapes rejuvenate my spirit. It’s a small victory each time, but enough to keep me going through another round-the-clock day.

Life with Lily is beautiful and daunting; every day I’m learning to navigate this new world, one prayer at a time.

Today felt like a never-ending nightmare. The weight of this new life I've brought into the world feels suffocating. My daughter’s cries pierce my soul, yet when she sleeps, an eerie silence fills the room, leaving me with nothing but my thoughts to torment me.

I can barely summon the energy to care for her. It's as if my body and mind are locked in a constant battle, neither willing to give up, but both drained beyond measure. Every little thing feels like too much—changing diapers, feeding her, even just looking at her tiny face. She's all I have left now; everyone else seems so far away.

Last night, I found myself crying while she slept. Her small hand clutched mine as if to say, "Don't let go." But how can I when everything inside me is screaming for release? I'm drowning in this sea of despair and there’s no one throwing me a lifeline. It's just us against the world.

I keep telling myself that things will get better, but each day feels like another wave crashing down on me. How long until I can breathe again without feeling like I’m suffocating? When will these tears stop?

She is my anchor in this stormy sea of postpartum depression. She’s all that keeps me going, even when every fiber of my being wants to give up.

I need help. I need someone to hold my hand and guide me through this darkness. Until then, I’ll keep holding on for her sake, hoping one day the sun will break through these clouds.

April 3, 2023

I can't believe it's been a week since little Emma joined our family. I've barely slept and I feel like my head is spinning all the time. Today was particularly tough; I just wanted to cry for no reason at all. The baby blues are real, and they're hitting me hard.

But you know what? My husband has been incredible. He's always there with a hug or a kind word when I'm feeling down. I couldn't do this without him. When Emma started crying again last night, he stayed up to help while I rested. It's little moments like that which remind me how lucky I am.

I've felt so alone at times, but having support is everything. I know it gets better with time, and I'm taking small steps each day to feel more hopeful about the future. For now, though, I'll hold on tight to my husband and our little miracle. Here's to another week of figuring out this crazy adventure called motherhood.

Tomorrow feels like a fresh start.

Today marks exactly one month since little Lily joined our family, and the rollercoaster of emotions just keeps going up and down like a wild ride at an amusement park. Some moments feel overwhelmingly beautiful—like when I watch her sleep or when we cuddle on the couch—but then there are other times where everything feels heavy and dark.

I can't shake this constant worry that something isn’t quite right with me. Am I really just overwhelmed by being a new mom, or is it more than that? There’s this voice in my head telling me to snap out of it, but the truth is, I don’t know how. It's like there's a fog clouding everything around me.

I wish someone could understand what I’m going through without having been through it themselves because sometimes even saying "it gets better" just feels empty. But then I meet another mom who looks lost and anxious in those same hallways, and I see myself. And suddenly, we’re not so different after all.

Today, as I was at my support group meeting, a woman shared her story about struggling with postpartum depression. It hit me like a wave of relief mixed with recognition; someone else knows what it’s like to walk through this dark tunnel and come out the other side. For the first time in weeks, I felt less alone.

I’m trying to take small steps towards healing—like going for walks outside or reaching out when I need help. It's not easy, but maybe that’s okay too. Maybe feeling all these confusing emotions is just part of the journey.

Tomorrow will be another day with its own set of challenges and moments of grace. Until then, I’ll keep breathing and holding on to hope.

Today was a whirlwind of emotions, starting with the realization that my baby has grown so much already and ending in disappointment from yet another appointment. I thought today's virtual visit would be different, that maybe this time someone would truly listen to what I'm going through—something more than just numbers on a screen.

I sat down, holding back tears as I prepared for our discussion about the medications I've been prescribed to help with my postpartum depression. All I wanted was support and understanding from Dr., but it felt like she was checking off boxes rather than really hearing me out. The conversation was rushed, filled with medical jargon that felt distant from my reality.

She said things were "normal" despite the EPDS scores showing otherwise. How can someone so detached understand what's happening inside my head? I left feeling more alone and misunderstood than ever before. It’s just another day of fighting a battle no one seems to see or care about enough.

I'm trying to stay positive, but it's hard when even supposed experts seem dismissive of your struggles. Maybe tomorrow will be better—I hope so, because today was exhausting in every sense.

Today feels like one of those days where everything is just a bit too much. Waking up to the sound of my little girl’s laughter should be enough to lift any mood, but it’s not. It's been two years since she was born, and I still feel like I’m walking through quicksand most mornings.

Monte used to joke that parenthood would make me a superhero. If he could see me now, I wonder what he’d say. Raising our daughter on my own has made some parts of me stronger, but it’s also worn away at the edges until there's barely any left. There are moments when holding her feels like catching lightning in my hands—beautiful and dangerous all at once.

I remember sitting here last year, writing this same thing: that I need to get help. But there's a part of me that keeps putting it off because what if nothing changes? What if this is just how life with two kids will always feel?

The hardest part isn’t the exhaustion or even the loneliness; it’s knowing I don't want any of this for my children. They deserve more, and every day when they hug me tight, I wonder if I’m doing enough to give them that.

It's a cycle I'm trying to break, but breaking cycles is hard work. Especially when you're already carrying the weight of so much loss. But today, as I watch her play with her brother, laughing and full of life, I feel something stir inside me. Maybe there’s still hope for a tomorrow where my heart isn’t just beating, but living again.

I’m not sure if it's enough to move mountains, but it’s the start of trying to build one small step at a time. For Monte, for them, and for me.

March 14, 2023

Today feels like one of those days where my mind is a jumbled mess of thoughts and fears that won't stop swirling around in my head. I’ve been obsessing over this idea that postpartum depression could somehow sneak up on me even though I've never given birth or held the hope of becoming a parent anytime soon.

It’s like having an imaginary baby that feeds you these worries, telling you to panic about something so far from your reality. But there it is, lurking in the back of my mind, threatening to take over when I least expect it. The thought of being overwhelmed by emotions I can't even imagine scares me more than anything else right now.

I've been trying to distract myself with books and podcasts about mental health, hoping to find some kind of reassurance. I guess I’m just so used to worrying about everything that this feels like a new territory where my imagination runs wild and my rational self is left behind in the dust.

It’s strange how much power these fears have over me when they're based on nothing more than my own anxieties. Maybe it's time for a reality check, or perhaps just some good old-fashioned relaxation techniques to remind myself that I’m okay, right here and now, without all the hypothetical baggage.

Tomorrow is another day, and maybe today’s worries will be less daunting in the light of morning. For now, though, I’ll let these thoughts settle and hope for clearer skies tomorrow.

Today marks exactly nine months since baby arrived, and it’s a weird day for reflection. The sun is shining like it always does when I'm feeling particularly fragile, but my heart isn’t light at all. There’s this constant worry that won't go away, the kind of anxiety that feels like it's eating me from the inside out. It starts with little things—a sudden loud noise can make my chest tighten, and I catch myself checking to see if she’s still breathing.

I know something is off because it wasn’t always like this. Before, there were moments of pure joy and love for our baby girl, but now those moments are few and far between. The exhaustion is real, and the anxiety only seems to get worse with each passing day. There's a part of me that feels guilty for not being happier about all the amazing things in my life right now.

Breastfeeding has been an incredible journey, but it’s also made finding help really tricky. I’m aware that there are medications out there that could potentially make this easier, but they’re off-limits because she’s still so little. I can’t shake the feeling that something is wrong and needs addressing. It's time to reach out for support—maybe talking to someone will help me figure things out.

Today feels like a turning point. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, though, it’s about acknowledging how I feel and taking steps towards getting help. It’s okay not to be okay all the time; what matters is doing something about it.

December 7th

The darkness was suffocating tonight. It swallowed everything, leaving me feeling utterly alone in a world where my baby is supposed to be the light. In this dream, I wandered through an endless void, the shadows closing around me like hungry hands. There were voices whispering promises of peace and release, but the words tasted bitter on my tongue.

I found myself standing at the edge of a cliff, the wind howling past as it tried to pull me over. It was such an odd sensation—feeling the cold air against my skin while knowing this was just a dream. But even in dreams, the choice seems so clear: jump and find freedom from the overwhelming weight that drags at my soul, or stay and face another day of feeling like I’m drowning.

It’s days like these when I wonder if anyone truly understands what it feels like to be me right now. The constant exhaustion, the fear of not being good enough, and the crushing silence when all you want is someone to hold your hand through this nightmare. But then, in those quieter moments before sleep or while feeding my baby, there’s a glimmer of something else—hope that maybe one day I’ll be okay again.

I know I need help. That whisper in the back of my mind telling me to reach out isn’t going away anytime soon. It’s terrifying and exhausting, but it also means there’s still some part of me fighting for this life we’re creating together. And so, even though the darkness feels like a shroud that won’t lift, I’ll keep holding on until help arrives.

Today marks another week since bringing baby home, but the joy I expected feels distant. The term 'recital version' keeps floating around in my mind, though it’s vague and confusing. What does that even mean? I try to focus on how I’m feeling instead of trying to label everything.

I wake up each morning with a foggy head and heavy limbs. My heart sinks as soon as the clock ticks past 6 AM, and I know there's no escaping the day. Simple tasks like showering or cooking feel monumental. There’s this constant buzzing in my brain, but it doesn’t lead to anything productive.

Sometimes, looking at the baby just makes me feel more lost. Am I supposed to be happy? Is this normal? My thoughts are a whirlwind of confusion and doubt. Everyone talks about love at first sight with their babies, yet here I am questioning whether I’ll ever truly connect.

I keep telling myself it’s okay not to be okay right away. Yet, the nagging fear that something's wrong lingers. Maybe tomorrow will be better? Or maybe it won't. For now, I’m just trying to navigate through each day without losing sight of who I am beneath this new identity.

Feeling overwhelmed and unsure is exhausting. It’s a strange kind of emptiness mixed with a sense of helplessness. I don’t want to fall into the abyss of postpartum blues, but how do you fight something when you’re not even sure it exists?

Maybe tomorrow will bring some clarity or at least a sliver of hope. For now, though, today’s just another day to survive and wait for tomorrow.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of exhaustion and despair. It’s been seven years since the birth of my first child, and I still can’t shake this overwhelming sense of failure as a mother. The house is messy, the laundry piles up, and my children seem to be constantly hungry for attention that I just don’t have enough energy to give.

Sometimes I wonder if anyone else feels this lost in the chaos of parenting. It’s like every day is a struggle to put one foot in front of the other, but there are moments when I feel a flicker of hope. Maybe it’s reading about others who’ve walked this path and found their way back to joy, or talking to friends who remind me that I’m doing my best.

But today, as I watched my youngest trying to figure out how to tie his shoes, all I could think was, "Why am I not better at this?" It’s a cycle of self-doubt and guilt, and it feels suffocating. I want so badly for things to be different, but where do I start? How do I break free from this darkness that seems to envelop me every day?

I know there are resources out there—therapists, support groups—but the thought of reaching out just adds another layer of stress and anxiety. Maybe it’s time to take a step back, breathe, and find that glimmer of light again. For my kids’ sake, if not for mine.

Maybe tomorrow will be better.

December 13, Day 30

Today marks a month since little Emma joined our lives, and yet it feels like an eternity has passed. The weight of these last few weeks is heavy—both literally and figuratively.

Giving birth to her was the loneliest moment I've ever experienced. The sterile hospital walls seemed to close in as I cried out for someone, anyone, to be there with me. But everyone around felt clinical and distant, not the support system I craved. That initial isolation has only grown into a deep sadness that lingers despite her joyful giggles.

And then there's this extra baggage—Emma's arrival came with more than just love and hope. The scale shows something other than what I'd expected: an extra 25 pounds of baby weight, which feels like a constant reminder of how much I've changed. It's hard to shake the feeling that my body is not mine anymore.

I know I should be grateful for every moment, but sometimes it’s a struggle just to smile and pretend everything is fine. The days blur together in a haze of exhaustion and confusion. When will this fog lift?

So here I am, trying to hold onto hope and reach out for help because I can’t do this alone. Maybe tomorrow will be better?

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world. The hospital walls seemed to blur together as I held her for what felt like an eternity before returning home. But now, in this quiet house, it’s just me and my thoughts.

Every day feels like a battle with myself. It starts early in the morning when I catch glimpses of my reflection while brushing my teeth. The stretch marks on my belly seem to taunt me, reminding me that everything has changed. My body was once so strong, so full of life, and now it’s bloated and saggy.

I’ve tried to remind myself that this is temporary, that I’m creating a new normal. But the weight of those words feels heavy as molasses. Every time I look at my midsection, I see failure. Failure to be what society tells me I should be—a perfect mom with a perfectly toned body.

The therapist suggested journaling, but it feels like an uphill climb just to get started. Today was especially tough. I cried in the shower when I noticed how different my skin felt against my thighs. It’s not just about the physical changes; it’s about the emotional toll of feeling unrecognizable.

I’ve been trying to eat healthier and exercise, but every time I step on a scale or see a before-and-after image online, I feel like I’m suffocating. Why can’t I be happy with who I am right now? It’s not fair that my happiness depends so much on how I look. But it does.

Tomorrow is another day, they say. Another chance to get it right. But as I lay here in the dark, it feels like there’s no end to this tunnel. Maybe counseling will help me find a way out of this darkness. For now, all I can do is breathe and hope for better days ahead.

Today marks two weeks since little Ellie joined our family. The joy of holding her is unparalleled, but the exhaustion and confusion are overwhelming. I've been telling myself it's normal to feel down after all the changes, yet there’s a nagging voice in my head whispering that this isn’t just baby blues.

Last night, I cried because I couldn't remember where I left my phone. Was it before or after nursing? The constant cycle of feeding and changing feels like an endless loop. My husband tries to help, but sometimes his offers feel more like a reminder of what I can't do on my own.

I've always known about postpartum depression from research and personal history, yet it’s hard to believe it could be happening to me again. It's like this invisible weight that no one else can see. But I also know now that just feeling sad for a day doesn’t mean you're depressed. It's when those feelings start to take over, when every little thing feels insurmountable.

I'm trying to educate myself about what PPD really means and how it affects everyone differently. Maybe talking more openly about this will help me understand my own experience better. I can't let the fear of stigma silence me—I need support, and that's okay.

Today was a long day, but I made it through. Tomorrow is another chance to find hope in the haze.

April 14th, 2023

Today marks the one-month anniversary of bringing little Ethan into our world. It's hard to believe how much has changed in just four weeks. The hospital staff was right when they said it would feel like a whirlwind. I've been trying to navigate this new life with a mix of joy and uncertainty.

I’ve noticed a lot of media portrayal around postpartum issues, but nothing quite prepares you for the real thing. There’s this TV show I watch where the mom just disappears one night because she can't handle being a mother. It's so far from reality it's laughable. My days are filled with diaper changes, feedings, and countless middle-of-the-night wake-ups. I love every moment of it, even though it’s exhausting.

People talk about postpartum depression like it's an epidemic that strikes without warning, but for me, there’s no depression. There's only this overwhelming sense of love and gratitude. Sure, there are times when I feel overwhelmed, but those moments pass as soon as Ethan smiles at me or wraps his tiny hand around my finger.

I’m learning to ask for help more often now, which is a big adjustment. My mom visits every weekend to lend a hand, and it’s amazing how much easier everything becomes with an extra set of hands. Even though the sleep deprivation is real, I can’t imagine sleeping through any moment of this precious time.

Today, Ethan gave me his first gummy smile, and for a split second, I felt like everything would be okay. This journey isn't easy, but it’s beautiful in its imperfections.

January 17th

Today marks the first week since my daughter’s birth. My emotions have been a rollercoaster, with moments of pure joy followed by waves of sadness and anxiety that feel almost debilitating. It’s not easy adjusting to this new reality, but I’ve found solace in unexpected places—like YouTube.

I stumbled upon a channel dedicated to postpartum support last night when the weight of my feelings felt too heavy to bear.
