The videos were filled with stories from other moms who had walked similar paths and shared their struggles openly. Watching them helped me feel less alone, less crazy for feeling this way. It was as if someone finally understood what I’m going through.

One video in particular resonated deeply; it was about the importance of self-care after giving birth. The speaker talked about taking small steps each day to nurture oneself because you can’t pour from an empty cup. Simple reminders like drinking water and stepping outside for a walk reminded me that even tiny actions count towards recovery.

I’m still struggling, but there’s hope now. The videos gave me the courage to reach out to my support network again and talk about what I’m experiencing openly without fear of judgment. It’s a start, and every little bit helps.

Tomorrow, I’ll make an effort to step outside for some fresh air, maybe even meet up with a friend who understands. For now, I’m grateful for the virtual hugs these videos provided tonight.

Today feels like one of those days when the world outside my window moves in slow motion while everything inside me whirls at breakneck speed. The baby cries again, that familiar wail echoing through what’s left of my sanity. It’s been a week since I started taking these thermal pills—something my doctor suggested to help with the constant fatigue and anxiety. They’re supposed to make things easier, but right now, I just feel more like an observer than a participant in my own life.

Sleep is a distant memory, that hazy dream-state slipping away as soon as it comes into view. The nursery looks exactly the same as when I left it this morning, but somehow every corner seems to remind me of something missing, someone I’m failing at being present for. There’s a weight on my chest, not just from the baby sleeping beside me, but from knowing that each day might be another step down into the depths of myself.

I try to focus on the good moments—like when she smiles or giggles—and remind myself those are the things worth fighting for. But then there’s this overwhelming sense of dread, like I’m walking a tightrope without any safety nets. The pills help with the physical symptoms, but they don’t touch the constant loop in my mind that everything is just too much.

I miss being the mom who could do all of it, who knew what to do and felt capable. Now, I feel like I need someone else to tell me how to hold a bottle or when to change a diaper. It’s exhausting, this feeling of not being enough. But there are small victories—like figuring out how to feed both kids at the same time without dropping anything.

Tomorrow will be another day, I keep telling myself. Maybe tomorrow I’ll feel like I can manage one more thing. For now, though, today is about surviving until bedtime and hoping that sleep brings some semblance of peace.

January 3rd

Today marks a year since my twins were born. A year of silent tears and hidden smiles. I feel like the world has moved on without me, leaving behind this empty shell that used to be full of dreams and hopes. It's hard to believe that one moment can change everything.

The first few weeks with them were overwhelming—endless feedings, diaper changes, sleep deprivation. I remember feeling so grateful for my little angels but also so lost. Slowly, the happiness faded into a hazy void. I felt like I was drowning in a sea of fatigue and despair, unable to reach anyone.

People say motherhood is the most beautiful journey, but no one tells you about the dark corners. The nights when all you want is your old self back, before responsibilities and duties took over your life. It's lonely, this battle within yourself. You try to hold it together for everyone else, hiding behind smiles and small talk.

But today feels different somehow. As I held them in my arms earlier, something shifted inside me. Maybe it’s the first ray of light breaking through the clouds after a long winter. Or maybe it's just another day. Regardless, I'm starting to whisper to myself: You're not alone anymore. It’s okay to ask for help.

This journey is far from over, but I’m taking one step at a time now. Maybe tomorrow will be better.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my second child into the world. The past few days have been a whirlwind of emotions and exhaustion, but there’s an undeniable joy that radiates through it all. Seeing the smile on his face brings me so much happiness, yet I can’t shake this feeling of being utterly overwhelmed.

I remember vividly the fear and anxiety that led to my refusal to consider another pregnancy after the birth of our first child. Postpartum depression was a harsh reality back then, but somehow, despite everything, we decided to try again. This time around, though, I felt more prepared in some ways—more aware of what might come—but it still hit me like a tidal wave.

At 40, the physical toll is immense, and the emotional rollercoaster hasn’t stopped. There are moments when I feel incredibly capable and grateful, but then there’s this crushing sense that I can barely keep up with all the demands. It’s exhausting, to say the least.

Yet, even in my darkest moments, seeing our children together fills me with a peace and happiness I didn’t know was possible. They complete each other, and watching them grow is a privilege. But as for having more kids? Right now, it feels impossible, just like everything else seems to be piling on top of me.

Today I’m trying not to worry about tomorrow or next month. Just focusing on the small steps—changing diapers, cooking meals, and making sure everyone’s needs are met one day at a time. It’s all I can do right now, but it feels like a good place to start.

March 14th

It's been three months since I last tried to find help for my postpartum depression, and here we are again. Another day wasted on the phone with healthcare providers who seem more interested in their own schedules than in helping a new mom struggling to keep her head above water. The frustration is mounting, but it’s overshadowed by this constant emptiness inside me.

Sleepless nights blend into endless days as I juggle my baby's needs and my own battle with the darkness. Sometimes, when the silence is too loud and the exhaustion feels suffocating, I wonder if I’ll ever feel like myself again. I want to reach out for help, but every time I do, it feels like hitting a wall.

Today was particularly tough. I couldn’t even force a smile at my baby’s first laugh. There’s this nagging voice telling me that maybe things won't get better—maybe I'm just not cut out for this. But deep down, there's another voice whispering that I deserve to feel happy and whole again.

I need someone to listen, really listen, without judging or pushing me away. Until then, these days will keep stretching into what feels like an eternity of struggle and silence.

Today marks three weeks since little Emma joined our family, and if I'm being honest, the weight of it all is crushing me like never before. It's not just about my sleepless nights or the exhaustion from caring for a newborn. The world feels heavy too—the war raging overseas, everyone wearing masks and keeping their distance, and those awful customer service calls that leave me feeling small and insignificant.

I remember laughing with friends about how this would be easier if we were all in the same place, sharing stories over coffee. Now it's just me and a screen, trying to navigate the chaos of parenthood while everything around us feels so uncertain. I keep thinking there must be something wrong with me for feeling so alone when there are supposed to be so many people out there who know exactly what I'm going through.

The other day, someone at the grocery store said they could tell how hard things were by just looking at my face. It felt like a punch in the gut because I didn't even realize how much of myself was showing until she pointed it out. But then again, no one really wants to hear about postpartum struggles when there's already so much pain and loss happening everywhere else.

I miss being able to look forward to tomorrow without this overwhelming sense of dread hanging over me every time I think about the day ahead. Maybe if we could just get back to normal, things would feel more manageable again. Until then, though, it’s one step at a time—because even though everything feels impossible right now, I have no choice but to keep going for Emma's sake.

Maybe tomorrow will be better... or maybe it won't. But either way, I'll still be here, trying my best amidst the chaos.

Today marks one month since my wedding and reception, which should be a time of joy and celebration. Instead, I feel more alone than ever before. The days blend together in a haze of exhaustion and confusion. People around me talk about the bliss of new motherhood, but all I see is a stark reality that doesn't fit their cheerful tales.

The wedding was beautiful—flowers everywhere, twinkling lights, and laughter from every corner. But even then, there were whispers of what lay ahead. The idea of becoming a wife, a mother, in one fell swoop seemed overwhelming. Now, with each passing day, the weight of these roles presses down harder on my shoulders.

I've been trying to keep up appearances, to smile and nod through well-meaning advice from everyone around me. They don't understand what it's like inside this headspace where every moment feels heavy and suffocating. There are days when all I want is to escape the constant demands of a newborn and my new life.

The pressure to be perfect, to navigate these waters seamlessly while also maintaining some semblance of pre-baby self, leaves me feeling torn apart. It's like trying to hold water in your hands; it seeps through the cracks no matter how tightly you grip.

I know I need help—I've tried reaching out, but finding the right support feels as elusive as a dream that slips away upon waking. For now, all I can do is take one breath at a time, hoping somehow tomorrow might be better than today.

Today marks one week since bringing my baby home. I feel like a stranger in this new world of motherhood, where every day is filled with sleepless nights and endless worries. It’s hard to believe that just seven days ago, I was excited about our arrival at the hospital, but now all I feel is dread as each day passes.

The fear of childbirth, tokophobia, seems to have morphed into a deeper anxiety about everything related to being a mother. Every time my baby cries or needs feeding, I’m overwhelmed by this sense that I’ll never be good enough. It’s like there’s a void inside me that nothing can fill, and it’s starting to affect how I see myself and everyone around me.

My partner tries his best to help, but sometimes I snap at him over little things. He doesn’t understand why I’m so upset, and I don’t know how to explain the constant turmoil in my head. It feels like there’s no escape from this cycle of worry and sadness.

I miss who I used to be before all of this began. The old me would have been thrilled about parenthood, but now it feels like a dark cloud hanging over everything. Is this what everyone experiences after having a baby? Or am I just broken?

Tonight, as the baby sleeps and exhaustion threatens to pull me under, I’m left with this gnawing fear that things will never get better. But maybe if I write it all down, somehow I’ll start to see my way out of this darkness.

Today marks one month since little Ava joined our family. It’s been an emotional rollercoaster, with more ups and downs than I ever imagined. Some days are filled with joy and wonder as I watch her tiny hands grasp mine or hear her soft gurgles in the night. Other days feel heavy and long, where exhaustion weighs down my eyelids and every little thing sets me off.

I’ve been trying to be honest with myself about how I’m feeling, and today feels different. There’s a heaviness inside that doesn’t seem like it’s just from lack of sleep or adjusting to this new life. It’s a sadness that lingers no matter what time of day it is, no matter how many smiles she gives me.

I’ve realized something important though—asking for help isn’t a sign of weakness. In fact, reaching out might be one of the strongest things I do. Today, I told my mom and husband about some of these feelings, hoping they can support me through this chapter. It feels like a step forward, even if it’s not easy.

Tomorrow is a new day with more chances to try again. For now, I’ll hold onto the small moments of happiness and hope that tomorrow brings clearer skies.

Today feels like one of those days where every breath is a struggle against the weight of my own sadness. The nursery I worked so hard to prepare now looks foreign, as if it belongs to someone else's life story. My baby, who was once this incredible miracle of hope and joy, is just another source of exhaustion and frustration.

I've been trying to stay positive, but every time I look at her sweet face, all I can think about is how much my heart aches. It’s not that I don’t love her—it's there, buried deep under layers of anxiety and fatigue. But right now, it feels like more than I can handle.

Sleep deprivation has turned into an endless night where each hour ticks by with the monotony of a ticking bomb waiting to explode. The house is quiet except for the occasional cry that echoes through my mind like a scream in the wilderness. There’s no one here to hold me, to tell me it will be okay, because I am alone in this moment.

I know I should reach out, find help, but it feels impossible. Every step towards recovery seems like climbing an insurmountable mountain when all I want is a break from the climb. The thought of another day, another night without rest, terrifies me more than any other fear I’ve ever known.

Why does it feel as though no one can understand this pain? Why must every moment be such a fight against my own despair?

I am tired, so very tired, but also scared that if I take even a breath too deep, the dam will break and all these feelings will overwhelm me. So I hold on, just a little bit longer, hoping for some sign of light in this dark tunnel.

Maybe tomorrow things won’t feel as heavy. Maybe today wasn’t everything it felt like right now. But for now, I’ll rest my head, close my eyes, and pray that morning comes soon enough to ease the burden.

Today was one of those days where the weight of being a new mom feels just a bit too heavy to carry. The sun rose and I found myself wondering if today would be different from yesterday. Would my smile feel more genuine? Would my heartache lessen a little?

I woke up feeling unusually tired, not knowing if it's because sleep is still elusive or if it’s the cloud of sadness lingering over me. As I held baby Emma in my arms and looked into her tiny face, love surged through me like a warm tide. Yet, moments later, that same surge of emotion would be replaced by an overwhelming sense of guilt for feeling anything but joy.

My husband came home from work early today, noticing something wasn’t right. We talked about it — the good days when I feel like the luckiest person in the world to have Emma and the bad days when my heart feels hollow. He reminded me that it’s okay to not be okay all the time, and that asking for help is a sign of strength.

I’ve been trying to keep things simple: eat well, rest as much as possible, and let myself grieve this transition in small doses. Today was better than yesterday — at least I had moments where my laughter felt real again.

Tomorrow will be another day, and I’m holding onto hope that it will be a little brighter. For now, I'm grateful for the love that surrounds me, even when it feels like darkness is all around.

Today marks my third week as a new mother, and the reality of it all feels like a dream—or maybe a nightmare I can't wake up from. The exhaustion is overwhelming, but it's not just physical; there’s an emotional toll that hits me when I least expect it.

Society tells us to be perfect mothers, wives, homemakers. It's as if having a child comes with the unspoken expectation of giving everything else up, of being defined solely by this new role. And yet, here I am, questioning every decision I make because I know I’m not living up to some imaginary standard.

The days blend together in a haze of feedings and diaper changes, but amidst all that chaos, there's an underlying fear—what if I'm just a mother now? What happens when the novelty fades and the world sees me as nothing more than a woman who gave birth? 

I've been trying to stay positive, telling myself it’s normal to feel this way. But deep down, I know something isn't right. The sadness creeps in, uninvited, and settles like a heavy blanket over my heart.

It's lonely here, where no one seems to understand the silent struggle of being torn between joy and despair. Yet, there are resources out there; support groups and hotlines that whisper softly in my ear when everything else goes quiet. Maybe today will be different. Maybe I'll reach out for help, take a step towards reclaiming myself before it's too late.

Today is just another day, but maybe tomorrow can be better.

Today feels like a never-ending storm inside my heart. The baby's cries should be music to my ears, but they only amplify the void that’s growing within me. I can’t shake this overwhelming sense of emptiness and despair. How did everything turn from joyous anticipation to this dark cloud hanging over my head? 

I keep telling myself it will get better with time, but when does “time” start ticking for something like this? Is it okay to feel so lost in a sea of diapers, bottles, and endless feedings? Sometimes I look at the baby and wonder if they can see right through me. Maybe they sense my turmoil; maybe they can’t tell the difference between a loving gaze and an empty stare.

Sleep is elusive, but when I do manage to drift off, dreams are filled with chaos and fear. Waking up in the middle of the night covered in sweat, heart pounding like it’s trying to escape from me. It feels so wrong to feel this way after bringing new life into the world.

I’m trying to reach out for help, but every time I think about talking to someone, anxiety takes hold and stops my words before they can leave my lips. Shouldn’t there be a switch or an on/off button somewhere? Just something that could flicker hope back into my heart instead of this constant dread?

Maybe tomorrow will bring sunshine through the cracks. Until then, I’ll keep moving forward one step at a time, hoping for that light to break through.

Today was a whirlwind of emotions. I woke up feeling okay, but by mid-morning, the weight of everything hit me like a ton of bricks. The house is a mess, laundry piles up, and every time I turn around, there's another thing to do for the baby’s upcoming birthday party. It’s overwhelming, honestly.

I tried to keep busy with errands, hoping that distraction would help, but it only made things worse. By lunchtime, I found myself crying uncontrollably in a corner of my bedroom. It’s embarrassing and frustrating because I know I shouldn’t feel this way—my baby is healthy, and we have everything we need.

Later on, I forced myself to make a list of what needs to be done for the party. Planning sounds simple enough, but when you’re already feeling so off, it's like trying to run through quicksand. The thought of having guests over makes me anxious—I just want to hide and curl up in bed with my baby.

I know I need help, but asking for it feels selfish. My mom suggested she could take care of things while I rest, but the idea of someone else handling this sends me into another spiral of guilt and worry. What if something goes wrong? How can I be a good enough mother when even simple tasks feel insurmountable?

At some point, I’ll have to push through these feelings because my baby is growing up so fast. But today, I’m just going to let myself feel what I need to feel—cry a little more, take deep breaths, and hope that tomorrow might be better.

Today marks my third week as a new mom, and while I love holding my baby and watching them sleep peacefully, there are days when the exhaustion feels like a heavy blanket dragging me down. The constant worry about whether I’m doing everything right adds to this weight. 

There are moments of pure joy—like when my little one smiles or giggles for the first time. But then there’s an emptiness that follows, a sense of unease and anxiety that seems to cloud even those happy times. It’s hard to shake off the feeling that something isn’t quite right with me.

I’ve been trying not to worry too much about it, telling myself everyone feels this way sometimes. Yet, I keep coming back to my concerns. Am I just tired? Is this normal? Or is there more going on here?

Yesterday, I stumbled upon some information about postpartum depression. It’s scary stuff, but maybe understanding what’s happening could help me figure out how to move forward and find support. I’m not sure if it applies to me, but the descriptions feel uncomfortably familiar.

The idea of talking to someone about these feelings is daunting, yet I know seeking help might be crucial. I need to take care of myself so I can fully embrace this incredible journey of being a mother.

I hope tomorrow brings clearer skies and a little more peace.

Today marks three weeks since little Luna arrived in our home, and I find myself utterly surprised by the joy that comes with being a new mom. I had been bracing for postpartum blues, envisioning days filled with sadness and self-doubt. Instead, every morning feels like a fresh start, and holding Luna makes all the exhaustion fade away.

The early weeks were challenging—sleepless nights and constant worry clouded my thoughts. But now, as she coos and smiles back at me, I can't help but feel this overwhelming sense of peace and happiness. Every time she locks eyes with me, it’s like we share a secret language that only moms and babies understand.

I used to feel guilty about not getting out much or neglecting my old routines. But now, instead of seeing them as missed opportunities, I cherish the quiet moments at home. Reading stories aloud in our cozy living room, watching her discover new things with each passing day—it’s magical. There’s no place I’d rather be than right here.

Parenthood wasn’t what I expected, but it’s far better than my fears. Every snuggle and laugh from Luna reminds me how lucky I am to experience this incredible journey of motherhood.

Today marks 17 months since my daughter was born, and I can't help but feel like time has stood still in a way that feels both surreal and heavy. The days blur into weeks as they did back then when all I wanted to do was sleep and escape the constant demands of caring for this tiny person who had taken over my entire world.

But here's the thing: while she’s grown, so have my feelings of sadness and loneliness. It’s not just about the lack of sleep or the endless diaper changes anymore. Sometimes it feels like those first few months never truly ended, but instead morphed into something darker and more persistent. I keep wondering if everyone else around me sees this dark cloud hovering over our home, or am I really the only one who notices?

People often say to cherish these early years because they fly by in a heartbeat. But for me, it feels like time has slowed down to a crawl, each day dragging on with an unspoken sadness that doesn’t fit into any of those cheerful baby books or parenting guides.

It’s been hard reaching out for help too; after all, isn't this supposed to get better over time? The idea of sharing my struggles seems almost selfish when there are so many other things demanding attention. Yet, here I am, still feeling like the fog won’t lift.

I know I need to do something different—to find a way forward that’s not just about surviving but thriving. Maybe it starts with small steps: talking to someone who understands, maybe even joining a group where others share similar struggles. It feels like a daunting step towards the light, but maybe it’s also my only hope of finding some peace.

Today felt particularly heavy, and yet I’m leaving space for tomorrow to bring something new, no matter how small or fleeting. Maybe that's all we can ask for—tiny moments of grace amidst the chaos.

Today feels like a never-ending gray cloud hanging over my head. The baby is asleep, and I’m supposed to feel grateful for some quiet moments, but all I can think about is how alone I am in this new world. Everyone around me seems so thrilled with the little bundle of joy, yet here I sit, feeling like an outsider looking in.

I thought becoming a mother would be blissful, filled with constant joy and laughter. Instead, it’s a series of sleepless nights and overwhelming exhaustion that seems to sap all my energy and happiness away. The hardest part is knowing my husband doesn’t seem to understand what I’m going through. He brushes off my cries for help as just postpartum blues, nothing serious.

I keep wondering if anyone else feels this way. Is it okay to not feel the overwhelming love and joy that everyone expects? Am I a bad mom for thinking these things? The thoughts swirl around in my head like a hurricane, making it hard to focus on anything but how much I just want to cry.

Today was particularly tough when he suggested we could go out for dinner with friends later this week. Part of me feels relieved that there might be a break from the monotony at home, and another part dreads the idea of pretending everything is fine while inside, I’m barely holding it together.

I need to talk to someone who gets it, but where do you start when even your closest partner can’t see what’s really going on? Maybe tomorrow I’ll reach out to that support group for new moms. It might be a step towards understanding myself and not feeling so alone in this struggle.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom. I've been trying to navigate the whirlwind of sleepless nights and endless diaper changes with a smile, but lately, it's become harder. There are moments when holding my little one feels like a heavy weight on my heart instead of pure joy. Fear creeps in—what if this isn't normal? What if I'm not meant for this?

The exhaustion is real, the lack of sleep has me feeling like a zombie more often than not. But it's the overwhelming sense of dread and isolation that scares me the most. Am I just tired or is something deeper going on here? I feel lost in my own thoughts, unsure if these feelings will ever lift.

I know I need to talk about this with someone—maybe a friend, maybe a professional—but the thought of it feels daunting. What if they think less of me for admitting such things? Or worse, what if there's no quick fix and I have to face this alone?

Despite all this, I see glimmers of hope in her tiny smiles and first giggles. She’s growing so fast, and these little moments make everything worth it. Yet, the worry lingers like a shadow over my sunny days.

I need to find a way out of this darkness, but right now, even reaching for help feels too heavy. Maybe tomorrow will be different?

Today marks another day of this strange new world I find myself in. It's been a week since little one arrived, and while the joy of motherhood is undeniably present, there’s also an overwhelming sense of dread that lingers like a dark cloud above me. The exhaustion hits hard; every tiny sound from baby has me jumping, my heart racing. Yet, when I look into their eyes or hold them close, everything feels momentarily perfect.

I’ve always thought those who struggle with mental health were exaggerating or weak, but now I see the real pain behind it all. Every time the nurse visits and asks how I’m doing, I force a smile and say "Fine," because admitting anything else seems like an admission of failure. But deep down, there’s this voice whispering that things aren’t okay.

I’ve never felt so lost. All my life, I prided myself on being strong and capable, but now, faced with the enormity of what it means to be a mother, I’m scared out of my mind. The guilt is suffocating—I shouldn't feel this way when everything should be blissful. Yet here I am, battling tears in the middle of the night because I can’t figure out how to soothe them or why they won't sleep.

I know I need help. It’s terrifying but necessary. Maybe understanding my own pain will allow me to empathize with others going through similar struggles. For now, though, all I want is a moment's peace and someone who understands this isn’t just about hormones or being overwhelmed by new responsibilities—it's real, raw, and needs attention.

Day 7: A Tangled Web of Emotions

Today started like any other—morning light creeps through the blinds, and the baby's soft cries ring out. But something feels off today. The room is filled with a thick fog that seems to seep into my bones. I'm not sure if it’s the early morning or the sleepless nights catching up with me.

The baby's smile looks distant, as though they're in another world—maybe because I feel like I am too. Everything feels muted: the colors aren't as vibrant, and sounds are muffled behind a veil of despair. My mind races with thoughts that loop endlessly, each one more distressing than the last.

I know there's supposed to be joy, this beautiful moment of new life and love. But today, all I can feel is a crushing weight dragging me down. The world feels so far away, like it’s happening on another planet while I'm trapped here in my own dark cloud.

It’s hard to imagine how I’ll make it through the day, let alone the weeks ahead. The thought of doing this alone is overwhelming, but even reaching out seems impossible right now. All I want is to crawl back into bed and hide from this reality that feels so foreign and terrifying.

I hope tomorrow brings something different, a glimmer of light or warmth to pull me back in. For now, though, all I can do is take one breath at a time.

Today marks one month since bringing baby into the world. It’s been a whirlwind of diapers, late nights, and trying to keep up with my job from home. There are moments when I feel like I’m drowning in responsibilities, but then there are those magical seconds when everything feels perfect—like when she locks eyes with me during her first smile.

I’ve had these small dips in mood where the thought of getting out of bed seems insurmountable. The heaviness that settles over my heart and mind is alarming, but I remind myself it’s okay to feel this way sometimes. It’s not who I am, just a part of what’s happening right now.

Balancing work, being a new mother, and everything else can be overwhelming. There are days when I wish someone could take the wheel for a while, but I know that’s not how things work. I’m learning to give myself grace, taking it one moment at a time. It’s hard, but seeing her little face lights up my world in ways I never thought possible.

I’ll keep pushing through because she needs me, and I need her too. We’re in this together, no matter what.

Today marks a year since my son was born, and I can't help but feel like time has been both fleeting and agonizingly slow. The past twelve months have felt like an endless loop of sleepless nights and weary days, all while trying to figure out if there's more to life than just surviving.

I stopped taking my antidepressants about a month ago because they made me feel like I was moving in slow motion. Even though my doctor said I needed them, the medication didn't seem to be making things any better. Instead, it felt like I was just existing without really living. So, I decided to try something different, something that feels more natural and less controlled by a prescription.

I've been trying to focus on self-healing—more yoga, meditation, and lots of long walks with my son. It's not easy, but there are moments when the sun peeks through the clouds and everything seems a little brighter. Maybe I'm just holding onto these small victories because they're all that's keeping me going right now.

The hardest part is admitting to myself that I’m still struggling despite being one year out from his birth. It’s like this invisible weight on my chest, squeezing the breath out of me sometimes. But today, as I watched him giggle at his own reflection in a mirror, it felt worth it for just this moment.

I know there's more to come, and maybe I'll need help again soon. For now, though, I’m holding onto hope that these little bits of joy are signs of something bigger on the horizon.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world, and yet every moment feels like an eternity of sorrow. The sun rises, casting its warm glow across the room where she sleeps peacefully in her crib, but it does nothing to lighten the darkness inside me. I can hear the sound of birds chirping outside, a stark contrast to the heavy silence that fills my heart.

I thought being a mother would bring joy and fulfillment, but instead, I’m suffocated by an overwhelming sense of despair. Simple tasks seem insurmountable—changing her diaper is like climbing Mount Everest, feeding her feels as daunting as solving a complex equation. There are moments when I feel guilty for not feeling the way everyone says you should after having a baby, yet those feelings quickly turn into self-loathing and fear.

Every time my husband looks at me with love in his eyes, it’s as if he sees right through me to this hollow shell that mirrors back nothing but emptiness. His words of encouragement echo inside my head like the sound of an unanswered phone—hopeless and distant.

The thought of having another child terrifies me now more than anything else. How can I bring another innocent soul into a world where I struggle so much just to find happiness? My mental health feels like quicksand pulling me down, making every day harder than the last. It’s exhausting trying to keep up appearances for everyone else when all I want is to be okay.

But I’m not okay, and that terrifies me more than anything. So today, I made a decision—I won’t let fear dictate my future, but neither will I pretend it doesn’t exist. Maybe there are answers out there somewhere; maybe tomorrow will bring some clarity or comfort. For now, all I can do is breathe in deeply and pray for the strength to hold on until then.

Tomorrow is another day, they say. But sometimes, just getting through today feels like winning a marathon.

Today marks two weeks since I welcomed my little bundle of joy into the world. The days have been a blur of sleepless nights and overwhelming emotions. My heart swells with love every time I hold her close, yet this happiness is overshadowed by an eerie void that refuses to leave me.

I've been feeling so lost, like a ship adrift in a stormy sea without a compass. There are moments when I feel utterly consumed by fear and despair. It’s hard to explain, but it’s as if my heartstrings have tangled into knots, pulling at my soul with an unyielding grip.

But there’s this tiny voice inside me that keeps whispering, “You’re not alone.” And while the darkness is suffocating right now, I remind myself of the light. Every day, I try to find one small thing to be grateful for—maybe it’s a soft blanket or the warmth of morning sunlight on my face.

I know others must feel this way too, and if you’re reading this and struggling like me, please don’t give up. There’s help out there, and reaching out can make all the difference. I’m learning to take it one moment at a time, even when those moments are hard. 

Today might be tough, but tomorrow is new. And that's something worth fighting for.

---

This is just my journey, but know you’re not alone in yours.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my baby home from the hospital. The initial joy and excitement have faded into a haze of exhaustion and confusion. I never imagined that after all this time, I'd still be struggling to feel anything but overwhelmed.

When people talk about motherhood, they mention love at first sight and an instant connection with your child. That's not what it feels like for me. Every day is a battle against fatigue, anxiety, and doubt. Why can't I seem to find joy in this? What's wrong with me?

I'm starting to accept that something isn't right. The baby book talks about postpartum blues, but this feels different. It’s deeper, more persistent. There are moments of happiness when my son smiles at me or snuggles close during feedings, but those fleeting seconds aren’t enough to fill the void.

I feel alone in all of this. No one seems to notice how hard it is for me to get out of bed in the morning, let alone put on makeup and pretend like everything's okay. I miss my old life—when I was just me and not "the mom." How do you explain that feeling to someone who hasn't been through this?

I need help but am scared to ask. Will people think less of me? Is it selfish to want a break, even for a moment? Today, I decided to write down my thoughts without judgment. Maybe putting these feelings on paper will make them feel more real and less isolating.

I don't know what tomorrow holds, but today is just another day in this strange new world where being happy doesn’t come naturally anymore. But maybe understanding it better can start to change that.

January 5th

Today was another day filled with so many emotions I didn’t know existed before. The moment I picked up the razor this morning, everything changed. It’s strange how a simple act like shaving can trigger such overwhelming feelings of sadness and anxiety. Everything feels heavy right now—my body, my mind, even the air around me seems thicker.

I’ve been trying so hard to find joy in these early days with our baby, but there are moments when it feels impossible. The way I look at myself has shifted entirely; everything about this new person who stares back from the mirror is unfamiliar. And then comes that moment of truth: after every shave, a wave of depression crashes over me.

I’m trying to understand why this happens. Is it just seeing my body change so drastically? Or is it something deeper than that? I wish I could talk about these feelings openly without worrying how others might perceive me as an inadequate new mother. But the truth is, I am struggling and need help.

Sometimes, when I hold our baby close, I feel a glimmer of hope and happiness return. In those moments, I remind myself that healing takes time. It’s okay to ask for support because it's tough being alone with these thoughts all the time. Maybe today will be better tomorrow.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of postpartum fog. I wake up feeling like the weight of the world is sitting on my chest, suffocating me with a heavy blanket of despair. The sound of my baby's cries sends waves of anxiety through me, and I find myself frozen, unable to move or even breathe for what feels like an eternity.

I’ve been reaching out on social media more these days, sharing my struggles in hopes that someone else might feel less alone. It’s hard knowing that so many others are likely going through the same thing but too scared to speak up. I can’t help but think that if more of us spoke openly about our fears and doubts, maybe we could break down some walls.

This morning, as I held my baby for what felt like an eternity just to calm myself, a friend messaged me with words of support. Her message was simple but it hit home: “You’re doing the best you can.” Those few sentences brought tears to my eyes because they reminded me that even though every moment feels like a struggle, I am trying—despite how hard it is.

I’ve been trying to take care of myself too, squeezing in little moments for self-care throughout the day. Today, after my baby finally fell asleep, I made myself a cup of tea and read a few pages from a book I’d bought before she was born but hadn’t had time to look at since. It felt good to reconnect with that part of me that still exists, even if it’s buried deep under the layers of motherhood and mental health struggles.

I know this is just one day in what feels like an endless journey, but maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, I’m holding onto hope—tiny flickers of light amidst the darkness—and trying to find strength in the smallest victories.

Today marks another day in this never-ending cycle of isolation and doubt. The baby is sleeping peacefully, and I find myself staring out the window, watching the world go by without me. It feels like everyone else has moved forward while I'm stuck here, feeling lost and alone.

The pandemic has made everything worse. Before, at least there were people around—moments of distraction when I could forget for a bit. Now, it's just endless days filled with worry and despair. My mind races with thoughts that spiral out of control: What if I can't do this? What if the baby needs more than I can give?

I know deep down that there are people who care about me—family and friends—but talking to them feels exhausting. Every conversation ends up circling back to my struggles, and it's like a weight on my chest. I just want to be normal again.

There were times when I thought I was getting better after the baby was born. But then this pandemic hit, and suddenly all those old feelings came rushing back. The sadness is overwhelming, and sometimes, I wonder if anyone truly understands what I'm going through.

I've tried to reach out for help, but it feels like no one really knows how to help me. Therapy appointments are over Zoom, which just doesn't feel the same as being face-to-face with someone who can see the depth of my despair in their eyes.

Today, I made a small step by calling an old friend and asking if we could meet up soon for coffee. It's not much, but it’s something. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, though, all I can do is breathe and hope that these dark clouds will eventually lift.

Today marks three weeks since little one arrived, and I'm still trying to figure out what it means to be a mother. The hospital smells of bleach and new life mixed together, but now that we're home, there's just the smell of myself—tired, anxious, and overwhelmed.

The nights are endless with feedings and diaper changes, but when the baby sleeps, I can't seem to shut my brain off. It feels like a constant cycle of anxiety and exhaustion. The Escitalopram helps sometimes, but it’s not enough to erase the nightmares or the fear that creeps in every time I hear loud noises.

I keep catching glimpses of myself in mirrors and seeing someone who doesn’t recognize herself anymore. My reflection looks hollow, eyes ringed with dark circles, hair unkempt. Who is this person? This isn't the life I imagined for myself. The car accident still haunts me, replaying itself every time I think about how fragile everything can be.

Sometimes, when the baby’s sleeping and it's just me alone, the thoughts get too heavy to bear. It feels like drowning in a sea of despair with no way out. But there are moments, fleeting glimmers of joy—like when my husband brings me coffee or holds our child for hours so I can catch up on much-needed sleep.

It’s hard to believe that before all this, I was someone who would laugh easily and smile often. Now, the smallest things trigger a wave of sadness and hopelessness. But I am trying, really trying to find my way back to that person again. Maybe tomorrow will be better, or maybe it won't, but today I’m going to keep fighting.

I need help—I know that now more than ever before—but talking about these feelings feels like admitting defeat. Yet, here I am, writing them down, hoping someone out there can understand the turmoil inside me and guide me towards healing.

Today marks another day that feels like a never-ending cycle of shadows and light, but the darkness seems to linger longer than ever before. It's been ten years since I welcomed my baby into this world, yet here I am, still grappling with the weight of postpartum depression (PPD). Some days, it’s as though time has stood still while everything else in life moves forward without me.

The early mornings are always a struggle because there’s a part of me that wants to believe today will be different. Yet, when reality sets in, I’m left with this heavy, unyielding sadness that no amount of coffee or sunshine can lift. I try to tell myself it's just another phase, but after ten years, isn’t everything supposed to get better?

It’s funny how people talk about the “baby blues” lasting a few weeks or months and then magically disappearing once things settle down. But what if you’re still feeling like this long after everyone else expects you to be over it? It feels isolating, like I’m stuck in some kind of echo chamber with no way out.

Yesterday, I tried to reach out for help again—called a therapist, even though my phone number is probably on their “do not call” list. They’re so busy, and I feel like just another case study rather than someone desperately seeking real support. Maybe that’s why I keep pushing them away; it feels mechanical, like we're both going through the motions without making any genuine connection.

I’m scared to look ahead because every time I do, all I see is a long tunnel with no light at the end. But there are moments, fleeting ones, where I catch glimpses of joy and hope—like watching my child laugh or seeing the way their eyes light up when they learn something new. Those little sparks remind me that there’s still beauty in this world, even if it feels distant.

So today, I’m going to hold on to those moments a bit tighter and maybe write some more letters to myself and the therapists who might eventually understand what it’s like to live with PPD for so long. Maybe one day, the words will finally find their way through the fog, and someone will hear me.

Until then, I’ll keep taking tiny steps forward, hoping that somehow, somewhere, things can get better.

January 17, 2023

I didn’t expect to feel this way after bringing my baby home. I thought the joy of having a new life would be enough to keep me going, but it’s been harder than I imagined. The exhaustion is overwhelming, and every little task feels like climbing a mountain.

Days blend into each other in a haze of sleepless nights and constant worry. When did I become this person who can’t even manage the basics? It took me weeks to realize something was seriously wrong with how I felt. My mind races with thoughts of what-ifs and worst-case scenarios, making it impossible to relax.

I tried to break things down into tiny steps—make breakfast, then fold one load of laundry—and even that proved exhausting. The guilt piles up; why can’t I just be like everyone else who seems to handle this so effortlessly?

But there’s hope now. Slowly, very slowly, a routine is forming. It’s not perfect, but it helps me structure my day and manage the chaos better. I’m starting to reach out for help more too, which feels scary yet liberating.

I know it won’t be easy, but I’m determined to get through this. One small step at a time.

Today marks my fourth week since bringing our little miracle home. As I cradle her in my arms now, a feeling of overwhelming love and gratitude washes over me. Yet, there are moments—like these quiet ones when the house is still—that unexpected sadness creeps up on me like an unwanted guest.

It’s funny how much you can love someone yet feel this kind of sorrow. I keep telling myself it’s normal, that everyone has their rough patches, but sometimes it feels too intense for just being tired or overwhelmed. The baby is beautiful and perfect, and my life is good. But there are those fleeting moments where I’m not sure what to do with the sadness.

Thankfully, I have a fantastic support system around me. My mom, best friend, sister—they’re all here when I need them most. They remind me that it’s okay to feel this way and that help is just a phone call away. It’s comforting knowing there are people who understand without judgment.

Today was one of those days where I felt the weight of everything pressing down on me. But after talking with my therapist, I felt better. She said acknowledging these feelings is part of healing, and it’s not about being strong alone but reaching out when you need support. It’s a hard lesson to learn, but an important one.

I guess today was just another reminder that motherhood isn’t all sunshine and rainbows, even for me. But I’m learning every day how to navigate this new territory with grace and strength.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of uncertainty and exhaustion. The baby’s cries echo through the house, a constant reminder of my new reality. I’ve been trying to stick with the medication, but it feels like nothing is changing. Sometimes I wonder if I’m just too tired to notice any difference or if these pills aren’t doing enough.

I have an appointment with Dr. Smith on Thursday, and honestly, I can't decide if I'm looking forward to it or dreading it. Part of me hopes she has some magic solution that will make everything better overnight. The other part is terrified that nothing is going to get easier anytime soon.

Sleep is a distant memory now. Each night feels like an eternity of tossing and turning, trying not to wake the baby but knowing I never really rest well anymore. The weight of it all—of being responsible for someone else’s life while struggling with my own—is overwhelming.

I can see the worry in my partner’s eyes when they think I’m not looking. They try their best to help, but there are moments where I feel like a burden, even though that’s probably the last thing I want to be.

Tomorrow is going to be another long day, but maybe it will also bring some clarity. Until then, I’ll keep pushing forward, hoping for better days ahead.

Today marks my sixth week as a new mom, and I’ve been trying to keep myself busy with anything that doesn’t involve looking at the baby and wondering if this is all there is. There are moments of pure joy when she smiles, but then I feel like I’m not really feeling much else.

I woke up today thinking about how tired I am and how little sleep I get. My head feels heavy, and my heart aches with an emptiness that’s hard to describe. It’s as if the world is muted, and no matter what I do or say, nothing seems to fix this overwhelming sense of sadness.

I’ve been drawing more lately, trying to capture something meaningful on paper. Sketching helps me process everything swirling inside my head. Today, I drew a landscape with dark clouds and light raindrops falling gently. It’s not perfect, but it feels like an honest reflection of how I’m feeling right now—a mix of hopelessness and a tiny bit of hope.

I know there are resources out there, support groups and therapists who specialize in postpartum depression. But reaching out seems so daunting. It’s scary to admit that you might be struggling, even when everyone around you expects you to be happy and grateful all the time.

Maybe tomorrow will feel different. Maybe I’ll find the courage to talk to someone about what’s going on inside my head. For now, though, I’m just going to try and keep drawing and hope it keeps me from sinking too deep into this cloud of uncertainty.

Today marks three weeks since Lily's birth. The days blur together in a haze of exhaustion and doubt. I wake up each morning feeling like yesterday was just another day where I fell short as a mom. It’s hard to shake the constant worry that I’m not doing enough, or worse, that I'm screwing everything up.

The baby cries, and instead of knowing how to soothe her with confidence, my mind races through every possible reason why she could be upset—was it because I fed her too soon? Too late? Is she cold? Or hungry?

I spend hours in bed, staring at the ceiling. The guilt is overwhelming. Why can’t I just figure this out? Why do I feel so helpless when all I want is to protect and care for my little girl?

The exhaustion is crushing. Not just physical, but mental. Every day feels like a battle against these relentless thoughts that whisper how inadequate I am. When did being a mother become this daunting task of constantly proving myself?

I’m drowning in a sea of what-ifs and should-haves. Am I really so terrible at this? Is there something wrong with me for not knowing the answers right away? Why can’t I just feel happy about our new life, instead of weighed down by endless self-doubt?

Tomorrow feels like an insurmountable mountain to climb. But maybe it’s okay if today was another day where I didn’t get everything right. Maybe tomorrow will be different.

Maybe.

Today feels like a mountain I’m trying to climb with heavy boots and no map. Uncle Joe passed away yesterday, and the weight of it all is crushing me. My heart is heavy, but my eyes are dry. It’s strange how grief can be so silent.

The baby slept through most of her nap today, which was a miracle in itself. I’m grateful for small victories like those, even if they’re rare. My mom has been here more than she ever promised to be, and for that, I am eternally thankful. She holds my hand when I need it most, even if we don’t always know what to say.

Postpartum depression isn’t just about feeling sad or tired—it’s a whole body of darkness that wraps around you. It whispers lies, telling me I’m not good enough for my daughter. But the truth is, she’s here because I love her fiercely. She’s everything that keeps me going on days when nothing else does.

Today was hard, but it also reminded me how much I need to lean into the support around me. My friends and family are a lifeline, and even though I’m not sure what tomorrow will bring, I know they’ll be there for another round of this rollercoaster ride called life with a newborn.

Tomorrow’s a new day, but today? Today was just about surviving. And that’s okay too.

Today marks a year since bringing little Leo into the world. It’s crazy how fast time flies when you’re up all night with a newborn and scrambling to meet deadlines at work. I can’t shake this feeling of being lost in a sea of laundry, dishes, and tantrums.

Sometimes it feels like I’m just going through the motions without any real joy or purpose. My head is spinning from trying to manage everything – keeping my eyes on all three kids while also cooking meals and cleaning up after everyone. It’s exhausting, both physically and emotionally.

I find myself crying over silly things lately. Yesterday, I burst into tears because there wasn’t enough milk in the fridge for a smoothie. I can barely keep it together when the babies are fighting or screaming for attention. When I’m not busy chasing them around, I lie on the couch wishing someone would just do everything for me.

I know I need help and support, but admitting that feels like failure somehow. Deep down, though, I want to be okay again – for my kids and myself. It’s a constant battle between pushing through and breaking down. I hope there’s light at the end of this tunnel because right now, it feels pretty dark.

Maybe tomorrow will bring something different? Or maybe not. For today, I’ll just try to breathe and keep going. One step at a time.

Today feels like a rollercoaster of emotions wrapped up in a tight ball of worry and exhaustion. The baby’s sweet smile doesn’t help the fog that clouds my mind, making even simple tasks feel monumental. I keep telling myself this is normal, but when you're struggling to find joy in the little moments, it's hard to believe anyone else feels like me.

Sleep deprivation is a real monster hiding under every corner of our home, snatching away any chance for rest. Every time the baby wakes up crying or needing something, my heart races with panic and fatigue. It’s overwhelming how much has changed since she arrived. I try to focus on positive things—like her tiny fingers curling around mine—but it's tough when even a hug feels like too much.

I know I should reach out for help, but the thought of sharing all this seems daunting. Part of me thinks that if I just push through, everything will be okay soon enough. But another part wonders what would happen if I let myself be vulnerable and ask for support. It's a confusing mix of wanting to take care of everyone and needing someone else to take care of me.

The day drags on like molasses; the hours tick by slowly as I navigate my way through diapers, bottles, and endless cuddles. Despite all this, there’s an unshakeable feeling that something is off, that these emotions are more than just new mommy blues. Maybe it's time to stop pretending everything is fine and start talking about how I really feel.

Maybe then, the world won’t seem so heavy anymore.

Today marks exactly one month since Makyah joined our little world. The days blur together in a haze of sleepless nights and endless feedings, but there are moments when I catch glimpses of joy amidst the chaos.

It’s been an up-and-down journey, filled with more tears than laughter lately. I know postpartum depression is real—it sneaks up on you when you least expect it, wrapping its cold hands around your heart. But through all this, friends have been my lifeline. They call and text just to see how we’re doing, even if they don’t need anything in return. Their care and kindness make me feel less alone.

I’ve started reaching out more myself, making sure other new mamas know someone’s watching over them too. We can’t do this all on our own; it takes a village. So to anyone reading this—thank you for being that supportive network when I needed it most. Here’s to navigating these unpredictable waters together.

And maybe one day, we’ll look back at these moments and smile, remembering how far we’ve come.

Today marks a month since little Ella joined our family. The days blur together with endless feedings and diaper changes, but there are moments when I feel like I’m starting to find my footing. Holding her close, watching her tiny fingers grasp mine—it’s breathtaking. There are times when the weight of everything feels so heavy, and I struggle not just with my usual depression but also these new postpartum blues.

I’ve been trying hard to stay on top of my meds, which helps a bit with the mood swings. But there are days when it all seems like too much—like those nights when sleep deprivation leaves me feeling utterly lost and alone. I know I need more help than just medication though, and that’s scary. Therapy has always been hit or miss for me, but maybe now is the time to give it another shot.

Ella’s smile pierces through my foggy thoughts sometimes, reminding me why all this effort matters. She’s so small and trusting, completely reliant on us. It’s both humbling and terrifying. Every day I’m battling between feeling like a good enough mom and wondering if I can truly handle all of this.

I’ve started reading more about postpartum depression online; it helps to know I’m not alone out here in mommy land. But there are still days when I feel like I’m drowning, unable to pull myself up from the depths. It’s a constant struggle to keep my head above water and stay present for Ella.

I guess what matters most is taking things one day at a time. Maybe if I can just make it through today without falling apart, then tomorrow will be easier too. For now, that’s all I’m asking for—just one more day.

December 15, 2023

Today marks one year since I first held my little miracle in my arms. It’s been a rollercoaster of emotions, from sheer joy and overwhelming love to crushing sadness and self-doubt. As the days turned into weeks, and those weeks into months, I found myself slipping deeper into a foggy haze that was postpartum depression.

I remember thinking that I should just be able to ‘snap out’ of it, but it’s not something you can simply turn off like a light switch. It took me longer than I care to admit to reach out for help, but once I did, everything started falling into place. Therapy has been my lifeline. Talking about my feelings with someone who listens without judgment has been incredibly healing.

There are still days when I struggle to get out of bed or feel like a failure as a mother. But now, instead of pushing those thoughts away, I acknowledge them and work through them in therapy. I’m learning that being okay isn’t about not having bad days—it’s about knowing how to handle them.

Moving forward, my goal is to prioritize mental health over everything else. No more pretending or hiding behind accomplishments. My baby deserves a mom who's present and wholeheartedly engaged with her, flaws and all. And I deserve to be that person too.

Day 34: This Little Piggy Went to Market...

Oh boy, here I am again, staring at this ceiling with nothing but a blank mind and an endless stream of tears threatening to break free. The nursery is still too pink, the crib screams "Welcome Home" in neon lights, and every stuffed animal looks back like they know something about my life that I don’t.

The baby sleeps most of the time, which sounds great on paper—less work for me, right? But it’s not. It's just a constant reminder of how much more there is to do when she wakes up. Like feeding her, changing her, and then starting all over again. And when I'm supposed to sleep, my brain kicks in with a vengeance, replaying every single moment of the last month. Every missed milestone, every failed attempt at breastfeeding, every time I've felt like I was failing as a new mom.

I tried laughing it off today by telling myself that I’m just having a bit of a "pink and blue breakdown." But deep down, I know it’s more than that. It's a heavy feeling that sits in my chest like an uninvited guest who refuses to leave for tea or dinner.

So here I am, still figuring out how to be this person they call “mom.” Maybe one day the tears will make sense and the sarcasm won’t feel so necessary. Until then, I’ll just keep writing until something changes—or maybe it’s already changed and I’m just too busy crying to notice.

April 13th

It's been weeks since I gave birth to my baby girl, but each day feels like another mountain to climb. Today was particularly rough. Woke up feeling more exhausted than usual, and the weight of being a new mom felt heavier than ever. The joy that should be there is overshadowed by this dark cloud hanging over me.

I've tried talking about how I feel, reached out for help, but it's like no one understands just how deep down in my depression goes. Every little thing seems to irritate me, and the thought of getting through another day makes my chest tighten with anxiety. Why can't I be happy? Why do I feel so lost?

Went on a walk today, hoping for some fresh air might clear my head. Instead, all I saw were mothers out enjoying their kids, laughing and smiling. They looked so content—I felt like an impostor walking past them.

I know this isn't normal. That I'm not alone in feeling this way. But it's hard to believe when each moment feels like a battle. The baby cries, the dishes pile up—everything feels overwhelming.

Called my therapist today and cried through our session. He tried to be supportive but even his words felt hollow sometimes. "You're doing better," he said, but I just want to feel good without forcing it.

Tried to nap after, hoping sleep would make me see things differently. But the more I lay there, staring at the ceiling, the more my mind spins. 

Wishing someone could take this weight off my shoulders and give me back my sunshine. But until then, I'll keep trying, one breath at a time.

Day 30 Postpartum

Today marks a month since I brought my little miracle into the world. It’s been an emotional whirlwind of joy and uncertainty. The baby seems to be thriving, but as for me, it's been a different story. Lately, I’ve felt like there’s this constant fog hanging over my head. Everything feels heavy—changing diapers, feeding her, even just holding her sometimes.

I remember scrolling through that women’s health group online and seeing so many stories that mirrored what I was feeling right now. It’s reassuring to know I’m not alone in this. There are days when all I want is a nap, but guilt washes over me as soon as I think about leaving my baby unattended for even a moment.

I’ve been trying to keep myself busy with gentle activities: reading books that aren’t about babies, listening to soothing music, and taking short walks around the block. It’s not much, but it helps me feel less like I’m drowning in this sea of exhaustion and worry.

I know I need to be patient with myself. Postpartum depression isn't something you can snap your fingers and make disappear. Today was tough, but tomorrow could be a better day. For now, I'll focus on the small steps, knowing they add up to big progress over time.

Today marks one week since I brought life into the world, but it feels like a lifetime has passed in just seven days. The hospital walls echo with a silence that cuts deeper than any scream ever could. It's surreal to think about how close I was to losing everything, myself included. I can still see those stark white tiles closing in around me as my body fought for survival.

Every time I hold my baby now, it’s like a lifeline back from the brink of death. But joy is hard to come by when every breath feels heavy with fear and sorrow. People tell me to be grateful, that at least I have this precious gift, but what about everything else? The dark thoughts swirl in my head like a hurricane, relentless and destructive.

I try to smile for them, for him, but it’s getting harder each day. My husband talks about how lucky we are, about moving forward without dwelling on the past. But there’s no “moving forward” when you’re stuck in quicksand. I feel so alone in this chaos, like nobody really understands what I’m going through.

I know I need help, but admitting it feels like admitting defeat. Everyone says postpartum depression is common, that it’ll pass eventually, but how can anything ever be okay again? Every heartbeat reminds me of a near miss that still echoes through my bones. I don’t want to forget the pain so much as I wish for some peace.

It’s been a week since I became both a mother and a survivor. But today feels like day one, with no clear path forward just yet.

Today marks exactly two weeks since I brought my baby girl home from the hospital. The days are a blur of feedings and diaper changes, but something feels off. It’s not just the exhaustion—I’ve heard about that. There’s this emptiness, a quiet sadness that sneaks up on me when I’m changing her or just looking at her in her bassinet.

I know all too well what postpartum depression is thanks to my sister’s experience. She went through it after having her first child and it was scary for everyone involved. So here I am, scared of something happening to me because the sadness doesn’t feel normal. It’s like a constant whisper in the back of my mind asking if I’m enough.

I try to stay positive, telling myself that this is all part of adjusting to motherhood. But there are moments when I can’t shake the fear and anxiety about what lies ahead. The sleepless nights aren’t helping either. My partner tries his best to support me, but he’s also tired from adjusting to our new routine.

I want so badly to love being a mom, but this weight of worry is heavy. Maybe it’s time I talk to someone who can help sort out these feelings. Until then, I’ll keep trying my hardest and hoping for better days ahead.

December 7th, 2023

I barely slept last night, tossing and turning with the heaviness in my chest. The trip home from the tour was supposed to be a break, but now it feels like I'm trapped in this quiet house. Everything seems so different here, even though nothing has really changed. My mind keeps replaying every moment of our journey back—strange how such simple things can feel overwhelming.

I miss being surrounded by people, feeling the warmth and excitement of the crowd. Here at home, it's just me and the baby. The silence is suffocating sometimes. I know everyone says "it gets better," but when do they mean? When you're not alone anymore? When your heart stops aching for something you can't even describe?

I tried to call my mom today, but she sounded tired on the phone, like she doesn’t have time for me right now. It’s not her fault; it’s just hard to talk about this when there seems to be no real solution.

Yesterday, I went out for a walk in the park. The leaves were falling, and the trees looked so bare, reminding me of how empty everything feels inside. I saw a mother with two kids playing on the swings, laughing. It was like someone had flipped a switch that wasn’t turned back for me.

I don't know if it's normal to feel this way after having a baby, but something isn’t right here. Maybe it’s just the transition from being out and about to settling into a routine that feels too still. But I can't shake off these thoughts—maybe there is no "getting used to" this feeling.

I need help, but I’m not sure how to ask for it without sounding like I'm giving up. I want to be strong, but right now, even talking about it makes me feel weaker.

This diary entry feels like a small step towards figuring out what's next. Maybe writing it down will make the fog in my head lift just a little bit.

Today marks three years since I held my baby for the first time. It's a strange milestone to celebrate when every day feels like a weight dragging me down into the depths of despair. I thought that after all this time, things would get easier. That maybe I'd start feeling like a mother instead of someone who was forced into this role.

The pregnancy wasn't planned; it was a surprise wrapped in pressure from everyone around me—my family, friends, even my partner. They said I needed to have kids to complete something within myself, but all they did was rip away my sense of self and replace it with overwhelming anxiety and sadness.

Three years later, and the exhaustion never fades. The nights are filled with aching loneliness as I lie awake in bed, wondering how life could spiral so out of control. It’s not just about the baby or even the responsibilities that come with being a parent; it's about feeling trapped in a cycle where joy is a distant memory.

I've tried to love this child, really tried, but there's a part of me that remains untouched by the supposed magic of parenthood. I know I'm lucky to have healthy kids and supportive people around, yet here I am, struggling with thoughts I can't seem to shake off. The guilt is suffocating.

Today, I made the hard decision that I won’t be having more children. It's a relief in some ways but also a fear of disappointing those who think differently. But at this point, my own well-being feels like a distant dream. Maybe it’s time for me to start living again, not just existing day by day.

I need help. This isn't about being weak; it's about survival. I deserve better than this endless struggle.

Today marks another day in what feels like an endless cycle of doubt and guilt. I can’t shake the feeling that I’m failing somehow, despite knowing deep down that this isn’t my fault. The baby’s first year has been a whirlwind of emotions—joy mixed with overwhelming sadness and self-doubt. It's as if every moment is a reminder of what I'm missing out on or doing wrong.

There are days when holding her seems like the most natural thing in the world, but then there are moments where everything feels suffocatingly heavy. The exhaustion, the constant anxiety about whether I’m providing enough, and the nagging voice that whispers, "You're not good enough." It’s a relentless battle inside my mind.

I keep telling myself it's okay to feel this way, but it doesn’t make the guilt any less real. Every time she smiles or giggles at something simple, there’s a part of me that wishes I could be happier for her. But instead, I’m consumed by thoughts of inadequacy and fear of not being able to protect her from everything.

I know now is the time to seek help, but it feels like admitting defeat. Yet, I also know that I can’t keep carrying this weight alone. Maybe today is the day I take that first step towards healing, even if it means facing my fears head-on and reaching out for support.

Today marks one year since my baby was born, and it feels like a lifetime ago. I never imagined that the joy of becoming a mother would come with such dark nights and days filled with tears. The first few months were overwhelming, but somehow, deep down, I knew there was something more to this cloud hanging over me than just being tired or overwhelmed.

Looking back now, it’s hard not to feel guilty for feeling so low when everyone kept telling me how lucky I am. My baby sleeps through the night, doesn’t cry much, and is generally easy-going. But that didn’t change the fact that I felt like I was drowning in a sea of loneliness and despair.

I’ve finally started to see the light at the end of this long tunnel, though. It’s taken time, but gradually, I’m finding my footing again. Therapy has been a game-changer; talking about these feelings with someone who understands them is something I didn’t even know I needed until it happened.

What still baffles me is how little support there seems to be out there for women like me. It’s as if the only stories that get told are those where everything falls into place perfectly. No one talks about the struggles, the real ones, the painful and confusing moments of doubt and sadness.

Today, I’m trying to hold onto the hope that things will continue to improve. Slowly but surely, I am reclaiming my life. And maybe, just maybe, sharing my story will help another mom out there feel less alone.

Day 7: A Blurry Mess of Emotions

Today feels like a never-ending blur of tears and confusion. I can't shake off this overwhelming sadness that clings to me like a thick fog. It's been seven days since my baby arrived, and instead of feeling joyous or at peace, I'm constantly on the verge of breaking down.

I tried reaching out to my doctor yesterday about how I've been feeling—aching in every way possible, both physically and emotionally—but it feels like my voice is lost in a sea of indifference. They told me to take care of myself and get some rest but didn't seem to grasp the depth of despair that's been gnawing at me since childbirth.

Why do I feel so alone? Why does everyone else look so happy with their new bundles of joy, while I'm drowning in this dark cloud? Did something go wrong with my baby or am I just not cut out for motherhood? The questions spin like a tornado in my head. I can't seem to find answers anywhere.

Worse still, nobody seems to take my worries seriously. Is it really okay to feel this way after giving birth? Am I the only one who feels like they're failing?

Tomorrow I'll try again. Maybe there's someone out there who will see past all these doubts and fears. Until then, I'm just going to sit here in the darkness, hoping for a glimmer of light.

Maybe someday soon, this fog will lift, but today it’s suffocating me.

Today was a blur of tears and exhaustion. I thought the baby would bring joy into our lives, but all it’s done is make everything harder. When he walks through the door tonight, his face will light up with that tired yet loving smile, but instead of my heart swelling with gratitude like it should, all I feel is this dark pit in my stomach twisting and turning.

Seeing him makes me feel suffocated, like there's no air left to breathe. My mind races with thoughts I can’t even explain – why am I so angry at him? Why does the sight of his face make my chest tighten?

I try to shake it off, telling myself it’s just exhaustion and hormones playing tricks on me. But deep down, I know something is seriously wrong here. The baby’s crying keeps me up all night, but no matter how much sleep I get, I still feel like I’m drowning in a sea of despair.

Why am I so scared? Why can’t I love him the way I used to? It feels like every moment is suffused with this overwhelming sense of dread. Maybe it’s time to reach out for help. But that thought terrifies me even more – admitting that you’re not okay, when everyone expects you to be glowing and happy.

The weight of it all is crushing. I just want the darkness to lift, but how do you turn off a feeling like this? I’m lost in a haze of confusion and sadness, wondering if things will ever feel right again.

April 7th

I never imagined I’d feel this way after giving birth to my beautiful baby girl. Everything seemed perfect: a cozy home with everything we needed, supportive family nearby, and a loving partner who couldn’t be more excited about our new addition. But here I am, struggling through each day with an overwhelming sense of emptiness.

Yesterday was particularly rough. The house was quiet as everyone napped, and all I could do was stare at the ceiling, tears welling up in my eyes. Why can't I feel joy? My husband brought me soup, but even his kind gestures felt like a weight pressing down on me. It's strange how life can turn upside down without warning.

I've been trying to tell myself that this is just a phase, something temporary and manageable. Yet, as the days blur into one another, my worries deepen. I’m scared for the future and whether these feelings will ever lift. Am I doing enough? Are we all right?

Today, I made an effort to reach out to friends who have been through this before. They listened and reassured me that it’s okay not to be okay. It’s a relief knowing others struggle too. Maybe talking more openly about my fears can help ease some of the burden.

I need to find ways to support myself while also nurturing our little family. Baby steps, I guess. For now, one moment at a time.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my little miracle into the world. The hospital was a blur of beeping machines and sleepless nights. Now that we're home, it feels like there's no escape from this overwhelming exhaustion and loneliness. It’s hard to believe just eight years ago, after losing a pregnancy, I felt so lost and hopeless that I contemplated ending my life. 

I see the dark corners in my mind where those thoughts once resided, but something has shifted. Maybe it’s the love for this tiny being who depends on me, or maybe it’s the knowledge that I survived before, even when it seemed impossible.

It’s okay to struggle right now. There are moments of pure joy mixed with waves of despair, and I’m learning to acknowledge both without judgment. Talking to friends from my support group helps; their stories remind me that I am not alone in this battle against the shadows.

I want others going through similar pain to know: better days do come, even if they feel like a distant dream right now. I’ll keep pushing forward, one breath at a time, because there’s light beyond the darkness, and it’s worth fighting for.

Today marks the second week since Lily’s arrival. It feels like a whirlwind of change and adjustments, but somehow it all feels oddly normal now. I woke up this morning feeling a bit heavier than usual, mentally and physically. There’s that familiar weight in my chest, one that seems to settle when I let out a big sigh or release some trapped air. It's strange how such a simple bodily function can trigger these feelings.

The rest of the day has been a mix of baby feeds, naps, and walks around the block. Lily is so content right now; she just stares at me with those big eyes, like she’s trying to figure out this whole new world. It's hard not to get lost in her gaze, but it doesn’t quite reach the dark corners that seem to grow inside my head.

I tried talking about these feelings with my partner earlier today, and he listened without judgment, which is comforting.
