But there are days when I feel like a stranger to myself, as if this isn't really happening to me, or maybe it’s just not real at all. The thought that something so mundane as releasing gas could send me spiraling into sadness feels ridiculous yet true.

I’m trying to take things one day at a time and remind myself that everyone goes through rough patches postpartum. It's okay to feel this way, but I know I need to keep pushing forward and reach out if it gets worse. For now, I'll continue to breathe deep and hope for better days ahead.

Today marks a week since little Olivia joined our family, and while I’m filled with joy and love for her, there’s this constant tug of war inside me. The hospital nurses were so adamant about exclusive breastfeeding that it felt like they didn’t hear my concerns or see the reality of my struggle. My body is still recovering from delivery, my sleep is shattered, and every time Olivia cries, I feel overwhelmed.

I’ve barely slept more than two hours straight since she arrived home, and with no help in sight, the idea of going it alone feels daunting. Why do they push exclusive breastfeeding so hard when I’m not sure if this is the right path for us? Every time someone mentions formula or a pacifier, I feel guilty as if I’m failing my baby somehow.

My mom lives too far away to offer immediate support, and with work piling up, it’s like there’s no escape. How can I keep up when everyone expects me to be supermom right out of the gate? It doesn’t help that every post on social media seems to celebrate breastfeeding as if it’s some sort of golden ticket to happiness and health.

I’m trying to navigate these challenges with grace, but sometimes, I just need a moment to breathe without feeling like I’m letting everyone down. Maybe tomorrow will be better—I hope so.

Today is day 34 since my baby was born, and I’m trying to figure out why everything feels so heavy, even the air I breathe seems thick with worry. It’s like there’s a cloud hanging over me that won’t lift no matter how many times I remind myself how lucky I am.

I tried smiling today when someone asked if I was happy being a new mom, and it felt fake. The thought of holding my baby and feeling love didn’t come easy at all. Instead, it was just another thing to do on the endless list of tasks that seem impossible without any help.

The sleepless nights are catching up with me. I’m constantly anxious about every little sound or bump in the night. Is she crying because she’s hungry? Did I leave her somewhere unsafe by accident? The fear is suffocating, and it doesn’t let up for a second.

I know I need to talk to someone about this. It feels selfish to be upset when I should just feel grateful, but the truth is, I’m struggling so much with postpartum depression and anxiety. Maybe reaching out isn’t being weak; maybe it’s what I need right now to find my way back to feeling like myself again.

Tomorrow I’ll try calling that support line I found online. It feels scary to admit how I’m really doing, but it might just be the first step in making this all a little less overwhelming.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my baby home. I keep telling myself it’s just the fatigue talking, but every day feels like a struggle. It's as if there's this dark cloud hovering over everything—I can't shake off the feeling that something is seriously wrong with me.

The other night, when everyone was asleep and the house was quiet except for my baby's tiny snores, I found myself overwhelmed by an intense sadness. I sat on the floor of her nursery, staring at her little crib, wondering what kind of mother I am if I can’t feel joy right now. It’s like a heavy weight is pressing down on me, making it hard to breathe.

I've been trying so hard to be okay for everyone else—my partner, my parents who help out, even my baby—but inside, I’m a mess. There are moments when all I want to do is cry, and then other times where I feel numb to everything. Is this what they call postpartum depression? It sounds like something from a textbook, but it feels real.

I know I should reach out for help, talk to someone about how I’m feeling, but part of me thinks maybe if I just push through it, things will get better on their own. But then there are these moments—like when my baby smiles at me—that make me want to believe everything is going to be okay.

I’ve got a call scheduled with my doctor tomorrow; she’s been great about checking in and offering resources. Maybe this time I’ll finally open up about how I’m feeling. For now, though, all I can do is take it one day at a time and hope that the clouds will eventually lift.

Today marks another day in this long tunnel of postpartum blues. I'm trying to be strong for my baby and myself, but sometimes it feels like an uphill battle. The weight of the world is heavy on my shoulders, and every little task seems insurmountable.

Last night was particularly tough. I tried to sleep, but exhaustion doesn't make the darkness any less daunting. My mind wanders back to those harsh words from his grandfather—“broke bitch.” It’s like a knife in my heart each time it comes up. How can someone say such things? Yet, here we are, and I have no choice but to keep going.

I’ve been isolating myself more and more, trying not to let the negativity affect our little family bubble. But it's hard when even the smallest tasks seem overwhelming. Feeding my baby isn’t just about sustenance; it’s a reminder of what I'm supposed to be capable of doing—caring for him, being strong.

The leave from work was necessary, but it feels like an eternity away from reality. I miss my colleagues, the simple routine of going into the office. Instead, every day is filled with naps, feedings, and trying not to break down completely. 

I know I need help, but admitting that feels like a weakness. I’m scared of what others might think if they knew how much this is getting to me. How can I be there for my baby when I feel so utterly alone?

I want to believe that tomorrow will bring better days. For now, though, I’ll take it one moment at a time and hope for a little bit of sunshine through the clouds.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of exhaustion and despair. The baby cries incessantly, as if the world revolves around their tiny demands, while I barely have the energy to lift myself off this couch. Every moment feels heavy with an unshakeable sadness that clings to me no matter how much I try to brush it away.

Yet, amidst all this darkness, there's a glimmer of light in my partner's unwavering support. He’s been my rock, cooking meals when I’m too tired to stand, and holding the baby so I can rest. It’s small acts of kindness that keep me going, but they’re not enough to banish the shadows lurking just beneath the surface.

I know I need help; it's a realization that feels both liberating and terrifying at once. The thought of reaching out for support fills me with anxiety, yet the alternative is an endless spiral of despair. Maybe today will be different—I’ll start by calling my therapist tomorrow morning when the baby finally falls asleep.

Please, if you’re reading this, know that somewhere deep down, I’m trying too. Maybe together we can start to unravel these knots of fear and sorrow one tiny step at a time.

Today feels like an endless loop of tears and exhaustion. I’m trying to be the perfect mom, but it’s sucking me dry. But there are still moments when reality hits hard, and I feel that heavy weight of exhaustion and worry settling back in. It’s then that I try to remember all the good things: my baby’s first smile, the warmth of snuggling with them at night, and the love from those around me who have become a second family.

I’m still learning how to navigate this new phase of life, but I’ve started to believe it might be okay to take it one day at a time. Today, that feels like progress.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and it’s been one of the most challenging yet rewarding experiences I’ve ever had. Every day feels like an uphill battle, but I know it's not just me struggling with these feelings.

I've heard so many stories from other women about postpartum depression (PPD), and while I haven’t felt completely overwhelmed or sad to a debilitating degree, there have been moments when I feel lost and unsure. It’s scary knowing that something as life-changing as PPD could happen, but at the same time, it’s comforting to know that I’m not alone.

I’ve tried to stay positive by connecting with other new moms online and reading about ways to cope with those tough days. Knowing that my feelings are normal helps a bit. But sometimes, when the exhaustion hits and everything feels like too much, I worry if I'm doing okay or need more help.

Today, I made an effort to reach out to my mom for support. She’s been through this before and offered to come over later so I can get some rest. It was a relief knowing that someone else understands what it's like.

The hardest part is not being able to fully enjoy everything right now because of the constant worry about PPD looming in the background. But I’m trying to take things one day at a time and focus on the small moments of joy and connection with my baby.

June 7th

Today marks the one-month anniversary of bringing my baby into this world. It's been an incredibly mixed bag of emotions and experiences. There are days when I feel like I'm flying high with joy and contentment. Watching my little one smile for the first time, hearing their tiny coos as they fall asleep... it’s magical.

But then there are moments, especially late at night or early morning when the house is quiet and all I hear is my baby crying in another room, that a wave of sadness and anxiety washes over me. It's not just about being tired; it feels deeper than that. There have been times when I've felt overwhelmed, like the weight of everything is too heavy to carry alone.

It took me a while to admit this out loud, but talking about these feelings has made such a difference. Sharing with friends and family who understand or have gone through similar struggles has been incredibly healing. It’s okay not to feel perfectly joyful all the time; it's okay to struggle and seek help when you need it.

Today, I’m reminded that every day is another opportunity to find my footing again. The support from loved ones keeps me going, and knowing I'm not alone in this journey helps a lot too. If you’re reading this and feeling lost, know there’s hope. You are stronger than you think, and seeking help is the first step towards healing.

Tomorrow is a new day, full of possibilities. And even when it's hard, we keep going because our babies need us. We’re in this together, and that thought alone gives me strength to carry on.

Day 21 Postpartum

It feels like there’s no time for me to bond with her, no moments to just be present and soak in this precious new chapter.

I try to sneak in some quiet nursing sessions when possible, hoping that the physical closeness will somehow bridge the gap of my emotional absence. I need to find a way out of this spiral before it’s too late. Maybe taking some time off would help? Or asking for support from my partner or family? It feels like I’m treading water with no land in sight, but there must be something better than this endless struggle.

Today, as she sleeps soundly next to me, I decide that tomorrow is the day things change. I have to make space for her and myself. Because even if it’s just a tiny step forward, any progress feels like hope right now.

November 14, 2023

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of exhaustion and anxiety. The baby is finally asleep for the moment, but my mind refuses to rest. I keep worrying about everything—whether I'm feeding her enough, if she's gaining weight properly, am I being too strict or too lenient? It’s overwhelming.

This isn’t how it was supposed to be. Before, when I was pregnant, I had all these dreams and plans for my baby girl, but now that she’s here, everything feels different. The depression creeps in like a thief in the night; I can feel it settling into every corner of my thoughts, making me doubt myself more than ever.

I’ve tried to talk about how I’m feeling with friends and family, but their responses are always so full of optimism and positivity that it makes me question whether I'm just being overly dramatic. But deep down, I know this isn’t normal for me. It’s hard enough trying to figure out what my body needs after giving birth, let alone deal with the constant mental turmoil.

I miss who I was before all of this happened. Sometimes I catch glimpses of that person in mirrors or old photos, and it feels like she's a stranger now. How did things get so complicated? Every day seems to be a battle between hope and despair.

Maybe today is just one of those days when everything feels too much. But maybe tomorrow will be different. I can only hope that there’s light at the end of this tunnel, and it won’t take forever to reach it.

Today marks three years since I found myself in the midst of a whirlwind of change and chaos. Becoming a mother was both an incredible gift and a daunting responsibility all at once. The joy of holding my baby for the first time was overshadowed by the looming shadow of postpartum depression, something no one really prepares you for. Those early days were filled with tears and sleepless nights, exacerbated by the sudden end of what had seemed like a stable relationship.

Looking back now, it feels surreal how far I've come. The journey through those dark times taught me resilience and self-compassion in ways I never imagined possible. Today, as I watch my little one grow and explore the world with such curiosity and wonder, I am filled with gratitude for every challenge that brought us to this point.

I used to think happiness was a distant dream, but now it feels like an ever-present companion. My health has improved dramatically, both physically and mentally. The self-sabotage is a memory, replaced by a newfound love for myself and my family. I've built a support system that keeps me grounded, and each day feels like another step forward on this incredible journey of motherhood.

It’s funny how life can turn full circle. What once felt impossible now seems manageable, even enjoyable. Here's to three more years—and all the wonderful surprises they will bring!

Today marks two weeks since bringing our little miracle home. I woke up feeling like a zombie, dragging myself through each hour, unsure if I’ll ever feel normal again. The exhaustion is overwhelming, but the emptiness feels even worse. It’s been this way for days now—tears come easily, and joy seems so far away.

I’ve tried every SSRI under the sun, hoping something might work without making me vomit or lose my appetite completely. But each new pill I swallow just adds to the frustration. The doctors keep suggesting different options, but nothing’s sticking. It feels like a never-ending cycle of disappointment and hopelessness.

Yesterday was especially rough; I couldn’t stop crying while trying to feed our baby. She looked at me with such confusion, and all I could think was how much better things would be if I wasn’t here to cause her pain. That thought scared me more than anything else has since the birth.

I know talking about it is important, but reaching out feels like climbing a mountain without a map or gear. I’m so tired of fighting this battle alone. Maybe today will bring something new, some spark that shows there’s still light at the end of this dark tunnel. For now, though, all I can do is keep putting one foot in front of the other and hope it leads somewhere better.

It’s hard to believe how quickly life has changed, but here we are. I’m doing my best, but it’s not enough. I need help, real help, before this darkness consumes me completely.

April 7th, 2023

Today marks one month since I welcomed my little bundle of joy into the world, and while she brings me endless love and joy, there are days when I feel more overwhelmed than ever imagined. The exhaustion is real, and not just from sleepless nights or physical recovery—there’s something deeper gnawing at me.

I didn’t know this could happen; no one told me about postpartum depression until it was too late. If I had known, would things be different? Would I have prepared differently? Maybe talked more openly with my partner and family about what to expect?

There are days when the weight of being a new mother feels like too much to bear. But then there are moments—like holding her for the first time—that fill me with such profound happiness and gratitude, making all the hard times worth it.

I wish someone had warned me that this journey would be as challenging as it is beautiful. I am determined now to educate myself about what’s happening, to take care of my mental health just like I’m taking care of her. No more pretending everything is perfect when it isn’t. We’re in this together, and every day gets a little easier knowing that help is out there if you reach for it.

Tomorrow feels daunting but hopeful too. One step at a time.

Today feels like an eternity in slow motion. The clock ticks away, but nothing else seems to move forward. I’ve been trying my hardest to smile and pretend everything is okay for the baby’s sake, but inside, it’s all a mess. Why do they say motherhood is supposed to be beautiful? It’s just so lonely here.

The days blend together with no end in sight. My baby sleeps soundly, oblivious to the turmoil within me. I can’t seem to find anyone to talk to about this. Everyone seems so happy and confident, but inside, it’s a different story. I feel like I’m drowning in a sea of isolation, unable to breathe or reach out for help.

Sometimes, when I look at him sleeping peacefully, my heart swells with love. Other times, I just stare blankly, feeling detached from this reality. It’s hard to believe that being a mother is supposed to make you feel whole and complete. Instead, it feels like pieces of me are missing or broken beyond repair.

I wish someone would notice how much I’m struggling. But no one does, and every day I pretend everything is fine. How do you explain to others that you’re not okay when everyone expects you to be over the moon with joy? It’s a heavy weight on my shoulders.

Today was just another day of trying to keep up appearances. Maybe tomorrow will be better, but until then, here I am, feeling lost and alone in this new world of motherhood.

Today feels like a never-ending loop of fatigue and despair. I thought holding my baby would be the happiest moment of my life, but instead, it’s overwhelming. The exhaustion hits me in waves; every hour is another battle to stay awake, to keep going. My mind swirls with thoughts that are so dark, they make me feel like I’m suffocating.

I worry about everyone else struggling silently, not knowing where to turn for help. How many new mothers out there are feeling just as lost and alone? It’s a lonely place, this postpartum depression thing, and it’s hard to see any light at the end of the tunnel right now. But I’m trying to focus on taking small steps forward—reaching out when I need to, even if it feels like climbing mountains.

The other day, I saw an article about support groups for new moms dealing with similar struggles. It scared me but also made me curious. Maybe talking to someone who truly understands could make a difference. For now, though, I’m just trying to keep my head above water and hope that tomorrow will be better.

January 15th

Maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe I’ll take a step back and admit that I’m struggling and need support. It’s hard to breathe sometimes when the world keeps spinning but you feel like you’re stuck in place.

Tomorrow seems far away right now though. For now, I'll just try to find some sleep tonight. Maybe if I can rest, things will look different in the morning.

Day 42: A Mess of Emotions

Today, I woke up feeling like the weight of the world was crushing me, but there’s a strange sort of comfort in acknowledging that this is just another day with postpartum depression. The exhaustion never truly lifts; it's more like waves crashing over and over again. Today, I tried to take things one moment at a time—feed baby, nap when possible, repeat.

I’m learning to let go of the expectations I had for myself as a new mother. It’s okay to feel lost and overwhelmed, but it doesn’t mean I’m failing as a parent or person. In fact, reaching out for help has been one of the bravest things I’ve done so far. Talking about my struggles with friends who have also gone through this gave me the strength to keep pushing forward.

I know there are days ahead that will be harder than today, but I’m trying to find hope in the little victories—like finishing a load of laundry or simply remembering to take deep breaths when anxiety hits hard. It’s not easy, and some days it feels impossible, but speaking up about my struggles is crucial for recovery.

To anyone out there who might be feeling this way: You are not alone. Postpartum depression is real, and it's okay to ask for help. Speak your truth because silence only makes the darkness deeper. We need each other now more than ever, so please, don’t hesitate to reach out if you’re struggling.

Tomorrow will come with its own challenges, but I’m holding on to hope that small steps forward are still progress made.

Today marks a milestone in my journey as a new mom. I finally decided to look at myself in the mirror without flinching or covering up with layers of clothing. It feels strange now that I can actually smile when I see my reflection. My body is different, but it's also strong and resilient from carrying and birthing our little one. The stretch marks don't bother me anymore; they're just reminders of a beautiful experience.

It's incredible how much better I feel when I focus on the present rather than dwelling on past struggles or worrying about future uncertainties. I haven't taken any pre-baby photos, and that’s okay because now I can see beauty in myself without needing those comparisons.

The real me is here, more confident and at peace with my appearance. Weight loss wasn’t a goal; feeling good was the target. And guess what? I’ve hit it. No need to wait for an exact number on the scale or size tag to feel beautiful. Today, I choose to celebrate every inch of who I am right now.

December 3, Day 7 Post-Delivery

Today marks a week since I brought my little one into the world, but honestly, it feels like an eternity has passed. Every moment is a whirlwind of new responsibilities and emotions, all swirling together in this chaotic dance called parenthood.

Maybe it’s not supposed to start so early? Or is everything going to be okay if I just keep reminding myself that these feelings are normal?

Tonight, as I lay awake staring at the ceiling while my baby sleeps soundly next to me, I vow to talk to someone tomorrow—maybe a friend or even my doctor. It can’t hurt to get another opinion and maybe some reassurance. Maybe it’s all going to be okay after all.

Day 30 Post-C-Section

Today marks a month since the birth of our beautiful baby girl. But as I lie here in my bed, exhausted and emotionally drained, it feels like an eternity. The physical pain from surgery is starting to fade, but the emotional toll is just beginning to surface.

Looking back at these past weeks, I can't help but feel guilty for pushing myself too hard. Maybe it was that stubborn part of me wanting everything to be perfect, or perhaps sheer exhaustion made me deny my body's limits. Whatever the reason, the reality is clear: I overdid it. Simple tasks like getting out of bed and taking a shower have become daunting challenges. But when you're surrounded by so much newness and change, there’s pressure to stay on top of everything.

My partner has been wonderful in many ways, but he had to return to work after only three weeks. I understand the financial constraints, yet it feels like every moment alone has stretched into an eternity. The loneliness and the weight of responsibility can be overwhelming. It's not that he doesn’t care; it’s just different. He offers practical help when he visits but struggles with emotional support.

Today, as I held our baby for her bath, a wave of sadness washed over me. Was this normal? Should I feel so overwhelmed all the time? The idea of postpartum depression had never crossed my mind until now, and it’s terrifying. Delayed recognition is real here—every day feels like trying to navigate a new challenge without clear direction.

Tomorrow is another day, and I will try again. But tonight, amidst the chaos of diapers and tears, I write this down for myself. To remind me that it's okay to feel unsure and overwhelmed, because everyone’s journey postpartum looks different. And perhaps, seeking help could be a sign of strength rather than weakness.

April 7th, Week 4

Today marks four sleepless weeks with a tiny human who seems to thrive on my exhaustion. The room is spinning, and the walls are closing in as I try to navigate this new world where every moment feels like an eternity. Sleep has become a luxury reserved for dreamland, leaving me stranded in reality's harsh light.

I catch glimpses of myself in mirrors, a stranger with hollow eyes and frazzled hair, struggling against forces beyond my control. The baby cries again, the sound piercing through the fog that envelops me. I want to run away, to escape this endless loop of feeding, changing diapers, and the eerie quiet that follows.

Walls are bruised from my fists—I can’t help but punch them when no one’s around, a silent scream turned into action. It's my only way out, my release valve against the rage building inside me. But today, there's something different—a whisper of darkness at the edges of my mind, telling me to give up.

I’m lost in this storm, and it's starting to feel safer to slip away into dreams than face this nightmare that wakes me with every cry. But somewhere deep down, I know that even if everything else seems dark, there’s hope. It might be faint, but it's there.

For now, though, all I can do is take one breath at a time and hold on tight to the hope that tomorrow will bring something better than today.

I’m learning to navigate these new responsibilities with patience and self-compassion. It’s not always easy, but it's undeniably beautiful.

Today marks the eighth day since my daughter's birth. I thought holding her would be like a dream come true, but now it feels more like a nightmare from which I can't wake up. It felt like they didn't even ask if I wanted to be part of the decision-making process. They just took over.

Now here I am, feeling like a failure for not being able to handle this naturally, despite knowing it wasn't my choice. My body hurts so much from labor and surgery—my mind is worse. There's no time to heal emotionally when you're expected to be a "perfect" mom right away. But perfection doesn’t feel real here; only the pain does.

I’ve had moments of sheer anger, wondering why I was reduced to just a vessel that needed emptying during childbirth. And then there’s disappointment—disappointment in myself and others for not supporting me better through this intense time. The pressure is suffocating. How can one be expected to deal with all of this alone?

I miss the woman who used to laugh easily, who could see beauty in everything around her. Today, I feel like a stranger inside my own skin. But maybe tomorrow will bring clarity, or at least a way out of this fog.

—Sinking into despair but holding onto hope.

April 14th, Week 4

Today marks a month since I welcomed my little one into the world. A month of sleepless nights, constant feedings, and endless diaper changes. But more than that, it's a month of overwhelming sadness and confusion.

I keep telling myself to feel happy, to be grateful for this precious life I created. But every time I try, all I can see is my own failure. My body feels heavy, like dragging through mud with every step. Food tastes bland, no matter what delicious meals are prepared for me. Sleep evades me, leaving me exhausted and irritable.

I spend hours staring at the walls of our nursery, tears rolling down my face without any control over them. Sometimes I wonder if anyone else feels this way, or if it's just me who can't seem to figure out how to be a good mother. Is this what they mean when they talk about postpartum depression?

I don't know what to do. I've reached out for help but feel like no one understands the depth of my despair. The weight of societal expectations crushes any hope I might have felt before. Today, I just want to crawl into bed and hide away from it all.

Please, if anyone can hear me, please help me find a way back to myself.

Lily cries, and I want to comfort her so badly, but the anxiety and sadness make it hard to even get out of bed. My mind races with thoughts of how much better life was before she came.

Mom’s words sting: “You should be happy, you have a beautiful baby.” It feels like an indictment, as if my feelings are somehow wrong or selfish. The truth is, I’m drowning in this sea of emotions and can’t seem to catch a breath. I wish someone would see me for more than just a new mom who’s supposed to love everything.

I know there’s something seriously off with how I feel, but it’s hard to admit that I need help when everyone expects me to handle it all on my own. Today, as Lily sleeps peacefully in her crib, I’m left feeling alone and scared. The weight of this burden is heavy, and I fear no one understands the depth of what I’m going through.

April 14th

I've been talking with a therapist more regularly too, and while some days feel like I'm taking two steps forward and one step back, there's an undeniable shift happening within me. Today was one of those good days where the sunlight streaming through the window felt warm on my face instead of cold against my skin. Baby giggles today were not just background noise but a sweet melody that lifted my spirits.

It’s a strange journey, this postpartum depression thing. Some days it feels like I’m stuck in a fog, and others are as clear as if someone had turned on the lights for the first time since he was born. And through all of it, there's TaskUsPH offering support at every turn.

I'm trying to hold onto those moments that feel good because they remind me that better days are possible. For now, though, I'll take today and its small victories one step at a time.

Today felt like an eternity of fog and fatigue. The baby sleeps, but I don’t feel any closer to rest. Hormones are a whirlwind, swirling emotions that leave me feeling lost and inadequate. Makeup? I keep telling myself it's normal, but the nagging voice inside says otherwise. Why can't I be stronger? Why do simple tasks feel so monumental? Every day is a battle against this cloud of negativity, and it’s exhausting trying to push through without letting anyone see how much I’m struggling.

There’s an unspoken pressure that moms should just handle everything seamlessly, but nothing could be further from the truth. Even reaching for my phone to write this feels like too much effort. Maybe there's value in admitting when things aren’t okay and seeking help. It can't hurt to try, right?

Tomorrow is a new day, but today ends with me questioning if I’m doing enough, wondering what it takes to break free from these feelings.

Today marks another day in what feels like an endless cycle. The baby's cries echo through the house, a familiar tune that I should be used to by now, but it still hits me hard. Every time she needs something, my heart races and my hands tremble. It’s not just about caring for her; there are days when even getting out of bed feels like an insurmountable task.

I tried to set some goals for myself: more sleep, better nutrition, and finding the strength to exercise a little. But here I am, three weeks in, and none of those things have really come to pass. The anxiety about whether I’m doing enough is overwhelming, and it’s hard to see beyond that cloud of worry.

I’ve been thinking about reaching out for more help, but every time I think about talking to someone or joining a support group, the idea feels too daunting. It’s like there’s this constant tug between what I know I need and what my mind tells me is impossible.

Tonight, as I lay in bed, listening to the quiet hum of the house settling down after the day, I remind myself that it’s okay not to be okay. These feelings are real, but they don’t define who I am. Tomorrow is another chance to try again.

Today marks another day in this endless sea of postpartum fog. The baby's cries echo through the house like a distant memory; I can't seem to find my way back to them. It feels as though every moment is a battle against this overwhelming sense of despair that clings to me like a second skin.

The room spins when I try to think about anything more than the next breath, the next meal. My head tells me there's joy and love out there somewhere, but my heart isn't buying it. It’s as if every fiber of my being is rejecting this supposed happiness that everyone seems to believe should come with new life.

I keep trying though. For myself, for them. But it's hard when the thought of getting dressed feels like climbing a mountain. Each step forward feels like a betrayal to the person I was before all of this began, the one who had dreams and laughter in her eyes.

The nights are the worst. The emptiness is so loud that my tears seem quiet by comparison. But they fall anyway, silent prayers for something to change.

There's talk about support and help out there, but it feels like a distant dream. Today I'll try again though, because maybe tomorrow will be different. Maybe tomorrow I won't feel quite so lost in this storm of new beginnings that are supposed to bring joy instead of darkness.

Today marks another day lost in the fog of postpartum depression. The weight of my newborn's smile feels like a heavy stone in my chest. I can't shake this overwhelming sense of despair and fear. It’s hard to believe that just weeks ago, I was brimming with excitement about bringing our little one into the world.

The days blur together—feed, nap, cry, repeat. There are moments when I feel a glimmer of hope, only for it to be snatched away by a flood of anxiety and guilt. Why can't I just enjoy this? Everyone around me seems to think that motherhood is supposed to be blissful, but all I see is darkness.

I know I need help, and I've started seeing a therapist who understands how real this struggle feels. But the pill in my hand, prescribed by a doctor with kindness in her eyes, still seems like an admission of failure. Medication for being a mom? It's absurd, yet necessary.

The nights are the hardest; silence amplifies every thought and fear. I reach out to anyone willing to listen—friends who offer solace but can't fully grasp what I'm going through. They mean well, but their words feel hollow against the roar of my inner turmoil.

I remind myself that it's okay not to be okay. It’s a cliché, but clichés exist because they're true. Recovery won’t happen overnight, and it might never look like what others have painted as "normal." But I’m starting to believe that even in this darkness, there is a path forward, one step at a time.

Today, I'll try again. One breath, one step.

Today felt like a never-ending rollercoaster of emotions. Being a single mom and dealing with postpartum depression is something I thought I had mastered through the support of my community, but lately, it feels like I’m being pulled back into a dark place by some insensitive people around me.

The other day at the park, this group of women just sat there judging every move I made with my kids. They acted like they were perfect and had everything under control—like raising kids as a single mom isn’t already hard enough! It’s moments like these that make me feel isolated and misunderstood.

But then there are beautiful days when everything seems to click into place, and the love from family and friends fills me with hope again. Today was one of those heavy days, but I’m trying not to let it consume me. My kids deserve to see a happy mommy who’s fighting her way back up every day.

I wish someone had told me how hard this would be. But then again, who wants to prepare for something so painfully beautiful?

Today feels like an eternity of blurry days and endless nights. My baby won’t stop crying, and I can barely keep my eyes open. The exhaustion is crushing me; every little thing feels monumental. There are moments when I feel so blessed to have this beautiful life, but then the weight of it all hits hard.

I’m struggling with these waves of sadness that crash over me without warning. Why does everyone else seem to handle this better? They say time heals all wounds, but right now, it just feels like a never-ending cycle of sleepless nights and never-ending worries. 

The postpartum depression is real, and it’s draining every last bit of strength I have left. How do you find joy in something that feels so overwhelming? The guilt eats away at me; why can’t I be happier with the greatest gift life has given me?

I need help, but I don’t know where to start or if anyone will understand what I’m going through. It’s okay not to be okay, they say, but it doesn’t make the loneliness any less painful.

Tomorrow is another day, I keep telling myself, but for now, all I want is a moment of peace and some relief from this constant turmoil. Maybe sleep will bring me clarity; maybe it won’t. All I know is that today was hard, really hard, and tomorrow might be even harder. But I’ll try again because that’s what mamas do, right?

Today feels like a blur of exhaustion and confusion wrapped in layers of anger and sadness. The doctor’s words about ADHD still echo in my head—“You’ve been dealing with this your entire life.” It’s as if the universe is mocking me for being so clueless, yet another thing to feel guilty about when I should be celebrating new life.

I’m trying to hold it together for everyone else. My husband has been amazing, but there are days when his calm and understanding only heighten my sense of failure. How can he see strength in me that feels like weakness?

Postpartum depression crept back in with the ADHD diagnosis, a double whammy of emotional turmoil. The baby is beautiful and perfect, but I’m struggling to connect, to feel anything beyond this deep well of despair.

I keep thinking about all the times I should have known better, could have understood my own needs sooner. Now here we are, me feeling like a stranger to myself, trying not to let it show in front of the tiny miracle who relies on me more than anyone else.

The anger is fierce and raw, burning hot against the cold emptiness inside. Why wasn’t I diagnosed earlier? Why did no one see that my struggles weren’t just about being tired or stressed after having a baby?

I’m drowning in a sea of “what ifs” and “if onlys.” The doctor says there’s help out there, but right now it feels like a distant shore when all I can do is tread water.

Tomorrow will be better. It has to be. For him, for me, for the little one who deserves so much more than this messy version of happiness we’re stuck in.

Today is day three since bringing baby home. I was excited to leave the hospital, but now I feel like something has been taken from me, a piece of my soul maybe. The nights are endless and every sound wakes me up in cold sweat. Why can't I just be happy? Why do I want to scream every time someone suggests a smile or a hug?

I thought it would be different, more magical. Instead, I feel like I'm drowning in a sea of loneliness and fear. My heart races when the baby cries, and my chest tightens with each passing moment. The joy from before seems so distant now, as if it was a dream that never truly existed.

My mind is racing with thoughts of how this will all go wrong, despite knowing logically everything should be okay. I can't shake off these dark clouds hovering over me, heavy and suffocating. It's like being trapped in quicksand, the harder you struggle, the deeper you sink into despair.

I miss my old self so much. The one who laughed easily, who saw beauty in small things. Now, all I see is a mountain too big to climb alone. And it hurts, oh how it hurts, to feel this way and know there's no easy escape from these feelings that weigh me down every second of the day.

Please let someone understand what I'm going through...

January 14th

I just got back from the hospital today, and I can't seem to shake this numb feeling that's hanging over me like a thick fog. The DOGPILE is done, but instead of feeling accomplished or relieved, all I feel is empty. Maybe it's because now everything feels so real—holding my baby for the first time didn't bring any joy; it just brought exhaustion and worry.

Sleeping through the night seems like an impossible dream right now. The constant crying and waking up every two hours are taking their toll on me, but I know it’s temporary or at least that's what everyone tells me. Yet, when you're drowning in this sea of darkness, time feels eternal.

I keep thinking about how I should be grateful for having a baby and all the love he’ll bring to our lives, yet I can’t seem to feel anything other than an overwhelming sense of dread. It’s like my heart is made of lead, dragging me down with every passing moment.

The thought of leaving this room feels daunting. How do you face the world when you don't even want to face yourself? But I know I have to try, for him if not for me. Maybe tomorrow will be better, but until then, I'll just take it one breath at a time.

Today feels like an endless loop of darkness and despair. The baby is sleeping peacefully in the next room, but I can't shake this overwhelming sense of sadness that's been building since I gave birth a few weeks ago. It’s as if the joy everyone expected me to feel has somehow morphed into something heavy and suffocating.

I keep trying to push through it, reminding myself that having a baby is supposed to be magical and life-changing in all the right ways. But instead of bliss, I’m stuck with this constant feeling of being trapped by my own thoughts. The exhaustion from lack of sleep doesn’t help, but it’s more than just physical tiredness.

There are moments when everything seems okay—when I see how tiny and perfect my baby is—but then reality crashes back in like a wave, washing away all the hope. My mind circles around old fears and anxieties, as if they've been waiting for this moment to pounce. It’s scary, because before the baby, those feelings felt more manageable, even when I struggled.

Today, though, everything feels magnified. The house seems quieter than ever, yet louder with my own inner turmoil. My husband tries his best to be supportive, but it's hard to explain how much this is weighing on me. It’s like there’s a storm brewing inside of me that no one else can see.

I need help, and I know it. But asking for it feels daunting—like admitting defeat in the face of what should be my biggest triumph. Maybe tomorrow will feel different. For now, though, I'm just trying to breathe through another day.

Today, I woke up to the soft hum of the baby monitor, and as usual, my heart fluttered with a mix of love and anxiety. But today felt different; it was like walking through fog, each step weighed down by an invisible force. As I cradled our little one, the smell of newborn skin brought back memories from senior year, when everything seemed so clear—like the first day of summer break after a long winter. Those days were filled with music and plans for the future, dreams that now feel like they belong to someone else.

The playlist on my phone started playing an old song, one I hadn't heard in years. It’s the kind of track that hits you in your gut, making you miss things you never knew you wanted until they’re gone. Suddenly, it was as if time had stopped and I was back there again, laughing with friends under starlit skies, dancing at a school dance with my headphones on, completely lost in the rhythm. It’s strange how music can transport you, but also remind you of all that’s changed.

The song ended too soon, leaving me feeling hollow. The baby slept through it all, blissfully unaware of the storm brewing inside me. I know there are resources out there for new moms like me who feel lost in this transition. Therapy sessions and support groups—things I should probably look into more seriously. But right now, it feels too daunting to face another challenge when everything else seems so overwhelming.

I’m trying not to let the weight of those memories crush my spirit, but some days are harder than others. There’s a part of me that wonders if this feeling will ever lift off my chest and allow me to breathe again without choking on sadness. The idea of reaching out for help feels like admitting defeat, but I know I can’t keep going through this alone.

Maybe tomorrow, when the sun rises and brings with it another day, I’ll find a way forward. For now, though, I’m just holding on, hoping that somehow, someday, everything will feel right again.

Today marks two weeks since baby arrived, and as the days blur together with sleepless nights and endless feedings, I find myself drifting into a strange haze of exhaustion mixed with wonder. The reality of being a new mother is both overwhelming and oddly thrilling. There's this constant hum in my head that whispers doubts—am I doing enough? Am I good enough?

Sleep deprivation is the beast lurking behind every closed eye, waiting to pounce the moment I dare to close mine for more than an hour at a stretch. And while everyone talks about how magical it should be, all I feel right now is sheer exhaustion and a nagging sense of being unprepared.

Every time the baby cries or needs another feed, I brace myself. It’s like every ounce of energy gets drained out with each demand. But amidst this fatigue, there are moments of pure joy too—like when I finally manage to get her down for a longer nap than usual, and I steal a quick shower or a moment alone.

I know it's not okay to feel overwhelmed all the time, but how do you balance being present and caring while also acknowledging your own limits? Everyone keeps telling me that “postpartum blues” is normal, yet part of me can’t help wondering if there’s something more going on. Maybe I need a break, or perhaps just someone to talk to about these feelings.

For now, though, it's one day at a time. Getting through each moment as best I can and hoping that tomorrow will bring more clarity and less exhaustion.

Today is Day 30 with baby number two, and I’m feeling like a rollercoaster ride without the breaks. The exhaustion is real; it’s like trying to keep my eyes open while running a marathon. But then there are moments when everything feels okay—baby's smile, husband’s laughter—that’s when the world seems manageable.

The dark thoughts still sneak in though, whispers of inadequacy and doubt. I remind myself that this isn’t about me failing or being weak; it’s about needing help to navigate these murky waters. So here I am, holding onto my meds like a lifeline, grateful for every little boost they give against the current.

Support systems are crucial, and I’m lucky to have them. Friends who listen without judgment, family who offer quiet strength, and professionals who guide me back when I start drifting away from myself. It’s comforting knowing I don’t have to go through this alone.

I want to tell anyone out there feeling lost or overwhelmed: it’s okay not to be okay, but it doesn’t mean you can’t find your way forward. Resources like postpartum support groups and mental health hotlines are there for a reason. Reach out when the darkness feels too heavy; people who care about you will help carry that weight.

Tomorrow is another day with its own set of challenges and small victories. I’ll keep writing these little notes to myself, reminders that even on days when everything seems impossible, I’m still moving forward. One breath at a time.

Today marks a significant moment in my journey as a new mother. I've been battling the invisible weight of postpartum depression for weeks now, and it's only recently that I began to see light at the end of the tunnel. It started with something as simple as joining a book club—a group of women who share similar stories and struggles.

Reading has always been my escape, but somehow, when I was alone in the house caring for my baby 24/7, it felt like an impossible task to pick up a book or even watch TV. But today, sitting among friends talking about our favorite novels, I realized how much I needed this outside focus. It’s funny how something as basic as discussing literature can make you feel more connected to the world.

It hit me hard: I need activities beyond just being a mom. Self-care isn’t selfish; it’s necessary for my mental health and my baby's wellbeing too. Tomorrow, I’m going to sign up for that yoga class downtown. Maybe there will be other moms there who understand what I'm feeling. It’s about finding balance, not perfection.

I’ve learned that reaching out for help isn't a sign of weakness but a step towards recovery. And as I prepare to leave the book club tonight, filled with hope and new ideas, I feel like maybe, just maybe, I’m on my way back to being me again.

Today marks two weeks since baby’s arrival, and the joy I felt in those early moments is slowly being replaced by a foggy cloud of doubt and sadness. Holding my newborn should be the happiest time of my life, but instead, I find myself overwhelmed with exhaustion, confusion, and an unsettling feeling that something isn’t quite right.

I’ve been trying so hard to pretend everything’s okay, like this dark cloud hanging over me is just a fleeting thing. But every time I look at my baby, all I can think about is how much I wish someone else could take care of them for a while. It's not because I don't love her; it's more the fear that maybe I’m not cut out for this. Why am I feeling like such an impostor in my own life?

Last night, after what felt like hours of staring at the ceiling unable to sleep, I finally admitted to myself that I might have postpartum depression. It’s a scary thought, but it also feels oddly validating. Maybe there is something wrong with me, or maybe there isn’t—I don't know anymore. All I know is that I need help, even if just knowing what steps to take next seems daunting.

I wish I could be the mom everyone thinks I’m supposed to be. The one who’s excited about every milestone and sleeps in tiny shifts because it means her baby is growing bigger by the day. Instead, all I feel is this constant pressure to act like everything's fine when inside, I’m struggling more than ever.

I need to talk to someone soon, but the thought of sharing these feelings with others terrifies me. Yet, maybe that’s what will start to make things better—talking about it, getting support instead of pretending it doesn’t exist at all. For now, though, I’ll just focus on taking small steps each day and hoping they lead somewhere hopeful.

I'm not sure where this road leads, but for the first time in days, I have a tiny glimmer of hope that maybe, just maybe, things can get better.

Today was a rollercoaster of emotions. I visited my grandmother’s house and felt something akin to joy for the first time in weeks. She doted on my baby like only an over-the-top grandma can, and for a moment, everything felt okay. But as we walked back home through the quiet neighborhood, the familiar weight of postpartum depression pressed down on me again.

It’s frustrating because I know that seeing her makes me feel better in some way, yet the sadness still creeps up when it seems like it should be lifted. The baby sleeps peacefully beside me now, innocent and unaware of my inner turmoil. Part of me feels selfish for not being able to appreciate this moment more fully.

I wish I could tell myself that things will get better soon, but right now, all I can do is acknowledge the struggle. Visiting grandma was a bright spot today, but it’s just one day in an endless sea of them. I’m trying to take small steps and remember that each day counts, even if they’re not perfect.

It’s hard to talk about this feeling with others; sometimes it seems like everyone else is okay or at least pretending to be. But talking to a friend today reminded me that I don’t have to go through this alone. Maybe sharing more openly will help me start to feel better too.

Day 3 Postpartum

Well, it's been a whirlwind of hormones and sleep deprivation since little Bundle arrived. I thought the baby blues would be just a gentle breeze, but turns out they’re more like a hurricane. 

Right now, I’m struggling to find joy in anything beyond the obligatory love for my newborn. It’s funny how you can feel physically attached yet emotionally disconnected. My body is a battlefield of stitches and soreness, and if that wasn’t enough, my mind is playing the most depressing loop of thoughts.

Last night, I tried counting sheep but ended up tallying all the ways this baby will inevitably ruin my life (kidding…sorta). The humor helps, right? 

I know everyone means well when they say “it gets better,” but in the moment, it feels like a cruel joke. Today, I just want to crawl back into bed and pretend this isn’t happening, but there’s little Bundle with wide eyes waiting for me. It’s overwhelming.

So here’s my confession: today, I hugged the pillow instead of the baby because it was easier. Don’t judge me; it was a rough day. But tomorrow, I’ll try again. Maybe.

If anyone out there is feeling this too, just know you’re not alone. Let's hold hands and survive this storm together.

Today marks a strange new chapter in my life. It's surreal to see the red on the toilet paper that shouldn't be there right now. My body is betraying me, sending signals of normalcy when I feel anything but.

I held him so tightly these past few weeks, cradling him every moment I could, cherishing his warmth and presence. Yet, here I am, feeling like a void has opened inside me, swallowing up all the joy and peace that was once there in abundance. It's hard to explain this emptiness; it feels like a part of me is missing, even though he's right beside me.

The period I've been dreading has arrived, but instead of relief at having one less thing to worry about, I feel overwhelmed with sadness. My body remembers what it once knew, and now it's reminding me that this new phase of my life doesn't come without its challenges. There's a sense of loss, a reminder that my body isn’t the same as it was before.

I know there are resources out there for new mothers like me, but somehow reaching out feels like admitting defeat. I should be overjoyed and grateful, yet all I feel is this heavy cloud hanging over my head. It's exhausting trying to keep up appearances when everything inside screams that something is wrong.

Maybe tomorrow will be better. Maybe the sun will shine through these dark clouds and bring a sense of peace back into my heart. Until then, I'll try to hold on tight and hope for the best.

Today was one of those days where the sun blazed high and hot, but inside me, it felt like winter had set in. I woke up to another relentless day of blue skies and laughter from families picnicking at the park. The contrast hit hard; while everyone else seemed to be reveling in the summer sunshine, my heart remained locked in a perpetual gloom.

I couldn't shake off the feeling that making that photo album about our baby's first year was a bad idea. I thought it would be therapeutic, something beautiful to look back on when we were all grown up. But instead, flipping through those pages is like opening a floodgate of memories—each one a reminder of how far from happy and contented I feel now.

The guilt is relentless. Why can't I just enjoy this precious time? Every new mom faces challenges; they must understand what it's like to be so overwhelmed by life that even the smallest task feels insurmountable. But here’s the thing: no one talks about how devastatingly alone you feel when everyone else seems to have it all figured out.

I tried calling my old therapist today, but her office is booked until next month. I miss talking to someone who gets it, understands the turmoil without judgment or pity. In the meantime, I'm left with these heavy thoughts swirling in my head like a storm cloud threatening to burst at any moment.

Maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe not. Either way, I'll keep pushing through because that's all I know how to do right now—just push forward and hope for change.

April 7th

Today was another sleepless night, filled with worry and restlessness. The baby is only a few weeks old now, but it feels like an eternity since I brought her home from the hospital. I can’t shake this feeling of being overwhelmed all day long, and every time I close my eyes, my mind races with thoughts about everything that could go wrong.

I tried calling someone earlier tonight just to talk things out, but no one was available at such a late hour. The silence in our house is deafening, except for the occasional cry from her crib down the hall. Every single sound keeps me on edge, wondering if I’m doing enough, if she’s okay, and if this will ever get better.

The days blur together now—changing diapers, feeding, rocking to sleep—only interrupted by moments of sheer panic when I wonder if it’s normal for new moms to feel like they’re drowning in a sea of uncertainty. There are times when I feel completely detached from everything around me, as though watching my life unfold through a foggy pane.

The exhaustion is relentless, but the worry gnaws at me even more than that. How do you stop your mind from spiraling? Why does every little thing seem so monumental right now?

I need to reach out for help soon. This can’t be normal, and I don’t want it to become my reality. Tomorrow will bring another day of figuring things out, but tonight, I’ll try to find a moment’s peace before the cycle begins again.

—
Tonight was hard, and tomorrow is coming.

Today marks two weeks since little Lily joined our family, and as much as I love holding her close, the joy isn’t quite reaching my heart like everyone says it should. I feel tired all the time, even though I sleep more than I ever have before. The days blend together in a haze of feeding, nappy changes, and endless worry about whether I’m doing everything right.

I keep second-guessing myself—did I feed her enough? Is she gaining weight fast enough? Am I changing her often enough? It’s exhausting just thinking about it. And there are moments when the thought of getting out of bed seems too overwhelming for me to handle, but everyone says new moms should get up and start moving around.

I’ve noticed my appetite has gone down; I find myself skipping meals or just nibbling on snacks instead of sitting down properly. Is that normal? Why does everything feel so hard when it’s supposed to be the most wonderful time?

Last night, when she cried for what felt like hours, and I couldn’t soothe her no matter what I tried, I broke down in tears myself. That scared me a bit—I didn’t expect to cry like that over a crying baby. My mom says all new moms have rough days, but every day feels rough to me.

I know it’s okay not to be okay all the time, but when will it get better? When do you feel like yourself again after having a baby?

---

Today felt particularly tough, and I couldn’t shake off this feeling that maybe something isn’t right. Maybe it’s postpartum depression, or just a really rough adjustment period. Either way, I know talking about my feelings is important, so maybe tomorrow I’ll reach out to someone who can help me understand what I’m going through.

March 7th

I woke up to a quiet house today, the kind of silence that feels almost too heavy. It’s been three weeks since I gave birth, and every day feels like a replay of the last. The exhaustion is overwhelming, but it’s not just physical—I can barely keep my eyes open during the day because of how much I’ve tossed and turned at night.

The thought of going back to work in a few weeks scares me. How am I supposed to manage when all I want to do is stay in bed? I feel like I’m drowning, but no one around me seems to understand what I’m going through. I know it’s not healthy to think this way, but sometimes I wonder if things would have been different if the pregnancy had been planned.

I’ve felt so alone since having my baby. My mom lives hours away and has her hands full with work, and my friends are busy with their own lives. It’s hard to talk about how I’m really feeling because I don’t want them to worry or feel like they need to take care of me. But the truth is, I do need help—I just don’t know where to start.

Today was particularly rough. The baby cried endlessly, and I couldn’t figure out what she wanted. My mind kept wandering to worst-case scenarios—what if something goes wrong? What if I can’t be a good mother?

I’m scared that no one will understand the depth of my struggle. It’s hard enough dealing with postpartum depression without the added burden of an unplanned pregnancy. How do you explain to someone else what it feels like when your body and mind are at war, and there’s nothing you can do about it? I wish there was a magic button to make all this better, but for now, I’m just trying to keep one foot in front of the other.

Maybe tomorrow will be different. But today, all I can hope for is that someone, anyone, will reach out and offer some support. Until then, I’ll keep taking it one moment at a time.

Today feels like one of those days where the world is just a little too bright and loud. I woke up with the sun beaming in through the windows, but instead of feeling grateful for another day to get to know my baby, all I wanted was to pull the covers back over my head and hide from everything.

The nursery looks so peaceful, but it’s also full of reminders—nursing schedules scribbled on sticky notes, piles of clothes that need folding. It feels like a never-ending to-do list with no breaks for just being me. And then there's him—the baby’s dad—he's around, sure, but he doesn’t seem to get the extent of how much I'm struggling. He brushes off my feelings as if everything is going fine and dandy.

My family visits are supposed to be supportive, but they come with their own set of expectations. They want me to be this perfect mom, cooking elaborate meals and playing games that involve more energy than I can muster right now. It’s not just about the physical exhaustion; it's this overwhelming sense of failure when I can't seem to meet everyone else’s standards.

Sometimes, I catch myself wishing I could just fast-forward through all these difficult moments, but then there are fleeting glimpses of joy—the baby's tiny fingers curling around mine, a smile breaking through their tiredness. Those moments make everything feel worth it, but they’re so brief and hard to hold onto when the day-to-day feels like such an uphill battle.

I know I need help, but admitting that out loud feels impossible right now. It’s just another thing on my list of things to do, which I don’t even have the energy for. But maybe today is a good day to start whispering it to myself and hoping it grows into something louder.

Day 30: The Weight of Silence

The days blur together like a never-ending grayscale movie. Today is no different from yesterday, or the day before that. I wake up to another empty room and an echoing silence. There's a strange numbness in my heart—a heavy blanket that smothers any joy or affection for this tiny life I’ve brought into the world.

It’s funny how people say babies bring sunshine and laughter. For me, they’re just shadows of what could be a future full of smiles and first steps. But right now, all I see are dark corners and endless nights filled with worry and loneliness.

I remember those moments after my daughter was born—everyone talking about the ‘baby blues,’ telling me it would pass in a few days. It didn’t. The sadness grew heavier every day until it felt like drowning under the weight of everything.

But there’s hope, too. I started taking Zoloft last week, and already, the edges are starting to soften. Today was better than yesterday—I managed a smile when she cooed at me from her crib. Small victories, but they count.

What this experience has shown me is that mental health care isn’t just about individual recovery—it’s about community support and understanding. No one should feel like they’re alone in their struggles. We need more awareness, more access to help, and less judgment for those who are going through it.

I’m still learning to walk again, but with each tiny step forward, I believe we can all make strides towards a world where everyone feels seen and heard when they’re at their lowest.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of exhaustion and despair. The baby cries, the house is a mess, and all I want to do is curl up in bed with a bottle of wine. It’s like everything that was once so exciting about being a new mom has faded into a haze of confusion and sadness.

I keep telling myself it's just fatigue or hormones, but deep down, I know something isn’t right. Why can’t I enjoy the simple joys anymore? Why does every moment feel like an uphill battle?

The nursery is beautiful, yet looking at it makes me want to cry. Another day passes by with no joy, only a relentless sense of emptiness. Maybe if I drink enough tonight, I’ll wake up feeling better tomorrow.

But I know that’s not true. The wine won’t solve anything; it will just make everything feel worse in the morning. Still, part of me thinks it might dull this pain for just a little while.

I need help. I don't want to be alone with these thoughts anymore. Maybe talking to someone could make a difference. But reaching out feels like such an impossible task today.

Tomorrow, I’ll try. Tomorrow will be different. For now, though, all I can think about is closing my eyes and hoping for some relief.

February 23rd

Two months have passed since the day I became a mother. It feels like both an eternity and just yesterday at the same time. Today, I had my follow-up appointment with Dr. Patel, who confirmed what I've been feeling for weeks—postpartum depression.

I thought it was just the exhaustion, or maybe being overwhelmed by new parenthood. But the truth is, there's a heavy fog in my mind that won't lift. Some days, I feel like crying over everything and nothing; other days, I'm angry at myself for feeling this way. Why can't I be happier? I keep asking.

Dr. Patel said it’s okay to not be okay right away. She encouraged me to focus on small victories—like getting out of bed each morning—and to reach out when I need help. The hardest part is admitting that I’m struggling, but now that I’ve taken this first step, things feel a bit lighter.

I'm trying to accept the reality of my situation instead of fighting against it. It’s not easy, and some days will be tougher than others, but I know I’m not alone in this journey. The next steps are finding support, whether through therapy or talking with friends who understand.

Maybe tomorrow will feel better. For now, I’ll just try to breathe and take things one moment at a time.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of tears and exhaustion. I can't shake the feeling that everything is wrong—my head, my heart, even my newfound role as a mother. The world outside my small apartment seems to be spinning at a different speed, while I'm stuck in this overwhelming fog.

It's been just over two months since little Ellie joined our family. She’s perfect and beautiful, but she's also an unrelenting reminder of the choices taken away from me by those who think they know better than I do about my own body and future. How can anyone believe that shutting down clinics is going to make a difference? It just makes it harder for women like me to get the help we desperately need.

I should be celebrating this new chapter, but instead, I'm drowning in an abyss of anxiety and sadness. There's no one here to tell me what's normal and what isn't; every moment feels raw and uncertain. Sometimes, I wonder if anyone would even notice if I disappeared tomorrow because I've felt invisible for so long.

I keep thinking about how it was supposed to be different this time around. No more secrets, no more hiding in the shadows of fear and shame. But now that I'm here, in this place where my heart breaks just a little bit every day, I feel lost and alone. How do you navigate being a mother when you're barely keeping yourself afloat?

I wish there was an easy answer, a quick fix to make all these feelings go away. Maybe if the world wasn't so cruel, if we had access to the resources that should be ours by right, then maybe I wouldn't feel like this all the time. But until that changes, I'll keep writing in this diary and holding on to hope that things will get better somehow.

Right now, though, it feels impossible.

Day 7: Postpartum Reflections

Today marks the seventh day since I welcomed my little miracle into the world. Looking back at the past week feels like a whirlwind of emotions and exhaustion. The transition from being pregnant to becoming a mom has been more challenging than I anticipated, but also incredibly rewarding.

I remember when I was going through postpartum depression after my first child’s birth, and it felt like an endless tunnel with no light at the end. This time around, I’ve been taking care of myself better and following up on some preventive measures. My doctor prescribed Zoloft again, and it's starting to work its magic. Two weeks in, and while I’m still tired, I feel more equipped to handle daily tasks without feeling completely overwhelmed.

The vivid dreams have been a curious side effect—last night, I dreamed about flying over the city with my baby securely tucked in a cozy blanket. It’s surreal how my brain concocts such imaginative scenarios at 3 AM. But honestly, these dreams add an element of excitement to the mundane routine of diaper changes and sleepless nights.

Overall, I’m trying not to beat myself up for feeling exhausted and occasionally weepy. Each day is a new beginning, and as long as I keep moving forward with support from my family and medication, things will fall into place gradually. Here’s to hoping tomorrow brings another beautiful sunrise and more chances to love this tiny human unconditionally.

Today feels like one of those days when the world is moving too fast and I’m stuck in quicksand. Postpartum depression isn't something people talk about enough. It’s the quiet monster whispering in my ear, telling me I’m not good enough. But I know deep down, I am so much more than just a mother who can’t hold her baby when she cries.

Wishful thinking, huh? Another day in the life of a woman trying to find her way through chaos.
