And maybe, just maybe, today won’t be as hard as yesterday.

Day 4 Postpartum

I woke up to the sound of my baby's tiny cries, a feeling of dread settling in my chest. How am I supposed to be this person who knows exactly what she’s doing? The nurse said everything was fine, but there’s no way everything is fine. What if I hurt him? What if he’s hungry and I can’t figure out how to feed him properly? My mind races with questions that feel impossible to answer.

The room feels too small, suffocating even. Every moment seems like a test, and I don’t think I’m passing. The exhaustion hits me in waves, making it hard to stay focused or coherent. Why do they say motherhood is beautiful when all I see is chaos? There’s no manual for this, nothing that tells you what it feels like to be so scared of your own shadow.

I can feel the tears welling up, but I blink them back. I need to be strong for him, right? But being strong means ignoring my fears and doubts, which only makes everything worse. The loneliness is almost unbearable; everyone seems happy, confident, and competent except me. Am I really that weak?

The thought of going through this alone feels like a nightmare. I want someone who understands these moments of panic and confusion. Is it okay to admit how terrified you are? Does anyone else feel this way but hide it behind smiles and nods? Maybe if I talk more about my fears, they’ll lessen.

I need help, and I’m not sure where to start. All I know is that today has been a battle against myself, trying to stay afloat in a sea of uncertainty. But maybe tomorrow will be different. It has to be, doesn’t it?

Today marks another whirlwind day with our triplets and my two-year-old. I feel like a superhero wearing three tiny capes instead of just one this time around. It’s been a month since they arrived, and I’m amazed at how different this postpartum experience feels compared to the first time. Back then, I was barely keeping my head above water, drowning in exhaustion and despair. Now, it’s like someone flipped an energy switch inside me.

Waking up at 4 AM to start a new day with babies is exhausting yet exhilarating. The house stays clean, laundry is done, meals are prepared. I’m not sure where this extra boost of stamina comes from, but I feel like I can take on the world—or at least the next hour’s feeding schedule.

My mind buzzes with ideas for activities and care routines that keep us all going smoothly. It’s crazy how being so busy helps me forget about postpartum blues. But then there are moments when my heart aches thinking about those dark days after my first baby, wondering if this new energy is just another roller coaster ride.

For now, I’m cherishing the high and trying to soak up every moment. Maybe it’s okay to enjoy the ride for as long as it lasts, while also keeping an eye out for any signs that things might shift back into familiar patterns. After all, taking care of myself means looking after everyone else too.

Today marks three weeks since bringing little Ellie into the world. The hospital was a whirlwind of emotions—exhilaration and exhaustion in equal measure. But now that I'm home, everything feels different.

I've been trying to stay positive, telling myself it's all part of being a new mom. There’s supposed to be an overwhelming sense of joy, right? Yet here I am, struggling with this dark cloud hanging over me. The constant fatigue is one thing, but the sadness and anxiety are so intense. Even cuddling Ellie doesn't feel like enough anymore.

I’ve been feeling incredibly alone in these moments, as if nobody else could possibly understand how I’m truly feeling. But then I remember all those stories from other moms who have talked about postpartum depression. And you know what? It’s okay to talk about it too. Maybe even necessary.

It's scary admitting this out loud, but there are days when I just want to cry and retreat into my own little corner of the world. Yet on others, I feel an inexplicable warmth towards Ellie that makes me think everything will be alright in the end.

So here’s what I’m doing: talking openly about it. Sharing with friends who might understand or know how to help. And seeking professional advice if needed. Because hiding these feelings won’t make them go away; they’ll only fester inside and grow into something much worse.

It’s not brave, it's necessary. And maybe, just maybe, by being open about this journey, I can help someone else feel less alone too.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my baby home from the hospital. The nights are long and full of endless feedings, diaper changes, and soothing cries that seem to stretch into infinity. My body aches with fatigue, but it's not just physical exhaustion. There’s this constant feeling of sadness hovering over me like a dark cloud, no matter how much I try to shake it off.

I've been having these crying spells out of the blue. One moment I'm fine, and the next, tears are streaming down my face for reasons that don't make sense to anyone else. Even my husband looks at me with concern in his eyes when it happens. He tries to comfort me, but what can he do? It's not like you can turn off something inside of you just because someone tells you to.

Last night, I woke up drenched in sweat, feeling completely overwhelmed by the weight of responsibility for this tiny human who needs me so much. And then there’s the constant worry about whether we’re doing everything right—will she sleep well? Will she cry less if we swaddle her differently? It’s all consuming.

I know I need help, but part of me feels like admitting it means failure. How can a mother not be happy to have a baby? But here I am, crying because the laundry piles up and there's no time to clean anything. The guilt is suffocating.

But you know what? As much as I feel lost in this fog of despair, I also feel a glimmer of hope when my little one smiles at me or reaches out with tiny fists grasping for my finger. Those moments are pure magic and they make everything else seem worth it. Maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, though, I'll just try to take each moment as it comes and hold on to those tiny bits of joy like lifelines in a stormy sea.

Today was a strange mix of emotions as I watched 'Free Guy' all the way through for the first time since giving birth. It used to be such an enjoyable ritual—sitting down with my husband, sharing popcorn, and eagerly waiting for that moment when the movie would finally start playing after the trailers. But now, those little moments of anticipation are gone. They've been replaced by a hollow feeling inside me.

The trailers played as usual, but instead of excitement, I felt this eerie sense of emptiness. It's like everything is on pause except my thoughts, which seem to go in circles. Watching the movie was bittersweet; there were moments where I laughed and others where I just couldn't shake off that deep, persistent sadness.

I keep thinking about how simple things used to make me happy—like watching a movie—but now they don’t have that same effect. I miss those days before everything changed. The baby is wonderful, but sometimes it feels like too much weight on my shoulders. 

It’s hard not to feel overwhelmed by these small losses and changes in my routine. Maybe talking about this with someone could help me understand why I’m feeling so low. For now, though, I’ll try to take it one day at a time and hope that tomorrow brings some sense of joy back into the mundane pleasures of life.

Day 3 Postpartum

Today was a blur of feedings, diaper changes, and endless hours trying to coax my little one into sleep. The exhaustion is overwhelming, but there's more than just physical fatigue weighing on me. Every time the baby cries or I hold her close, old traumas resurface like waves crashing against the shore.

I've been told there’s no cure for what ails me—Complex Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (CPTSD). It feels isolating and hopeless sometimes, knowing that traditional treatments aren't cutting it. But here I am, trying to juggle motherhood with my past. The guilt is suffocating; why can’t I just be happy like everyone says?

I know deep down it’s not about being ungrateful or depressed, but something else entirely. Yet, every tear and restless night feels like a sign that maybe I’m failing at this more than I ever imagined.

But there are moments too—tiny ones where the world seems to pause and everything is okay for just a second. And in those brief respites, hope flickers again. Maybe if I keep looking, there’s something out there to help me navigate this new chapter without being dragged back into old pain.

Right now though? It’s survival mode, one breath at a time.

Today marks a week since bringing little one home from the hospital. I've been trying to keep it together, but everything feels so overwhelming. The doctor mentioned postpartum depression during my check-up, and while I didn't expect to hear that, it explained so much.

I’ve been oscillating between feeling like a superhero mom and falling apart at the seams. There are moments when holding my baby makes me feel complete in ways I never thought possible. Yet, there’s this lingering sadness, this emptiness that seeps into every corner of my day. It's exhausting to pretend everything is perfect.

Waking up in the middle of the night with no sleep and a mountain of laundry feels like an eternity. Sometimes, I just want someone to tell me it’s okay to not be okay. There’s a part of me that wishes I could go back to who I was before pregnancy, but then again, there's this new person inside me now—a mommy.

It’s funny how much has changed in such little time. I’m still learning what it means to be a mother and it feels like everyone else figured it out long ago. I keep thinking maybe if I can just figure things out soon enough, the sadness will lift and everything will feel better. But for now, I’m trying to take each day as it comes.

I know help is available and I need to reach out. The thought of doing so scares me more than anything else right now. Yet, there’s a small voice in my head telling me this isn’t about being weak; it's about being brave enough to ask for support when you desperately need it.

Today, as the baby sleeps peacefully beside me, I’m going to start by talking to someone who can help guide me through these uncharted waters. It might feel like a tiny step forward today, but every little bit counts.

Today marks three weeks since I brought little Emma home from the hospital. The joy of holding her for the first time is still vivid in my mind, but it's mixed with an overwhelming sense of exhaustion and anxiety that I can't seem to shake off. Every day feels like a marathon, and the nights are filled with endless feedings and diaper changes. 

I've been trying to reach out to my doctor about how I'm feeling, but they're on vacation until next week. It's frustrating because I know something isn't right—I feel so lost and disconnected from everyone, even Emma at times. Is this just the baby blues, or is it more than that? The thoughts of whether I should be reaching out for help are swirling in my head like a storm.

I keep telling myself to take each day one step at a time, but the weight of uncertainty feels heavy on my shoulders. There are moments when I think everything will get better soon, and others where I feel completely overwhelmed by it all. It's hard to know what's normal and what's not after giving birth, especially with no one here to talk things through with.

Maybe tomorrow I'll find the strength to pick up the phone again, even if my doctor isn't available yet. For now, though, I'm going to try and get some rest. It's all such a blur right now, but somehow, I know that clarity will come eventually.

Today feels like a never-ending cycle of exhaustion and emptiness. The baby is sleeping, which should be a moment to breathe, but instead, I feel an overwhelming sense of despair. Why can't I just enjoy this? Every time I look at him, there's a part of me that's supposed to be filled with joy and love, yet all I see are the challenges ahead.

I try to tell myself it’s normal, that everyone feels overwhelmed sometimes, but deep down, I know something is seriously off. The little things—changing diapers, feeding him—are like mountains I have to climb every day. There's this constant voice in my head saying, "You're not good enough," and it just won't shut up.

Yesterday, when he cried and I couldn’t console him, the panic set in so quickly. It was suffocating, like a dark cloud hovering over me, making everything feel impossible. How can I be a mother if I struggle with even these small tasks?

I keep telling myself to reach out for help, but it's scary. What if they think I’m being selfish or a bad parent? The truth is, I just want someone who understands and can offer a hand—or maybe just an ear.

The nights are the hardest. When he wakes up every hour, I do too, feeling more and more lost with each passing moment. Sleep deprivation only adds fuel to this fire of anxiety and sadness that consumes me.

I need a break from all of it. A chance to catch my breath and figure out what’s happening inside my head. Maybe then, I can start to see through the fog and find some peace. For now, though, all I know is that today feels like another battle lost.

Today marks two months since little Eleanor joined our family. It feels like an eternity has passed already. The days blend together in a haze of feedings, diaper changes, and endless rocking. My arms ache from holding her night after night when she cries for hours on end. I can barely remember what it's like to have a full night’s sleep.

The exhaustion is overwhelming. It’s not just the physical fatigue but the mental toll of being alone with this tiny life. Sometimes I feel so consumed by fear—fear that I'm doing everything wrong, fear that I won't be enough for her as she grows up. The tears come unbidden, washing over me in waves. They are silent and private, leaving a residue of shame behind.

I know I’m not alone in this struggle; countless women face the same challenges. Yet, it’s hard to believe anyone understands what it feels like right now. Every day feels like a battle just to keep my head above water. Postpartum depression isn’t something I ever thought would happen to me. It's an unexpected visitor that has turned our home into a place of struggle instead of joy.

I wish I could feel the sunshine on my face without it being filtered through clouds of worry and despair. Eleanor deserves so much more than this, yet here we are. I pray for strength—strength to hold her when she needs me and strength to ask for help when I need it too. Maybe tomorrow will be better. But today, I’m just surviving.

I wish someone could understand that the love is there, but right now, it’s hidden under a thick layer of exhaustion and fear. Eleanor doesn't know what's going on inside her mommy's heart, but she deserves to see that heart smile again.

Today marks one month since little Lily joined our family. It’s funny how time flies when you’re up all night with a newborn, yet it drags by in moments of stillness during the day. I’ve come to realize that this journey is less about sleep deprivation and more about rediscovering myself amidst chaos.

The days blur together, but there are moments when everything feels crystal clear. Holding Lily for the first time was like holding my heart in my hands. It’s a mix of overwhelming love and sheer terror – what if I can’t do this? But every time that thought hits me, I remember: I’ve faced challenges before and won.

This week, something shifted inside me. Maybe it was the warm sun on my face while strolling through the park with Lily in her new baby carrier, or perhaps it was simply making myself a cup of tea without feeling guilty for taking a moment just for me. Whatever it was, I’m starting to feel like I can breathe again.

It’s important to remind myself that recovery from postpartum depression isn’t linear. There are good days and bad ones, but the key is acknowledging each day for what it brings. Today felt like a victory lap – not because of grand achievements, but because I chose joy in small moments.

Self-care isn’t selfish; it’s essential. I’m learning to listen to my body and mind with kindness, rather than judgment. Meditation helps center me, reminding me that inner peace can coexist with the external noise.

As I tuck Lily into her crib for what feels like the millionth time today, I feel a sense of gratitude washing over me. This is more than just surviving; it’s thriving in ways I never imagined possible.

Today marks one week since bringing home our new baby girl. The joy of holding her for the first time was overwhelming and beautiful, but the reality of life with a newborn is hitting me hard. I feel so tired all the time; it's like my body just won't catch up to the rest of me.

Waking up every few hours in the night has left me exhausted, and there are moments when I feel completely overwhelmed. Last night, as she cried for what felt like forever, I found myself questioning everything. Why do I feel this way? Is it normal to be so tired all the time?

The thought of having to start from scratch with postpartum depression hits me harder than ever. I remember how dark and isolating those moments were after my first child was born. It’s scary to think about going through that again, but part of me knows I need to prepare now rather than later.

I’ve been trying to reach out for support, talking more openly with friends who've gone through similar struggles. Knowing they understand makes it a little easier. But deep down, there's still this nagging fear that everything will spiral out of control again.

Today, I decided to call my therapist and make an appointment right away. It’s not easy admitting when you’re struggling, but taking care of myself means being honest about how I feel and reaching out for help. I want to be the best mom I can be, and that starts with acknowledging where I’m at now.

It’s a tough road ahead, but I have hope. I'm going to take it one day at a time, leaning on my support network and focusing on self-care. Today might not be perfect, but it's okay. We’re all learning together.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my little bundle of joy home from the hospital. It's been a whirlwind, and while there are moments that sparkle with pure bliss—like when she smiles in her sleep or when we finally figured out her night-time routine—I can't shake this cloud hanging over me.

I keep telling myself it’s just postpartum exhaustion, but something feels off. There are days where the thought of getting out of bed seems like too much effort. My husband tries to help, but I feel guilty for not being able to do more on my own. I see other new moms posting about how they're glowing and loving every moment, and it makes me wonder if there's something wrong with me.

Today was particularly tough. She cried all night, which left us both exhausted in the morning. Instead of feeling connected like everyone says you should, I felt disconnected from her and myself. Maybe it’s just hormones playing tricks on my mind, but when even basic tasks seem insurmountable, it makes me question everything.

I know I need to talk about this more openly with someone who understands. I’m reaching out for support because I don’t want to go through this alone anymore. There must be others out there feeling the same way, right?

Tomorrow is another day, and maybe tomorrow will be better. For now, I just hope that I'm not the only one struggling behind a façade of smiles.

Today marks my third week as a new mom, and the reality of it all is starting to hit me hard. There are moments when I feel like everything is perfect—the baby's tiny hands gripping mine with surprising strength, her sweet yawns as she drifts off to sleep—but then there are other times where I’m overwhelmed by this dark cloud that seems to follow me around.

I thought having a baby would be magical and blissful, but instead, I find myself struggling more than anyone could ever understand. The fatigue is crushing, and every little task feels like climbing Mount Everest. Why do I feel so broken when everyone else seems to glide through it effortlessly? It's not just the physical exhaustion either; my mind plays tricks on me, whispering that I'm a terrible mother, that something will go wrong if I take my eyes off her for even a second.

Yesterday, as she cried and I tried to soothe her with all the love in my heart, I broke down. Tears mingled with my frustration, and there was no one around who could understand how isolated I felt. That’s when I realized I needed help—real help, beyond just reading articles about sleep schedules or diaper changing techniques.

I’m reaching out because it feels like a weight has been lifted off me to acknowledge that this isn’t normal for everyone. There are others out there who feel exactly as lost and scared as I do right now. We need each other—not to judge but to hold hands through the stormy days, celebrate tiny victories together, and remember that we aren't alone in this battle against postpartum depression.

I'm taking a step towards healing today by sharing my struggles. If you're reading this and nodding along because you’ve felt these same feelings, know that you’re not alone either. Let's find strength in our shared vulnerability and build a support network where we can thrive together.

Today marks three weeks since the birth of my little miracle. The hospital rooms were filled with bright lights and cheerful congratulations, but now that I'm home, it's a different story. I feel like I’m drowning in this sea of baby clothes and endless feedings, yet there’s an eerie silence hanging over me.

Every time I look at her, my heart feels both full and empty. The exhaustion is overwhelming—I can barely muster the energy to smile at her even though she’s the most beautiful thing I’ve ever seen. My mind plays tricks on me; sometimes I feel like a failure, but then other times, I’m filled with this incredible love that makes everything seem okay.

The days blend together in a haze of diapers and bottles, but amidst all the chaos, there are moments when she gazes up at me with those big, innocent eyes. It’s like looking into a tiny version of myself, and for brief seconds, I forget about the darkness.

I know I need help—I can’t keep going like this alone. The thought of reaching out makes my chest tighten, but I’m not ready to give in. My mom mentioned some support groups; maybe it’s time to take her up on that offer. Small steps forward, right?

The road ahead might be tough, but I believe there will come a day when the weight lifts off me and all I feel is joy again. Until then, I’ll keep holding on, one breath at a time.

Tomorrow is another day, after all.

Today was one of those days when everything felt like a heavy weight on my chest. I had just shared with Mom-in-law about the postpartum depression diagnosis and that I’m taking medication to help manage it. She responded with something so hurtful, calling me names like “pill head” and questioning if these meds were really necessary. It’s not like she understands what I’m going through; she thinks all this is just a phase or some kind of weakness. Her words cut deep because they remind me how alone I feel in all of this.

How do you explain to someone who doesn’t believe in mental health issues that you’re struggling more than ever? It’s not just the lack of sleep and endless crying; it’s the overwhelming sense of dread and sadness that won’t let up. And now, with her comments, there's an added layer of guilt and shame about needing help.

I can see how Mom-in-law is worried and trying to protect me from what she perceives as a slippery slope. But I need support, not judgment. The meds aren't making it all better, but they’re helping me manage the worst moments. And for that, I'm grateful.

But talking about this with her today just made everything feel so much harder. I know I can’t change how she feels overnight, and maybe we won’t ever agree on these things. But right now, I need to find a way to keep pushing forward, one step at a time.

Today is my birthday, and I'm supposed to be happy, right? But instead, I feel like the weight of the world is pressing down on me. It's not just today; every day feels heavy with exhaustion and an overwhelming sadness that doesn't seem to lift.

I've been trying so hard to find joy in being a new mom, but it's just not there. Everything seems harder now—changing diapers, feeding the baby, even just trying to sleep when the house is quiet. My husband says he’s here for me, but sometimes his words feel hollow, like they’re coming from far away.

We had an argument yesterday about how much help I need around the house and with the baby. He says it's not fair that he has to do everything because I can't seem to get out of bed in the morning. I know he means well, but his frustration only adds another layer to my already heavy heart.

Today is supposed to be a celebration, but all I want to do is cry and sleep. The darkness feels like it's closing in around me, making every step forward feel impossible. I'm scared this feeling will never go away, that the joy of having our baby will get lost under layers of sadness and exhaustion.

I wish someone could understand how hard it is to just keep going day by day. Maybe if I can talk to a friend or reach out for help, things won't seem so overwhelming. For now, though, all I want is for today to be over.

Today feels like an endless blur of crying and fatigue. I woke up to the sound of my baby's cries, as usual, but today it felt different. The weight of responsibility is crushing me. Every time I try to talk to my OB about how I'm feeling, I feel like they're not really listening. They just tell me to take it easy and get more sleep—like that’s all there’s to it.

I’m so tired, but every moment of rest seems to be invaded by these overwhelming emotions. Why is this happening? All I want is for someone to understand how hard each day feels. The exhaustion is a constant companion now. Sleep eludes me, and when I do manage to nod off, my dreams are filled with worry.

The world outside my room is hazy and distant. My husband tries his best, but it's not the same as having someone who truly grasps what I'm going through. Today, in particular, was one of those days where every breath felt heavy, like each inhalation was pulling me deeper into a dark cloud.

I wish there were magic words or some kind of potion to make this better. But here we are, day after day, and it just feels worse. Maybe I should try calling the OB again—though part of me thinks maybe talking won't help at all. 

This postpartum journey was supposed to be beautiful and joyful, not this endless struggle. Please, someone, tell me how to make it better.

---

Today felt particularly tough. The emotional turmoil is relentless, and I'm starting to wonder if anyone really understands the depths of what I’m going through.

Today feels like a never-ending haze of exhaustion and despair. The baby is just six weeks old, but it feels like forever since I’ve slept more than an hour at a time. My body aches from the remnants of childbirth, and my heart hurts with a loneliness that’s hard to explain.

I remember last year when I had postpartum depression after my first child was born. It felt like no one understood or could help me because I didn’t have insurance then either. Now it feels even harder, knowing there are so many things I can’t afford and no clear path forward.

The doctor suggested I try therapy, but without insurance, it’s out of reach financially. Every time I think about calling a mental health hotline, the voice in my head whispers that I’m just wasting their time because nothing will change anyway. So instead, I sit here, feeling like I’m drowning and no one is throwing me a rope.

Sometimes I look at this tiny human sleeping next to me and wonder how it’s possible for them to be so peaceful when everything around me feels shattered. But then the fear creeps in again, questioning if I can really keep going without breaking down completely.

I know I need help, but finding that help when you’re stuck feeling helpless is like trying to find a needle in a haystack. Maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe it won’t. All I know for sure right now is that today has been another one of those days where the darkness seems to stretch on endlessly.

Today marks two weeks since little Liam joined our family. The whirlwind of emotions and responsibilities is dizzying yet exhilarating in a way I never imagined. Navigating postpartum depression feels like walking through a dense fog; every step forward is blurry but necessary. I've been attending counseling sessions, which have become my safe haven amidst the chaos.

Liam is strong-willed from day one, much like his dad and myself. This isn’t surprising given our history, but it’s challenging at times. My therapist suggested finding support groups or online forums for parents of strong-willed kids. It's comforting to know I'm not alone in this journey.

I’ve realized that being gentle with myself is crucial. Postpartum depression doesn't define me; it’s a part of my story, one I’m determined to write positively. Seeking advice from others who've walked this path helps ease the anxiety and reinforces that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

Tomorrow feels daunting, but so does every day when you're a new parent. I'm learning to take each moment as it comes, cherishing the quiet snuggles and loud giggles alike. Here’s to embracing the unpredictable nature of this incredible adventure called parenthood.

Today marks two weeks since I welcomed my little bundle of joy into the world. The reality of motherhood is hitting me hard—every hour feels like a marathon instead of a momentous occasion. While the birth itself was miraculous and filled with overwhelming love, I can't shake this persistent sadness that creeps in when the baby's asleep or during those late-night feedings.

I remember reading about postpartum depression before but never imagined it would feel so personal. It’s like having this secret sadness that no one else seems to notice except me. And yet, just yesterday, I found myself comforting a friend who lost her pregnancy. The empathy and support flowed easily for her, while my own struggles felt insurmountable.

I keep hoping that each day will bring some relief from these heavy feelings. Maybe tomorrow will be better? But then the exhaustion hits again, and it’s hard to see past it all. I’m trying so hard not to lose myself in this storm of emotions. Praying for strength, peace, and a bit more sleep would go a long way right now.

In the midst of everything, I hold on to the hope that things will get easier, even if it feels impossible at times. Maybe God is listening, whispering comfort into my heart when no one else can hear me crying. Today, I’m just trying to take one step forward and see what tomorrow might bring.

Today marks one week since I lost Jake. The house feels colder, quieter without him. I try to keep busy with the baby, but it doesn’t stop the tears that fall when I least expect them. My body aches from everything—the new motherhood, grief, and this heavy sadness that clings to me like a second skin.

I’ve been posting smiles on social media because everyone expects it. They think if you look happy, you are. But inside, it's dark and quiet. I’m barely eating or sleeping, let alone looking after myself or the baby properly. It’s hard enough being a new mom without the added weight of this constant grief.

Decided to take a break from social media today. Maybe that will help me focus on taking care of myself for once. I don’t know if I’ll ever get back into it. My goal is just to feel better before going back to school in a month. But right now, everything feels like an uphill battle.

Jake’s absence is everywhere and nowhere at the same time. His laughter echoes when there should be silence. It’s a struggle just getting through each day without breaking down completely. Yet somehow, I manage to put on a smile for the world, even though it feels forced most of the time.

I’m trying not to beat myself up over how I feel. Grief and motherhood are hard enough alone; together, they’re overwhelming. But I know I can’t keep going like this forever. So today is about taking small steps forward—eating when hungry, sleeping when tired, crying when needed. Maybe tomorrow will be a little easier.

Today marks another day in this endless cycle of darkness. I thought the anxiety during my first pregnancy was bad enough, but this is something entirely different. It's like a thick fog that won't lift no matter how hard I try to shake it off. I feel trapped inside my own mind, unable to escape the constant worry and sadness.

The funny thing is, back then with the anxiety, I felt like I could fight it. I had coping mechanisms and ways to manage it. Now, this depression feels insurmountable. It’s suffocating and relentless, and no matter how many times I tell myself that everything will be okay, those words don’t mean anything anymore.

I keep thinking about all the things I want to do for my baby but can't bring myself to start. The exhaustion is overwhelming, and every little task seems insurmountable. It’s like there's a wall between me and the person I used to be, and it feels impossible to break through.

I miss feeling capable and in control. I know that talking about these feelings isn’t going to make them disappear overnight, but at least with anxiety, I felt like I could do something. With this, all I can do is wait for it to pass and hope that it will get better soon. But today, I just feel lost.

I’m reaching out because maybe, just maybe, someone else has walked this path before me. Maybe there’s a light at the end of this tunnel that I haven’t seen yet. Until then, all I can do is keep trying to find my way back.

Today marks two weeks since little Luna’s birth. The hospital room was a blur of beeping monitors and the soothing hum of my baby's cries. Now, at home, reality sets in—a whirlwind of diapers, bottles, and endless rounds of feedings that never seem to end.

The nights are the hardest. After tending to Luna’s needs, I find myself lying awake, staring at the ceiling. My mind races with worry—will I ever feel like myself again? The fear of slipping back into the darkness feels overwhelming. But today, I made a conscious decision: my mental health matters more than anything else.

I’ve been reaching out to friends and family for support, but it’s not just about them holding me up; it’s also about leaning on self-care. Yoga this morning was refreshing—I felt connected to something greater than the daily grind of diaper changes and sleepless nights. Even small moments like sipping a hot cup of tea alone in my room feel monumental.

Luna is growing every day, and so am I. Each challenge is an opportunity to grow stronger. I won’t let past fears dictate my future. Today, I’m choosing hope over despair.

Today feels like an endless loop of exhaustion and emptiness. I woke up to another day where the world seems to move in slow motion while my mind is racing with thoughts of failure and inadequacy. The baby sleeps peacefully beside me, but I can't shake this overwhelming sense of being utterly lost.

Looking back, I realize how much I've ignored the warning signs. It's not like they weren’t there—I mean, who wouldn’t notice that something was seriously off? But instead of addressing it head-on, I’ve been trying to soldier on, pretending everything is okay when deep down, I know it’s not.

I’ve been through this before with past traumas, seeking help and slowly piecing myself back together. It worked then, so why does it feel like such a daunting task now? Maybe because having a baby changes everything—it’s not just me anymore; there's this little life that needs me to be okay. But how do I even begin when I’m barely holding on?

There are moments of joy and love, fleeting glimpses of the beauty in all of this chaos. The way she smiles at me or the sound of her tiny laugh can bring tears to my eyes for reasons I don’t fully understand. Those moments make it worth fighting through the fog, but they also highlight how much harder everything feels.

I know I need more than just sleep and coffee to get better. My therapist is great with helping process past hurts, but this—this feeling of being completely overwhelmed by parenthood—is something different. It's like no matter what I do, it’s not enough.

Maybe the first step is admitting that I’m struggling right now, today. That acknowledging the darkness doesn’t mean it wins; it just means I recognize its presence and can start to figure out how to let it go.

Today marks another day that feels like a never-ending loop of darkness and exhaustion. I'm trying to be strong for everyone else, but it's hard when the weight of this depression feels so heavy. It's been nearly a year since my baby was born, yet some days feel like they stretch out forever, mocking me with their endless gloom.

The sun rises, and all I want is to crawl back into bed. Everything feels too much—feeding, changing diapers, even just being present for my little one when she needs me most. The support from friends and family means the world to me, but it doesn't change how isolated I feel inside my own head.

I've started to notice patterns in my mood swings, which is a small victory. On good days, there's hope that maybe today will be better. On bad days, I hide away, afraid of letting anyone see how truly broken I am. It’s not fair on them, or me, but it feels like the only way to survive.

I've talked to my doctor about medication and therapy, but the journey is long and fraught with setbacks. Some nights, when the baby finally falls asleep, I find myself crying out of sheer frustration and loneliness. Other nights are blessedly quiet, allowing me moments of clarity where I can see a glimmer of light at the end of this dark tunnel.

I know I'm not alone in my struggles, but it feels that way sometimes. Each day is a battle, but also a chance to keep fighting. Maybe tomorrow will be different. Maybe today was just another step forward.

Today marks two weeks since I brought my little bundle of joy home from the hospital. As I sit here with her sleeping peacefully in my arms, I can’t help but feel overwhelmed by a mix of emotions. The love and affection I have for her are indescribable, yet there’s this lingering anxiety that keeps creeping up on me.

I’ve always felt competent when it comes to taking care of babies. I adore playing with them, soothing their cries, and just being in their presence. But now that the reality of parenthood has hit, I’m not so sure if I’m ready for everything that comes with it. The exhaustion is real, the lack of sleep, and the constant worry about whether I’m doing enough.

I keep having these moments where I wonder what if? What if this overwhelming feeling doesn’t go away? What if I end up slipping into a place where I can’t enjoy being a mom? It’s scary, and I don’t want to let myself think too much about it. But every time I catch glimpses of my reflection in the mirror staring back at me with circles under my eyes and a worried look on my face, it’s hard not to wonder.

I’ve always been an auntie who loved visiting my nieces and nephews but never imagined myself as a parent. Now that I am one, I feel like I’m still figuring out how to be both an aunt and a mother all at once. It feels daunting, confusing, yet there’s this undeniable joy that keeps pulling me through the tough moments.

Right now, I’m trying my best to take each day as it comes, learning what works for us without putting too much pressure on myself or expecting perfection. Maybe that’s part of the journey—accepting that it’s okay not to have all the answers right away.

Today marks another week since my youngest turned eight. The days blur together in a haze of exhaustion and overwhelming sadness. I thought having two boys would bring me joy, but instead, it's like carrying around an invisible weight that refuses to lift. My older son is entering his teen years, full of energy and questions about life. It's hard not to feel like I'm failing him. 

There are moments when I can almost imagine what happiness feels like—maybe a fleeting smile from my husband or the sound of laughter echoing through our house. But these brief respites do little to ease the constant emptiness inside me. Sometimes, I wonder if anyone else out there feels this way too.

The baby clothes that still fill the closet feel like a mockery. Another chance at motherhood that will never be mine. Why can't I just snap out of it? It's not fair to my kids or my husband. 

I try to keep busy with work and household chores, but it’s like trying to outrun a storm that’s always chasing me. I'm tired of pretending everything is okay when really, deep down, I feel lost.

Maybe talking to someone could help. But where do you start? How do you explain this void without sounding selfish or crazy?

Another day in this never-ending loop.

December 14th

Today marks a significant milestone in my journey as a new mother. The weight of the world has lifted ever so slightly since I started working with doulas during this tumultuous period after giving birth. Their support and guidance have been more than just helpful; they've been transformative.

I feel a sense of calm today, something that feels almost foreign amidst the chaos of adjusting to life with my baby. It's like finding a quiet corner in an otherwise bustling room. The doula I spoke to on the phone this morning talked about her experiences as a bereavement doula. Her voice was soft and understanding, but there was also strength there—a reminder that even through darkness, support is available.

The podcast she recommended touched me deeply; it highlighted stories of other mothers who've faced challenges similar to mine. Listening to their journeys has been incredibly comforting and affirming. I'm starting to see my own struggles not as a personal failing, but as part of the complex tapestry that is motherhood.

I'm so grateful for the community around me—especially these doulas who walk alongside me in this process. They help me remember that even though each day feels like its own mountain to climb, I’m not alone in this. There’s a light at the end of the tunnel, and with every step forward, it becomes clearer.

Tomorrow is another day, but for today, I'll hold onto the peace I've found here.

March 3, Day 17

Today feels like a rollercoaster of emotions. I woke up with a heavy heart, thinking about my dear friend who just had her baby last week. She’s struggling so much and her therapist diagnosed her with postpartum depression and PTSD. When she told me, all I could think was “Oh no, what does this mean?” It felt like the weight of the world came crashing down on her.

I get it—I’m feeling tired and overwhelmed too, but there’s a difference between just having a hard time adjusting to new life changes versus being diagnosed with something serious. I worry about her because honestly, some days she seems fine and other times, it’s as if everything is falling apart. But then again, maybe my perception isn’t accurate.

I’m not sure what to believe sometimes—do mental health diagnoses come too easily these days? Or am I just overthinking things? Maybe the best thing for me is to focus on myself right now, take each day at a time and hope that she gets better. After all, it’s only been two weeks since her little one arrived. It feels like an eternity already.

I should call her later today. Maybe we can grab some coffee and chat about how things are going for both of us. Sometimes just being there to listen is enough. And if she needs more than that, I’ll be there for her too, even if it means stepping into the unknown with her.

Today’s a new day—let’s see where it takes me.

Today marks three weeks since little Ella joined our family, and it's like the world stopped moving for everyone else but me. The hospital room was a dreamland of soft smiles and well-wishes. But here at home, reality hits hard.

I look around this nursery I've spent months decorating and can't help but feel empty inside. My friends talk about baby bliss and how magical every moment is supposed to be. All I see are dirty diapers, endless crying, and a mountain of laundry that seems to grow by the minute. The exhaustion? It’s not just from sleepless nights—it's like my soul is drained too.

The guilt eats at me day in and day out. Why can't I feel more joy? Every time I look at myself in the mirror, all I see is a failure. A mother who can’t even enjoy her child. The thought of talking to anyone about how I’m feeling makes my stomach churn with shame. They won’t understand—I’ve tried.

People tell me to be positive and take it one day at a time. But what if I can't? What if every day feels like walking through quicksand, where each step pulls you deeper into despair?

I wish there was an instruction manual for this mess inside my head. A clear path forward would make everything easier. Instead, all I have are these endless thoughts that swirl around me like a storm.

Maybe it's time to reach out and ask for help. But what if they think less of me? What if I'm not strong enough?

I don’t want to be alone in this anymore, but the thought of seeking help terrifies me. Maybe tomorrow will be better. Or maybe it won't, but either way, today is just another day that passes by without any real hope.

January 3rd, 2024

Today marks the end of a week since I gave birth to my beautiful daughter. I've been trying so hard to find joy in this new chapter of life, but every day feels like a battle. There's this term 'partum' floating around in my head that I keep mixing up with postpartum, and it’s driving me crazy. Is it just me? Did I misunderstand something?

Sleep is elusive, and the constant fatigue has made everything feel overwhelming. Even small tasks seem monumental. I'm not sure if anyone else feels this way, but every little thing seems to weigh on my mind heavily.

I've been trying to stay positive, talking to friends who've gone through this before, hoping for some magic advice that will make it all better. But there’s a lingering sadness and anxiety that won’t let up. It's like I’m walking through fog, unable to see the light at the end of the tunnel.

I know I should reach out for help, but the thought of doing so feels exhausting in itself. Maybe tomorrow will be different? For now, I'm just trying to breathe, one moment at a time.

Today marks one week since I brought my baby home. The hospital was a sanctuary of sorts, but now that we’re back in our own space, the reality hits harder. There’s this constant exhaustion layered with an unsettling feeling—a heavy cloud hovering over me. It’s hard to shake off these thoughts that I’m going to spiral into postpartum depression like everyone warned about.

The physical toll is just as daunting. My body feels like it was hit by a truck, and every movement reminds me of how much work lies ahead for recovery. The stretch marks, the loose skin, everything screams imperfection to my overly critical mind. I keep catching glimpses of myself in mirrors around the house, and each time I see this new reflection staring back at me, it’s like looking at a stranger.

I try not to dwell on all these negative thoughts because I know they won’t help anyone. Yet, there are moments when holding my baby makes everything feel okay for a little while. The love that swells up inside is incredible and undeniable, but even that can’t completely erase the shadow of doubt hanging over me.

It’s just so overwhelming right now—every day feels like an uphill battle without any clear victory in sight. I wish there was a switch to turn off all these anxieties and worries, but until then, I’ll keep trying my best to hold it together one breath at a time.

Today marks three weeks since Lily’s birth. The days feel like an endless loop of feedings, diaper changes, and sleepless nights. I can’t shake this overwhelming feeling that I’m not doing enough as a mother. Every time she cries or fusses, my heart sinks, and I question everything. My husband has been incredible, holding me when the tears fall, reminding me over and over again that it’s okay to feel this way.

He tells me I’m doing just fine, that every new mom feels like they’re drowning sometimes. But I can’t help but wonder if he’s just being kind or if there really is no reason for these deep-seated fears. Last night, we watched the sunset from our window seat, her tiny form nestled safely in my arms. It was a fleeting moment of peace, but it didn’t last long.

I’ve been trying to take things one day at a time, focusing on the small victories rather than getting lost in the storm. The midwife mentioned something about postpartum depression and suggested resources that could help. Maybe reaching out isn’t such a bad idea after all. I need someone else to tell me it’s okay to feel this way.

Tonight, I’ll try to remember those moments of calm instead of letting the fear consume me. It won’t be easy, but for Lily’s sake—and mine—I’ll keep trying.

Today marks three weeks since little Lily arrived in our world, and while she's a tiny miracle with the most perfect fingers and toes, I find myself drowning in a sea of confusion and doubt. It’s been such an overwhelming whirlwind of sleepless nights and constant worry—will I ever be able to feed her enough? Is my milk good enough? Am I changing her diaper right? And then there are moments when everything feels utterly normal, like it's all going to be okay.

But other times, these dark clouds descend upon me without warning. They come in waves of anxiety and despair, leaving me feeling lost and alone even as everyone around celebrates the new life we’ve brought into this world. How can I feel so grateful for my beautiful baby while simultaneously being consumed by thoughts of how inadequate I am? Is it normal to question whether every little hiccup means something is seriously wrong?

I keep telling myself that Lily’s perfect in every way, and surely those feelings should lift the moment I look at her sweet face. But they don’t. Instead, she seems to magnify my fears and insecurities, making me wonder if anyone else out there feels this way too. Maybe I’m just being overly critical of myself—after all, I’ve always been a bit of a perfectionist. Can you really expect to be the perfect mother right from day one?

Tonight, as she sleeps peacefully in her bassinet, I can’t help but feel like an outsider looking in on my own life. It’s not just postpartum blues—it's something deeper, more intense. Maybe it’s time to reach out for help before these shadows consume me completely. Because while Lily is everything I’ve ever wanted and dreamed of, the reality of being her mother right now feels like a different story altogether.

Today marks seven months since my baby was born, and I’ve been reflecting on how far we’ve come. The days of endless crying and sleepless nights feel like a dream now. Looking back, it’s clear that the early weeks were filled with a fog of depression, both prenatal and postpartum. It was hard to see past my own despair then, but as time passed, I started to notice small changes.

I began to appreciate the tiny milestones—like when he first smiled at me or when she grabbed my finger without flinching. These moments are what pulled me through. Of course, there were days when everything felt overwhelming again, and I wondered how much longer I could keep going. But somehow, each day brought a little more clarity.

Now, as we approach this seventh month, I feel like I’m starting to understand myself better. It’s not that the struggle is over; it’s more about recognizing what helps me cope. Talking to friends who’ve been through similar experiences has made all the difference. Knowing that others have felt the same way gives me a sense of community and support.

I still catch myself questioning whether I’m doing enough or if something will go wrong, but now there’s a voice inside reminding me to breathe, to take it one day at a time. It feels like progress, even if it’s slow.

Today, as I watch him playing with his toys, everything seems brighter and less daunting than before. Maybe tomorrow will bring its challenges, but for now, this moment is enough.

Today marks a week since I brought my baby home from the hospital. It feels like a lifetime ago when we were strangers in that sterile room with nurses bustling around us. Now, every moment at home seems to stretch endlessly.

I thought being a new mom would be magical and blissful, but instead, it’s just exhausting and overwhelming. My body is still healing from the delivery, but my heart feels shattered. I never expected postpartum depression after this second pregnancy—it was so different when I had my son seven years ago. Back then, everything felt right.

Now, though, I can’t shake the feeling that something’s terribly wrong. Maybe it’s just all the changes—the sleepless nights, the constant worry about whether I’m doing things right. Or maybe it’s because of what happened with my partner. Finding out he was cheating while I was pregnant… it was a knife in my heart.

I keep thinking, "This is supposed to be joyful." But joy feels like an impossible dream. How do you find happiness when your mind keeps whispering that you’re not good enough? Even as I hold my baby and feel the love for her, there’s this dark cloud hanging over me, a weight that won’t lift.

I want to be strong for both of us, but some days it feels like everything is too much. The nights are especially hard—when she cries and cries, and all I can do is lie here feeling so lost and alone. It shouldn’t feel this way, but somehow it does.

Tomorrow will bring another day full of diapers and feedings and the endless cycle of new beginnings that feels more like a never-ending struggle. For now, though, I’ll just try to breathe through tonight. Maybe tomorrow will be better.

Today marks one month since I welcomed our little miracle into the world. As the days blur together in a haze of feedings and diaper changes, I'm starting to find my footing. The exhaustion is still there, but it's paired with an undeniable sense of purpose. Holding her close at night while she sleeps brings a peace that feels both new and eternal.

There are moments when the fog of postpartum depression creeps in, whispering doubts about whether I’m capable enough, strong enough. But then my baby stirs, her tiny fingers curl around mine, and all those doubts dissipate. It’s like there’s this quiet strength inside me that awakens whenever she needs me.

I’ve started to reclaim some self-care rituals—curling up with a book before bed or taking a quick shower on my own. These small moments of solitude feel precious now, a reminder that I am more than just a new mother. My identity is expanding rather than being erased.

The challenges are real, but so too are the triumphs. Each time I navigate a tricky feeding session or manage to keep up with household chores (well, most of them), it’s like another step forward on this journey. There’s no denying that healing from childbirth and navigating postpartum life is tough, tougher than anyone prepares you for really. But there’s also an incredible community out there—other moms who know exactly how I feel—and knowing they’re just a phone call away helps.

One month down, countless more to go. Here’s to finding balance amidst the chaos and cherishing every imperfect moment with my baby girl.

Today was a whirlwind of emotions and unexpected stress. My niece dropped by with her baby, who shares the same birthday as my unborn child, but here’s where things get confusing—her baby is already nine months old! I’m still expecting in two weeks, yet everyone assumes our kids are twins. She didn’t mean any harm; she was just excited to meet us all, but it threw me off completely.

The thought of having a newborn and dealing with another child who’s barely older than my bump feels overwhelming. It's like the baby books and advice suddenly doubled in complexity overnight. I’m supposed to be overjoyed at this stage, yet here I am questioning everything from sleep schedules to diaper changes. 

My sister didn’t mean to cause trouble; it was just a mix-up of dates that spiraled into an avalanche of mixed emotions. She’s always been supportive, but right now, I need some space and understanding more than anything else.

It’s strange how this little mix-up has brought so much anxiety. The idea of having two babies around at once—well, it might be great one day, but today it just feels daunting. Maybe it’s time to reach out for support, talk things through with someone who understands the unique challenges of being a new mom.

Tomorrow is another day, and hopefully by then I’ll have figured out how to navigate this unexpected turbulence without losing sight of my joy and excitement for what’s ahead.

Today was one of those days when I felt like everyone could see right through me. My manager dropped a bomb during our meeting this morning—something about how taking time off after giving birth is just an excuse to avoid work responsibilities. She suggested that putting in extra hours would distract from everything else going on. It’s not the first time she's said something like this, but today it hit harder than usual.

Sitting at my desk now, I’m trying to focus on finishing a project, but all I can think about is how much I need to finish pumping so I can get back to work. Every minute feels like an eternity when you’re dealing with exhaustion and the constant worry that your baby isn’t okay. But every time I take too long for a break or seem too tired, it’s like I’m failing.

I’ve tried talking about how hard this is with friends and family, but sometimes even they don’t understand. The pressure to be supermom while battling postpartum depression feels insurmountable. It's frustrating because part of me wants so badly to prove that I can handle everything, but the other part just wants someone to acknowledge that what I’m going through is real and difficult.

I’m not sure how much longer I can keep this up without cracking. Maybe it’s time to seek help before I crumble completely.

Today marks another day of pushing through the haze. I woke up with my head spinning, still in that quiet chaos that follows me like a shadow since baby’s arrival. But then there's this new rhythm—my running shoes on the pavement, the wind against my face. It’s become more than just a way to clear my mind; it’s a lifeline.

Running has been my constant during all of this turmoil. When the world seemed to be crumbling around me because of the pandemic and the demands of being a new mom in a high-stress job, I found solace in those long miles under the stars. It didn’t solve everything, but it gave me space to breathe.

Now that things are starting to stabilize—or maybe just feel like less of an apocalypse—my focus is shifting slightly. I’m setting small goals for myself: running longer distances, trying out new trails. And I’m thinking about how to share this with other women who might be struggling too. There’s something so powerful in seeing someone else pushing through their own darkness and coming out the other side.

It’s not always easy. Some days are just a struggle to put one foot in front of the other, literally or metaphorically. But each step forward is progress, even if it feels small. And that’s okay—I’m learning to celebrate those tiny victories too.

So here I am, putting one foot in front of the other again today. Fingers crossed for some good weather and maybe a few new running buddies along the way.

Today marks my fourth week as a new mom, and I feel like I'm barely hanging on by a thread. The fatigue is overwhelming, and every time I close my eyes to rest, the guilt sets in about neglecting my baby. It's like there's this constant battle inside my head between wanting to be the perfect mother and just needing to survive.

Sleepless nights have become a harsh reality, but trying to catch up on sleep during the day feels impossible with all the household chores piling up. I’m struggling with simple tasks that once seemed so easy. The weight of it all is crushing me, and I can’t shake this feeling that no one understands what I’m going through.

My mind wanders back to my first time being a mom, and how similar this feels now. That previous episode of postpartum depression was a dark tunnel I hoped never to revisit, but here we are again. The fear creeps in—will it ever get better? Am I alone in this?

Every day is a challenge, but there’s also beauty in the small moments: my baby's smile when she sees me or her little hands reaching for mine. Yet, those precious times are overshadowed by sadness and doubt.

I need help, but asking feels like admitting defeat. It’s hard to let go of the facade that everything is okay, even though it’s clearly not. I know seeking support isn’t a sign of weakness; it’s survival.

Today, I’m going to take small steps—maybe talk to someone who understands, or just sit with my thoughts for a moment without judgment. It’s okay if I need this time to heal, and it’s okay to ask for help.

January 14th

The night is never quiet anymore. It's filled with the sound of a tiny human learning to navigate this big world. Tonight was especially hard. I tried putting baby down for bed again using that 'cry it out' method everyone talks about, but it feels like a nightmare. The crying echoes in my ears and tears up my heart. How can anyone say it's okay to let them cry? It feels like torture.

I'm struggling so much with everything these days. Postpartum depression hits me hard tonight. It’s overwhelming how the world just keeps spinning while I’m stuck in this dark, heavy place. The baby monitor is now a constant reminder of my failures and inadequacies as a mother. Why can't I do this? Why can't I just get through one night without feeling like I'm drowning?

Tomorrow might be better, right? Maybe the crying won’t seem so unbearable then. For now, though, all I want to do is curl up in bed with my tears and hope for a day when it feels easier to breathe.

12 months later

The baby's bedtime routine has changed drastically since those first few months. She’s older now, more aware of her surroundings, and understands our routines better. The nights aren't perfect yet, but they're far less agonizing. I still struggle with the lingering shadows of my postpartum depression, but today feels like a step forward. Maybe one day, when she's all grown up, we'll look back on this journey with only memories of progress and growth.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my baby girl into this world, and while she’s beautiful and perfect in every way, the reality of postpartum life is hitting me hard. Between the constant feedings, diaper changes, and lack of sleep, there are moments when it feels like no one understands what I’m going through. I’ve always been a private person, but now it seems even my closest friends have forgotten about me.

It’s not that they don’t care—I know deep down they do—but life moves on for everyone else while I’m stuck in this whirlwind of new responsibilities and feelings. The exhaustion is overwhelming, and the guilt follows closely behind whenever I can’t muster up a smile to match the expectations others have for how happy I should be.

There are moments when I catch myself looking at baby pictures online and wondering if all these women feel like me or if they’re just putting on a brave face. It’s hard not to compare, but it only leads to more anxiety and sadness. My therapist says it’s normal, that everyone processes things differently, but right now, her words don’t comfort me as much as I hope.

The hardest part is the silence from most people outside my immediate family. Only a few friends have dropped by with meals or called to check in. Their small acts of kindness make me feel seen and heard, even if it’s just for a moment. It’s those moments that remind me I’m not alone, but they’re so infrequent that the loneliness still weighs heavy.

I know there’s help out there, but reaching out feels like admitting defeat. Maybe tomorrow will be better—I keep telling myself this every day. Until then, I’ll try to take things one step at a time and hope for brighter days ahead.

March 14, 2010

I can't believe it's been eight years since I first felt the weight of this darkness after my son was born. It started as a whisper, a quiet fear that no one seemed to notice. The days blended into nights, and before I knew it, they were all part of a haze where joy and love should have shone through.

Today feels like just another day in a long stretch of them. But there’s something different, maybe because my youngest is finally two and the constant chaos has eased a bit. Yet, instead of feeling relieved or happy, I feel this heavy burden of silence, a weight that doesn’t want to lift. It’s exhausting, this battle within me between hopelessness and the desire for peace.

I reached out recently to an organization specializing in postpartum support. They offer one-on-one sessions with trained professionals who truly understand what I’m going through. The thought of talking to someone who gets it is both terrifying and comforting at the same time.

It’s okay not to be okay, right? These words echo in my mind, reminding me that there are others who have walked this path, finding light after darkness. Maybe today, tomorrow, or next week will be when I take a step towards that light.

For now, I’ll keep writing here, piecing together the fragments of myself amidst the shadows.

Today marks three weeks since I brought my little one home. It feels like an eternity ago that I was walking down the hospital hallway under those sterile lights, holding this tiny bundle of life in my arms for the first time. But every day since then seems to blur together into a haze of exhaustion and confusion.

I thought it would get easier after leaving the hospital, but if anything, it’s harder now. The world outside feels so much bigger, more overwhelming. Just today, I had to pause on our walk because one of those street light poles looked too familiar, too similar to something from another time—a dark memory resurfacing in a wave that almost knocked me over. I can’t shake this feeling of being trapped by my own thoughts and the things around me.

Sleep is still elusive, but I’m trying not to stress about it too much. My doctor said that’s normal for now, even if I feel like I’m barely functioning. But there are moments when all I want to do is crawl into bed and never wake up again because everything feels so heavy—my body, my mind, this new life we’re starting together.

I’ve been trying to reach out more, talking to friends or calling the support line they gave me at the hospital. Today’s phone call helped a little, though I still feel like I’m not making much progress. It’s strange how you can know something is wrong and yet struggle so hard to change it. Maybe tomorrow will be better? Or maybe it won’t.

For now, all I can do is take tiny steps forward every day, even if they’re baby steps. Today, I just want to rest and let the support around me lift some of this weight off my shoulders.

Today marks my seventh day postpartum, and there's an eerie calm that follows me wherever I go. The nursery is a sanctuary of sorts, with soft pastel colors and the faint hum of the monitor. Yet, as much as I try to find solace in these moments, a heavy fog clouds my mind, making simple tasks feel like monumental challenges.

I can't help but notice how different this feels from when I had my older two kids. Back then, it was an overwhelming mix of love and fear, joy and exhaustion all at once. This time around, the emotions are muted, replaced by a deep well of anxiety that seems to seep into every crevice of my being.

The room is silent except for the soft breathing of my newborn. I try to focus on their tiny features—the delicate nose, the perfect little fingers—but the thoughts keep swirling inside my head like leaves in a storm. Will this ever get better? Am I going through the same thing again?

I remind myself that it's okay to feel this way. It's part of the journey. But then doubt creeps in, questioning if I'm strong enough to handle another bout of postpartum depression and all its complications.

It’s only been a week, but it feels like an eternity. Each day, I try to find small moments of joy—like when I hear my older kids playing upstairs—and hold onto them tightly. Yet, the anxiety persists, casting shadows over even these brief glimpses of happiness.

I know I need help. It's not easy admitting that, especially after everything I've been through before. But today, as I rock this new life in my arms, I whisper a promise to myself: I will seek support, because no one should face this alone.

Today feels different, a little lighter than usual. I’ve been going through so much lately, but today is one of those rare moments when everything just seems to settle for a bit. The baby slept longer last night, and instead of lying awake wondering if this was normal or not, I actually got some rest.

I’m starting to understand that it’s okay to feel this way. It’s tough admitting there are days I don’t want to get out of bed, but talking to my therapist yesterday helped. She reminded me that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. And honestly? I think she’s right.

Today, I called the support group and signed up for their next meeting. There’s something comforting in knowing there are others who understand what it feels like. Maybe today won’t be perfect, but maybe tomorrow will be better because of that step forward.

The sun is coming through the window, casting a warm glow over everything. It’s easy to forget about the darkness when you look at moments like this one. Today, I’m choosing to focus on the good and take it from there.

January 14, 2023

Another day passes like the rest. The baby sleeps through the night for the first time in weeks, but instead of feeling relieved and joyful, I feel a heavy weight pressing down on me. Tears are always at the surface, threatening to spill out at any moment. Today they came while I was trying to put together some semblance of order amidst the chaos of diapers and bottles.

I look around this room that once felt so new and exciting. Now it seems stale, like a place where time stands still. My thoughts are consumed with how inadequate I feel as a mother, as if everything I do is wrong or insufficient. The joy I thought would accompany my baby's birth is nowhere to be found.

I am functioning, at least on the surface. I feed her, change her, and rock her to sleep when she cries. But inside, it feels like I'm just going through the motions. No one can see how deep this sadness goes; no one notices the constant battle within me to keep moving forward each day.

Sometimes I wonder if anyone sees the real me—this woman who is struggling so fiercely with her role as a mother and a person. Does my husband? Do friends? Am I just putting on a mask, fooling everyone into thinking everything is okay?

I know I need help, but seeking it feels like admitting failure. Yet, what kind of future am I building for myself and this tiny human who relies solely on me? It's terrifying to think about continuing without support.

Today, I will make the call to a therapist. For my sake, for our baby's sake, and maybe even for any hope of finding happiness again.

Day 34 Postpartum

Today marks a month since I brought my little miracle into the world, but honestly, it feels like an eternity has passed. Every day starts with the promise of new life and love, yet by evening, that initial euphoria is replaced with an overwhelming sense of dread.

I know it’s normal to feel tired and overwhelmed after having a baby, but something about these feelings just doesn’t sit right. My mind races with thoughts I can't quiet, no matter how much sleep I get—or don't get. The joy of holding her, the wonder of her first smile—it all feels like it's happening through a thick fog.

I keep telling myself to snap out of it, that it’s just hormones and exhaustion talking. But deep down, I know there’s more to it than that. It's been hard reaching out for help; my family means well but doesn't understand how much I’m struggling inside. They see me as the mom who should be happy 24/7.

Today was particularly rough. I couldn’t bring myself to feed her or change a diaper, even though she cried endlessly. The guilt eats away at me; why am I this way? Why can't I just be happy?

Tomorrow feels like an unending void, and tonight’s sleep won’t come easy. Yet, somehow, tomorrow comes anyway. It's okay to not be okay, but it's crucial to find a way out of the darkness. Maybe tomorrow will hold some answers, or at least someone who can guide me through this storm.

Until then, I'll keep holding on and hoping for better days ahead.

Today feels like an eternity. The room is quiet except for the soft hum of the baby monitor and the occasional sound of my newborn's breathing. I stare at the ceiling, wondering if anyone can see through my eyes how scared I am. Financial stability isn't a shield against this darkness; it’s eating away at me like acid.

I worry constantly about the little one sleeping in the next room. What if something happens? What if I'm not strong enough to keep her safe and healthy? These thoughts spiral out of control, making it hard to sleep or eat. Even though we have a roof over our heads and food on the table, nothing seems to ease this relentless fear.

Sometimes I try to convince myself that these feelings will pass once I get more rest. But what if they don’t? What if I can't protect her from my mind’s darkest corners? The thought of leaving her alone fills me with dread. Yet, staying here feels like a prison sentence without an end in sight.

I know I need help, but reaching out feels impossible right now. It's all-consuming and isolating. Will I ever feel normal again? Can anyone understand this overwhelming sense of despair that nothing can fix?

I want to be a good mother, but it seems like the more I try, the further away from that goal I slip. Please let me find my way back.

Today marks two weeks since little Emma joined our family. The birth itself was beautiful and overwhelming, a mix of joy and fear that still lingers beneath the surface. I can't help but feel like I'm walking on eggshells, wondering if this will be different from last time—when everything changed.

Sleeping in fits and starts has become my new norm, each waking moment filled with a foggy haze where worry sits comfortably next to exhaustion. Yet, there are moments of pure clarity, when the baby's cries turn into melodies that soothe me back to memories of love and hope.

The first time around, it was like falling off a cliff without warning. The sudden shift from blissful anticipation to deep despair left me feeling isolated and alone. This time, though, I've been proactive about seeking help early. Reading stories from other moms who've walked this path has been incredibly healing—I'm not the only one struggling to find balance.

As Emma's tiny hands grasp mine, her eyes searching for comfort, I feel a surge of determination to advocate for my mental health. It’s scary to think about what lies ahead, but with each supportive conversation and resource I discover, hope starts to creep back into my heart.

I want more children someday, but the thought still scares me half to death. Yet, today feels different. Today, there's a whisper of courage telling me that even if it gets hard again, I won't be alone in this journey.

Today marks two weeks since I brought our daughter home from the hospital. Two whole weeks and yet, there's a void inside me that doesn't feel right. Every time someone asks how I'm doing, all I can muster is a forced smile and a nod. How can this be? Why am I not overflowing with joy?

It’s like my heart isn’t fully engaged in the reality of having her here. There are moments when I stare at her sleeping face, wondering if there's something wrong with me for not feeling as happy as everyone expects me to feel. My life partner (LOML) is overjoyed and constantly talking about how wonderful it is to have our daughter around. But when he looks at me expectantly, waiting for the same glow of happiness I see in him, all I can do is shrug my shoulders.

I’ve been trying so hard to feel what everyone else feels—love instantly, a natural bond, and this overwhelming sense of completeness. Instead, there’s this nagging doubt that maybe something is wrong with me. Why don’t I just know how to be a mother? Am I supposed to have these feelings of emptiness and uncertainty?

I wish someone could tell me it's okay not to feel happy right away because everyone says it will come eventually, but what if it never does? What if there’s something deeply wrong with me for feeling this way? It’s exhausting, the constant internal battle. How am I supposed to be a good mother when all I want is to crawl into bed and hide?

I'm scared that my daughter deserves more from me than just going through the motions. What happens next?

Today was a strange mix of emotions. Dad stepped in with the kids this morning, and for once, I got to sleep an extra hour. The house is quiet, and it’s just me and my thoughts. It feels good to have some space, even if it's only for a little while.

I’ve been struggling so much lately, mostly with myself. The exhaustion, the fear, the constant worry about whether I’m doing enough or being enough for these tiny humans who depend on me completely. It’s overwhelming and I find myself questioning everything. Dad saw that I needed help today, and honestly, it was a relief.

It’s tough admitting how hard this is, especially when everyone expects you to just ‘bounce back’ after having a baby. But the reality is far from that fairy tale. I’ve missed work days because of this foggy cloud of sadness hanging over me. My boss is understanding, but she can’t fill in for me every time.

Postpartum depression isn’t something I ever thought would hit me. But here I am, and it’s real. It’s hard to even put into words how much it affects you from day to day. Today was a bit better because of Dad’s help, but tomorrow is another day with its own set of challenges.

I’m grateful for today, though. Just being able to breathe without the constant demands of the house and kids felt like a gift. I hope tomorrow brings more of that peace, if only in small doses.
